Praefatio.	Prefatory.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	After I have finished with you, my son, this book which is the last of my works on medicine, completed with its end in view, following the explanations and affirmations of this treatise, I wish to complete it for you with this treatise which is a part of the operation, that is, surgery with the hand.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	Since surgery with the hand is now abandoned in our time and is a private matter: until perhaps its science is lost and its practice has ceased, except for brief notices in ancient books, which have been altered by the hand: and there have happened to be mistakes and hesitation, until its intentions have been closed and its purpose prolonged: I have deemed it necessary to provide this treatise with an orderly arrangement of its contents, according to its position and affirmations, and with brevity: and to include the forms of instruments, such as the Cautery and other implements, with their specifications and their preparation which is necessary
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	However, because a skilled artisan of this sort is not to be found easily in our time with his hand: for the art of medicine is long, and the author must exercise himself beforehand in the science of anatomy, as Galen has said, until he knows the functions of the limbs, their forms, and their connection, and separation, and has an understanding of the bones, nerves, and lacerations, and their number, and their exit, and the pulse of veins, and quietness, and the locations of their exits.
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	For this reason Hippocrates said, "A name is much more than a name, and work is little, especially in the art of the hand.
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	We have indeed mentioned this at the beginning of this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	For one who is ignorant of what we have said concerning anatomy will fall into error, and will endanger human life: as I have seen many who have learned this science carelessly and without study or experiment
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	Why is it that the doctor has secured the scrofula in the woman's neck with a stiff ligature, and has thereby obstructed some of the arteries in the neck? Because of this, blood flows from the woman until she dies in her hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	And the doctor observed another one who had presumed to extract a stone from the bladder which was in the bladder, and the stone was large.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	He went to him and extracted it with the bladder's husk
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	Because the man died on the third day.
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	And I too was called to extract it: and I saw from the size of the stone and the condition of the patient that he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	And I saw another doctor who took hold of a certain Duke of our land because of medicine: and it happened to a black eunuch who was with him, that he fractured his leg near the heel: and the doctor, with his ignorance, bound the fracture with vinegar and nails, and tight bands, and did not let the wound breathe.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	And he died according to his desires.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	Afterwards he sent him away for a few days, and gave him orders not to loosen the ligament: and he stood thus until the swelling of his leg had gone down, and his foot and leg, and came to an end
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	I was called to him again: and I set about loosening the ligament: and there ensued peace, and he was freed from his pains
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	But indeed the corruption was confirmed in the limb: and I could not restrain it
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	So the corruption ceased to spread in the limb, until it died
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	And the physician went to another, who had perforated the cancerous abscess: and it was ulcerated after days, until its malice was increased with the lord himself.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	For when a cancer is pure from melancholic humour, it must not be treated with iron in every case, except in a limb which can tolerate it, that it be entirely excised
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	And therefore, my son, you must know that an operation is divided into two parts: that which is associated with health, and that which carries risk in various situations
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	I am grieved in every place of this book where an operation is mentioned, where fear and terror are present.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	Therefore you must be cautious of this, and be restrained: lest they find fault with you, and speak dishonestly
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	Receive therefore with humility and protection, and the sick with facility and firmness, and use the better way that leads to greater glory to God concerning the preservation of life and the obtaining of praise: and banish the terrifying diseases which are difficult to cure: and take away from your soul that which makes you fear, so that there may be no obstacle to your faith and your comfort
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	For there remains for you a greater glory in your faith, and a sublimity in this world, and finally in the number of your souls.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	For Galen has said in some of his admonitions.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	You do not heal a bad disease: do not speak of a bad physician.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	I have indeed divided this treatise into three chapters
Capitulum primum.	Chapter One.
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	Of cautery with fire, and of cautery with acute medicine, a chapter, and ordered from the head down to the feet, concerning the forms of instruments, and of materials for cautery: and everything which is necessary for the operation
Capitulum secundum.	Second Chapter.
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	Concerning incision and perforation, phlebotomy and packing, wounds: and the extraction of arrows, and things of that kind: and the whole of this chapter, arranged in order of the instruments.
Capitulum tertium.	Third Chapter.
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	Concerning restoration, and dislocation, and the treatment of twisting, and things of that kind: this chapter is arranged from the head to the feet, and concerning the forms of instruments.
Soli Deo Gloria.	Glory be to God.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	The Book of Surgery by Albucasis.
Pars I.	Part I.
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	Concerning the application of bandages, and the use of cautery: and in what complexions it is suitable, and when: and if with iron, or gold.
Caput I.	Chapter I
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	But before any operation is performed, it is necessary to state the qualities of the bandages and instruments to be used: and in what complexion they should be displayed
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	I say therefore, that the discourse concerning the quality of the cautery instrument, and its name, is a lengthy, subtle, scientific, and occult discourse.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	And it is said by many wise men in this matter, and they disagree among themselves: and indeed little is sufficient from their discourses, fearing the prolongation of the discussion
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	I say therefore, that the cautery instrument is useful in all complexions, which is with material, and without material: except for two complexions, which are the hot complexion without material, and the dry complexion without material
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	In the hot and dry complexion with material they disagree
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	Some indeed say that the cautery instrument is useful in these.
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	Others argue that Cauterium is not suitable for carbuncles, which arise from heat and dryness, because fire itself is hot: and it is unsuitable to cure a hot and dry ailment with heat and dryness.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	Others maintain that Cauterium is not suitable for any hot and dry carbuncles that occur in the bodies of men, because when you compare the body of a man with fire and moisten it, you find the body of a man to be cold.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	I too have heard from experience that this is true.</start_of_turn>
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	It is true that it does not suffice simply to say that Cauterium is not suitable for carbuncles; for one must have studied Cauterium in its final exercise and become acquainted with the diversity of human complexions, the nature of ailments, their causes and their course.</start_of_turn>
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	With the other complexions there is no fear; and especially with cold and moist ailments.</start_of_turn>
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	I know that all physicians agree about this: and they do not deny the use of Cauterium in these matters.</start_of_turn>
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	And indeed, the sons know that the secret of Cauterium with fire and its advantage over Cauterium with burning medicine lies in the fact that fire is simple, and its action does not extend beyond the part which is cauterized: and it does not harm any other connected part, except for a slight bruising.</start_of_turn
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	Burning medicine, however, extends its action to the parts surrounding the cauterized area: and sometimes it makes the healing of the ailment more difficult, and sometimes it even brings about death.</start_of_turn>
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	Fire, however, because of its subtlety and the excellence of its substance, does not make this [surgery] ill, unless it be excessive.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	Fire, however, by reason of its subtlety and the excellence of its substance, does not make this [surgery] bad, unless it be excessive.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	Fire, however, by reason of its subtlety and the excellence of its substance, does not make this [surgery] bad, unless it be excessive. And although this is not mentioned in this book, I shall tell you a secret concerning fire which is useful for this operation and which is demonstrated by philosophers with reference to the expulsion of ailments from the body.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	And behold, children, that even they [philosophers] disagree concerning the time when fire becomes a cautery, and they say that it is better to delay the time of the operation.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	I say also that cautery is useful at all times: for in every case the document becomes submerged in urine, which is attracted by the cautery.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	Above all, if the cautery is to be used for severe and sudden pains, which do not tolerate delay, for these are subject to the danger of an increase in evil which is greater than the slight damage done by the operation at a later time.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	Do not be deceived by the minds of the vulgar or stupid physicians, who say that surgery is never necessary for ailments which are cured by cautery: for in this they are mistaken. Indeed, cautery alters the complexion and dries up humors which are the causes of these ailments.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	Indeed, cautery surpasses medicine in speed of action, in the excellence of its operation, and in its gentleness: and it is possible that the ailment will be cured at some later hour according to the complexion of the patient, the location of the ailment, and the excellence of the operation itself. And this is effected in the body by the collection of superfluous humors which are evacuated by the cautery. And this is the reason why it brings about the healing of ailments which medicine cannot cure.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	Acute pain in a few superabundant and humid parts, as in a burnt tooth, because of pain, and similar to it, is possible that it will not depart from there without pain.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	But this is in few cases.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	Indeed, it is right that the cauterism is the most recent of the medical arts, and that is why they do not believe that there is any healing that can be obtained by medicine, nor by anything else after the cauterism has been made.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	But the thing is contrary to that. The intention is not that the cauterism is the most recent of the medical arts, but when we administer methods of treatment in some ailment, and they do not confer that treatment: then we administer in the end the cauterism, and it confers: thus it is that the cauterism is the last thing, not according to the intention which the vulgar people and the multitude of the physicians understand
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	The ancients say that the cauterism with gold is better than the cauterism with iron: and they do not say this except because of the equality of the gold and the fineness of its substance: and they say that it does not form pus at the place of the cauterism
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	But it is not absolutely so. For I myself have seen this to be the case, and I have found that it does not do this in some bodies without other things
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	And the cauterism with the very thing is good, and better than with iron, as they say.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	But when you ignite the cauterism with fire from gold, you are not to declare that it is ignited according to its quantity, because of the redness of the gold: and when it approaches the cold and if you add to it more fire, it liquefies in the fire, and turns into plates.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	Why does the artificer depart from that to engage in this business? And because of this, the Cauterium with the iron is brought near and is more rapid and proximate to the operation from its upright position.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	I have also ordered this Chapter in Cauterium, according to the Chapters: and I have ordered them from the head down to the feet: so that they may perform whatever they wish from it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	As to the manner of cauterizing the Head in the coronal suture.
Caput II.	Chapter 2: Of the Head.
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	Here the cauterization is done according to the lord of humidity and cold over the brain: because these two are the causes of swelling, and of the flow of humors from the head to the eyes and ears, and of the swelling of sleep, and of toothache, and of throat pain: and in general of all diseases which arise from cold, such as palsy, and swelling, and epilepsy, and apoplexy, and things like these from diseases.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	The method of cauterization is as follows: when the patient is in good health, he should be evacuated at first with a purgative medicine which softens the head for three or four nights, according to the nature of the disease, and the age of the patient, and his habit.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	Then command him to make a circular burn on his head with the lancet
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	Then make him sit between your hands square, so that you can place your hands on his chest
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	Then place the root of your palm on the root of his nose between his eyes
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	Wherever your middle finger touches, that is the place where you must cauterize with the burn
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	Then take the Cauterium Olive: which has this shape
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	Then place it upon the marked place with the cautery, descending gradually, so that your hand may be gradually constricted, and you shall withdraw it.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	Then draw your hand quickly, and grasp the place.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	If you see any quantity of bone or cartilage or herbs, then draw your hand quickly.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	And if not, repeat your hand with the iron itself, or with something else that is heated: until you see the bone which I told you of.
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then take some salt and dissolve it in water, and drink it down with this sponge, and place it upon the place: and keep it there for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	Then place upon it a sponge soaked in butter, and keep the flame over the place, until the eschar is consumed by fire.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	Then care for it with unguents of four herbs, until it is healed
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	It has been said that the greater the wound remains open, the more pus will be emitted: which is better and more useful.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	And some people say that the skin should be cauterized up to the bone: and let the Cautery remain in contact until something of the thickness of bone is charred
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	Then it will be withdrawn after that which was scorched from the bone, and it will be cured
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	And others say that it is necessary that the Cautery should remain until the very end, until it has left an imprint in the bone like a footprint, so that the bone will fall out, as it is like a woman's stylus made of a small letter: and they say that from this place vapor escapes from the head, and the wound will be healed in a long time
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	Then he cares until they are solidified.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	Neither of two species of cautery is useless in all people except in some in whom there is fear of excessive bleeding.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	Leave it [the cautery] and attend to the health of the patient. It is better for me like that.</start_of_turn>
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	The head grows weak from the continuity of its natural discharge: as we have seen in the rest of the limbs: and especially when the head of the patient is weak by nature: the first kind of cautery is most safe and better for me in this case, and I will work with it for the health of the patient.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	In the case of cauterizing the head in the pain of the whole head.</start_of_turn>
Caput III.	Head section III.</start_of_turn
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	When in the whole head there occurs chronic pain: and it persists in the patient, and there is pus, and boils, and head-purgings, and oil, and application of these things.</start_of_turn
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	And especially if one kind of cautery has already been applied, as we have mentioned, and no other of these things has been added to it: then consider carefully.</start_of_turn
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	For if the head of the patient is strong by nature and not weak, and there is cold sweat: then cauterize with another kind of cautery under that little bit.</start_of_turn
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	Then cauterize over the whole horn of the head with that cautery, but do not pass through the skin, and uncover an amount of bone as we have mentioned.</start_of_turn
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	And cauterize with one kind of cautery in the nape of the neck of the head, in the place which is called the uas: and this is the place where the marrow is placed: and elevate your hand in this and do not uncover the bone.</start_of_turn
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	The infirm one finds because of that pain which arises, and diverse from the pain of the other cauterizations of the head altogether.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	I say concerning this Cauterization: it must be that which cauterizes the horns of the head and the back of the head more finely, and which cauterizes the middle of the head more broadly.
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	Concerning the method of cauterization in hemianche, both with the medicinal unguents and with the iron
Caput IIII.	Chapter III.
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	When it happens in the part of the head that there is pain and swelling, or that the pain extends up to the eye, and it is evacuated with the physicians who moderate the head, and the rest of the treatment is administered as I have said in the discourse on the diseases of the head, and it does not suffice for that: then the cauterization in that case is done in two ways: either with an acute burning medicine or with the iron
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	The cauterization with the acute burning medicine is that, you take a tooth from another person and burn it, and you remove the bark from it, and you split its extremities from both sides
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	Then split the place of the pain in time with a wide phlebotomy, until there is under the skin in that place where the tooth is taken
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Introduce it there under the skin until it is hidden: then bind over it with a bandage of constriction of low tension, and leave it for fifteen hours. Then take out the dressing and leave it for two or three days. Finally put on a wet bandage over it which is immersed in butter, until the place heals. Then care for it with an unguent until it is healed
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	And if you wish to do this with some burning medicines which I have written about in the twelfth tractate, on the Burning Medicines.
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	Burning the inside of the belly with iron is in this way.
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	Burning with iron is like this
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	It is called Clausais: for its head has the shape of a key, in which there is some curvature, and in the middle there is a small prominence.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	Then put it on the place and hold your hand: and move the iron slowly while applying pressure: and let the quantity which is enough to burn through the thickness of the skin be as much as half of its size
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Lift your hand so that the artery below is not burned and the blood flow does not increase
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then soak the area in salt water, and put it on the place, and leave it for three days: then put the area with butter: afterwards care with unguents until it is healed.
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	If necessary, burn the haemorrhoids with the second extremity of the knife according to the Cauterization technique.
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	Burn from the incision of the artery in this haemorrhoid, not from the old way directly.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	In the old way, the haemorrhoids were cauterized like this.</start_of_turn>
Caput V.	End of document.
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	When treating haemorrhoids, with all that has been said about the treatment of ailments, and when the cure has not taken hold: and when the pain persists, and the ailment has not been overcome by the cautery with medicine or with fire, then it is necessary to burn the haemorrhoids with the knife until they become white when there are signs of pain along a line whose length is half the digit, or almost like that: then take your hand away from the area with one hand, and hold the area firmly until the artery is cut through, and keep it that way until bone is reached.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	It is necessary to restrain you, so that you do not suffer from the continuation of the mandible, which moves during mastication, lest it become wide or the nerve which moves it, from which the spasm arises.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	And take care of the guarding of the artery which has been cut off, and of the flow of blood from it.</start_of_turn>
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	For in the cutting of it there is fear, especially for him who is ignorant of what it does, and who is not studious or experienced: and he departs from the operation at once.</start_of_turn>
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	And I come with the reminder of the regime of the flow of blood which is accidental to the artery according to its method, and in its place here in this book.</start_of_turn
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	If you see that the wound is of such a kind that the Cauterium is not sufficient for it, and that the body of the sick man can tolerate the Cauterium in the middle of the head, as we have mentioned, take care of the burn until it is healed.</start_of_turn
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	And if you wish, apply the Cauterium, as we have said in the chapter on the extraction of the artery with the Cauterium which has two blades.</start_of_turn
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	For the cauterization is better in this way and more effective.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	Of the way of cauterizing in the pain of the ears.</start_of_turn
Caput VI.	Chapter VI.</start_of_turn>
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	When it happens in the ear a pain from the cold, and it is cured with solutions, and the rest of the cure as we have said in the preceding, and the pain does not move, then ignite the Cauterium: and that is what is called the Point, which has this shape.</start_of_turn
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	Then the point with it after its ignition around the whole ear, as it is turned: or around both sides, if the pain is in both.</start_of_turn
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	And prolong thee with the Cauterium from the root of the ear downwards, after you have marked the area with the Cautery: and let the quantity of the Cautery be ten points in every aure, and thus in all.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	And then care for the area until it has healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	In this manner Cauterize in Tortura.
Caput VII.	Chapter VII.</start_of_turn>
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	Torture which is cured by Cauterization is nothing except for those species which arise from phlegmas, as we said in the discussions of the causes of diseases.</start_of_turn>
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	And you must Cauterize the species which arise from exication and nerve spasm.</start_of_turn
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	When you have cured this species of torture with baths, catapults, and gargles, and the cure has not taken effect, then you must Cauterize the patient three times with the Cautery: once at the root of the ear, and once somewhat lower from the earlobe, and once at the junction of the two lips.</start_of_turn
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	And place the Cautery on the side opposite the diseased part.</start_of_turn
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	For the soothing of the parts must be in the sound part.</start_of_turn
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	And the form of Cauterization is that you Cauterize with the Cautery itself at the root of the upper ear under the earlobe: and on the earlobe itself. The length of the Cautery should be as long as the length of the thumb.</start_of_turn
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	And hold your hand with the Cautery until half of the thickness of the skin has been consumed by the flame.</start_of_turn
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	And this is the form of the Cautery, and it is of the kind of knife whose form is as described: truly it is not more delicate than that of the needle: and it must be so that the knife is of a suitable thickness.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	Then care for the place until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	Then care for the place until it is healed.
Caput VIII.	Then care for the place until it is healed.
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	Then care for the place until it is healed.
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	Then care for the place until it is healed
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then care for the place until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	Then care for the place until it is healed
Caput IX.	Then care for the place until it is healed
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	Then care for the place until it is healed
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	Then care for the place until it is healed
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	Then care for the place until it is healed
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	Then care for the place until it is healed
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	Then care for the place until it is healed
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then care for the place until it is healed
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	Then care for the place until it is healed
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	Then care for the place until it is healed
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	Then care for the place until it is healed
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	Regarding the cauterization of paralysis and its soothing.
Caput X.	Regarding the cauterization of paralysis and its soothing.
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	One must proceed with care in the cauterization of the head with lye and with that which we have mentioned.
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	Then touch the head of the patient: afterwards cauterize the middle of the head, and the corners of the head, and the back of the head, and three times on the prominence of the collarbone
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	If, however, you deem it appropriate in the soothing of the body by means of many of these, and the patient is tolerant, and the ailment is severe: then cauterize four times on the prominences of the back, and the last with a fifth cauterization, until the greatest part of its surface is consumed by fire, and lift your hand up.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	Then care for it until it heals: and thus is the treatment complete.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	Regarding the cauterization of epilepsy.
Caput XI.	Regarding the cauterization of epilepsy
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	Epilepsy is not cauterized, except for that which is due to phlegm
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	One must therefore first soften the brain of the patient with lye, and with the rest of the treatment which we have mentioned: when the patient is great or is tolerant of the medicines
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	If, however, it is a child who does not tolerate the medicines, then gargling and nourishing bites are administered before many days with the improvement of the appetite
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	Then touch the head of the patient: afterwards cauterize the middle of the head as we have mentioned before, and another on the back of the head, and over every corner of the head with a single cauterization
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	If the patient be robust and endure pain, then cauterize him with cautery, as I have mentioned in the case of paralysis, and to soften the body above the cervical vertebrae and the vertebrae of the back: and let the cautery be performed according to the method which went before.
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	If, however, the patient be a boy, then apply the cautery gently, according to this method.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	Method of cauterization in Melancholia.
Caput XII.	Chapter XII
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	When the cause of melancholy is corrupted humors, and thick phlegm, then cauterize him with cautery, as I have mentioned in the case of paralysis.
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	And if the cause of melancholy is excess of bile leading to melancholy, and the patient’s body be moist, then give him something to drink which will stimulate his brain, according to what has been mentioned previously: then bind the head of the patient, and make a small incision in the center of the forehead, like a circle
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	Then place the cautery in the middle of the head: and the patient sitting upright is to be held secure from all sides
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	Then apply linimentum.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	And it is good to use old butter or oil
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	And heat it over a moderate fire, as much as the finger can bear when it is introduced into it
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	Then evacuate it in the middle of his head in a circle, and hold it until it is cold
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	Do this to the patient every week once, along with the rest of his treatment, until he is healed
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	Or if you wish, cauterize him by making many small holes in it, besides that you hold the hand with the cautery: and let it stink.
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	This kind of cautery moistens the brain with the same quality.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	Then put upon it a covering soaked in butter, or fat from a hen.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	In descending water, cauterize to the eye.
Caput XIII.	Chapter XIII.
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	When the water in the eye is declared by the signs which I mentioned in the previous discourse, then you begin and apply the cautery to the diseased part, until it changes the head of the limb
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	And keep it away from all moistness, and let it sit in a bath for a few days
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	Then command him to raise his head, and cauterize in the middle of his head
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	Then cauterize on either side of the two temples with two cautery instruments at once: if the descent of the water is simultaneous in both eyes: or from one side only if the descent of the water is in one eye only: and cut away with the cautery all the veins and arteries which are under the skin: and let the cautery be long in length in the width of the temples: and burn from the flow of blood.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	If anything else escapes from it, then immediately cut away with whatever medicine is possible: and I will come with wisdom in the extraction of the arteries, and the cutting away of them, and care for the flow of blood
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	And when cauterizing in the brain, under two bones, with two ultimate cautery instruments.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	In the ancient lacrimal glands.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter XIIII
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	When the tears of the eyes are ancient, sticky: and are on the veins and arteries which are in the exterior of the head, it is proved that this comes from the excessive cold, phlegmatic humours: then cauterize with the same cautery which I mentioned in the beginning of the discourse, the cautery in the middle of the head, and with two cautery instruments on either side of the two temples, and with two cautery instruments in the brain under two bones
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	If the swelling persists after the addition of medicine, then burn the area all around the eye cautiously, over the outer edge of the eyebrow with a small burn.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	In the case of an eye wound, burn around the eye cautiously, over the outer edge of the eyebrow with a small burn.
Caput XV.	Chapter 15.
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	When you have treated it with the medicine we have mentioned and the swelling persists: then make the patient drink three doses of castor oil every night: then bandage the head and burn it with an average burn, with olive oil
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	Then burn it with two small burns, over the two eyebrows under the hair
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	And take care not to burn the artery, lest you cause blindness
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	This is the method of burning the eyebrows
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	Method for burning for the softening of the eyelids
Caput XVI.	Chapter 16
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	When the eyelids of the eye are softened by the brightness or humidity: then burn the eyelid once with a lunar burn
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	And if necessary, burn it over the two eyebrows a little at a time with two small burns in every part: and stretch for two times: and the length of each burn should be as long as the eyebrow: and do not touch your hand with the burn, but according to the quantity which is to be burned of the third of the eyelid.
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	This is the method of burning for the softening of the eyelid in this way.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	Method for burning the eyelid when the hair of the eyelashes is inflamed by the eye
Caput XVII.	Chapter 17
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	The cautery is of two kinds: either with fire or with burning medicine.
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	When using the cautery with fire, the surgeon should precede the instrument over the wound so that it may expel its hair, if there be any, until the hair has become prolonged and equal
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	If, however, the cautery should touch the edge of the wound: then clamp the edges of the wound with forceps so that they do not move until they have healed.</start_of_turn>
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	When they have healed and become equal, then place the head of the patient upon your lap: then mark over the pupils of his eyes with the cautery, making a sign which is like the shape of a myrtle leaf: and let the beginning of the sign be near the hair.</start_of_turn>
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	Then place a soaked compress on the white of the eye: or on the hair of the eyelashes over the eye.</start_of_turn>
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then apply the cautery, which is shaped like this.</start_of_turn>
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	Then burn over the figure which you have marked slowly in many places, until the surface of the skin, which is like the shape of a myrtle leaf, is completely consumed.</start_of_turn
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	And the sign of the completion of your work is that if you touch the pupil of the eye it will contract, and the hair will be plucked at the point of the eye.</start_of_turn>
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Lift your hand then: and let it go in three days.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	Then place upon it a compress with butter, until the scar has disappeared.</start_of_turn>
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with unguents, until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	Should any hair remain after an hour, and the pupil be soft: then repeat the cautery in the same place as before.</start_of_turn
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	If, however, the hairs are in the lower part: then cauterize it itself, until it rises to its natural place: and make it even so that it does not puncture the eyes.
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	In the same way, cauterize with the burning medicine in this case.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter XVIII.</start_of_turn>
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	It is necessary to order the sick person to remove the hairs, until they grow long and are evened out.</start_of_turn
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	Make from parchment in the shape of a leaf of myrtle.</start_of_turn
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	Then take from boiled soap, which has been ground, and from chalk which has not been imbibed from one pound about an inch or somewhat less: then mix these together with good pressure, and make it so that it does not freeze.</start_of_turn
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	Then take from this ball what is above and put it on the eyelid of one or both.</start_of_turn
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	And put under the eye a soaked bandage in albumin or oil: and keep the head of the sick person in your hand.</start_of_turn>
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	And put your index finger on the medicine and press it slightly.</start_of_turn
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	And you move it whenever the sick person feels the biting of the medicine: because it has found its biting like fire.</start_of_turn
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	When therefore you have persevered with this and it has found its biting, then remove the medicine and move it with your finger.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	When the biting has subsided, then remove the medicine and bathe the eye with water.</start_of_turn
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	And consider then, if the eyelid is raised by the expansion with the fire, or with the incision, it is good: and if not, then repeat the medicine on the place where the medicine does not press, and does not irritate, until your operation is complete, and the eyes are closed.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	Then place above the utmost part of the cushion with butter, until the skin of the wound has been eradicated.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	Then keep the wound covered with ointment, or something else, until it has healed
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	And it is necessary to keep the patient near at hand during the operation, so that nothing from the medicine should fall into the eye
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	If the eyelashes become soft after a day, and something from the hair gets into the eye, then repeat the medicine on the place where the eyelashes softened of their own accord, just as you did at the beginning
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then keep the wound covered, until it has healed.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	And this is the form of the myrtle leaf.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	And you know that the eyes of men differ in size and shape
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	Therefore take into consideration the following: and do not hide the straightness of the limb, which is the study of this art
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	Concerning the cauterization of the fistula of the tear duct.
Caput XIX.	Chapter XIX.
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	When you have cured the fistula, when you know that your treatment has not been effective: then it is necessary to cauterize the thing according to this method
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	Command the patient to place his head in your lap, and hold his head between your hands like this, so that it does not move or shake with his head
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then place buttered cotton in the eye-socket or in the hair of the eyelashes over his eye: then burn the Cauterium, which is of this shape.
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	Sit concave, like the shape of the tip of a wing of a feather, as it is with the Cauterium: and if you wish that it should penetrate until the other end, and if you wish that it should remain above, do so as you please
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	It is better to make the incision with this curve for your work.
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	If the abscess is open, express its contents and remove them entirely. Then dry it: if it remains closed, then open it and remove its pus.</start_of_turn>
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	Then place above the wound a Cauterium, which is made of an ignited wool.</start_of_turn>
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	Hold your hand near the Cauterium from the eye to the nose, so that your hand does not slip, or irritate the patient: and place the Cauterium on the fatty tissue of the eye and burn it through.</start_of_turn
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	If you proceed with the Cauterium at the beginning until the bone, it will be good.</start_of_turn
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	And if not: then repeat the Cauterium once or twice if necessary: and keep it for three days.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	Then apply a bandage with butter, and care for it with an ointment until it heals.</start_of_turn
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	If after forty days it has not healed: then apply above it an acute corrosive medicine, until the bone is exposed: and remove it according to what is written in its chapter.</start_of_turn
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	There is another method of Cauterizing the fistula, which some of the first said.</start_of_turn>
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	Direct it to the location of the fistula and find it: then put under the fistula a thin cushion, that is, a needle of a fine size, whose form is like this.</start_of_turn
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	And pour into it the quantity of a drachma of liquid lead, and hold your hand firmly with the needle retention, and do not move the patient at all, so that it does not run, or that the liquid lead reaches his eye.</start_of_turn
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	It is necessary that you place above the eye of the patient a compress soaked in albumin or in water.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	Lead will consume the place of the fistula, and will effect a remarkable healing.
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	When the fistula has been healed, as we mentioned previously from the Cauterium and treatment, it is good
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	And if not, it is necessary to administer a nose-opening, and reduce the fistula to the course of the nose, according as it comes to its own place
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	Regarding the cauterization of fissures of the lips
Caput XX.	Chapter XX.
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	Many accidents happen in the lip fissures, which are called Pili, and especially in the lips of children
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	When you treat these fissures, when the healing is not confirmed, then slightly burn the cautery according to this shape
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	And let the concavity of it be according to the sharpness of the knife
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	Then put the flame quickly onto the fissures themselves until the cautery reaches the depth of the fissures
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with oil until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	Regarding the cauterization of the fistula of the eye
Caput XXI.	Chapter XXI
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	When there is swelling in the root of the gums, or in the palate, or in the roots of the teeth: then pus forms, and it ruptures: afterwards it becomes infected, and pus comes out, and there forms a fistula: then treat this, and do not allow healing in it, then it is necessary to burn the cautery according to the quantity which is in the fistula.
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	Then insert the burning object into the fistula, and keep your hand there until the iron burns deep into it, and finally: do that once, or twice at most.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	Then care for it afterwards as we have said about the care until it heals completely.</start_of_turn>
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	If it severs and heals, it is good.</start_of_turn>
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	And if not, then it is necessary to remove the place and take out the corrupt bone according to what comes to light in its head.</start_of_turn>
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	In this way, cauterizing in the Gingiues and softening of teeth is done.</start_of_turn
Caput XXII.	Chapter XXII.</start_of_turn>
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	When the gingiva is softened because of moisture, and the teeth are loose, and you take care of it with the physicians, and do not confer: then put the head of the patient in your lap.</start_of_turn
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	Then burn the cautery, whose form will come afterwards, so that you put the cannula on the tooth: and insert the burning cautery into it quickly: and keep your hand still, until the patient feels the heat of the fire has reached the root of the tooth.</start_of_turn
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	And lift your hand: then repeat the cautery a few times, as you wish.</start_of_turn
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	Then let the patient rinse his mouth with salt water, and keep it for one hour: and then expel it.</start_of_turn
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	The tooth will then be firm again, and the gingiva will be softened and stretched, and the moisture will be dried up.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	In this way, cauterizing in toothache is done.</start_of_turn
Caput XXIII.	Chapter XXIII.
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	When the toothache is caused by cold, or if the tooth itself is cold, or if there is a worm therein, and the cure does not succeed with physicians: then Cauterium is used in two ways: either with butter or with fire.
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	Or with fire, as it takes butter to smear thickly, and applies it to the tooth in the ear or in the root
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	Then take alum, and smear it over the edge of the tooth.
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	Then soak it in boiling butter: and put it on the painful tooth quickly, and hold it until it cools down: then repeat it several times, until the fire has reached the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	Or if you wish, soak wool, or alum in cold butter, and put it on the painful tooth: and put on top of it a burning iron, until the fire has reached the depth of the cavity of the tooth.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	Note: Cauterium refers to burning or cauterizing, which involves treating a wound or disease by applying intense heat or burning.
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	And be careful that there be no excess of the heat, lest it should reach the bone of the infirm person.
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	Then let the Cauterium be cool: and put it on the tooth: and hold your hand, until the Cauterium cools down.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	Do it repeatedly, for the pain will disappear either on the same day or the next day
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	And it is necessary to impress that Cauterium into the cavity of the tooth, so that the infirm person may apply butter to his bone well, and keep it for an hour: then expel it.
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	This is the form of Cauterium.
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	Burn with whatever extremity you can manage: this is the form of the cannula.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	Burn with whatever extremity you can manage: this is the method of the cannula.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24.
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	When the swellings are from phlegm, and moisture of cold, and do not yield to medicine, and you wish to speed up their digestion: then burn with a concave cautery, whose form is like this.
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	Having two open extremities, so that the smoke may escape from the cautery between the extremities: and place the flame upon the swelling once, and again, if it does not digest, until it reaches the depth of the swelling
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	If the swelling is small: then burn the cautery according to the size of the swelling
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	Then remove it for three days, and place upon it a poultice soaked in butter, until the burnt part has disappeared
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	Then care for it with unguents until the shape of the cannula is restored
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	On the method of burning in a raucous voice and constriction of the chest.
Caput XXV.	Chapter 25
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	When the wind moistens over the channels of the lungs, and especially when it is with the coldness of the complexion: then it is necessary to evacuate the sick person immediately with resolving remedies
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	Then burn in the night at the root of the gullet in a depressed place: and burn cautiously, so as not to reach the gut or the skin, except for a little of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	Then burn again with another cautery at the junction of the collar in the last rib: and let the cautery be fixed according to the mode which preceded it
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then care for yourself until you are healed.
