¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	In the treatment of pulmonary and testicular ailments, cauterization should be employed.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter XXVI.</start_of_turn>
Quando Tussis et aegritudo Pulmonis sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, et infirmus non habet febrem, neque phthisim, et aegritudo antiqua: tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis supra furculam in locis depressis, lenibus, uacuis.	When cough and pulmonary ailment are caused by cold dampness, and the patient has neither fever nor phthisis, nor old consumption: then cauterize twice with two cautery instruments above the cartilage in the depressed places, in lenium, or in the lacunae.</start_of_turn
Et cauterio alio in medio pectoris inter duas mammillas: et sit cauterium cannulae secundum formam quae praecessit.	And cauterize once in the middle of the chest between the two nipples: and let the cautery instrument be in the shape that preceded.</start_of_turn
Et si uis sit cauterizatio tua punctando cum cauterio, quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma praecessit in punctatione doloris aurium: et sint puncta ex triginta punctis usque quasi ad alia.	And if you wish to cauterize by puncturing with a cautery, which is called Punctum, which has a shape like that which preceded in the puncture of pain in the ears: and let there be from thirty punctures up to almost as many.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then care for yourself until you are healed.</start_of_turn>
Et iam sit cauterium habens tres ramos: secundum hanc formam.	And let the cautery instrument have three branches: according to this shape.</start_of_turn
Quare alleuiatur cum eo cauterizatio, quando tu facis cum eo uice una tria Cauteria.	Because it alleviates with three cautery instruments when you do it with one of them at a time.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Titillico, in dislocatione Humeri.	In the treatment of dislocation of the Humerus in the Titillico area.</start_of_turn
Caput XXVII.	Chapter XXVII.</start_of_turn
Quando dislocatur caput adiutorii caussa humiditatum, et nonfigitur in hora reditus sui a dislocatione sua, donec sit illud ei consuetudo reditionis, deinde dislocatur a paruo motu, qui accidit sicut nos iam testificauimus illud, tunc oportet ut reducas dislocationem in primis.	When the head of the assistant is dislocated due to humidity and does not return to its place in an hour, until it has become accustomed to its return: then it must be reduced by a small movement, as we have testified to this. Then it is necessary to reduce the dislocation immediately.</start_of_turn
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, aut super latus sanum.	Then the sickly man lies upon his back, or upon his side towards the healthy side.
Deinde eleua cutim, quae est in interiori Titillici ad superiora cum digitis manus tuae sinistrae: et si iunctura dislocatur ad interiora.	Then lift the skin which is at the inner part of the Titillic to the upper part with your left hand: and if the joint is dislocated inwards.</start_of_turn>
Deinde igni Cauterium habens duo uerua.	Then take the Cauterium having two handles.</start_of_turn>
Cuius forma est haec.	Which is like this.</start_of_turn
Deinde cauteriza cutim, donec penetret eam usque ad latus aliud, et ueniet figura cauterizationis cum quatuor cauteriis.	Then burn the skin until it penetrates to the other side, and the figure of the burn will be like four cauterizations.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque fit cauterizatio cum cauterio habente tria uerua, quare fit figura cauterizationis tunc sex cauteriorum: et sunt uerua secundum subtilitatem tentae.	And when the burn is made with a cautery having three handles, because of this the figure of the burn will be like six cauterizations: and these are the handles that are according to the degree of tension.</start_of_turn
Et haec est forma cauterii habentis tria uerua.	And this is the figure of the cautery having three handles.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque additur super hunc modum unum, quare sunt cauteria octo.	And when you add on this manner one more, because there are eight cauteries in all.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone super cauterium porros contritos cum sale.	Then put upon the cautery fat sponges with salt.</start_of_turn
Deinde fac adhaerere infirmum tranquillitati, ut non moueatur membrum tempore aliquo, donec confortetur.	Then make the sickly man adhere to tranquility, so that he does not move the limb for some time, until he is comfortable.</start_of_turn
Et si dislocatio est ad superiora, et raro fit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super humerum cauterio clauili, aut cauteriis multis punctando.	And if the dislocation is to the upper parts, and this rarely happens, then burn the upper part of the humerus with the cautery claw, or with many punctures.</start_of_turn
Nam iunctura firmatur, et remouetur humiditas: et sanatur infirmus.	For the joint is solidified, and the moisture is drained away: and the sickly man is healed.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi Stomachum.	In this manner the Stomach is to be cauterized.</start_of_turn
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter XXVIII.
Quando accidunt in Stomacho frigus et humiditates multae, donec extrahant ipsum a complexione sua, et multiplicentur catarri ad ipsum, et assiduas modos curationis, et non confert: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat crura sua, et manus suas.	When cold and moisture abound in the stomach, until they are expelled from their composition, and multiply pus to it, and apply assiduous methods of treatment, and do not confer [treatments]: then it is necessary that the patient rest upon his back, extend his limbs, and clench his fists.
Deinde cauteriza cum tribus cauteriis, cauterio sub cochleari pectoris quantitate digiti unius cum cauterio clauili, et duobus cauteriis inferius a duobus lateribus cauterii unius, donec ueniat figura cauteriorum triangulata.	Then cauterize with three cautery instruments, the cautery under the collar of the chest measuring the quantity of a single digit with the cautery of the claw, and two cautery instruments beneath the two lower angles of the single cautery, until the triangle of cauteries appears
Et elonga inter utraque ut non coniungantur, quando facient pus.	And lengthen between each [cautery] so that they do not join, when they produce pus.
Et sit profunditas cauterii quantitas duarum tertiarum grossitudinis cutis.	And the depth of the cautery is the quantity of two-thirds of the thickness of the skin
Et sit figura cauteriorum secundum hanc formam sine additione: et si uis cauteriza cauterio magno in medio stomachi secundum hanc formam: et sit cauterium quo fit hoc cauterium unum secundum figuram circuli secundum hanc formam.	And let the figure of the cauteries be in this form without addition: and if you wish to cauterize the great cautery in the middle of the stomach according to this form: let the cautery be as much as this single cautery according to the form of a circle according to this form.
Et cauterizatur stomachus punctando ei qui terretur ab hoc cauterio: et est, ut signes super stomachum punctum secundum quantitatem, quam uis cum encaustro: deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio puncti: deinde cura ipsum cum curatione, quae praecessit donec sanetur.	And cauterize the stomach by puncturing it with that which returns from this cautery: and it is that the signs upon the stomach be pierced in quantity as much as you wish with encasement: then cauterize it with the cautery of the puncture: then care for it with the treatment which preceded until it heals
¶ De modo cauterizandi Epar frigidum.	In this manner cauterize the spleen when cold.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter XXIX
Quando accidit in Epate dolor ex frigiditate et humiditate, aut ex uentositate grossa, donec egrediatur a complexione sua naturali egressione superflua, et curatur infirmus, cum eo quod diximus, et non proficit in illo: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam, et signes cum encaustro tria cauteria secundum hanc figuram, et hanc quantitatem eandem super Epar inferius ab hypocundriis, ubi peruenit cubitus hominis: et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium secundum grossitudinem digiti: et sit cauterium secundum longitudinem corporis rectum: et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio multum.	When it happens in the spleen that there is pain from cold and moisture, or from great wind, until it is expelled from its natural composition by excessive emission, and the patient is cured as we have said, and does not profit from it: then it is necessary that the patient rest upon his chest, and put the signs with three cauteries according to this figure and this quantity on the spleen below the hypochondria, where the elbow of a man is found: and let the space that is between every cautery be according to the thickness of a digit: and let the cautery be according to the length of the body's rectum: and do not press your hand too much with the cautery
Et sit quantitas eius quod aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, quantitas medietatis eius non additum: et sit infirmus stans super pedes suos.	And let the quantity of that which is to be taken away from the thickness of the skin be not added to the middle: and let the patient be standing on his feet.
Si autem non est stans, tunc sit iacens, qui iam extendit crura sua, et eleuauit brachia sua.	And if he is not standing, then he is lying down, who has extended his limbs and raised his arms high
Haec est forma cauterii.	This is the form of cautery.
Et tibi quidem possibile est, ut cauterizes ista cauteria cum cauterio cultellari, quando tecum est subtilitas et prudentia in arte.	And indeed it is possible that these carbuncles may be cauterized with a knife, when there is subtlety and skill in the art.
Et custodi te, ut non ultime procedas in cauterizatione, et aduratur spissitudo cutis totius, quare aduratur corpus totum, et perueniat ad intestina: quoniam cutis illic est subtilis, scias ergo illud.	Beware lest you go too far in the cautery, and that you burn the whole body, because the skin there is thin, as you know well
¶ De modo cauterizandi apostemata Epatis.	Concerning the cautery of the after-eruption of the liver
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30.
Quando accidit exitura, et uis scire, si illud apostema est in carne Epatis, aut in tunica eius: tunc si est in carne Epatis, inuadit infirmum dolor, et grauitas absque acuitate: et si est in tunica Epatis, cum dolore est acuitas uehemens: et uides iam, quia fatigauit medicos eius curatio.	When this happens, and you wish to write, if the after-eruption is in the liver itself, or in its covering: if it is in the liver itself, there is severe pain and swelling without acute pain: and if it is in the covering of the liver, with acute pain there is also swelling: and know that I am commanding you to go away, because it fatigues the physician of its care
Oportet ergo ut resupinet infirmus super ceruicem suam.	It is necessary therefore that the patient lies down on his belly
Deinde figura locum apostematis cum encaustro: deinde ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	Then the figure of the place of the after-eruption with the cautery: then you will apply the cautery which is assimilated by the heat.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form
Et cauteriza cum eo cauterium unum, donec comburatur cutis tota, et perueniat ad siphac, donec egrediatur sanies tota: deinde cura ipsum curatione exiturarum, donec sanetur.	And cauterize with this knife once, until the whole skin is consumed, and it reaches the spleen, until the whole body is healed: then take care of the after-eruption, until the patient is healed
Et non oportet ut hac cauterii specie utatur, nisi cuius studium in arte medicinae prolongatur: et per cuius manus concurrunt aegritudines istae cum experimento aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super huiusmodi operationem.	Neither should any instrument of the cauterizing kind be used without thorough study in the art of medicine: for by means of such study the disorders mentioned above will concur with experience on numerous occasions.
At uero dimittere ipsam, apud me est melius.	It is better to omit it than to risk damaging it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Pleuresi.	On the method of cauterization in the chest
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 1
Dixerunt antiqui, cauterium cum radicibus aristolochiae ad Pleuresim frigidam secundum hunc modum.	The ancients say that cauterization with aristolochia roots is used for a cold pleurisis in this way.
Et est, ut recipias ex radicibus aristolochiae siccae longae, radicem unam longiorem, quae ex ea inuenitur, et sit sicut grossitudo digiti.	And it is to be taken that from the dry roots of aristolochia one should take a single long root which is taken from it and be as thick as a finger
Deinde submerge eam in oleo: et accende ipsam in igne.	Then immerse the root in oil: and kindle the same in fire.
Deinde cauteriza cauterio uno in eo quod est inter continuationem furculae cum collo, et duobus cauteriis paruis sub guidezi parum decliuibus ad partem, quae est sub barba.	Then cauterize with one cautery that is between the continuation of the collarbone and the jugulum, and with two small cauteries under guidance slightly bent downwards to the part which is under the beard
Et duobus cauteriis etiam in eo, quod est inter costam quintam et sextam decliuibus ad posteriora parumper: et cauterio alio in medio pectoris, et alio supra stomachum.	And with two cauteries also in that which is between the fifth and sixth ribs bent downwards to the rear: and a third cautery in the middle of the chest, and another above the stomach
Et tribus cauteriis a posterioribus: uno in eo quod est inter duas spatulas: et duobus cauteriis a duobus lateribus pectoris, inferius cauterio quod est inter duas spatulas.	And three cauteries from behind: one in that which is between two ribs: and two cauteries from both sides of the chest, the lower cautery which is between two ribs
Et non oportet ut comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit in manifesto cutis odorando.	Neither must you touch your hand with the cautery, but let it be evident that the skin is fragrant.
Et iam dixerunt quidam antiqui, quod ex hominibus sunt qui utuntur cauterio ex ferro simili radio: et igniunt, et intus mittunt ipsum in eo quod est inter costas, donec perueniatur cum eo ad ipsum apostema, et egrediatur sanies: sicut diximus in apostemate Epatis.	And some ancient writers say that there are certain men who use a cautery like iron to burn: and they burn and throw it into that which is between the ribs, until it is consumed by it to the very bone, and comes out whole: as we said concerning the spleen
Sed in hac perforatione cum cauterio est ex timore, quod aut moritur infirmus statim, aut accidit in loco fistula, cui non est sanatio.	But in this perforation with the cautery there is fear, for either the infirm dies immediately, or it happens that in the place of the fistula there is no healing.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Splenem Caput XXXII.	In this way the cautery is to be used for the spleen head.
Quando tu curas aegritudinem splenis, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua, tunc cauterium in ea est secundum tres modos, qui omnes sunt recti.	When you are treating a spleen ailment, when it is such that your treatment does not suffice for the healing of the ailment, then the cautery must be used in three ways, all of which are correct
Quorum unus est, ut facias tria cauteria, aut quatuor lineando secundum longitudinem splenis secundum figuram cauteriorum Epatis, quorum praecessit figura.	One of them is to make three cauteries, or four in line, following the length of the spleen according to the figure of the cauteries of the Liver
Et sit inter omne cauterium quantitas grossitudinis digiti, aut plus parum.	And let there be between every two cauteries the thickness of a finger, or less
Et sit modus cauterii, quem diximus in cauterio epatis aequaliter.	And let the mode of the cautery be equal to that which we said of the cautery of the Liver
Et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio: et sit infirmus resupinus super dorsum suum.	Do not touch your hand with the cautery: and let the infirm lie supine over his back
Et modus alius de cauterizatione est: ut ignias cauterium habens duo uerua, quod diximus in capitulo dislocationis humeri: et eleua cutem, quae est in directo splenis, ubi peruenit cubitus infirmi sinister: et sit eleuatio tua qua eleuas cutem secundum latitudinem corporis, ut cadant cauteria secundum longitudinem corporis.	Another method of cautery is: to take two fingers and grasp the cautery as we said in the chapter on the dislocation of the humerus: and raise the skin which is over the spleen, where the left elbow of the infirm lies: and raise the skin as much as the breadth of the body, so that the cautery falls along the length of the body
Deinde intromitte duo uerua ignita ualde, donec cum eis penetres cutem a parte altera: deinde extrahe cauterium: fiunt ergo cauteria quatuor.	Then introduce two fingers with the flame upwards, until when the flame has pierced the skin from the other side: then withdraw the cautery: there will be four cauteries thus made
Et si uis cauteriza cum cauterio alio habente tria uerua.	And if you wish to cauterize with another cautery which has three fingers.
Deinde cura cauterium postquam dimittis ipsum emittere pus diebus multis: est enim magis conferens quamque reliqua quae praecesserunt ex curatione.	Then care for the cautery after you have put it away: let it emit pus for several days: for this is better than any other remedy which has preceded it
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Hydropisi.	On how to cauterize in Hydropisi.
Caput XXXIII.	In the treatment of hydropisis, cauterize accordingly.
Cauterium non cadit in Hydropisi, nisi ascliti proprie.	The cautery must not be applied directly to hydropisis, but must be used with the asclitium tool.
Quando tu curas Hydropicum cum modis curationis, quos diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, et cauterio uno super stomachum, et cauterio alio super epar, et cauterio super splenem, et cauteriis duobus post dorsum inter spondiles, et uno in directo pectoris, et alio in directo stomachi: et sit quantitas profunditatis cauterii propinqua spissitudini cutis.	When you are treating hydropisis with these methods of treatment, which we mentioned in the previous chapter, and the condition does not improve, then it is necessary to cauterize four times around the belly button, once on the stomach, once on the liver, and once on the spleen, and twice on the back between the vertebrae, and once on the chest and once on the abdomen: and the depth of the cautery should be equal to the thickness of the skin.
Deinde dimitte cauterium apertum, ut emittat pus tempore longo.	Then remove the cautery without delay, so that pus can be emitted over a long time
Et non euacues infirmum a curatione post cauterium cum eo: quod oportet ut aggregentur ei duae intentiones: et festinabit ad ipsum sanatio cum auxilio Dei.	Do not remove the patient from treatment after the cautery: two intentions should be added together for this purpose. And it will quickly recover with the help of God
Forma uero cauterii cum quo cauterizatur uenter, sit clauilis: secundum quod praecessit forma eius: et illius cum quo cauterizatur dorsum, sit oliuaris secundum quod praecessit eius forma.	The shape of the cautery which is to be used for the uterus is like a claw: as we have previously described. And that which is to be used for the back is like an olive tree, as we have previously described
¶ De modo cauterizandi Pedes, et Crura.	On how to cauterize the feet and legs.
Caput XXXIIII.	The chapter is not included in the provided text.
Quando apostemantur in Hydropico, et replentur aqua citrina: oportet ut cauterizes super dorsum Pedis in nocrati, quae est inter auricularem et anularem: et eleua manum tuam cum cauterio, et non torqueas ipsum: deinde eleua manum tuam: et non iteres ipsum omnino.	When the swelling subsides in hydropisis, and the area is filled with yellow water: it is necessary to cauterize on the back of the foot between the instep and the heel: grasp your hand with the cautery and do not twist it: then grasp your hand again: do not move it at all
Resudet enim aqua citrina, et sit cauterium secundum hanc formam.	The yellow water will then rise up, and the cautery should be used in this shape
Deinde fac super duo crura duo cauteria in omni crure, et fiat cauterium cum extremitate cultellari cauterii: et fiat cauterium secundum longitudinem cruris, unum sub genu, et alterum inferius eo, circiter medium cruris: et super omnem coxam cauteria duo: et dimitte cauterium apertum absque curatione tempore longo: ut resudet ex eo aliquod aquae: deinde cura ipsum cum reliquis quae diximus.	Then make over two crura two cauteria on every limb, and apply the cautery with the extremity of the knife of the cautery: and make the cautery according to the length of the limb, one under the knee and the other below the knee, approximately in the middle of the limb: and over every hip make two cauteria: and withdraw the cautery opened without care for a long time: so that it will dry up from it some water: then care for it with the rest which we have said.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in solutione Ventris.	Then make over two incisions two cauteria on every limb, and apply the cautery with the tip of the knife: and make the cautery according to the length of the limb, one under the knee and the other below the knee, approximately in the middle of the limb: and over every hip make two cauteria: and withdraw the cautery opened without care for a long time: so that it will dry up from it some water: then care for it with the rest which we have mentioned.
Caput XXXV.	Then make over two incisions two cauteria on every limb, and apply the cautery with the tip of the knife: and make the cautery according to the length of the limb, one under the knee and the other below the knee, approximately in the middle of the limb: and over every hip make two cauteria: and withdraw the cautery opened without care for a long time: so that it will dry up from it some water: then care for it with the rest which we have mentioned.
Quando est solutio uentris ex frigore et humiditatibus, donec debilitet uirtutes retentiuam et digestiuam, quae sunt in stomacho et intestinis: et curatur illud cum modis curationis, et non sanatur: et uides infirmum tolerantem cauterium exuberantis uirtutis, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio magno super stomachum suum, secundum quod praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi cum cauterio circuli, et quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici subtilibus, cum cauterio clauili subtili: et cauterio super alcatin supra alhosos magno, aut duobus cauteriis.	When the solution of the belly is from cold and moisture until the hardness of the retention and digestion is softened, which are in the stomach and intestines: and care for that with the methods of treatment, and do not cure it: and give the sick person the power to tolerate the excessive virtue of the cautery, then burn the belly itself with a large cautery over the stomach, according to what was previously said concerning the cautery of the circle, and four cauteries around the navel below the ribs, with a cautery of the navel itself: and a cautery over the fat above the buttocks, or two cauteries.
Et si uides humiditates exuberantes, et infirmum tolerantem illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio super pectinem, et cauterio super omne ilium: et fortasse addes duo cauteria parua super stomachum prope magnum.	And if the liquid moistens the excessive, and the sick person tolerates it, then burn the belly itself with a cautery over the ribcage, and a cautery over all the intestines: and perhaps add two small cauteries over the stomach near the large one
Est enim curatio proficiens, cuius iuuamentum non errat.	There exists a proficient treatment whose application does not err.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Hemorroidas.	There exists a proficient treatment whose application does not err.
Caput XXXVI.	There exists a proficient treatment whose application does not err.
Quando in ano sunt Hemorroides antiquae multae, aut una, et sunt ex humoribus grossis, frigidis, aut humiditatibus corruptis, et curantur cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: tunc cauteriza tribus cauteriis super inferiorem spondilem dorsi sub almeidati parumper triangulatim, et cauterio sub umbilico quasi duobus digitis.	When in the rectum are many old hemorrhoids, either one, and they are from gross, cold, or humid humors, they are cured when these things are used, as we said before, and do not require treatment: then cauterize three times with cautery over the lower part of the spine under the almonds in a triangular shape, and cauterize under the navel like two fingers.
Et si cogitas, quod stomachus eius infrigidatus sit, et cibus eius non digeratur, et faciem eius uides apostemari, tunc cauteriza eum super stomachum cauterio magno, secundum quod praecessit: et cauterio super Epar eius, et alio super Splenem ipsius, cum cauterio clauili: et dimitte cauterium apertum tempore aliquo: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	When you think that its stomach is stiff, its food does not digest, and its face is pale, then cauterize it over the stomach with a large cautery, as before: and cauterize over the spleen and the other over the tailbone: and remove the open cautery at some other time. Then take care of it until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
¶ De modo cauterizandi althelul post abscisionem eorum.	When you think that its stomach is stiff, its food does not digest, and its face is pale, then cauterize it over the stomach with a large cautery, as before: and cauterize over the spleen and the other over the tailbone: and remove the open cautery at some other time. Then take care of it until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Caput XXXVII.	When you think that its stomach is stiff, its food does not digest, and its face is pale, then cauterize it over the stomach with a large cautery, as before: and cauterize over the spleen and the other over the tailbone: and remove the open cautery at some other time. Then take care of it until it is healed.</start_of_turn
Quando tu abscindis althelul, tunc ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	When you cut away the anal fistula, then apply the cautery which is absorbed by the radix.</start_of_turn
Deinde intromittite ipsum ignitum in ipsum althelul abscisum: et ultima manum tuam, donec perueniat cauterium ad orificium uenae, ex qua currit sanguis: fac illud semel, aut bis.	Then introduce the fire into the cut fistula: and keep your last hand until the cautery reaches the opening of the vein from which blood runs: do this once or twice.</start_of_turn
Si ergo althelul fuerint multa, tunc cauteriza unumquodque cauterio secundum quod narrauimus.	If there are many boils, then cauterize each one individually as we have said.

Et si cauterizas eum cauterio magno super alcatin, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if you cauterize it with a great cautery over the boil, that is the last thing in its treatment.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Fistulam in ano.	In this way cauterize the fistula in the rectum.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter XXXVIII.</start_of_turn>
Quando non obedit infirmus sectioni et operi quod narrauimus in loco suo, et terretur ab illo, fortasse sanatur cum cauterio.	When the patient does not obey the section and the work that we have said in its place, and returns from it, perhaps it will heal with cautery.</start_of_turn>
Cum ergo accidit alicui Fistula, et antiquatur, currit pus ex ea, et humiditates corruptae.	When there is any fistula, and it has become old, pus runs from it, and it softens the corrupted matter.</start_of_turn
Dignius ergo quod oportet est, ut probes eam cum tenta subtili.	Therefore it is proper that you should try with a fine needle.</start_of_turn
Deinde cognosce quantitatem profunditatis eius cum tenta.	Then know the quantity of its depth with the needle.</start_of_turn
Deinde ignias cauterium, quod est simile radio.	Then ignite the cautery, which is like a rod.</start_of_turn
Deinde intromit te ipsum ignitum in ipsam Fistulam et quantitatem in qua intrauit clauus.	Then introduce yourself with the ignited cautery into the fistula and the quantity in which the thread has entered.</start_of_turn
Et itera super eam cauterium, donec comburantur illa omnia corpora corrupta, semel, aut bis, aut ter, secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And repeat over the cautery until you have burned all the corrupted bodies, once, or twice, or three times, according to the necessity.</start_of_turn
Et custodi te ab adustione nerui, si est illic, aut uenae magnae: aut si Fistula uadit ad corpus uesicae, aut ad corpus intestini, tunc custodi te ab istis locis omnibus.	And take care that there is no scorching of the nerve, if there is any, or great veins: or if the fistula goes to the body of the bladder, or to the body of the intestines, then take care that you are not burned in those places.</start_of_turn
Et non facias illud, nisi quando fistula est in loco carnoso: et cogitas, quia non est penetrans.	Do not do this except when the fistula is in a fleshy place: and think that it is not penetrating.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura locum usquequo sanetur.	Then care for the place until it heals.
Si autem sigillatur locus, et abscinduntur ab eo materiae, et remanet sic tempore longo: tunc scias, quia iam sanatus est integre.	If, however, the place is sealed and matters are excised from it, and it remains thus for a long time: then you know that it is already healed whole.</start_of_turn>
Et si non abscindunt ab eo materiae, tunc scias quia est penetrans, aut in profundo eius est os corruptum, aut quasi illud ex illis: quorum rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	If they are not excised from it, matters, then you know that it is penetrating, or that its bone is corrupt, or as if from those things: of which recollection will come to its place.</start_of_turn>
¶ De modo cauterizandi Renes.	In this way it is necessary to cauterize the reins.</start_of_turn>
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter XXXIX.</start_of_turn
Quando accidit in Renibus dolor ex frigore, aut ex uentositate grossa, et minuitur propter illud coius infirmi, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum super almethenem super ipsos renes, cauterio super omnem renem cum cauterio clauili, cuius praecessit rememoratio.	When it happens in the reins that there is pain from cold or from great moisture, and they diminish because of that from which the patient is suffering, then it is necessary to cauterize them over the fat over the kidneys, cauterizing every kidney with a cautery needle, of which there is recollection.</start_of_turn
Et fortasse cauterizamus ipsum secundo in ipso almeidatu.	And perhaps we cauterize them a second time in the same fat.</start_of_turn
Quare uenient tria lineata.	Because three lines come.</start_of_turn
Ergo erunt magis ultima in iuuamento.	Therefore there will be four last things in the treatment.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauteritzandi Vesicam.	In this way it is necessary to cauterize the bladder.</start_of_turn
Caput XL.	Chapter XL.</start_of_turn
Quando accidunt in Vesica debilitas, et mollificatio a frigo re et humiditatibus, donec non retineat infirmus urinam, tunc cauteriza ipsum in inferiori parte suminis super Vesicam, ubi incipiunt pili pectinis, et cauterio a dextra suminis, et alio a sinistra illius: et sit longitudo illius cauterizationis lateris secundum quantitatem nodi pollicis: et cauteriza ipsum cauterio inferiori dorsi, aut duobus cauteriis, si indiges illo: et sit secundum quod praecessit cauterium clauile.	When there is weakness in the bladder, and softening from the stone and moisture, until the patient does not retain urine, then cauterize it in the lower part of the belly above the bladder, where the hair of the testicles begins, and cauterize from the right side of the belly and from the left side of it: and let the length of that cautery be as much as the breadth of the thumb: and cauterize it with a lower burn, or with two burns, if you like: and let that be according as the cautery needle went before.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi Matricem.	How to cauterize the Matrix.
Caput XLI.	How to cauterize the Matrix.
Quando accidunt in Matrice frigus et humiditates, et prohibetur per illud ab impregnatione, et corrumpuntur menstrua eius, et tardatur prouocatio eorum, et accidit ei apud aduentum eorum dolor, tunc oportet ut cauterizetur tribus cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, sicut diximus in cauterizatione uesicae, et cauterio super alcatim inferius dorso, aut duobus cauteriis: et sit cauterium clauile.	When cold and moisture abound in the Matrix, and it is prohibited by this [moisture] from being impregnated, and its blood is corrupted, its periods are delayed, and there is pain at its side, then it is necessary to cauterize three times around the navel, as we have said concerning the cauterization of the uterus, and to cauterize above the lower edge of the liver, or to make two cauterizations: and let the cauterium be blunt.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Ancham in dislocatione.	How to cauterize the Ancham in dislocation
Caput XLII.	How to cauterize the Ancham in dislocation
Quando effunduntur humiditates mucosae ad pixidem Anchae, et fiunt caussa exitus eius a loco suo: et signum illius est, quod prolongatur crus super alterum, quando comparantur adinuicem: et inuenitur locus dislocationis in eo uacuus.	When moisture of the mucous membrane flows down to the ankle of the Ancham and becomes the cause of its displacement from its place: and the sign of this is that the leg is prolonged over the other when compared with the limb below: and the place of dislocation is found in that hollow space.
Oportet ergo ut cauterizes infirmum super pixidem Anchae ipsius cauterio simili circulo: postquam tu signas cum encaustro in circumitu pixidis, sicut reuoluitur: et ut cadat ipsa pixis in medio circuli.	Therefore it is necessary to cauterize the diseased part over the ankle of the Ancham with a circle: after you have marked the circumference with the cautery, as if you were rolling over: and that the ankle itself falls in the middle of the circle.
Et sit cauterium cuius forma praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi.	And let the cauterium be of the form which was mentioned in the cauterization of the stomach
Quod si tibi non est praesens hoc cauterium, tunc cauteriza ipsum tribus cauteriis, cum cauterio oliuari magno: et fiat cauterio profunditas secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis totius.	If you do not find this cautery [for the ankle] previously mentioned, then cauterize it three times with a large olive cautery: and make the depth of the cautery equal to the amount of thickness of the skin of the whole body
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it until it is healed
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Sciatica.	How to cauterize in Sciatica
Caput XLIII.	Chapter XLIII.
Quando accidit dolor in pixide anchae, et sunt caussa illius frigus et humiditates: et curatur infirmus cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, et antiquatur illud: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum ab humoribus grossis cum pillulis foetidis, aut cum pillulis artificialibus, et similibus.	When pain occurs in the area of the knee, due to cold and moisture: the physician should treat the patient as we have said previously, and if no benefit results from this treatment, it is necessary to evacuate the patient from the humours with large pills of foetid material, or with artificial pills, and the like.
Deinde cauteriza eum.	Then cauterize it.</start_of_turn>
Et modus cauterii in ea est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum medicinis adurentibus, aut cauterium cum igne.	And the mode of cauterization in this case is in two ways: either with cautery and astringents, or with fire.</start_of_turn>
Cauterium cum igne, est secundum multos modos.	Cauterization with fire is done in many ways.</start_of_turn
Quorum unus est, ut cauterizes super pixidem anchae ipsius tribus cauteriis triangulatis, secundum hanc formam.	One of them is to cauterize over the knee with three triangular cautery instruments, according to this form.</start_of_turn
Et fac eis profunditatem bonam, uel malam.	And do it with a good depth, or a slight depth.</start_of_turn
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium quantitatis grossitudinis digiti: sitque cauterium oliuare.	And let there be space between every two cauteries equal to the thickness of a finger: and let the cauteries be small.</start_of_turn
Quandoque autem fit cauterium in medio super caput anchae ipsius.	When the cauterization is done in the middle of the knee, it must be done cautiously.</start_of_turn
Quare sunt quatuor cauteria.	For there are four cautery instruments.</start_of_turn
Et si uis cauteriza cum circulo, cuius praecessit forma in cauterizatione dislocationis anchae, uno: ut sit circulus continens ancham totam.	And if you wish to cauterize in a circle, whose form precedes the cauterization of dislocation of the knee, do one: so that the circle contains the whole knee.</start_of_turn
Et combure spissitudinem cutis totius.	And burn the hairiness of the whole skin.</start_of_turn
Iste est modus cauterii in Sciatica, quando dolor est adhaerens anchae ipsi, et non extenditur usque ad coxam et crus.	This is the mode of cauterization in Sciatica, when the pain is attached to the knee itself, and does not extend up to the hip and thigh.</start_of_turn
Si autem extenditur usque ad coxam et crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis super coxam, super locum ad quem innuit illic infirmus, in quo est dolor, et cauterio tuo super cauillam quatuor digitis ad partem syluestrem parumper: et sit cauterium cultellare.	If it extends up to the knee and thigh, then cauterize it with two cautery irons above the knee, above the place where the sick person has pain, where the pain is, and cauterize your cautery iron four digits above the heel to the outer side: and let the cautery iron be sharp.
Et sit profunditas cauterii secundum profunditatem spissitudinis cutis.	And let the depth of the cautery be according to the depth of the thickness of the skin.
Quod si infirmus innuit quod dolor extenditur usque prope digitos pedis, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic ubi innuit cum cauterio puncti, tribus, aut quatuor, aut pluribus, si indiget illo.	And if the patient complains that the pain extends up to near the toes, then cauterize it there where he complains with the cautery needle, three or four or more, as he needs it
Et si innuit dolorem esse sub genu uersus crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic cauterio uno cultellari.	And if he complains that the pain is under the knee or thigh, then cauterize it there with one cautery iron.
Et caue tibi in omni cauterizatione tua, ut non ultimes cum cauterio ad hoc ut comburas neruum, aut arteriam magnam, et attrahas per illud super infirmum nocumentum malum, aut contractionem.	And take care in all your cauterizations that you do not reach the nerves or great arteries, and that you do not pull on it over the patient's bad tissue, or cause contraction.
Et ego quidem iam uidi unum et alium, ex eis qui cauterizauerunt supra cauillam, et ultimauerunt in cauterizatione, et inflatum est crus, donec tumor consecutus est pedem, et perforatus est totus, et corruptus est totus pes: deinde accidit solutio uentris, et mors post illud.	I also know of one and another who have cauterized above the heel, and have finished their cauterization, and the thigh has swollen, until the tumor has followed the foot down to the ground, and has burst open, and become corrupted throughout: then the solution of the belly has followed, and death after that.
Quod si dolor est in duabus partibus simul, cauteriza utramque secundum hunc modum.	And if the pain is in two parts together, cauterize both of them according to this method.
Et sapientes quidam dixerunt in cauterizatione anchae, cuius cauterii iste est modus.	And some wise men say that the cautery of anchan is like this.
Fac simile samio ex ferro, cuius diametrus sit medietas palmi: et sit apud orificium suum secundum grossitudinem nuclei dactyli, aut minus parumper: et intra illud samium sit samium tertium.	Make like a wise man from iron, whose diameter is the middle of the palm: and let it be at the level of its orifice according to the thickness of the kernel of the thumb, or less wide: and there is to be within it the third of the same.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne samium per quantitatem nodi pollicis: et sint samia aperta a duabus partibus: et sit altitudo eorum quasi nodus, aut duo nodi: et fac eis manubrium ex ferro decenter aptatum in samiis.	And there shall be space between every two fingers according to the quantity of a thumb-node: and the fingers shall be opened by two parts: and the height of them shall be like a thumb-node, or two thumb-nodes: and make a handle of iron adapted to the palm of the hand.
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form.</start_of_turn>
Deinde igniatur in igne, donec rubeat, et proiiciat scintillas: deinde ponatur super pixidem anchae infirmo accubitato super latus sanum.	Then it is to be ignited in fire, until it is red, and the sparks are to be thrown away: then it is to be placed upon a wound covered with a soft cushion on the side of the healthy hand.</start_of_turn>
Cauteriza ergo eum tribus cauteriis rotundis in uice una.	Burn thus three round burns in oil together.</start_of_turn
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then leave it for three days.</start_of_turn
Postea emplastra cum butyro: et dimitte uulnus apertum diebus multis.	Then apply with butter: and take away the wound after many days.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with unguents, until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Inquit Albucasis, hac specie cauterii o filii, parum usi sumus, propter terrorem aspectus eius: et propterea, quod paucos inuenimus qui expectent super ipsum.	Albucasis saith, in this kind of cautery, or of the sons of men, we use it little, because of the fear of its appearance: and therefore, because of this, we find few who are willing to endure it.</start_of_turn
Verumtamen est ex bonis cauteriis ei qui suffert, et inuenit cum eo locum eius.	But truly it is from the good cautery that it is useful to him who endures it, and he finds it when he needs it.</start_of_turn
Cauterium autem cum medicinis adurentibus est, ut tu facias duo samia habentia perforatam armillam, in quam descendit cardo portae eius ex aere, aut ferro, longitudo parietis: quorum in altitudinem eorum sint duo nodi, aut quasi ipsi.	But the cautery with the physicians is best when it is used on two fingers which have a perforated palm, in which the tendon of the wrist has descended from the air, or from iron, the length of the edge being two thumb-nodes, or as much as these.</start_of_turn
Et sit spacium quod est inter utraque quantitas grossitudinis digiti, et sint aperta inferius et superius: et sit quod contineant se adinuicem, secundum hanc formam.	And there shall be space between every two fingers according to the quantity of a thumb-node: and the fingers shall be opened below and above: and the thumb-node shall contain itself inward, according to this form.</start_of_turn
Deinde depone eam super pixidem anchae, infirmo iacente super latus sanum.	Then lay the wound above the heel of the bed, the sick man being over the wide side of the bed.
Et comprime manum tuam super pixidem anchae multum.	And press your hand firmly above the heel of the bed much.</start_of_turn>
Deinde funde inter duos circulos ex aqua calida, quae sit calefacta cum igne parumper, et tene eam quantitate horae temporalis: et toleret infirmus mordicationem eius, et ipsius adustionem, nam ipse inuenit mordicationem sicut ignis, donec quiescat mordicatio.	Then pour between two circles of warm water, which is heated with a moderate fire, and keep it for an hour: and the sick man will endure the biting of his wound, and its swelling, for he himself finds the biting of the wound like fire, until the biting subsides.</start_of_turn>
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum instrumento, et absterge aquam calidam ab ancha tota cum aqua dulci: deinde dimitte illud tribus diebus.	Then lift your hand with the instrument, and wipe away the warm water from the wound with sweet water: then leave it for three days.</start_of_turn
Et pone super illud butyrum, donec remoueatur nigredo adustionis: et dimitte illud diebus aliquot, et curret ex eo pus.	And put upon it butter, until the black of the wound has disappeared: and leave it for a few days, and it will come out with pus.</start_of_turn
Est enim ultimum in iuuamento.	This is the end of the treatment.</start_of_turn>
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with unguents, until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Quod si extendatur dolor usque ad coxam, aut crus: fac ei statuam in eo quod continet aquam, secundum quod fecisti in ancha aequaliter.	If the pain extends up to the hip or thigh: make for him a support in which there is water, just as you did above the wound.</start_of_turn
Et iste est modus aquae calidae: et ego iam scripsi eam in tractatu rectificationis medicinarum.	This is the way of warm water: and I have written about it in the treatise on medical rectifications.</start_of_turn>
Sume alcali, et calcis non extinctae amborum ana partem unam: tere utraque, et pone ea in ollam nouam, cuius inferior pars sit perforata foramine uno paruo, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum radius: et pone sub fundo ollae ollam aliam uitreatam: et proiice super alcali et calcem ex aqua dulci, quod submergat utraque per digitum: post quam tu comprimas ea manu tua compressione bona: et dimite ollam, donec descendat aqua acuta inferiori parte ollae uitreatae.	Take alkali and unslaked lime, both of which take up half each: put both into a new vessel, the lower part of which is pierced with a small hole, according to the quantity of the radius which is to be treated: and put under the bottom of the vessel another vessel filled with water: and pour over the alkali and lime from sweet water, which submerges both by a finger: and when you have compressed them with your hand with a good compression: and pour out the vessel, until the acute water has descended from the treated part.</start_of_turn
Deinde aggrega illam aquam totam, et proiice eam super aliam calcem: et cola, donec renouetur.	Then add all the water, and throw the sponge over the other heel: and withdraw the heel until it returns.
Ipsa enim erit tunc fortis acuitatis ualde, quae administratur in multis operationibus medicinae, et in cauterizatione reliquorum membrorum.	The water itself is often strong and acute, which is administered in many medical operations and in the cauterization of the remaining limbs.
Quoniam efficit operationem ignis ipsius.	For it performs the work of fire itself
Et ex medicinis sunt, cum quibus cauterizantur ancha, etiam sicut tesisie, et mel anacardi, et calx cum sapone, ita quod utraque sint permixta. ¶	And there are many physicians who, when they cauterize widely, use tallow, beeswax, and soap, so that both are mixed together
Et Galenus quidem narrando retulit, cuiusdam uiri ex antiquis curationem, qua curatus est dolor anchae et uenae sciaticae: et magnificauit esse eius ualde.	Galen himself, speaking of an ancient practitioner, relates that he cured the pain of an aching heel and sciatica: and praised his method highly
Et dixit, quia non indiguit alia curatione, et quia sanatus est ex uice una, donec retulit, quia ipse fortasse intrauit balneum delatus, et exiuit ex eo iam sanus.	He said that no other cure was necessary, and that he himself had suffered from a swelling of the foot for a long time, until he was healed by this method
Et est, ut accipiatur ex seitaragi uiridi: et si non inuenitur uiride, sumatur siccum, recens: et teratur multum cum aliquanto adipe, et ponatur super ancham, ubi est dolor, aut crus, aut in coxa: et ligetur, et dimittatur quantitate trium horarum, aut per quantitatem quod sentiat infirmus sedationem adustionis.	It is like taking the thigh of a young man: and if you cannot find a young man, take dry [horse dung]: put much of it with some fat, and put it on the heel where the pain is, or on the knee or in the hip: and bind it, and let it go for three hours, or for as long as the patient feels comfortable.
Deinde intromitte eum in balneum.	Then put the sponge into the bath.
Cum ergo roridum fit corpus eius, intromitte ipsum in solium.	When the sponge is soft, put it into the shoe
Nam dolor recedit, et sanatur.	For the pain goes away and is healed.
Et scias, quia non oportet ut utatur aliquis cauterio cum istis medicinis, nisi post euacuationem corporis.	And know that no other cauterization should be used along with these medicines, except after the evacuation of the body.
Et Dioscorides qui dem dixit, quod stercus caprarum, quando cum eo cauterizatur uena sciatica, confert ei: et fit cauterium secundum hunc modum.	And Dioscorides, who says this, when he cauterizes the heel with horse dung, gives relief from sciatica: and does the cauterization in this way.
Sumatur lana, et imbibatur oleo antiquo, et ponatur super locum profundum, qui est inter pollicem pedis, et inter focile, et est propinquior focili.	Let a lancet be held, and let an old olive oil be taken, and let it be poured over the deep place, which is between the thumb of the foot and between the nails, and is closer to the nail.
Deinde accipe stercus caprarum siccum, et inflamma ipsum in igne, donec fiat carbo.	Then take dry goat dung and burn it, until it turns to charcoal.
Deinde pone ipsum super lanam, et dimitte ipsum, donec extinguatur.	Then place it over the lancet and let it go, until it is extinguished.
Deinde itera illud.	Repeat this procedure.
Non cesses ergo facere illud, usquequo perueniat sensus super mediatione usque ad ancham, et quiescat dolor.	Do not cease doing this until sensation returns above the application of the lancet, and the pain has ceased
Et iste modus cauterii nominatur cauterium Vaccinum.	And this method of cauterization is called cauterization of the Vaccinum
¶ De cauterizatione doloris Dorsi.	Of the cauterization of the dorsal pain
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter XLIV.
Quandoque accidit dolor in Dorso ex caussis multis, aut a casu, aut a percussione, aut euacuatione superflua, et illis similibus, ex infusione materiei frigidae, et humidae: et cauterium quidem non cadit, nisi in hac specie sola, quae fit ex infusione materiei frigidae.	When there is pain in the back from many wounds, or from a blow, or from excessive evacuation, or in like manner, from the infusion of cold and moist matter: in this case cauterization is not useless, except for one kind which is made from the infusion of cold matter.
Oportet ergo post euacuationem infirmi cum pillulis foetidis, et eis similibus, ut fiant super Dorsum, ubi est dolor, tres lineae secundum latitudinem almeidati ipsius, postquam signas cum encaustro in omni linea quinque cauteria, aut plura secundum quantitatem quae uenit ex tolerantia infirmi uirtute eius: et fiat cauterizatio cum cauteriopuncti.	It is necessary therefore after evacuation of the sick person with foul pills and like things, to make three lines on the back, where there is pain, according to the width of the almond of the eye: and let five cauteries be made on each line, or more according to the patient’s tolerance of the pain of the disease: and let the cauterization be made with the cautery needle.
Et si uis, cauteriza tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor, cum cauterio clauili mediali, secundum hanc formam.	Or if you wish, cauterize three or four times with the middle cautery needle, according to this form
¶ De modo cauterizandi in incaeptine Gibbositatis.	Of the manner of cauterizing in the groin.
Caput XLV.	Chapter XLV.
Multotiens accidit haec aegritudo infantibus paruis.	Many such ailments befall young children.
Et signum incaeptionis eius in pueris est: quod accidit super eum strictura in anhelitu apud eleuationem, et motum: et inuenis in ultima spondilium Dorsi et nodorum eius, quod iam incaepit eminere super reliquos spondiles.	A sign of its inception is that it happens over stricture in coughing, at elevation, and motion: and is found in the lower spine and its nodes, which begin to rise above the rest of the vertebrae.
Cum ergo uides illud, et uis facere illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio quod sit circulus secundum hanc formam.	When you have thus helped it, and wish to make it cease, then cauterize it with a cautery that is circular according to this shape
Et capiat cauterium super omnem partem spondilis aequaliter: et si uis cauteriza in circumitu spondilis cum cauterio puncti duas lineas, aut tres: et sint puncta propinqua adinuicem.	Capture the cautery over the whole of the vertebrae equally: and if you wish to cauterize around the vertebrae with a point cautery, make two or three points close together
Deinde cura locum, donec sanetur cum eo quod diximus.	Then take care of the place, until it is healed as we have said.
Et caue, ne administres cauterium in gibbositate, quae fit in spasmo nerui.	Be careful, do not apply the cautery to a swelling, which is in a nerve spasm.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Podagra, et doloribus iuncturarum.	In the same way as for cauterizing in Podagra, and for joined pains.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter XLVI.
Quando dolores iuncturarum sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, quae effunduntur ad cuiuslibet membra corporis, tunc quando accidunt dolores in pedibus, de consuetudine medicorum est, ut nominent illud Podagram proprie.	When joint pains are caused by cold humors which flow throughout the body, and when they happen in the feet, it is customary among doctors to call it Podagra
Cum ergo curatur Podagra frigidae caussae cum modis curationis, et non remouentur dolores, tune cauterium remouet eos.	When it has been cured with cold causes of Podagra, as with other medicines, and the pain does not go away, then the cautery will remove it
Et est, ut cauterizes eum post euacuationem in circumitu iuncturae pedum, cauteriis multis: et sit cauterium Oliuare.	And it is necessary to cauterize around the joint after emptying it with multiple cauteries: and let the cautery be of Olive oil.
Cuius haec est forma.	This is its shape
Et si indiges ut punctes super faciem pedis, tunc fac cum cauterio puncti.	And if you do not wish to make points over the face of the foot, then make them with the point cautery
Quod si ascendunt dolores usque ad genua, aut reliquas iuncturas, et multotiens accidit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super omne genu tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor ab omni parte, cum hoc eodem cauterio Clauili.	If pain ascends to the knee, or if the other ligatures remain, and this happens frequently, then burn the whole knee with three burns, or four from every side, with the same burn as Claudius.
Si autem necessaria sunt tibi plura hoc cauterio, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	If it is necessary to burn the knee more often, then burn it again.</start_of_turn>
Et non submergas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit circiter spissitudinem cutis tantum.	And do not immerse your hand with the burn, but keep the thickness of the skin only.</start_of_turn>
Si autem ascendunt dolores ad genua, et dorsum: tunc administra quod diximus ex cauterio in capitulo suo.	If pain ascends to the knee and the back: then perform what we said about the burn in its chapter.</start_of_turn>
Quod si dolores sunt in manibus tantum, tunc puncta in circumitu focilium, sicut reuoluuntur duae lineae.	If the pain is only in the hands: then puncture around the nails, like two lines are returned.</start_of_turn
Si autem remanet ex doloribus in digitis, tunc puncta eos, super omnem nodum punctum, et super pectinem manus.	If there remains pain in the toes: then puncture them, over every knot and over the palm of the hand.</start_of_turn
Si autem ascendunt dolores post dies ad cubitos, aut ad humeros, tunc cauteriza utrosque ab omni parte.	If pain ascends after a few days to the cubits or to the arms: then burn both from every side.</start_of_turn
Et non euacues infirmum ex regimine bono, ex recaeptione medicinarum.	And do not neglect the patient from the management of the good, from the recovery of medicines.</start_of_turn
Nam si bonum fiat regimen, et euacuetur phlegma, sanabitur auxilio Dei cum isto cauterio.	For if there is a good regimen, and the phlegm is evacuated, the patient will recover with the help of God with this burn.</start_of_turn>
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Rupturis.	¶ On the method of burning in ruptures.</start_of_turn>
Caput XLVII.	Chapter XLVII.</start_of_turn
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, et descendit intestinum, aut zirbum ad testiculum, et est illud incipiens propinquum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo dimittere comestionem in die suo.	When a rupture happens in the groin, and the intestines or the bladder descend to the testicles, and this is beginning close by: then it is necessary for the patient to vomit immediately in his day.</start_of_turn
Et utatur ex lenientibus, quo descendat stercus a uentre suo.	And so it is done from the soft things, from which the stool descends from its belly.
Deinde sedeat inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et praecipe ei, ut teneat anhelitum suum, donec egrediatur, uel appareat zirbum, aut intestinum.	Then sit between your hands over his back: and command him to keep his breath still until he goes out, or until he appears to have a wound or an intestine
Deinde reduc ipsum digitis tuis, et signa cum encaustro sub Ruptura super os pectinis, cum signo cuius extremitas sit similis medietati circuli ad superiora corporis.	Then press down with your fingers and sign with the thumb under the rupture above the hip bone, with the sign of which the extremity is similar to the middle of the circle of the body.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma, donec ueniat album, et proiiciat seintillas.	Then burn the cautery, whose shape is like this, until it becomes white, and throw away the fat.
Deinde reduc intestinum, aut zirbum ad concauitatem suam.	Then reduce the intestine or the wound to its cavity.
Deinde ponat minister manum suam super locum, ut non exeat intestinum: et tu iam aperuisti inter crura infirmi, et posuisti sub eo puluinar, et seruiens alius super crura eius, et alius super pectus eius qui tenet manus.	Then put your hand on the place, so that the intestine does not go out: and you have opened between the ribs, and put under it some powder, and another one on the ribs that holds his hand.
Deinde depone cauterium super ipsum signum, manu tua cum cauterio stante recta.	Then put the cautery on the sign itself, your hand with the cautery standing straight up
Et tene ipsum, donec cum eo consequaris os: aut itera cum eo uice alia, si non consecutus fueris cum eo in prima usque ad os.	And hold it there, until you follow the bone: or do it again with oil if you have not followed it with oil from the beginning until the bone
Et prudenter obserua ab exitu intestini in hora cauterizationis tuae, ne comburas ipsum, et eueniat per illud super infirmum aut mors, aut malicia magna.	And observe prudently the exit of the intestine at the time of your cautery, that you do not burn it, and that it comes out through that over the patient or the wound, or a great malice
Et scias, quod quando tu non consequeris cum cauterio os, non confert operatio tua.	And you know, that when you do not follow with the cautery the bone, your operation will be in vain.
Et oportet ut sit cauterium infantium subtile, secundum mensuram eorum.	And it is necessary that the cautery of the infants be subtle, according to their measure
Deinde cura cum reliquis unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the rest of the wounds, until they are healed.
Et sit infirmus iacens super dorsum suum quadraginta diebus, donec sigilletur uulnus.	And if the patient has been lying upon his back for forty days, until the swelling subsides.
Et oportet, ut ponas nutrimentum eius longitudine temporis curationis eius, quod leniat uentrem eius: ut non exeat intestinum apud conamen et egestionem.	And it should be provided that he be given nourishment during the course of his treatment, which will soften his belly: so that the intestine does not remain in the bowels and evacuate through the mouth.
Deinde quando uult surgere post quadraginta dies, tunc administra ligamentum decenter factum, et teneat ipsum quadraginta diebus aliis.	When the swelling subsides after forty days, then administer the ligature of the central part and keep it for another forty days.
Et minoretur a labore, et repletione cibi et potus, et uocibus uehementibus.	And let him rest from laborious work, and be given food and drink, and permitted to urinate at will
Nam quando utitur hoc regimine, ita sanatur sanatione integra.	For thus, if these things are observed, the patient will recover completely.
Et ego dicam curationem Rupturarum cum incisione in capitulo suo.	And I will speak of the treatment of ruptures with incision in this chapter.
Quando autem Rupturae accidunt in reliquo uentre, et sunt incipientes, et uis ut non addantur, tunc cauteriza Rupturam eius cauterio rotundo secundum quantitatem eius: et sit illud quod aduritur ex tunc sicut tertia eius.	When, however, ruptures happen in the rest of the belly, and are beginning to form, and it is desired that they should not grow larger, then cauterize the rupture with a round cautery according to their size: and let it be so that from that time on it appears as if a third of it has been burned away
Deinde cura ipsum, cum eo quod diximus: et non addetur.	And then care for it as we have said: and do not add to it.
Et iam dixerunt quidam primi: ut cauterizetur Ruptura cum cauterio triangulato, secundum hanc formam.	And some people say: cauterize the rupture with a triangular cautery, according to this form.
Postquam signatur cum encaustro, et ponitur linea quae est per latitudinem in latere superiori Rupturae, et linea altera ad inferius.	When it has been signed with charcoal, and a line is drawn which is through the breadth at the upper side of the rupture, and a line which is at the lower side.
Et depone manum tuam in medio cum cauterio clauili.	And place your hand in the middle with the cautery of the hook
Sed cauterium primum est facilius et melius.	But the first cautery is easier and better
¶ De modo cauterizandi in doloribus propter casum, aut percussionem.	In cases of pain caused by falling or percussion.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter XLVIII.
Quando accidit in quibusdam membris a casu, aut percussione dolor: et perseuerat ille dolor tempore longo, et non confert in eo curatio cum medicinis: tunc oportet ut cauterizetur cum cauterio Puncti.	When something happens in some limb by wound or blow, and pain persists for a long time, and does not yield to treatment with physicians: then it is necessary to cauterize with the Puncti cautery.
Et sit cauterium omnis membri cauterium secundum magnitudinem eius, et ipsius paruitatem, et debilitatem eius, et ipsius uirtutem, et locationem torsionis, et doloris ex eo.	And let the cautery be performed on every limb according to its size, its shape, its toughness, its strength, its position and the pain from it
Si ergo sanatur ex cauterio primo, est bene.	If therefore it is healed by the first cautery, it is good.
Si non: tunc itera super ipsum cauterium.	If not: then repeat the cautery over it again.
Quoniam de consuetudine horum dolorum est, ut permutentur ex membro ad illud quod appropinquat ei.	For the custom of these pains is that they change from one limb to another approaching that which is most painful
Quare oportet ut consequaris eos cum cauterio, donec sanetur infirmus.	Therefore follow them with the cautery until the infirmity is healed
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lepra.	And concerning the cautery of Lepra...
Caput XLIX.	Chapter XLIX.
Leprosi autem quandoque iuuantur cauterio iuuamento maximo.	Leprosy, however, is sometimes treated by cautery with the greatest care
Et praecipue species Leprae, quae fit propter putrefactionem phlegmatis et melancholiae: cum ergo uis cauterizare ipsam considera.	And especially those species of Leprosy which arise from the putrefaction of phlegm and melancholy: with such ones great care is necessary for the cautery
Si ergo Lepra est ineipiciens, et curasti eam cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non descendit, neque stat: et times super infirmum, quod comprehendat corruptio super totam complexionem eius: tunc cauteriza eum super caput quinque cauteriis: uno in medio capitis noto, et secundo inferius eo uersus frontem apud finem capillorum, et duobus super duo cornua, et uno posterius super nucea ceruicis.	If indeed the Lepra is not severe, and you wish to treat it with this, as we have said previously, and it does not subside, neither does it remain: and when it has spread over the whole face: then cauterize it over the head five times: one in the middle of the head between the ears, and the second below it at the edge of the hair, and two over the two horns, and one behind the earlobe.
Et ultima manum tuam cum cauterio parumper, donec imprimat in os impressionem paruam, et dislocentur ex eo cortices: ut alleuietur expiratio uaporum grossorum ex eo, et cauteriza cauterio etiam super ipsum splenem, secundum quod praecessit.	And finally touch your hand with the cautery lightly, until you make an imprint in the bone, and the cortices are displaced from it: so that the emission of thick vapors from it is alleviated, and cauterize the spleen also with the cautery, as we have said before
Sin autem Lepra iam sparsa est super infirmum, et apparet manifeste: tunc oportet ut cauterizes cum istis cauteriis, quae diximus in capite, et cauterio super extremitatem nasi, et duobus cauteriis super duas maxillas, et duobus cauteriis super spondiles colli, et sex super spondiles dorsi, et uno magno super alhahosos apud gran caudae et uno supra ipsum, in ipso almeidati: et duobus super anchas: scilicet super omnem ancham uno, et duobus super genua: uno super omne genu, et duobus super humeros, et duobus super cubitos, et duobus super teneritudines pectoris sui: et cauteriza ipsum super omnem iuncturam, ex iuncturis digitorum manuum suarum, et pedum suorum: et cauteriza super omnem calcaneum pedum suorum, et focilia manuum suarum.	If, however, leprosy has become sparse upon the sick person, and is apparent, then it is necessary that you should cauterize with these cauteries which we mentioned at the head, and with a cautery upon the extremity of the nose, and two cauteries upon the two maxillae, and two upon the spines of the neck, and six upon the spines of the back, and one large one upon the hairless parts at the root of the tail and one above the middle of the palm: and two upon the ankles: that is, upon every ankle one, and two upon the knees: one upon every knee, and two upon the humeri, and two upon the cubits, and two upon the armpits of the chest. And cauterize the whole of every joint, from the joints of the fingers of the hands and feet, and cauterize the whole of every heel of the feet.
Et caue tibi a neruis qui sunt super postremum calcanei, ut non comburas eos.	And cauterize the nerves which are upon the posterior heel, that you do not burn them.
Et quandoque cauterizatur cauterio super os pectinis, et alio super os stomachi, et alio super epar.	And when you cauterize with a cautery upon the bone of the pelvis, and another upon the bone of the stomach, and another upon the spleen.
Et scias, quod quanto plus addis cauterium, est magis iuuamentum, et magis conferens.	And you know that the more you add cauteries, the greater the damage, and the greater the suffering.
Et scias, quod infirmus non inuenit in cauterio dolorem, sicut inueniunt ipsum sani: propterea, quod corpus eius iam stupefactum est.	And you know that the sick person does not find ease in the cautery, as they find rest in health: because the body of the latter is already stunned
Et oportet ut sint cauteria ex magnitudine, et paruitate secundum membra et iuncturas: secundum quod praecessit ex speciebus ferramentorum.	It is necessary that there be large and small cauteries according to the members and the joints: according to what has preceded from the kinds of instruments.
Deinde cura cauterium ex farina herbi cum melle, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the cauteries with a mixture of barley flour and honey, and the rest of the treatment, until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Stupore.	In the manner of cauterizing in the Stupor.
Caput L.	Head L.
Quando stupet aliquod membrum, et curatur cum medicinis, et oleis, et emplastris, et non sanatur, tunc cauteriza ipsum membrum stupefactum cauteriis, secundum quod meretur magnitudo membri, aut paruitas eius.	When any limb is stiff and will not recover with medicines, oils, plasters, it is then to cauterize the stiff limb with cautery, according to the size of the limb or its degree of stiffness.
Et sit cauterium tuum intrans in spissitudinem cutis parumper.	And let your cautery not pass through the thickness of the skin superficially.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with unguents until it is healed
Et quandoque cauterizatur ad quiddam stuporis, qui accidit manui, et pedi, in spondilibus dorsi apud exitum neruorum, qui mouent illud membrum: et remouetur stupor.	And when it is cauterized for some stiffness of the hand, foot, in the bones of the back near the exit of the nerves which move that limb: and the stiffness will be moved away
Verum non praesumat super illud, nisi qui est sapiens in anatomia membrorum, et egressione neruorum mouentium corpus.	But it does not matter over that, except for one who is skilled in the anatomy of the limbs and the exit of the nerves moving the body
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Albaras.	Thus cauterizing in Albaras.
Caput LI.	Head LII
Quando antiquatur Albaras, et non confert in eo aliquid ex ingeniis medicinae: tunc cauteriza super ipsam cauterio profundo parumper, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis, donec remoueatur albedo, et mutetur color eius.	When Albaras has become old and does not yield to any medical treatment: then cauterize over the surface of the deep cautery sparingly, according to the quantity of the thickness of the skin, until the whiteness is removed and its color changes
Deinde cura ipsum cum farina herbi, et lentis cum oleo rosa, et foliis arnoglossae, et sanguine columbae, et sanguine hyrundinis: de unoquoque sit pars una: misceantur haec omnia, et liniantur super pannum, et adhaereant loco, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with flour of herbs, and lentils with rose oil, and leaves of arnica, and poppy seeds, and hyssop blood: from each of these things take one part: mix all these things together and smear them over the wound, and they will adhere to the place until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Cancro.	Thus cauterizing in Cancer
Caput LII.	Head LII
Quando Cancer est incipiens, et uis ipsum sistere: tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio circuli in circuitu eius, sicuti reuoluitur.	When Cancer is beginning and you wish to stop it: then cauterize it with a circular cautery around its circumference as it turns.
Sapientes autem dixerunt, ut cauterizetur cauterio ultimo in medio.	Wise men have said, 'The cautery should be performed with the last cautery in the middle.'
Mihi autem non uidetur illud: quoniam timeo quod ulceretur: et ego iam uidi illud aliquotiens.	I do not see that this is necessary: for I fear that it will cause a burn. And I have seen this happen many times before.</start_of_turn>
Et rectius est, ut cauterizetur in circumitu eius cum circulo, sicut diximus: aut cauteriis multis.	It is better to cauterize around it in a circle, as we have said: or with multiple cauteries.</start_of_turn>
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Adubelati.	Regarding the cautery of Adubelati.</start_of_turn
Caput LIII.	Chapter LIII.</start_of_turn>
Quando aliquis habet Adubelati, et tardatur in maturatione, aut propter superfluitatem facientem eam, aut propter aetatem infirmi, quando est decrepitus pauci sanguinis, aut propter tempus, et uis festinare in maturatione Adubelati, tunc cauteriza in circumitu eius cum cauteriis paruis multis punctando.	When someone has Adubelati and it is delayed in maturation, or because of excessive fat, or because of old age which makes the patient weak, or because of the passing of time, and he wishes to hasten the maturation of Adubelati, then cauterize around it with many small cauteries, puncturing.</start_of_turn
Deinde dimitte eam.	Then remove the dressing.</start_of_turn
Nam ipsa festinabit cum maturatione.	For it will itself hasten the maturation.</start_of_turn
Si autem uis perforationem eius cum cauterio, tunc igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma.	If, however, you wish to perforate it with the cautery, then make a burn with the cautery that has this shape.</start_of_turn
Et depone ipsum in medio Adubelati, donec penetret cutem: et sit cauterium ab eo quod sequitur infirmus, ut alleuietur cursus puris.	And place it in the middle of Adubelati, until it penetrates the skin: and let the cautery be far from the healthy parts, in order to relieve the pain.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi in malo corrodente.	Regarding the cautery of the soft swelling.</start_of_turn
Caput LIIII.	Chapter LIIII.</start_of_turn
Corrodens non est nisi corruptio in membro ambulans, et corrodit ipsum: sicut ignis comedit ligna sicca.	A soft swelling is not except for a corruption in a limb that is able to walk, and it corrupts it: just as fire consumes dry wood.</start_of_turn
Si ergo uides corrodentem in loco qui toleret cauterium cum igne, tunc igni cauteria multa, clauilia parua et magna, secundum quod conueniet illi loco in quo est corrodens.	If there is any fluid which has eaten away its place and tolerates cautery with fire, then burn the cautery much, make the nails small and great, as it shall be fitting in the place where the corrosive matter is.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum ab omni parte donec eradices corruptionem totam, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid penitus.	Burn it from every side until you have eradicated the whole corruption, and let nothing remain of it inside or outside
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super loca cauterizata sulphur tritum cum oleo, donec eradicentur escharae omnes, et omnis corruptio.	Then remove it in three days, and put upon the cauterized place sulfur three times ground with oil, until all the eschars are eradicated, and all corruption is gone.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis generantibus carnem.	Then care for it with nourishing unguents of flesh.
Si ergo uides, quod post tres dies caro nascitur natiuitate sana, in qua non est corruptio, est bonum.	If there is any fluid which after three days new flesh is born without corruption, this is good.
Et si non: tunc itera cauterium super illud quod remansit ex locis corruptis.	And if not: then burn the cautery once more over that which remains from the corrupted places.
Et corrodens medicatur quandoque cum medicina acuta.	And the corrosive is to be treated with acute medicine.
Ipsa namque surgit loco cauterii.	It itself arises in the place of the cautery.
Verumtamen cauterium cum igne est uelocioris iuuamenti: et ego quidem iam dixi cauterizationem eius cum medicina acuta in diuisione: accipe ergo eam illic quando ea indiges.	But truly, the cautery with fire is faster in its action: and I indeed said above that the cautery should be made with acute medicine in its application: take therefore care of it there when it is indigested
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Clauis, et Verucis.	In the manner of cauterizing nails and vericles.
Caput LV.	Chapter LV.
Multotiens accidit in inferioribus partibus pedum haec aegritudo: et est res grossa, filtrata, quae laedit pedem.	Many things happen in the lower parts of the feet with this disease: and it is a great, filtering thing that causes damage to the foot.
Et cauterium quidem in eis est secundum duos modos: cauterium cum igne, et cauterium cum aqua calida.	And the cautery is done in two ways: cautery with fire, and cautery with warm water
Quantum autem cum igne est, ut ignias cauterium concauum simile pennae uulturis: quod fiat ex ferro, secundum quantitatem quod contineat clauum ab omni parte: et sit subtilium marginum.	When done with fire, let the cautery be in the shape of a concave curve like the nail of a hare: which is made of iron, according to the quantity which contains the nail from every side: and be fine at the edges.
Deinde depone ipsum ignitum super clauum.	Then lay the burning [incense] upon the palm of the hand.
Deinde reuolue manum cum cauterio in circumitu claui, donec perueniat cauterium ad profunditatem claui: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, donec incipiat emittere pus.	Then retract the hand with the cautery around the circumference of the thumb, until the cautery reaches the depth of the thumb: and keep it there for three days, until pus begins to discharge.
Deinde emplastra ipsum cum maluis syluestribus, contritis cum sale: et dimitte emplastrum super ipsum in nocte.	Then cover it with sponges soaked in salt, and keep it covered with a bandage at night.
Ipse enim eradicabitur ex radicibus suis.	The inflammation will disappear from its roots
Deinde cura locum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then care for the place where the burn has generated tissue, until it heals
Quod si sunt non conuersi, et multotiens accidunt in superficie corporis, praecipue in manibus et pedibus: tunc administres in eis cauterium cum aqua calida: et est, ut accipias cannulam ex aere, aut ferro, aut ex penna uulturis: et depone eam super clauum, aut althelul.	If they are not healed, and are multiplied on the surface of the body, especially on the hands and feet: then apply cautery with warm water: or take a needle from iron or ivory, or from a quill, and lay it upon the thumb, or the great toe
Deinde proiice in cannulam ex aqua calida quantitatem paucam: retine manum tuam, et tu reuolue eam cum compressione manus tuae parumper, ut imprimatur margo cannulae in radice claui, et inueniat aqua calida uiam ad profundum, ad radicem claui: et expectet infirmus parumper super mordicationem aquae calidae hora una.	Then pour a small quantity of warm water into the needle: hold your hand, and retract the needle with pressure, so as to impress the mark of the needle at the root of the thumb, and to bring the warm water up to the root of the thumb: and expect the patient to endure the pain for an hour
Deinde dimitte ipsum, nam clauus eradicatur cum radicibus suis.	Then let it go, for the thumb is eradicated with its roots
Ita fac cum eis uno post unum, donec uenias super omnes qui ex eis sunt in corpore.	Do so with one hand after the other, until you have passed over all that is in the body from the hand
Deinde cura eos postquam eradicantur, cum eo quod generat carnem ex unguentis.	Then care for the rest after they have been eradicated, with that which generates tissue from the incisions.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tremore.	In this way cauterize in Tremore.
Caput LVI.	Chapter 66.
Quando accidit alicui Tremor ex frigore in neruo, aut ex febre quartana, aut alio: tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis, aut quinque super spondiles dorsi, et inter omnem spondilem cauterio, et in pectore eius cauterio, et super stomachum eius cauterio.
