Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	One must therefore introduce the tip of the radius under the eyelid, and lift it up: or stretch it out with a hook: then cut into the adhesion with a fine scalpel, which should not be sharp like the cutting of the scalpel, but rather obtuse so as not to irritate the patient during the operation, and to make the scalpel withdraw from the adhesion easily, and restore the eyelid to its natural form, and heal the adhesion completely.
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	Then pour water salt into the eye, when the eye has been washed with water: or instill from a syringe containing dissolved salt with water.
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	Then separate the eyelid from the eye with a piece of linen thread: and put over the eye wool soaked in alum or oil: and on the third day use the syringe, and solid dressings, until it heals
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	About the incision of the nail and the prominence of the flesh of the tear-ducts
Caput XVI.	About the incision of the nail and the prominence of the flesh of the tear-ducts
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	You know that the nail is according to two ways
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	Or it is fleshy: and is similar to hard cheese, fine-grained.
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	Or it is not fleshy, like frozen white moisture: which when it touches iron, or you try to grasp it with a hook, it breaks and does not stay fixed in it
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	Neither of these species commence until the greater lacrimal has flowed somewhat, until it covers the whole, and shuts out light and the movement of the eye.
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	The method of handling the incision is as follows: you place the patient's head in your lap.</start_of_turn>
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	Then open the eyes and lift the eyelids with your hand.</start_of_turn
Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	Then collect the nail with a loop of few doublings, and extend it upwards.</start_of_turn
Deinde accipe acum, et intromitte in eam pilum ex pilis equi, et bouis, aut uaccae: et sit filum forte, et duplica extremitatem acus parumper, et fige eam in medio ungulae: et penetra eam cum acu, et liga cum filo ungulam, et extende eam ad superiora: et excoria cum pilo latus ungulae quod sequitur pupillam, ac si tu serres eam cum pilo usque ad postreimnum eius.	Then grasp the needle, and introduce it through the hair of the horse, and blood, or fat: and let the thread be strong, and double the extremity of the needle slightly, and fix it in the middle of the nail: and pierce the nail with the needle, and ligate with the thread the nail, and extend it upwards: and remove the hair surrounding the pupil, as if you are clipping the nail until the black spot of the pupil.</start_of_turn
Deinde incide residuum in radice lachrymalis cum spatumili subtili, aut cum forficibus paruis: et dimitte carnem lachrymalis naturalem, ut non accidat ex incisione eius cursus lachrymarum assiduus.	Then cut the remainder in the root of the lacrimal with fine scissors, or with small forceps: and release the natural flesh of the lacrimal, so that it does not cause excessive flow of tears from the incision.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque extenditur ungula cum uncino solo: aut cum filo, sicut diximus.	And when the nail is extended with only a loop, or with a thread, as we have said.</start_of_turn
Deinde excoriatur cum spatumili leni, cuius haec est forma.	Then it is to be scraped with a soft sponge, which is of this shape.</start_of_turn
Et caue, ne tangat spatumile tunicam corneam, et accidat in ea ruptura, et perforetur pupilla.	And beware, lest you touch the corneal tunic with the sponge, and cause a rupture, and perforate the pupil.</start_of_turn
Deinde post incisionem, proice in oculum aliquid salis contriti, aut ex sief facto ex ziniar, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then, after the incision, put in the eye some powdered salt, or mix some up from barley, and keep it in until tomorrow.</start_of_turn>
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur.	Then care for yourself until you are healed.
Quod si ungula est non neruosa, et non potes intromittere in eam acum, neque figitur in ea uncinus, tunc multotiens curatur haec species ungulae cum medicinis, et sanatur sicut narraui in diuisione.	If the nail is not neurovascular and does not contain marrow within, or if it does not protrude in the nail, then this kind of nail is cured with medicines and heals as I have said before.</start_of_turn>
Quod si uis incidere eam, tunc aperi oculum infirmi, et accipe spatumile subtile, lene, debilis acuitatis, secundum hanc formam.	If you wish to cut the nail, then open the eye of the patient and take a fine sponge, soft and flexible, and apply it to the tip of the nail, according to this form.</start_of_turn
Et rade ungulam desuper rasione cum subtilitate.	And remove the nail with the root with subtlety.</start_of_turn>
Quod si uides quod ipsa rarificatur et confringitur, et imprimit in eam rasio, tunc distilla ex hora tua in oculum ex sief facto ex ziniar, aut ex sief rubeo, aut sale trito: et opila oculum usque ad diem alium.	If you see that the nail is becoming pale and cracking, and that it is leaving tracks in the flesh, then bathe your eye from an hour hence with vinegar, or with red alum, or with salt: and anoint the eye until tomorrow.</start_of_turn
Deinde itera super ipsam operationem, donec remoueatur totum eius.	Then repeat the operation until the whole of it is removed.</start_of_turn
Nisi contrarium sit tibi in oculo apostema calidum: tunc enim dimitte ipsam, et cura apostema, donec sanetur.	Except that in the eye there is a thick yellow pus: then hold it back, and care for the pus until it is healed.</start_of_turn
Deinde itera operationem super ipsam cum rasione, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the operation on the nail with care until it is healed.</start_of_turn
Eminentia autem carnis lachrymalis, si nocet in oculo nocumento magno, suspendatur cum uncino, et incide ex ea partem eius: et non ultimes incisionem, ut non accidat cursus lachrymarum.	The prominence of the tear duct, if it causes great suffering in the eye, is suspended with a stitch, and is cut from it: and do not make the last incision, lest you cause the tear to become obstructed.</start_of_turn
Deinde stilla in lachrymale sief rubeum, aut factum ex ziniari, donec sanetur.	Then bathe the tear with red alum, or make it from vinegar, until it is healed.</start_of_turn
¶ De incisione Alguardenic, et carne nata in oculo.	Of the incision of the nail, and the flesh that is in the eye.</start_of_turn
Caput XVII.	Chapter XVII.
Nascitur quandoque in quibusdam oculis hominum caro rubea composita, uel superposita, donec cooperit pupillam, aut appropinquat, aut stringit super palpebras, et fortasse conuertit palpebras ad exteriora: et assimilatur rosae balaustinae.	A redness sometimes occurs in the eyes of men, when the fatty substance which is in their bodies surrounding the pupil, or which is superposed, is either protruded, or approximated, or strained over the eyelids, and sometimes the eyelids are turned outwards: and it is assimilated like the scales of a rose.
Et operatio in ea etiam est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And also in this case there is an operation, that you put the patient's head in your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et collige illam carnem totam cum uncinis conuenientibus ad illud: et tene illud cum forcipe uno, aut gesti.	Then open his eyes, and gather all the flesh with hooks which are convenient for this: and hold that with a forceps or hand
Deinde incide carnem in primis, donec finiatur totum eius cum incisorio.	Then cut the flesh at first, until you have finished all of it with the knife.</start_of_turn>
Et caue ab oculo, ut non laedas ipsum apud operationem: et sit incisio tua qua ipsam incidis, aut cum spatumili, quod narrauimus in incisione ungulae: aut cum forficibus paruis, cum quibus colligitur asebel, secundum quod ueniet forma eius post hoc capitulum.	And burn from the eye, so that you do not damage it during the operation: and let your incision be as we have said in the incision of the nail, or with fine forceps, with which the fat is collected, according as its shape will be afterwards.
Cum ergo completur incisio tua, et remouetur tota alguardenici, tunc imple oculum ex sale contrito: aut distilla in eum puluerem rubeum, et similia illi ex medicinis corrosiuis: et pone super oculum deforis cottum cum albugine oui: ut securetur ab apostemate calido.	When you have thus completed your incision, and you have moved all the surrounding fat, then remove the eye from the salt, or distill it into red powder, and similar things are done by physicians with corrosive medicines: and put over the eye a bandage of wool or lint: so as to secure it from the heat of the after-burn.
Quod si remanet ex alguardenici aliquid, et dominatur tibi sanguis calidus, et times apostema calidum: tunc dimitte oculum, et cura ipsum cum eo quod sedat apostema.	And if anything remains of the fat, and the blood is hot, and there is a swelling: then remove the eye, and care for it until the swelling has gone down.
Deinde itera super ipsum cum operatione, donec sanetur.	And do the same again over the eye with the operation, until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Et similiter fac cum carne addita quae accidit in oculo ex hac specie.	And do the same with the addition of flesh which is in the eye of this kind.</start_of_turn>
Verumtamen oportet, ut alienes curationem omnis oculi debilis ex uia naturali, aut ex uia accidentali, operando cum ferro: et non intromittas manum tuam in aliqua harum operationum, donec uideas, quod illud membrum est tolerans illam operationem.	It is proper to know that all ailments of the eye, whether natural or accidental, must be treated with iron, without introducing the hand into any of these operations until you know that the limb can tolerate such an operation.
¶ De collectione Sebel ex oculo.	It is proper to know that all ailments of the eye, whether natural or accidental, must be treated with iron, without introducing the hand into any of these operations until you know that the limb can tolerate such an operation.
Caput XVIII.	It is proper to know that all ailments of the eye, whether natural or accidental, must be treated with iron, without introducing the hand into any of these operations until you know that the limb can tolerate such an operation.
Sebel sunt uenae rubeae quae texuntur super oculum, et prohibent uisui operationem suam: et debilitant oculum cum longitudine dierum.	The ailments of the eye are like red spots that cover the eye, and which prevent the liquid from performing its operation: and they weaken the eye with the length of the days.
Necesse est ergo tibi in primis, ut consideres, si oculus in quo est Sebel, est fortis, et non est in eo aegritudo aliqua, praeter Sebel: tunc collige Sebel eius.	It is necessary therefore, in the first place, to consider whether the eye in which the ailment exists is strong and not subject to any other ailment except for the ailment: then collect the ailment of that eye
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo.	And it is necessary to know, before all things, that the eye which has the ailment must be firmly placed in your hand
Deinde suspende illas uenas cum uncino uno, aut duobus secundum prudentiam tuam: et sit uncinus subtilis duplationis, secundum hanc formam, aut sint duo uncini gradat in corpore uno, secundum hanc formam.	Then suspend those veins with one hook, or two according to your prudence: and let the hook be of fine steel, like the form of a nail, or let there be two hooks graduated in one body, like this form
Deinde collige cum forficibus subtilibus illas uenas cum subtilitate, et absterge sanguinem hora post horam, donec uideas illas uenas remoueri ex oculo, et resoluuntur: et caue ne laedas oculum cum extremitatibus spatumilis.	Then collect with fine forceps those veins with diligence, and withdraw the blood every hour, until you know that those veins have been removed from the eye, and have dissolved: and beware that you do not damage the eye with the tips of the forceps.
Et sit operatio tua in meridie coram sole, et sis firmus in operatione tua ualde: ut non incidas nisi illas uenas.	And let your operation be in the middle of the day before the sun, and be firm in your operation so that you do not injure anything except for the veins
Et cum tu expleueris, tunc distilla in oculum sief uiride, aut rubeum: ut sua acuitate corrodat quod remansit ex sebel.	And when you have finished, then instill in the eye a little oil, or red pepper: so that your sight may restore what remains of the ailment.
Si autem non est tibi possibile colligere illud totum in illa hora, tunc emplastra oculum cum eo, quod sedat dolorem oculi: et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur dolor eius: et securetur ab apostemate calido: deinde itera super ipsum secundum modum eundem, donec sanetur.	If it is not possible to collect the whole of it in this hour, then plaster the eye with this, which will soothe the pain of the eye: and leave it for a few days, until the pain has subsided: and keep it away from a cold compress: and repeat over it again according to the same method, until it is healed.
Et haec est forma forficis.	This is the form of the scissors.
¶ De reductione Arissati ad nasum.	On the reduction of the swelling of the nose.
Caput XIX.	Chapter XIX.</start_of_turn>
Nominant medici Arissati Fistulam, quam curas cum cauterio, aut cum medicina acuta comburente, secundum quod praecessit eius narratio.	Physicians call the swelling of the nose a Fistula, which they cure with cautery, or with acute medicine burning, as it is appropriate to its nature.</start_of_turn>
Et si non sanatur, tunc non est ingenium in ea: nisi ut findas super apostema apud natiuitatem eius, et extrahas totam humiditatem quae est in eo et pus, donec detegatur os.	And if it does not heal, then there is no wisdom in that: except that you should find pus above the swelling at its origin, and evacuate all the moisture which is in it and pus, until the bone is cleansed.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo detegitur os, et uides in eo corruptionem, aut nigredinem, tunc rade ipsum cum instrumento, cuius forma est haec.	When the bone is cleansed, and the surrounding area is freed from corruption or blackness, then apply to it an instrument whose form is like this.</start_of_turn
Et nominatur Asperi capitis.	And it is called the Asperation of the head.</start_of_turn
Fiat ex ferro indo, et sit caput eius rotundum sicut azir, quod sit punctatum punctatione limae, aut punctatione aliskilferi punctatione subtili: et pone ipsum super locum corruptum ossis.	It is made of iron thread, and its head is round like an olive, which is pierced with the point of a lime-stone, or with the point of a needle or with a fine point: and place it over the corrupted place of the bone.</start_of_turn
Deinde reuolue ipsum inter digitos tuos, et tu preme manum tuam parumper, donec scias quod illa corruptio iam rasa est: et fac illud aliquotiens.	Then draw it out between your fingers, and keep your hand near, until you know that that corruption is gone: and do it again.</start_of_turn
Deinde restaura locum cum medicinis exiccatiuis stipticis.	Then restore the place with astringent drugs.</start_of_turn
Si ergo consolidatur locus, et nascitur in eo caro, et abscinditur cursus saniei: et remanet quadraginta diebus, et non renouatur, et non apostematur, et non accidit in eo accidens: tunc scias quia iam sanatus est.	If therefore the place is consolidated, and there is formed in it flesh, and the course of the ailment is over: and it remains for forty days, and does not return, and does not swell, and no accident happens in it: then you know that it is healed.</start_of_turn
Et si non, tunc non est in eo ingenium, nisi reducere fistulam ad foramen nasi, secundum hanc formam.	And if not, then it is not in this ingenuity, except to reduce the fistula to the opening of the nose, according to this fashion.
Et est, ut detegas ab osse secundo cum ferro, aut cum medicina acuta: et cum detectum est os, tunc accipe terebrum secundum hanc formam, sit extremitas ferrea, triangulata: et lignum eius sit pyramis extenuata usque ad extremitatem, sicut uides.	And it is like that you should detect the second bone with iron, or with acute medicine: and when it has been detected, then take hold of the prominence according to this fashion, when there is a ferrous extremity, triangular: and the wood of it should be a protracted pyramid up to the extremity, like a river.
Deinde pone illud super os ipsum: et sit illud prope lachrymale: et elonga manum tuam ab oculo parum.	Then place it over the bone itself: and let it be close to the tear duct: and extend your hand from the eye somewhat.
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum terebro, donec penetret os, et sentiat illud infirmus: per hoc quod inuenit uentum exire ex eo, quando tenet manum suam super nasum suum.	Then turn your hand with the prominence, until it penetrates the bone, and feel that it is infirm: by this it will be known that it has found the opening to exit from there, when you hold your hand over your nose.
Ergo tunc restaura locum cum medicinis stipticis exiccantibus, sicut docui te.	Therefore, then restore the place with styptic medicines that are being applied, as I have taught you.
Cum ergo nascitur caro, et induratur locus: tunc materia quae effundebatur ad exteriora, redit ad nasum: est ergo leuius illud super infirmum.	When therefore the flesh has been born, and the place has hardened: then the matter which was flowing outwards returns to the nose: thus it is easier for it to lie over the infirmity.
¶ De reductione eminentiae Oculi.	¶ On the reduction of the prominence of the eye.
Caput XX.	Chapter XX.
Quando eminet Oculus cum totalitate sua, et non accidit in uisu nocumentum, neque diminutio: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum: deinde phlebotomes eum: postea ponas uentosas in ceruice absque scarificatione, sed cum suctione.	When the eye protrudes with its entirety, and it has not happened in any liquid document, neither by diminution: then it is necessary to dissolve the infirmity: then perform phlebotomy on it: afterwards place ointments on the surface without scarring, but with suction
Deinde pone super Oculum linimentum quod fit ex acacia, et aloe, et olibano, et sarcocolla.	Then put on the eye a liniment which is made from acacia, and aloe, and olive oil, and beeswax.
Deinde stringe Oculum desuper super emplastrum cum puluillis multis.	Then bind the eye over the plaster with many small beads
Et modus puluillorum est: ut accipias pannos lenes, multos, et duplicetur omnis pannus ex eis super quatuor: fac ex eis multos: deinde pone eos unum super alium, secundum quantitatem qua indiget Oculus: deinde stringe super ipsos cum panno duro strictura forti.	And thus with the pouls [pullets] it is: take many fine threads and double every thread above four: make many from these: then put one over the other according to the quantity required for the eye: then tighten over these with a strong thread.
Et itera uentosas cum suctione sine scarificatione.	Repeat the process until the wound is closed without leaving a scar.
Deinde aufer uentosas, et dimitte oculum strictum die et nocte.	Then remove the sutures and keep the eye closed day and night.
Si autem ligamentum iterum mollificatur, tunc oportet ut stringatur multum: deinde aufer ligamentum post diem et noctem, sicut diximus.	If, however, the ligament is again softened, then it is necessary to tighten it much: then remove the ligament after a day and a night, as we have said
Si ergo uides oculum iam redisse uuae tunicae, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam, et uentosas, donec sanetur.	If therefore you again see swelling in the eye, it is good: and if not, then repeat the plaster, the pouls, the tightening and the sutures until the eye is healed.
¶ De incisionie Vuae tunicae.	Of the incision of the tunica of the eye.
Caput XXI.	Chapter 21.
Quando accidit disruptio in tunica Vuea, deinde eminet et procedit extra palpebras sicut granum Vuae, et foedatur forma hominis propter illud, et uis incidere illud: tunc operatio in eo est, secundum quod narro: et est, ut intromittas acum in radice Vuae ab inferiori ad superiorem partem.	When a rupture occurs in the tunica of the eye, then it will protrude and proceed outside the eyelids like a grain of the tunica, and will be deformed like a man because of this. Then it is necessary to make an incision in this: and the operation in this is as follows: and it is that you introduce a needle into the root of the tunica from the lower part to the upper part.
Deinde intromitte acum aliam in qua sit filum duplum a parte lachrymalis, et fac eam penetrare: et dimitte acum primam secundum dispositionem suam.	Then introduce another needle in which there is a doubled thread from the lachrymal part, and make it penetrate: and remove the first needle according to its position.
Deinde incide locum fili dupli, et liga cum eo partem Vuae in circumitu acus: et stringe eam multum.	Then cut the place of the doubled thread and ligate with it the part of the tunica around the needle: and tighten it much
Deinde extrahe acum, et pone super oculum lanam infusam in albugine oui: et dimitte eum, donec cadat filum cum Vua.	Then remove the needle, and put over the eye a lanolin bandage on an albumin: and leave it in place until the thread is gone with the tunica
Deinde cura oculum cum eo, quod confortat ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then care for the eyes while they are comforted, until the wound is healed.
Et quandoque stringitur Vua ab omni parte cum circulo ex panno, donec addat oculus eminentiam magnam.	And when the limb is bound up from every part with a circle of cloth, until the eye regains great elevation
Deinde perforetur cum spatumili subtili, quod perueniat ad profundum oculi, et currat humiditas albuginea, et descendat oculus, et ingrediatur statim: deinde stringe eum, donec sanetur.	Then pierce with a fine needle that reaches the depth of the eye, and let out the humidy of the albumen, and the eye will descend, and join immediately: then bind it up until it is healed.
¶ De curatione Alcomnati.	On the treatment of the eye.
Caput XXII.	Chapter XXII.
Haec Aegritudo quae nominatur Alcomnati, non, est nisi sanies, quae aggregatur in oculo, similis aquae descendenti, et non est ipsa.	This ailment which is called Alcomnati, is not except for health which collects in the eye, like descending water, and is not itself
Et modus operandi in ea est, ut facias sedere infirmum super sedem praeparatum, uel directum.	And the way of working on it is that you make the patient sit on a prepared seat, or directly
Deinde accipe caput eius manibus tuis a partibus duabus, et moue ipsum, donec uideas saniem peruenire ad inferiora oculis tuis.	Then grasp his head with your hands from two parts, and move him until you see the health go up to the lower parts of your eyes
Deinde figatur, et non descendat, et absoluatur lumen: et uideat infirmus res sicut uidebat: et si non descendit inferius, scias quia est aqua.	Then it will remain fixed, and will not descend, and the light will be extinguished: and you will know that it is water
Si autem non praeparatur descensus saniei cum eo quod diximus, tunc fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas.	If however the preparation of the descent of the health is not done with it which we have said, then make him sit between your hands
Deinde accipe spatumile subtile, et finde cum eo supra panniculum corneum parumper apud continuationem coniunctiuae cum tunica cornea in corona, donec egrediatur sanies.	Then take a fine needle, and pierce with it above the corneal membrane near the continuation of the conjunctiva with the membrane of the cornea in a circle, until the health comes out.
Cum ergo egreditur, tunc distilla in oculum aquam calidam in qua miscuisti mel: aut aquam in qua iam bullisti foenumgraecum et mel: deinde curetur cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	When it comes out, then instill in the eye warm water in which you have mixed honey: or water in which you have ground barley and honey: then care for it with the remaining treatment, until it is healed
¶ De cura aquae, quae descendit in oculo, uel cataracta.	Concerning the care of water which flows into the eye, or a cataract.
Caput XXIII.	Concerning the care of water which flows into the eye, or a cataract.
Iam Diximus species aquae in diuisione, et quae conuenit ad perforandum sermone declarante et exponente, tunc accipe illud idem secundum sanitatem.	We have already spoken of ten kinds of water which exist in the eye, and of which some are harmful and some are beneficial; take heed of this according to the state of health.
Tunc ergo oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas quadratum, oppositum lumini, prope solem: et liga oculum eius sanum, et stringe eum ualde: deinde palpebram oculi eius manu tua dextra, si oculus in quo est aqua, est oculus sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then therefore it is necessary that you should keep the diseased hand away from the eye opposite the light, near the cheek: and bind the healthy eye tightly: then grasp the eyelid of the eye which has the water in it with your right hand, if the water is in the left eye: or grasp the eyelid of the right eye if the water is in the left eye
Deinde accipe manu tua dextra almagda, si oculus est sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then grasp your right hand with the almond, if the eye is left: or your left hand if the eye is right.
Deinde pone extremitatem almagda prope coronam per grossitudinem radii in ipsa albedine oculi apparente lachrymalis minoris: deinde impelle almagda cum uirtute: et tu reuoluis cum eo manum tuam, donec penetret in albuginem oculi: et sentias, quod almagda iam peruenit ad rem uacuam.	Then put the tip of the almond near the edge of the visible white part of the eye: then press the almond with force: and you will see that the almond has penetrated the membrane of the eye. Feel that the almond has reached its endpoint
Et oportet, ut sit mensura itineris almagda ad profundum, mensura spacii quod est a pupilla usque ad finem nigredinis: et est corona oculi.	And it is necessary that the measure of the journey of the almond be to the depth, the measure of the space from the pupil to the end of the black part: and that is the circumference of the eye
Uidebis enim ea in ipsa pupilla uisione oculi, propter claritatem tunicae corneae.	You will see this in the pupil of the eye, because of the clarity of the cornea.
Deinde pone almagda usque ad locum in quo est aqua.	Then put the almond until it reaches the water
Deinde preme ipsum inferius uice una post aliam.	Then press the lower eyelid downwards one after the other.
Si ergo descendit aqua statim, tunc infirmus uidet illud super quod aperit uisum suum statim, et almagda in oculo suo.	If therefore the water descends immediately, then the diseased hand will immediately close over what has opened its eye, and the almond in the eye.
Deinde quiescas paululum.	Then rest a little while.
Si ergo descendat aqua, tunc depone eam secundo, praeter quod egrediatur almagda.	If water descends, then lay the sponge aside, except when the vomit is evacuated.
Quando ergo figitur, et non ascendit: tunc extrahe almagda cum facilitate: et tu reuoluis manum tuam paulatim.	When it has become fixed and does not ascend: then extract the vomit with ease: and you turn your hand slowly.
Deinde dissolue in aqua aliquid ex sale claro gemmae: et ablue cum eo oculum deintus.	Then dissolve in water something of clear salt pearl: and wipe away with it when the eye is closed
Deinde pone extra oculum totum stuppam, aut lanam infusam oleo rosato, et albugine oui: et liga cum eo oculum sanum.	Then put outside the eye the whole lump of ointment, or soaked wool fat with rosewater, and alum: and bind with it the sound eye.
Nos autem, et illi qui sunt nostri temporis, ponimus super eum ciminum tritum cum albumine oui.	But we, who are of our time, put upon it a soft cushion of beaten eggs with alum.
Quod si non obedit tibi almagda ad introitum in oculum propter duriciem suam, quoniam ex hominibus est, cuius oculus est durus ualde: tunc oportet ut accipias spatumile, quod nominatur Alberid, cuius haec est forma.	If the vomit does not yield to the eye because of its hardness, because it is from a man whose eye is hard like that of a stone: then it is necessary to take the sponge, which is called Alberid, whose form is like that
Pefora ergo cum eo ipsam coniunctiuam tantum, et non ultimes manum tuam in foramine: et non est nisi ut facias uiam ad almagda locum subtilem.	The sponge must be taken with it joined to the eye only, and do not touch the hand with the thumb: and do not do anything except to make the vomit go to the bottom of the eye
Deinde intromitte almagda, secundum quod diximus.	Then introduce the vomit, as we have said
Et apud complementum operis tui, praeparetur infirmo dormitorium decenter factum, in quo dormiat super dorsum suum in domo tenebrosa: et prohibeatur ab omnibus motibus, et a tussi: et pone cibum eius illud quo lenitur natura eius: et non moueat caput suum dextra, neque sinistra omnino.	And in addition to this, prepare a comfortable bed for the patient, made in the center of the room, in which he should lie on his back in a dark room: and be guarded against all movements, and from vomiting: and give him food that will soothe his nature: and do not move his head to the right or to the left at all
Et sit ligamentum secundum dispositionem suam usque ad diem tertium.	And remain quiet according to your custom until the third day.
Deinde solue illud in illa domo tenebrosa, et experire uisum eius: et fac eum uidere res.	Then loosen it in that dark room, and experience its effect: and make him drink something.
Deinde reduc ligamentum usque ad diem septimum.	Then reduce the ligament until the seventh day.
Et non oportet ut faciat illud in hora curationis, aut post incisionem statim: imo oportet, ut alienes illud: propterea quod aqua ascendit uelociter per aspectum uehementem.	The procedure should not be performed immediately after surgery or during the first hour of treatment. It is better to wait a while because the fluid ascends quickly through the painful area.
Si autem accidit apostema calidum: tunc oportet ut soluas oculum ante septimum: et rectifica illud cum eo quod sedat apostema, donec sedatur: tunc absolue ipsius uisum, et pone super faciem eius orale quo regatur uisus eius sub eo diebus aliquot, ipso existente in illa domo tenebrosa.	If there is a cold swelling: then it is necessary to wait until the seventh day: and straighten it out along with that which settles the swelling: until it settles down: then remove the cause of the swelling and place over the face of it a bandage which will regulate the swelling for a few days, even though it exists in the dark space.</start_of_turn>
Deinde egrediatur a domo gradatim, et conuersetur in casis suis.	Then gradually go out of the room and return to your home.</start_of_turn>
Et scias, quod in zaltea non excusatur discipulus a uisione aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super operationem.	And know that in the hospital a pupil is not excused from seeing for a long time: then indeed he will hear about the operation.</start_of_turn>
Et iam quidem peruenit ad nos quidam ex illis qui sunt de Alayrach, qui dixit, quod factum fuit in Alayrach magdan perforatum, quo sugitur aqua.	And indeed some people from Alayrach have said that a magdan was perforated in Alayrach, because of which water ascends.</start_of_turn>
Verum ergo non uidi aliquem in terra uostra, qui fecerit illud: neque legi illud in aliquo ex libris antiquorum: et est possibile, ut sit illud nouum.	But indeed no one in our land has done this: neither have I read of it in any of the ancient books: and it is possible that it is new.</start_of_turn
Et istae sunt formae specierum ex magda, ut stet super ea qui ea ignorat.	And these are the forms of the spirits of magdas, as they remain over it who are ignorant of them.</start_of_turn
Fiant ex aere proprie: et sint extremitates eorum cum hac eadem subtilitate triangulatae, et extremitas acuta.	Be like the air itself: and let their extremities be like those of a triangle with a pointed tip.</start_of_turn
Formae magda.	The spirits of magdas.</start_of_turn
¶ De cura Carnis natae in naso.	On the care of the newborn flesh in the nose.</start_of_turn
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter XXIII.</start_of_turn
Quandoque nascuntur in naso Carnes diuersae additae, ex quibus est aliquid quod assimilatur scorpioni multorum pedum: et ex ea est caro cancerosa, lapidea, fusci coloris: et ex ea est quae est caro lenis, non fusci coloris.	When the diverse meats of the nose are cut, something is absorbed from the numerous feet of scorpions: from this is a cancerous tumor, a stone, of saffron color; from this is what is a soft tumor, not of saffron color.
In ea ergo quae ex istis carnibus est lenis, non fraudulenta, neque cancerosa, oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas oppositum soli, et aperi nares eius, et proiice uncinum in illas carnes: deinde trahe eas ad exteriora, et incide quod comprehendisti ex eis cum spatumili subtili acuto a parte una, donec scias quod caro tota iam ablata est.	When the various meats of the nose are cut, something is absorbed from the numerous feet of scorpions: from this is a cancerous tumor, a stone, saffron-colored; from this is what is a soft tumor, not saffron-colored.
Quod si remaneret aliquid ex ea cuius abscisio non est possibilis: tunc rade illud cum uno instrumentorum subtilium cum facilitate, donec non remaneat ex eo aliquid.	When what remains of it from whose excision is not possible: then take that with a fine instrument with ease, until nothing remains of it.
Si autem sanguis tibi dominatur, aut accidat apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei per id quod oportet: aut est ex apostematibus malignis, tunc propera cauterizando eum, donec abscindatur sanguis, et auferantur omnes carnes.	If blood dominates it, or thick pus arises: then oppose it by that which is necessary: either by malignant pus, then cauterize it until the blood is stopped, and remove all the meat.
Deinde proiiciatur in nasum post incisionem acetum, et aqua, aut uinum.	Then spit into the nose after the incision of the flesh, and water, or liquid.
Si autem aperitur nasus, et procedat ex eo humiditas usque ad palatum, tunc scias quia iam sanus est.	If the nose is opened, and moisture proceeds from it up to the palate, then you know that it is healed.
Si uero non penetrat humiditas, secundum quod oportet, tunc scias quod intra ipsum est caro nata in superioribus ossibus naris, ad quae non peruenit cum incisione instrumentum.	If however moisture does not penetrate, according to what is necessary, then you know that inside there is living flesh in the upper bones of the nose, which does not disappear with the incision of the instrument.
Tunc ergo oportet, ut intromittas filum lini cui sit quaedam grossitudo, et noda in eo nodos multos: et pone inter omnem nodum quantitatem digiti, aut minus: et ingeniet infirmus, ut mittat extremitatem unam fili in nasum cum radio, aut cum quo possibile est ei postquam fecerit ipsum simile azer: et trahat odoratum suum, donec perueniat usque ad caassum, et egrediatur super guttur suum.	Then you must introduce a thread with some thickness, and pass it through numerous knots: and put between every knot the quantity of a digit, or less: and the patient will vomit, so that he sends out one extremity of the thread through the nose with a hook, or in whatever way is possible for him to do it: and he will pull out the stench until it reaches the stomach, and it will go out through his mouth
Et multotiens quidem faciunt simile huic Attomi pueri in scholis: et est res facilis ei, qui uult.	Many do like him, just as this Attomi boy often does in school. It is easy for him who wishes.
Deinde pone duas extremitates fili, extremitatem unam quae egreditur super nasum, et alteram quae remansit in naso.	Then place two extremities of the boy, one that projects over the nose and the other that remains in the nose
Deinde ac ministra serraturam carnis cum nodis qui sunt in filo.	Then the minister shall bind the flesh with knots that are in the limb.
Fac illud donec scias quod carnes iam sunt cum nodis fili.	Do this until you know that the flesh is joined with the knots of the limb.
Deinde extrahe filum: et pone in nasum post abstersionem sanguinis licinium quod imbibisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud tribus diebus, aut plus, donec unguentum corrodat totum quod remansit ex carnibus.	Then draw out the thread: and put in the nose after wiping away the blood with a bandage of Egyptian unguent: do this for three days, or more, until the unguent has eaten away all that remains of the flesh
Deinde pone in fine rei in nasum cannulam de plumbo, diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	Then put at the end of the matter in the nose a lead cannula for a few days, until it is healed
Si autem indiget curatione quae exiccet, utere illa.	If however urgent is the care which is required, use this.
Ad caputpurgium faciendum, cum quo distillantur olea, et aliae medicinae in nasum, fac illud ex argento, aut aere: quod sit simile lampadi paruae, apertum sicut conchula: et meatus eius similiter.	For the head-purging which is to be made, when oil and other medicines are distilled in the nose, do this with silver, or with air: which should be like fine pepper, opened like a conch shell: and its meat should be like that of the almond
Et si uis fac cannulam clausam, sicut canna.	And if you wish to make a closed cannula, like a tube.
Et conchula instrumenti ad caputpurgium faciendum, sit plena, detecta: cui sit manubrium in postremo eius, cum quo teneas ipsam, quando calefacis in ea oleum, aut quod uis ex succis, et rebus fluxibilibus.	And the conch of the instrument for head-purging must be full, closed: which must have a handle at its rear, with which you will grasp it, when you heat it in oil, or when you wish to draw out something from it, and from the fluxes.
Et haec est forma instrumenti.	This is the form of the instrument.
¶ De cura Thelul nasi.	On the care of the eye of the nose.
Caput XXV.	Day 25.
Multotiens nascitur in extremitate nasi Thelul, et magnificatur, et augmentatur cum diebus, donec foedus fit aspectus eius.	Many are born in the extremity of the nose of Thelul, and they grow large, and increase with the days, until their aspect becomes like that of a wound
Et propter illud oportet, ut in cidas illud in principio apparitionis eius, et eradices totum eius.	And therefore it is necessary, that in the beginning of its appearance, it should be cut in pieces, and its entirety should be excised.
Deinde pone super locum, aut cauterium, aut medicinam comburentem quae stat loco eius.	Then place above it, or cauterize, or apply a burning medicine which is in its place
Si ergo tardatur incisio eius, donec magnificetur, tunc considera, si est lapideum, durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro: quoniam apostema est cancerosum.	If, however, its incision is delayed until it has grown large, then consider, if it be a stone, hard, of the color of feces, with little sensation: then do not touch it with the iron: for the tumor is cancerous.
Multotiens enim uidi, qui incidit hmoni apostema, et accidit ex eo malicia magna super illum qui ipsum habebat.	Many are the times when a wound occurs from an abscess, and it proceeds from this great malice above all that which it had before
Et si apostema est lenis tactus, non fusci coloris, et uides quod incisio possibilis est in toto eius, tunc euacua infirmum, et incide ipsum sine timore, absque pauore: et cura locum cum eo quod exiccat et constringit, donec sanetur.	And if the abscess is soft to the touch, not of the color of feces, and if the wound is possible throughout its entirety, then evacuate the sick person, and cut it without fear, without pain: and care for the place where it has been excised until it is healed
¶ De sutura nasi, et labii, et auris.	Of the suture of the nose, and the lip, and the ear
Caput XXVI.	Chapter XXVI.
Scias Quia quando accidit solutio continuitatis in una harum cartilaginum, parum confert in ea operatio, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	You know that when a solution of continuity occurs in some cartilaginous substance, it provides little support in that operation, except in some people.
Oportet ergo quando accidit alicui aliquid ex illo, ut consideres, si est uulnus recens cum sanguine suo: et tunc aggrega duolabia uulneris cum sutura: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	It is necessary, therefore, when anything is excised from that, that you consider whether it has any blood vessels adhering to it: and then join together the edges of the wound with a suture: then care for it until it is healed
Et si solutionis continuitatis labia iam separata sunt, et facta est unaquaeque pars sana: tunc oportet ut excories omnem partem a cute sua apparente, donec sanguinetur.	And if the continuity of the lips has already been separated, and has become one entire healthy part: then it is necessary to remove every part from its apparent skin, until the blood has clotted.
Deinde aggrega duo labia cum sutura, et stringe ea, et pulueriza super ipsum sanguinem draconis, et olibanum trita: et pone supra pulueres frustum emplastri diafinicon, et alicuius alterius ex emplastris consolidatiuis: et dimitte ipsum ligatum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Then join the lips together with a suture, and bind them, and apply above it dragons' blood, and mastic of olibanum: and place above the powders a plaster of beeswax, and any other adhesive plaster: and leave it bound for two days, or three
Deinde solue ipsum, et permuta medicinam: et dimitte ipsum, donec abscindantur fila per se.	Then solve yourself, and move the medicine: and let go of yourself, until the threads are severed by themselves.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then take care of yourself with the unguent, until you are healed.
Modus autem suturae est, ut aggreges solutionem continuitatis, aut cum acubus, sicut narrauimus in sutura uentris: aut aggrega solutionem cum filo, sicut feci te scire.	The way of stitching is that you gather the solution of continuity, or with a loop, as we say in the stitching of the belly: or you gather the solution with the thread, as you were told
¶ De extractione nodorum labiorum.	About the extraction of the knots of the lips.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter XXVII.</start_of_turn>
Multis Quidem hominibus accidunt plaerumque in interioribus labiorum suorum apostemata dura similia granis herbi: et quaedam eorum minora, et maiora.	Many people have happened to have swelling in the insides of their lips like hard seeds of grass: and some of them are minor, and some are major
Ergo oportet ut conuertas labium, et findas super omnem nodum eius, et suspendas ipsum cum uncino, et incidas ipsum ab omni parte.	Therefore it is necessary to cover the lips, and find on every nodule of them, and suspend them with a hook, and cut them off from all sides
Deinde impleas locum post incisionem zegi trito, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then place the place after the incision with a bit of sponge, until the blood is separated
Deinde colluatur cum aceto, et curetur locus cum eo, in quo est stipticitas, usquequo sanentur uulnera.	Then it is to be bound with vinegar, and the place is to be cared for with that which has styptic power, until the wound is healed
¶ De incisione carnis natae super gingiuam.	About the incision of the newly-formed flesh upon the gum
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter XXVIII.</start_of_turn
Multotiens nascitur super gingiuam caro addiat, quam antiqui nominant abuluss.	Many times there is formed upon the gum new flesh which the ancients call abuluss
Oportet ergo ut suspendas eam cum uncino: aut teneas eam cum forcipibus, et incidas eam apud radicem suam, et dimittas saniem currere, aut sanguinem.	Therefore it is necessary to suspend the flesh with a hook: or to grasp the flesh with forceps, and cut it off at its root, and let the blood run, or the pus flow out
Deinde pone super locum zegi tritum, aut alios pulueres stipticos, exiccatiuos.	Then place upon the place some coarse sponge, or other powder which has styptic power.
Quod si redit illa caro post curationem, nam multotiens redit, tunc incide eam secundo, et cauteriza ipsam: ipsa namque non redit post cauterium.	If the flesh returns again after treatment, for it often returns many times, then cut through it a second time and burn it: for it will not return after it has been burned.
¶ De rasione Dentium cum ferro.	Regarding the wisdom of teeth with iron.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter XXIX.</start_of_turn>
Quandoque aggregantur in superficiebus Dentium ab interiori et extetiori parte, et inter gingiuas cortices asperi, turpes, et quandoque denigrantur, et citrini fiunt, et uirides, donec peruenit ex illo corruptio ad gingiuam, et foedi fiunt dentes per illud.	When teeth gather together on the surface both from the inside and outside and between the gums, their enamel becomes rough, dark, and sometimes even falls out, and ulcers form, and they become yellow, until the corruption reaches the gum and causes the teeth to loosen.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et caput eius in sinu tuo, et rade molam et dentem, in quo apparent tibi cortices, et res similis arenae: donec non remaneat ex eis aliquid, et similiter fac de nigredine, et uiriditate, et citrinitate, et aliis donec mundentur.	It is therefore necessary to make the infirm man sit between your hands and place his head in your lap, and grasp the molar and the tooth, where you see the enamel, and do like sand: until something remains from that, and do likewise with blackness, and yellowness, and ulcers, and other things until they are moved.</start_of_turn
Si ergo auferatur quod in eis est a principio rasionis, bonum est: et si non, tunc itera super eos rasionem die alio, secundo, et tertio, donec ad ultimum perueniat studium in eo quod uis.	If therefore something is taken away from the beginning of the wisdom, it is good: and if not, then repeat the wisdom again on another day, the second day, and the third day, until finally the study is complete in that which you desire.</start_of_turn>
Et scias, quod dens indiget rasoriis diuersarum formarum, multarum figurarum: secundum quod praeparatur operationi tuae: proptera, quod rasorium quo raditur dens ab inferiori parte, est aliud a rasorio quo raditur inter dentes, secundum formas alias.	You know that teeth need various rasps of different forms, many figures: according to the preparation of your operation: because the rasp which removes the tooth from the lower part is different from the rasp which removes the teeth between the teeth, according to other figures.</start_of_turn>
Et istae formae rasoriorum sint apud te praeparatae, quas uides.	And these figures of rasps are prepared for you, which you will use.</start_of_turn>
¶ De extractione doloris Dentium.	Chapter XXVIII.</start_of_turn
Caput XXX.	When the tooth is inflamed and painful, and the pain is great, and the swelling is such that it cannot be borne, and the tooth cannot be moved, then it is necessary to extract the tooth.
Oportet ut cures Dentem a dolore suo cum omni ingenio, et tardes in eradicatione eius.	It is necessary that the tooth be freed from its pain with all possible skill, and afterwards its eradication be aimed at.
Non est enim quod uicem eius suppleat quando eradicatur: quoniam est substantia sublimis: donec quando non est excusatio de eradicatione eius, tunc oportet quando cogitur infirmus eradicare ipsum, ut firmetur, et certificetur apud te dens dolens.	It is not in its power to remove the pain without eradicating it: for it is a lofty substance. Therefore, when eradication is not indicated, it is necessary to consider that the sickly person must eradicate it, in order to strengthen himself, and to confirm to you that the tooth is painful
Multotiens enim decipit infirmum dolor, et putat quia est in dente saha et eradicat ipsum: deinde non recedit dolor, donec eradicetur dens infirmus.	Many men indeed deceive the sickly person with their pain, and say that it is in the tooth itself and eradicate it: but the pain does not depart until the diseased tooth is eradicated.
Nos enim iam uidimus illud ex operatione phlebotomatorum.	We do not indeed go about this from the performance of blood-lettings.
Cum ergo certificatur apud te dens dolens ipsemet, tunc oportet ut scarifices in circumitu dentis cum spatumili, in quo sit quiddam uirtutis, donec soluatur gingiua ab omni parte: deinde moue ipsum digitis tuis, aut cum forcipibus subtilibus in primis paulatim, donec concutias ipsum.	When it is confirmed to you that the tooth itself is painful, then it is necessary to make incisions around the tooth with sponges, in which there is some advantage, until the gums are separated from all parts: then move the tooth with your fingers, or with fine forceps from the outset gradually, until you break it
Deinde loca tunc in eo forcipes magnos locatione bona, et caput infirmi inter genua tua: quod iam bene tenuisti, ita quod non moueatur: deinde trahe dentem secundum rectitudinem, ut non frangas ipsum.	Then place the forceps in a large place well, and hold the patient's head between your knees: which you have done well, for it will not move: then draw out the tooth in accordance with the rule, so that you do not break it
Si ergo non egreditur, tunc accipe aliquod illorum instrumentorum, et intromitte ipsum sub eo ab omni parte cum facilitate, et conare motionem eius, sicut fecisti in primis.	If it does not come out, then grasp any of those instruments, and introduce it under it from all parts with ease, and endeavor to move it, as you did at first.
Si autem dens est perforatus, aut corrosus: tunc oportet ut impleas illud foramen panno: et stringas ipsum cum extremitate radii subtilis, ut non frangatur in hora constrictionis tuae super ipsum cum forcipibus.	If the tooth is perforated or corroded: then it is necessary to fill the hole with gauze: and tie it with the extremity of a fine thread, so that it does not break in the time of your constriction with the forceps.
Et oportet, ut exquisite agas cum scarificatione in circumitu gingiuae ab omni parte multum.	And it is necessary that you take care when you make incisions around the gums from all parts much.
Et custodi fortitudinem tuam, ut non frangas ipsum, et remaneat pars eius, et redeat super infirmum ex ea malicia quae sit maior dolore eius primo.	Be steadfast in your fortitude, lest you break your own spirit, and a part of it remain broken, and return upon the infirm from that malice which is greater than his initial pain.
Et caue, ne facias illud quod ignorantes faciunt phlebotomatores in festinatione sua, et audacia ipsorum super eradicationem eius, praeter quod administrent illud quod narrauimus.	Be cautious lest you do that which the unskilled do, phlebotomists in their frenzy, and overween their own eradication, besides that which we have mentioned
Multotiens enim faciunt euenire super homines infirmitates magnas, quarum difficiliores sunt ut frangantur, et remaneant radices eius omnes, aut quaedam earum: aut ut extrahant ipsum cum quibusdam ossibus mandibulae: sicut testificati sumus multotiens illud.	Many do indeed make their patients endure great illnesses, from which it is difficult to recover, and leave behind roots of their entire being, or extract some of them with teeth of the jaw: as we have often seen
Deinde colluatur post eradicationem eius cum uino, aut cum aceto et sale.	Then it is joined after its eradication with wine, or with vinegar and salt.
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis ex locis (multotiens enim accidit) tunc tere aliquid ex zegi, et imple cum eo locum: et si non, cauteriza ipsum si non confert tibi zegi.	When blood flows out from any place (for many do indeed flow out from their limb), then there is something from the limb which remains: and put in with it the cautery. If not, cauterize it if it does not give you the limb back.
Formae forcipum subtilium quibus mouetur dens in primis, sint longarum extremitatum, breuis manubrii, grossi, ut non duplicentur quando cum eis premitur super dentem: sint sicut uides grossorum manubriorum, donec quando stringis cum eis, non dent seipsas, neque duplicentur: breuium extremitatum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut ex faled decenter facti, directarum extremitatum: et in eorum extremitatibus sint dentes, quorum quidam ingrediantur in quosdam, et stringant constrictione decenti, forti.	The tweezers which are used to grasp the teeth in the first place are long-handled, short-handed, thick, so that they do not bend when pressure is put upon them: they are like large nails, until when they are bound to the tooth, they do not bite into themselves, neither do they bend: short-handled, and made of iron or of hammered steel, direct-handed, and in their handles are teeth, some of which enter into some of the others, and bind them together loosely, firmly
Et quandoque fiunt extremitates sicut forma oris auis quae nominatur ciconia, et sunt fortis constrictionis.	And when the handles become like the beak of a bird which is called a ciconia, and are strong in their constriction.
¶ De eradicatione Dentium, et extractione ossium mandibularum fractorum.	Of the eradication of teeth, and the extraction of fractured mandibular bones.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 1.
Quando remanet apud eradicationem Dentis qui frangitur aliquid, tunc oportet ut ponas super locum cotum cum butyro die uno, aut duobus diebus, donec mollificetur locus: deinde intromitte ad ipsum algasti, aut forcipes: quorum extremitates assimilantur ori auis quae nominatur ciconia.	When the tooth remains at the eradication of a fractured piece, then it is necessary to place butter on the place of the tooth for one or two days until the place is softened: then introduce into the cavity itself the ligature or forceps, the extremities of which absorb the hair which is called ciconia.
Forma autem haec est forcipum.	The form of these forceps is as follows.
Sint extremitates eorum factae sicut lima deintus: aut sicut aliskilfegi.	Their extremities are made like a file or like a pair of pincers
Si ergo non obedit tibi ad exitum cum istis forcipibus, tunc oportet, ut caues super radicem, et detegas carnem totam, et intromittas instrumentum quod nominatur Palanca parua, cuius forma est haec.	If, however, these do not suffice to bring about the evacuation [of the fractured fragment], then it is necessary to place a hook over the root and remove the whole flesh, and introduce the small hook, which is called Palanca, whose form is as follows
Sit breuis extremitatis, grossae parumper: et non sit imbibitum, ut non frangatur.	Its handle is short, its head large: and it is not to be wet, lest it break
Si ergo egreditur radix per illud, est bonum: et si non, iuuare oportet cum istis instrumentis aliis quorum formae sunt istae.	If the root comes out through this, that is good: and if not, it is necessary to burn with these instruments which have a similar form
Forma primi triangulatae extremitatis, in qua est quaedam grossitudo.	The first has a triangular-shaped extremity, in which there is some thickness
Forma triangulatae extremitatis subtilis.	The second has a slender triangular extremity.
Etiam iuuatur cum hoc instrumento habente duos ramos, cuius haec est forma.	It is also used with this instrument which has two branches, whose form is as follows.
Et cum aliis instrumentis et ferramentis quae praecesserunt in rasione dentium.	And with other instruments and materials which are suitable for teeth.
Etiam sit iuuamentum cum hoc instrumento quod assimilatur uncino magno, huius formae, triangulatae extremitatis tortae, in qua est quiddam grossitudinis, ut non frangatur: et sit non imbibitum.	It is also necessary to burn with this instrument which absorbs a large hair, of this form, triangular-shaped extremity which has some thickness, so that it does not break: and it must not be wet.
Et scias, quod instrumenta dentium sunt multa: et similiter reliqua instrumenta non computantur, et artifex prudens, subtilis in arte sua inuenit per se ipsum instrumentum, secundum quod significant ei operatio et aegritudines ipsae.	You know that there are many instruments for teeth: and similarly the rest of the instruments do not agree. And a skilled craftsman, skilled in his art, will himself find the most appropriate instrument for each operation and for the nature of the disease.
Quoniam ex agritudinibus sunt ad quas non dixerunt antiqui instrumentum, propter diuersitatem specierum earum.	Since they are from diverse sorts of instruments, these things are not mentioned by the ancients.
Si autem frangatur os ex mandibula, aut ex aliis ossibus oris, aut putrefit: tunc perscrutare super ipsum in loco suo cum eo quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis et forcipibus quae dixi in extractione radicum, et iuuare cum gesti, cuius forma est haec.	If the jawbone or any other bone of the mouth is fractured, or if it becomes corrupted: then it is necessary to explore above that [affected area] in its place with the instruments and forceps which I mentioned in the extraction of roots, and to handle it with care, since its shape is like this.</start_of_turn>
Sit in eo quiddam grossitudinis paulatim, ut stringatur, uel teneatur cum eo os, et non fugiat et uadat, donec egrediatur os: et restaura locum cum medicinis conuenientibus ad illud.	Let there be something of size in it which is gradually tightened, or held with the bone, so that it does not slip away and become loose until the bone is extruded: and restore the place with the physicians who are competent in that.</start_of_turn>
Si autem in osse est putredo parua, tunc rade ipsum a putredine sua, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	If there is only a small amount of decay in the bone, then remove it from its decay and care for it, until it is healed.</start_of_turn
De serratura Dentium eminentium super alios.	About the closing of a prominent tooth over the others.</start_of_turn
Caput XXXII.	End of book II.</start_of_turn>
Quando Dentes eminent non secundum cursum suum naturalem, foeda fit per illud forma: et praecipue quando accidit illud in mulieribus, et puellis, scilicet uenalibus.	When teeth deviate from their natural course, a wound is formed by that shape: and especially when this happens in women and girls, that is, in those who are in their menstrual period.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	Therefore it is necessary to consider this.</start_of_turn
Nam si dens est natus post dentem alium, et non locatur, uel est possibilis eius serratura, neque limatura ipsius: tunc eradica ipsum: et si est annexus cum dente alio, tunc incide ipsum cum isto instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	For if a tooth has grown after another tooth and is not placed, or if it is possible to close it, or to file it down: then extract it: and if it is connected to another tooth, then cut it off with this instrument which has this shape.</start_of_turn
Est simile rostro paruo, et fit ex ferro indo, acutae extremitatis ualde.	It is like a small face, made of iron, with acute extremities that are blunt.</start_of_turn
Et sit incisio tua qua ipsum incidis in diebus multis, et propter duriciem dentis, et ut non commoueatur alius ex dentibus.	And make your incision such that you do not injure the other teeth on many days, because of the hardness of the tooth, and so that it does not break.</start_of_turn
Si autem est eminens expositus limaturae suae: tunc lima ipsum cum lima ex indo, cuius forma est haec.	If, however, the exposed part of the limb is prominent: then apply the limb itself to the limb from inside, whose shape is like this.
Sit totum ex indo, et manubrium eius minutorum punctorum ualdae, sicut lima cum qua fiunt acus: cum quo limetur dens paulatim in diebus multis cum facilitate, ut non commoueatur dens, et cadat: deinde leni ipsum, in fine rade ipsum cum quibusdam rasoriis.	If, however, the exposed part of the limb is prominent: then apply the limb itself to the limb from inside, whose shape is like that of a needle. With this, the tooth is gradually softened in many days with ease, so that it does not become inflamed, and falls out: then soften it again, and finally bind it up with some dressings.
Quod si est dens, ex quo frangatur pars, et laedit linguam: tunc oportet ut limes eum etiam, donec auferatur asperitas illius fractionis, et aequetur: et applanetur, et non laedat linguam, neque corrumpat sermonem.	If the tooth is loose from which a part has fractured, and bites the tongue: then it is necessary to bind the limb even more tightly until the sharpness of that fracture has gone, and it is equal: and it is flattened, and does not bite the tongue, nor corrupt the speech.
¶ De retatione Dentium cum filis auri.	On the return of the tooth with threads.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter 33.
Quando accidit Dentibus anterioribus concussio et commotio a percussione, aut casu: et non potest infirmus stringere super illud quod comedit ut non cadat: et curasti eos cum medicinis stipticis, et non ualuit curatio: tunc ingenium in eis est, ut stringantur cum filo auri: quoniam argentum fit uiride, et putrefit post dies: sed aurum nunquam mutatur.	When it happens to the front teeth that concussion and displacement has occurred from a blow, or in the case: and the patient cannot hold the bite with his hand because of pain: and it is not useful to apply treatment for it: then it is necessary to know in the tooth itself that it must be bound with thread: for silver is easily tarnished, and putrefies after many days: but gold never changes
Et sit filum medium in subtilitate et grossicie secundum quantitatem quod capiat inter Dentes.	And let the middle thread be of moderate thickness and strength according to the quantity that it can grasp between the teeth.
Et forma quidem retationis est, ut accipias filum, et intromittas duplum eius inter duos dentes sanos: deinde texeas cum duabus extremitatibus fili inter dentes motos, siue unus sit, aut plures, donec peruenias cum tela usque ad dentem sanum alterius partis.	And the form of the return is that you grasp the thread and pass the loop through between two sound teeth: then you tie with two ends of the thread between the teeth that are loose, whether one or more, until you have reached with the thread until the sound tooth of the other part
Deinde itera texturam usque ad partem a qua incaepisti: et stringe manum tuam cum subtilitate et sapientia, donec non remoueatur prorsus: et sit constrictio tua qua stringis filum, apud radices dentium, ut non euadat.	And repeat the tying until you reach the part from which you began: and bind your hand with moderate skill and knowledge, so that it does not move forward: and let your constriction be such as to bind the thread at the roots of the teeth, so that it does not swell
Deinde incide extremitates fili superfluentes cum forficibus: et aggrega utrumque, et conuerte eas cum gesti: et occulta ipsas inter dentem sanum et dentem motum, ut non laedat linguam: deinde dimittatur ita strictum dum remanet.	Then insert the superabundant extremities with scissors: and gather each one together, and close them with the thumb: and hide them between the sound tooth and the moved tooth, so that it does not damage the tongue: then release it very tightly as it remains.
Si autem soluitur, aut inciditur, stringe eos cum filo alio, et stabit cum eo taliter tempore toto.	If, however, it is dissolved or fractured, string it with another thread, and keep it firm as for the whole time
Et haec est forma Dentium, et figura retationis duorum dentium sanorum, et duorum dentium motorum, sicut uides.	This is the form of a tooth, and the figure of the alternation of two sound teeth and two moved teeth, as with water.
Et quandoque fit, ut redeat dens unus, aut duo post casum urriusque in locis suis, et retentur sicut narrauimus, et remaneant: et non facit illud nisi artifex, prudens, et expertus.	And when it is necessary, as a tooth returns or two after falling out in their places, and returns as we have said, and remains: and it does not happen except by a skillful, prudent, and experienced artist.
Et quandoque aptatur aliquod ex ossibus uaccinis: et fit ex eo sicut forma dentis, et ponitur in loco, ex quo munitur dens et stringitur, sicut diximus: et remanet, et seruitur cum eo tempore longo.	And when something is adapted from bones or teeth: and it is made like a tooth in shape, and is placed in the place from which the tooth is extracted and bound, as we have said: and it remains, and serves for a long time
¶ De incisione ligamenti quod accidit sub lingua, et prohibet loquelam.	Regarding the incision of the ligament that happens under the tongue, and which prevents speech.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter XXIII.
Quandoque ligamentum hoc quod accidit sub lingua, est aut naturale, cum quo nascitur homo, aut accidentale, a uulnere quod iam consolidatum est.	When this ligament under the tongue happens naturally, as when a man is born, or accidentally by an injury that has healed.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi in capite eius in sinu tuo, et eleua linguam eius: deinde incide illud ligamentum neruosum per latitudinem, donec soluatur lingua a retentione sua.	And the operation in this case is to open the jaw of the patient in your hand, and lift up his tongue: then cut through that nerve of the ligament across its width, until the tongue is freed from its retention
Quod si in eo fuerit quiddam duriciei et nodationis, et fuerit illud ex consolidatione uulneris: tunc proiice in illud uncinum, et finde illud per latitudinem, donec incidas ligamentum, et soluatur nodatio.	Which, if there is something of hardness and nodulation, and if it comes from the consolidation of an injury: then cut into that tissue, and find the nerve of the ligament across its width, until you cut through the ligament and the nodule is freed
Et caue, ne sit fissura in profundo carnis, et incidas arteriam illic, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And thus, let there be no fracture in the depth of the flesh, and cut the artery there, and blood flow will be increased.
Deinde colluatur in uestigio incisionis cum aqua rosata, aut cum aceto, aut aqua frigida.	Then it shall be bound in the groove of the incision with rosewater, or vinegar, or cold water.
Deinde pone sub lingua licinium ex lino, quod teneat infirmus in omni nocte: ut non consolidetur secundo.	Then put under the tongue a piece of linen that will keep the patient warm throughout the night: so that it will not harden in the morning.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc pone super locum zegi tritum.	If blood flow is increased, then put over the place a bandage that is soaked in urine.
Si uero uincit te sanguis, tunc cauteriza locum cum cauterio lentiginoso, quod conuenit ad illud: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	If blood boils, then cauterize the place with a sponge cautery that is appropriate for this: then care for the patient with the rest of the treatment until he is healed.
¶ De extractione Ranulae quae fit sub lingua.	As for the extraction of a ranula that is under the tongue.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter 5.
Quandoque accidit sub lingua apostema quod assimilatur Ranae paruae, prohibens linguam ab operatione sua naturali: et fortasse magnificatur adeo, donec implet os.	When it happens under the tongue a small swelling that is a ranula, preventing the tongue from its natural action: and perhaps it will grow so much that it fills the mouth
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi coram sole: et considera apostema.	The operation in this is that you open the mouth of the patient in front of the ear: and you consider the swelling.
Si ergo uides ipsum fusci coloris, aut nigri, durum, cui non inuenit infirmus sensum: tunc non tangas ipsum, quoniam est cancer.	If therefore you see the swelling red or black, hard, which does not respond to the patient, do not touch it, because it is cancer
Et si est decliue ad albedinem, in quo est humiditas, tunc proiice in ipsum uncinum, et incide ipsum cum spatumili subtili, et libera ipsum ab omni parte.	And if it is inclined towards whiteness, in which there is moisture, then project into it a needle, and cut it with a fine scalpel, and free it from all around
Quod si uincit te sanguis in hora tuae operationis, tunc pone super ipsum zegi tritum, donec abscindatur sanguis: deinde redi ad operationem tuam, donec extrahas ipsum cum complemento eius.	If indeed blood boils in your hour of operation, then put over it a bandage soaked in urine, until the blood is stopped: then return to your operation until you have extracted it with its complement
Deinde colluatur cum aceto et sale: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then it is bound with vinegar and salt: and care for the rest of the treatment suitable for this, until it is healed.
¶ De curatione apostematis duarum Amigdalarum.	For the treatment of an abscess of two amygdalar.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter 6.
Quandoque accidunt inter guttur godad, id est, glandulae, quae similantur algodad, quae accidunt deforis: et nominantur duae Amigdalae: quas quando curas cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non sanantur, tunc considera.	When these things happen between the guttur godad, that is, the glands which are like peas, which happen outside: and which are called two amygdalas: when you cure them with what we said in the previous discourse, and they do not heal, then consider them
Si ergo est apostema durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro.	If there is a hard abscess, of a brown colour, with little sensation: do not touch it with iron
Et si est rubei coloris, et radix eius est grossa: tunc non tangas ipsum etiam cum ferro, timens fluxum sanguinis, imo dimitte ipsum, donec maturetur.	And if it is red in colour, and its root is large: do not touch it even with iron, fearing the flow of blood, rather let it go, until it matures
Et tunc aut perforabis ipsum: aut rumpetur per se.	And then you will either perforate it: or it will rupture by itself
Et si est albi coloris, rotundum, et est radix eius subtilis: tunc oportet ipsum incidi.	And if it is white in colour, round, and its root is thin: then you must cut it open
Et operatio in ipso est, ut consideres ante operationem suam, si quieuit apostema eius calidum quiete completum, aut imminuitur quadam diminutione: tunc ergo fac sedere infirmum coram sole, et caput eius sit in sinu tuo: et aperi os eius, et accipiat seruiens inter manus suas, et premat linguam eius inferius cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	And the operation in this is as follows: as you consider before your operation, if the abscess has become cold and quiet: then lie the patient with his head towards you: and open the abscess, and take out the pus between your hands, and pull down the tongue with an instrument of this shape
Fiat ex argento, aut aere, quod sit subtile sicut cultellus.	Do it with silver, or with air, which is subtle like a knife
Cum ergo premis cum eo linguam, et ostenditur tibi apostema, et cadit super ipsum uisus tuus: tunc accipe uncinum, et fige ipsum in amigdalam, et extrahe eam ad exteriora quantum potes, praeter quod trahas cum ea aliquid ex tunicis.	When you have finished with the tongue, and you see the abscess, and it has gone down on your hand: then take pliers, and hold it in the abscess, and extract the pus to the outside as much as you can, without pulling out anything from the clothes.
Deinde incide eam cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma quae sequitur.	Then strike the wound with the instrument whose form follows this.
Assimilatur forficibus: uerumtamen extremitates eius sint curuatae, ita quod orificium cuiusque earum est in directo alterius acute: unde cura ut sit ex ferro indo, aut alfuled imbibitum.	The instrument's tip should resemble that of scissors: its extremities are bent outwards so that the opening of each is opposite the other at an acute angle: hence care must be taken so that it does not slip or be imbued with alum.
Si autem non est praesens hoc instrumentum, tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili, cuius haec est forma.	If such an instrument is not available, then strike the wound with the spatula, whose form is similar to that of the instrument described above
Sit acutum a parte una, non acutum a parte altera.	It should be acutely angled from one side, not from the other side
Et postquam incidis amigdalam unam, incide alteram secundum hanc eandem speciem incisionis.	And after you have made an incision in one place, make an incision in the other place according to the same kind of incision.
Deinde post incisionem gargarizet infirmus cum aqua frigida, aut cum aceto et aqua.	Then let the patient gargle with cold water, or with vinegar and water.
Si autem accidat ei fluxus sanguinis, gargarizet cum aqua in qua bulliti sunt cortices granatorum: aut folia myrti, et similia illis ex stipticis, donec abscindatur fluxus sanguinis: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	If blood flows from the wound, make the patient gargle with water in which pomegranate seeds or myrtle leaves have been boiled: or similar substances like sponges, until the bleeding stops: then care for the wound until it has healed
Et quandoque nascuntur in gutture apostemata alia, praeter amigdalas duas.	And when there are formed in the throat after the swelling of the two tonsils
Incide ergo ea secundum quod dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum aequaliter.	Strike these accordingly as I have said in the incision of the two tonsils evenly
Et ego quidem iam medicatus fui mulierem ex apostemate, quod natum erat inter guttur eius, quod trahebat ad fuscedinem, pauci sensus, quod iam fere clauserat guttur: et mulier respirabat a meatu stricto, et iam prohibuerat ei comestionem, et potum aquae: et iam peruenerat ad mortem, si remansisset uno die, aut duobus diebus.	I too have seen a woman who was suffering from a swelling in her throat, which caused her to gasp for breath, little sense, and caused her to close her throat: and the woman died from this, either in one day or two days.
Et apostema tantum ascenderat, quod emiserat duos ramos, donec exierant super duo foramina nasi.	The swelling only ascended as far as to emit two branches, until it went out through the two nasal passages
Properaui ergo festinanter, et fixi in unum eorum uncinum.	I did this quickly and bound them together in one loop
Deinde traxi ipsum, et tracta ex eo est portio magna.	Then I drew it out, and from it there is a great part.
Deinde abscidi eam, ubi comprehendi ex foramine nasi.	Then I drew it out, and from it there is a great part.
Deinde feci illud ei quod processit ex foramine nasi altero.	Then I drew it out, and from it there is a great part from the other side of the nose
Deinde aperui os eius, et pressi linguam eius: et postea fixi uncinum in ipsum apostema: deinde abscidi ex eo partem eius, et non cucurrit ex eo nisi sanguis paucus: absolutum est ergo guttur mulieris, et incepit statim bibere aquam, deinde accepit ex cibo.	Then I opened its mouth and pressed its tongue: and afterwards I fixed a hook into it at that place: then I drew out a part of it, and there did not run out from it little blood: it is quite complete, for the woman's gut has become accustomed to it, and it immediately drinks water, and then takes food.
Non ergo cessaui incidere ex illo apostemate multotiens tempore longo: et apostema succedebat loco eius quod incidebam, donec prolongatum est nimis et cum ea illud.	It does not cease to cut from that place many times a long time: and the apostema follows the place where I cut, until it is prolonged too much and with it
Ingeniaui ergo, et cauterizaui apostema inter guttur.	I devised, and cauterized the apostema between the gut
Stetit ergo ab additione: deinde ambulaui a parte, et non sciui quid fecit Deus cum ea post me.	It stood from the addition: then I went from the part, and I do not know what God did with it after me
¶ De incisione apostematis uuulae.	Of the incision of the small apostema.
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter 7
Quando descendit catarrus ad uuulam, et apostematur, et est long: tunc ipsa nominatur perpendicularis: et si est in inferiori parte grossa, rotunda, tunc ipsa nominatur uua.	When the catarrus descends to the lower part, and there is an apostema, and it is long: then it is called perpendicular: and if it is in the lower part large and round, then it is called a loop
Quando curatur cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: et uides quod apostema calidum quieuit ab ea, et est subtilis: tunc oportet ut incidas eam.	When it is cured with that which we said in the explanation, and the cure does not suffice: and you see that the apostema is cold and quiet from it: then it is necessary to cut it off
Et quae ex ea est aggregata rotunda, et non est ei longitudo, et est sanguinea, aut fusci coloris, aut nigri, et non est ei sensus: tunc oportet ut deuites incisionem eius.	And what is aggregated round about it, and is not of its length, and is bloody, or of the colour of rust, or black, and has no feeling: then it is necessary to make an incision of it
In ea enim est timor super infirmum.	In every ailment there is fear over the infirm.
Oportet ergo quando uides eam secundum modum quem dixi ex albedine, et longitudine sua, ut facias sedere infirmum coram sole: et premas linguam eius cum instrumento, cuius praecessit narratio: deinde fige uncinum in uuam, et trahe eam inferius: et incide eam cum uno duorum instrumentorum quae dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum.	Whenever you deal with an ailment, fear is proper when you do as I have said in white, and in length, so that you make the infirm sit before the sun: and touch his tongue with an instrument whose precedent I have mentioned: then fix the knot in one, and draw it downwards: and cut through it with one of the two instruments which I mentioned in the incision of two amygdales.
Et oportet ut non incidas ex ea, nisi illud quod additur super naturalem terminum sine additione.	It is proper that you do not cut through from that which adds to the natural limit without addition.
Nam si tu incidis ex ea plus, laedes uocem et sermonem.	For if you cut through from that which adds to the natural limit, you will make the wound and the speech worse
