Deinde post incisionem utere eo quod narrauimus in incisione duarum amigdalarum: et cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then after the incision make use of that which we have narrated in the incision of two amygdales: and care for him, until he is healed.
Si autem terretur infirmus ab incisione: tunc oportet ut utaris ingenio in cauterizatione eius absque timore et pauore.	If however the infirm person returns from the incision: then it is proper that you use your ingenuity in the cauterization of his without fear and aversion.
Et modus cauterii in ea non est, nisi cum aqua acuta: et est, ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	And the mode of cauterization in this is not except with acute water: and it is that you place the head of the infirm person in your lap.
Deinde preme linguam eius cum instrumento quod diximus.	Then touch his tongue with the instrument which we mentioned.
Deinde accipe ex aqua quam dixi tibi in capitulo cauterizandi, et confice cum ea calcem non extinctam, et pone eam non spissam, neque subtilem, et imple ex ea concauitatem huius instrumenti, cuius haec est forma.	Then take from the water which I mentioned in the chapter on cauterization, and mix it with burnt lime, and put it on him not thick, neither thin, and make an incision from this with the help of this instrument
Sit extremitati eius in qua ponitur medicina concauitas, sicut concauitas cochlearis radii.	So that the extremities of it where the medicine is placed are of the shape of the cochlea of a radius
Et pone instrumentum cum medicina super uuulam ipsam: et infirmus sit iacens super latus suum, ut currat saliua ex ore eius ex intrinseca medicina, ut non descendat ex ea ad guttur ipsius aliquid, et laedat ipsum.	And place the instrument with the medicine on the thing itself: and the infirm person lies on his side, so that the moisture from his mouth comes out from the medicine from within, so that it does not go down into his gut and harm him
Deinde tene manum tuam cum medicina.	Then take your hand with the medicine.
Et tu ex primas eam super uuulam quantitate medietatis horae, donec uideas eam iam denigratam, et sedatam mordicationem medicinae.	And you from the first part put it above the wound quantity of half an hour, until you see the wound has diminished, and then cease the biting of the medicine.
Et si uis ut accipias cotum, et inuoluas ipsum super extremitatem radii, et infundas cotum cum medicina, et intromittas radium cum coto in cannulam desuper, donec adhaereat cotum super uuulam.	And if you wish to take hold of the limb, and cover it with the medicine itself over the end of the radius, and fill the limb with the medicine, and introduce the radius with the thumb into the cannula above, until the limb adheres to the wound over half an hour
Fac illud multotiens, donec consequaris quod uis de cauterizatione uuae.	Do it many times, until you follow that you wish for the cautery of the vein
Deinde dimitte eam: ipsa namque arescit et cadit post tres dies, aut quatuor.	Then let go of the medicine: itself will dry and fall off in three days, or four.
Quod si indiges ut iteres medicinam, itera ipsam: et post cauterizationem absterge in circumitu uuae cum coto imbibito in butyro, et mundifica cum eo quod est in circumitu eius ex medicina: et colluatur cum aqua frigida.	And if you think it is necessary to go over the medicine, go over it: and after cauterization remove the surrounding area of the vein with the thumb, and moisten with butter, and bandage with the same as was in the surrounding of the medicine: and cool it with cold water.
Et curetur extrinsecus cum embrocis, et deintus cum gargarismis, donec sanetur.	And take care of the outside with sutures, and of the inside with gargling, until it is healed
Haec ergo species curationis est salubrior incisione et longinquior a timore.	Thus is this kind of treatment safer than an incision and longer lasting in fear
Et quandoque curatur uuula etiam cum eo quod est subtilius quam cauterium et incisio: curatur enim cum suffumigatione, secundum hunc modum.	And when the wound is healed even with this medicine that is subtler than cautery and incision: it is healed by fumigation, according to this method.
Sume calamentum, et hyssopum, et origanum, et rutam, et sseah, et chamomillam, et abrotanum, et similia eis ex herbis: et aggrega ea omnia, aut quaedam eorum in olla, et submergantur cum aceto, et bulliant: et olla sit lutata cum luto decenter: et sit in medio ollae foramen, super quod componatur instrumentum concauum secundum hunc modum.	Take calamine, and hyssop, and origanum, and rue, and asa, and chamomile, and marjoram, and similar things from herbs: and gather them all together, or some of them in a pot, and immerse them in vinegar, and boil: and the pot should be covered with a lid: and there should be a hole in the middle of the pot, above which is made a concave instrument according to this method.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	Let air or silver issue forth: and let the extremity be introduced into that which contains the pomegranate, until the vapor rises up to the upper opening of the tube, until the upper part becomes dark much.
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	Then repeat over the much, until it softens.
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	And be careful, lest you perform this treatment at the beginning of an attack of fever.
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	Praise be to you: for in fever there is to be added in the bowels: and it does not be necessary to do this except when the fever has subsided
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	But if this instrument is not present to you, then take the tube and compound in its extremity bark or resin: that it does not burn the bone of the sick: for the bark of the resin hinders the vapor from burning the bone: and this is from a good treatment with health.
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	About the extraction of thorns and bones from the gullet.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter XXXVIII.
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	Many things adhere to the gut: fish bones, or thorns, or something else.
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	It is necessary therefore that you extract what is seen to have fallen down from the gut, after you have moved the tongue with the instrument at the epiglottis, and declared that it is in the gut
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	And that which is not seen by you and is hidden in the gut, it is necessary that you make the sick vomit before food is digested in the stomach
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	Perhaps therefore also the thing that is annexed will go out with the vomit.
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	Or the sick person may swallow a piece of poppy seed, or the root of lettuce, or swallow a dry piece of bread: or take a dry piece of sponge of the sea and bind it up, and then swallow it down
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	When it has reached the place where the bones or spines are, or are extracted, it then departs.
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	If it does not depart with that which we have said: then use an instrument of lead in this fashion.
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.	Let it be thicker than a small radius, and have a curvature at its end, which intrudes into its gut without difficulty: and let its head be elevated above itself.
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	Beware of its touch upon the epiglottis, so that it does not cause it to swell, and drive out with it the bone, or the spine, or be carried in by the physician’s hand itself
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	However that the patient intrudes it, that is better: because of his knowledge of the place of the thing annexed: and he drives downwards, or pulls his hand with the instrument upwards, the whole thing according to the quantity which is prepared for it, until it departs
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	Of the extraction of the blood-sucker
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter XXXIX.
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When the physician has treated the blood-sucker with that which I have mentioned in the treatise on care with the physicians, and it does not yield, then consider in the belly of the patient at the sole or behind the tongue after you have drawn out its tongue with the instrument which I mentioned to you.
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	If therefore your instrument should fall upon the blood-sucker, draw it out with a small hook, or with a handle held loosely in the middle
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	If that is not possible with the hook: then take a curved needle, and introduce it into the belly of the patient up to near the gut: then introduce into the curve of the needle a burning iron with fire.
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Do this often: and let the patient abstain from all water for the whole day.
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Then he shall take a full treatment of cold water and open its mouth in it: and he shall join his jaw with it and he shall not swallow anything from it: and he shall drink water an hour after the other with his hand.
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	The blood-sucker will be almost finished when he feels the water falling.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	But if he does not depart with it as we have said, then he must fumigate the patient with sponges, or with an instrument as I have mentioned in fumigation of the fistula.</start_of_turn>
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	Do this often, for it goes away by itself.</start_of_turn>
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	And the manner of operation in fumigation is that you take a vessel in which there are grapes of vitriol with fire: and the vessel is covered with a cover, in the middle of which is a hole: and you make an incision in that hole with the instrument.</start_of_turn
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	Then he throws away the fumigation and places the patient's jaw at the end of the tube, and closes his jaw, so that it does not escape the fumigation, until you know that the fumigation has passed to the blood-sucker.</start_of_turn
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	For the blood-sucker immediately goes away.</start_of_turn>
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	And if it does not go away, then repeat the fumigation often.</start_of_turn>
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	And the patient can tolerate to remain sitting, and eat garlic and onions, and does not drink water.</start_of_turn
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	It is necessary therefore that he depart with this regimen.</start_of_turn
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	And this is the form of the instrument with which the blood-sucker is extracted from the gut when it falls upon the said vomit.</start_of_turn
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	It is like tweezers, thus: except that it has this curvature which enters the gut.</start_of_turn
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	And its extremity is like the wing of an owl named ciconia, in which there is coarseness of the lime: when it grasps something, it does not relinquish it entirely.
¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	And concerning the opening of abscesses, their section, and their care in general
Caput XL.	Chapter 40.
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	There are many kinds of abscesses, of various modes, according as the nature of the reminder of them is remembered: and they are diverse in their perforation and section into two modes.
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	One of them is the species of abscess which is from the moisture of the body itself.
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	The other is that which happens from the body itself
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	For indeed an abscess which happens in the head is different from an abscess which happens in the belly: and an abscess which happens in a fleshy part is different from an abscess which happens in a joint: and each one of them has its own judgment concerning the operation.
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	And concerning abscesses there are some which do not require perforation except after the completion of health in them, and the completion of their nourishment: and there are some which require perforation while they are raw and have not matured according to their nourishment.
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	For example, abscesses which are close to joints
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	Because an abscess when it happens near a joint and prolongs itself, until it putrefies, which is around it, perhaps the ligaments or nerves of that joint are corrupted: which is the cause of the closer contraction of that limb
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	Or an abscess near a principal limb: because if you delay its perforation until it matures, it will cause pain or swelling or both in that principal limb
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	If it be close to a hair, perforate it therefore immediately: and it is not necessary, when perforating, to leave a crude stool, not fully digested, except when it is close to a hair, that it not putrefy deeply, and extend to the interior of the rectum, and make a fistula, or remain in its termination which does not heal.
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	It is necessary to know the time of perforation of the stool, which is mature according to its completion: and it is with respect to the sedation of pain, recession of fever, and decrease of redness, and pulse, and the sharpness of the head of the stool: and the rest of the signs.
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	It is necessary to make the perforation in a lower place of the stool, and immediately above the prominence: and let the perforation be wide in length of the body, if the stool is in the parts of the hands and feet, and places of laceration, and strings, and nerves, and arteries, and finally in all the places equally, where there is no reflection
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	And in those which reflect, act with the perforation according to that member.
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	When the stool is in places of hardness: then it is better to omit the perforation of it, until its digestion is confirmed, as we have said according to its completion.
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	Because if you perforate it before that, you prolong the course of the disease from that, and there is much pain and swelling, and perhaps they will swell its lips, and depth of it
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	And some stools are perforated according to the width of the body in necessity: or according to that which the member requires
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	And it is necessary to administer in small stools a moderate perforation, and in large stools a wide perforation: or many sections similar to the magnitude of the stool.
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	And there are from the apostemata, in which it is necessary that the skin should be concaved: and it occurs when it has been made like a cloth, and has been made at the end, because it is dead: as it happens with many things, as with a dubelet and with boils.
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	And there are those which are cut through with a section having three angles.
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	And there are those which occur like the figure of a myrtle leaf
Sicut apostema inguinum.	Like a groin apostema
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	And there are those in which a round section and a lunar section are administered: and similar things are from sections
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	That which has no head, like the superficial lenious apostemata, must be perforated through a superficial perforation or flattened only.
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	And it is necessary, when the apostema is great and has collected much matter, to perforate it, so that it does not burst and draw out all the pus at once: rather extract from it a part of it immediately
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	Then anoint the apostema until another day.
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	Then extract some of the pus again.
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	Do this many times according to the degree [of severity]: especially if the patient is weak of spirit, or a pregnant woman, or a young child, or an old man: for the spirit of the animal is dissolved from the animal with the evacuation of the matter: and perhaps the patient will die, and you will not perceive it.
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	Therefore take heed of this chapter, for it contains great caution
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	And after you have perforated the apostema, which you have perforated, it is necessary to remove the wool: and consider carefully
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	If there is a small wound from a fracture, either perform a plane section or administer lead from an old vessel.
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	If the fracture is large and there are many holes in the perforation, it is necessary to administer medication into every wound until it reaches the innermost area
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	If you have excised a piece of skin from the fracture, or if you have bound the circumference too tightly: then you must apply an old vessel or as much lint as before, or cover it with wool without moisture: and keep it tight until the third day.
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	Then remove it and care for it as is necessary until it heals
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	If there is bleeding during your operation in this hour, then administer cold water and vinegar, after they have been absorbed into a cloth: and put it over the place of bleeding profusely
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	If the bleeding persists, then you must administer a regimen and treatment, and powders, which I have mentioned in many places in this book, and from experience.
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	If it is winter and the place of the fracture is full of nerves: then you must infuse lead with wine, and warm fat: and put it over the place.
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	And if it is summer and the place is fleshy: then you must put soaked sponges in water, or fat, or both with wine and fat, and keep it cold.
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	Until then, as we have said, on the third day you must drain the fracture, remove it, and administer treatment that is suitable for it until it heals.
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	This is what is necessary for the knowledge of the treatment of fractures in general
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	According to the method of distinguishing the signs, as I have already mentioned concerning every apostemate, how it is possible to cure it is explained in a singular chapter.
¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	Regarding the excision of apostemata that occur in the scalp.
Caput XLI.	Chapter XLI.
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	Small apostemata appear on the scalp and are of the kind known as knots, which contain tunica, which is like a sack: they are like little roosters' houses
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	There are many kinds of these.
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	Some are hard: others contain moisture like mud: others moisture like wet clay and stones.
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	In the excision of all of them, and their extraction, there is no fear, as long as one does not damage the arteries during the process.
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	The operation in the excision of these is as one must learn with the instrument which has a form like that which comes after these, which is called Intromissum, until you know what it contains
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	For if it contains moisture, dry it out by cutting through it superficially: in this way.
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	Begin from line b to line g. When the moisture has been evacuated, remove the knot which contains it, do not leave any residue behind
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	There is much risk if any residue is left behind
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then immerse the area in Egyptian unguent if it is present: or in water and salt: and apply with the willow and let it go until tomorrow
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	This dries up what remains of the knot
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then repeat above the said hip with the second and third finger, and if you find it not yielding, until you are confident that nothing remains of the boil, then indeed care for the wound with an unguent until it is healed.
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	If there is a nodulus of fat remaining in the abscess: then dry that up again in this fashion, with a section having the shape of a cross: and project the nails between the two lobes of the section, and scour it from every part: and try your skill in extracting the sac which contains it.</start_of_turn>
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	If, however, it makes resistance against you, an artery is probably involved, then do as I shall tell you afterwards.</start_of_turn>
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	Do the same with a stone abscess, by section and care in the same way as before.</start_of_turn
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	And the section of a stone abscess is easier: because there is little blood and moisture.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	And sometimes there are hours of abscesses which are in the head of some men, in which there is no moisture at all.</start_of_turn
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	Which is: because I have seen above an abscess in the head of a maidservant, and I found the abscess like a solid stone, hard, rough, white, which could not be broken: and if it was pierced with anything, it would burst.</start_of_turn
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	In other abscesses of the head which occur, besides these, such as abscesses which occur in the heads of children, and at the roots of the ears, the section of them is all superficial.</start_of_turn
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	Or make the perforation always from below upwards, so as to direct the course of the healing towards below.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	Then care for that which is fitting for them from the care.
¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	Then care for that which is fitting for them from the care of the throat section
Caput XLII.	Chapter 42.
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	Many of these wounds happen in the throat, under the armpits, and in the groin: and sometimes in other parts of the body.
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	And over these which happen in the throat, there are one or many: and they are generated from each one: and every Strophe is within its own tunic, as in the nodes and the head wounds which we have mentioned
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	There are many kinds of these Strophes
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	And from these there are soft: and there are those which contain humours: and there are malignant ones, which do not obey care
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	In this way, as the good humours are disposed in the touch, whose mark is the proximity of the colour of the skin, and which moves to all parts, and is not connected with the nerves of the throat, neither with the gullet, neither with the arteries, neither is it deep: it should be cut off with a superficial section from the upper part to the lower part of the body from the line, b. to the line, g. and be stripped from all sides: and extend two lips of the skin with a single layer, or with several layers if necessary, as we said in the head wounds, and pull out the contents little by little.
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	And it is with caution that one does not touch the bone, or the nerve
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	And let the blade be neither too acute nor too blunt: so as not to add your hand to the incision, or to frighten the patient, and cut only what is necessary
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	If, however, you cut a vein, or an artery, or are hindered by the operation, then put in the wound a piece of charred wood, or some powders which absorb blood, and tighten the wound, and leave it until the pain of the wound has ceased, and the wound has become soft: or else you will begin to putrefy it
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	Blood is severed by the clamp Redi therefore to the operation, until completion.
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	Then inquire with your finger, if anything remains from the other trocars: therefore cut easily, and wash away.
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	If it is in the root of the trocar a large one: then it is necessary that you do not cut that trocar from its root: rather it is necessary that you bind it with a strong doubled thread, and let it go until it falls off by itself without any pressure
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	Then apply a sponge soaked in Egyptian unguent under the area that you have submerged in the blood
Deinde cura ipsum.	Then care for yourself.
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	If the trocar is cut entirely, then it is necessary that you bring together the two lips of the wound: and hold these themselves immediately, after you have washed because there remains no excess.
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	If however you find that there remains excess blood because of the size of the trocar, then it is necessary that you extend to the cutting of its root and extract it: and administer the suture as we have said.
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	And what is contained from the trocar must be perforated with a superficial perforation: so that its maturity may appear: and place the perforation from that which follows below the body, as we have said
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then administer after the perforation, sponges with unguents, and similar things, so that it may consume that which remains from the corruption, until when you wash the wound will be found to be healed: then care for yourself with the unguents of generation of flesh until it is healed
¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	Regarding the excision of the epiglottis from the epiglottic cartilage accidentally in the gut.
Caput XLIII.	Chapter XLIII.
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	They say that the ancients performed this excision of the epiglottis, and no one in our land has ever done it: and this is the record of their sermon
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	When the throat is swollen with swelling of the epiglottis, it is necessary to make an incision of the epiglottis: for if this does not take place, all the veins and lungs will be weakened.
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	When there is a hard swelling in the throat, in the gullet, or in the tonsils, when there is no inflammation of the channel, it is necessary to perform an incision of the epiglottis to escape from the destruction which results from the obstruction.
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	It is necessary therefore, when we wish to perform this operation, to cut the epiglottis under three or four circles of the epiglottis, with a small incision in the middle of the two circles, so that the section is in the fat, not in the cartilage: and this is the most suitable place for the incision, because it is devoid of flesh, and the blood vessels from it are long.
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	If the physician is timid, it is necessary to extend the skin of the throat with one finger.
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	Then find the skin, until it reaches the channel: there will be bleeding from it at that point
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	Then cut the fat which we have mentioned: and it is signified over the incision of the channel by the phlegm which comes out of it, when it is ruptured, and by the cutting of the vessel.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	And let the wound be open for some time.
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	When the time has passed in which the obstruction has disappeared, gather together the two lips of the wound in the skin, and close it only with skin without cartilage.
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Then give medicines which cause the flesh to heal, until it is healed
Inquit Albucasis.	Thus spoke Albucasis.
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	The sum of this sermon which we have narrated is not an exposition, except when someone has seen that some of the aftereffects of the disease have already become softened in the gut of the patient: and the patient has died, and he desires to cut across his desire. They go to dissect Epiglottis so that the patient can breathe in the place of the wound which is causing his respiration to be difficult, and they rejoice at his death. Because of this they have commanded the opening of the wound until the malice of the disease has passed away. And it is the malice of this disease for three days, and like itself. Then they have commanded the closing of the wound and its treatment until it is healed.
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	And what I have seen myself is that a handmaid took a knife and put it into his gut, and it went into the part of the lung canal.
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	I was called to his care, and I found him spitting blood, like a dead man.
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	I saw that there was a wound there, and blood had escaped from the small wound
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	I was amazed, because neither the wound had burst open, nor did the intestines guide her: and the wind was coming out of the wound.
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	I did this, and I closed the wound, and I treated him, until he was healed: and the handmaid did not suffer anything, except that she coughed in the water. And she returned after a few days to a better state of health.
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	Henceforth it is clear that there is no fear in the section of Epiglottis
¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	About the section of the hernia of the gut.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter XLIV.
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	This aftereffect is called a hernia of the gut, is a great aftereffect, according to the colour of the body: and it is very common in women
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	There are two possibilities: either it is natural, or it is accidental.
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	Certainly not natural is the origin of it
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	Accidental is indeed according to two modes: one of which is like a knot of fat.
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	The other mode is like the outgrowth of an artery from a knotting
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	And in this is fear, and it is not right to assume it simply with the iron, except in the case where it is slight: you must try it and investigate it with the intestines
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	If indeed you find it like a knot of fat, and it is not suspicious with any other swelling: then dry it off like knots are dried: and extract it with the thing which contains it from the cyst, if it is in a cyst: or if not, then explore all of it
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the place with the thing which should be cured until it is healed.
¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	Regarding the cutting of things which are greater than knots.
Caput XLV.	Chapter XLV.</start_of_turn>
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	There are many kinds of knots, and I have mentioned all of their kinds in the explanation: and it is necessary to know the difference between a knot and an extrusion in case of doubt
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	I say, when an extrusion has become lukewarm, and fever, and pain which accompany it, until the heat of excess has passed away and the putrefaction has ceased: then indeed calm down the fever and heat
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	When a knot does not have lukewarmness, neither fever, neither pain, and contains within itself a cyst which is its own sac, which is according to the colour of the body: and it is an inclusion like millet, and makes like batter, and is greater and smaller.
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	There are two kinds: either fat or containing moisture.
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	The colours of moisture are many, as I said in the discourse on moisture
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	It is necessary therefore, when you are dealing with the cure of a Node, to experiment with it and inquire about it first with the instrument which is called the Intromissum, as its form will be found in the following chapter
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	The way to inquire about the posterior parts and of all Nodes is to take hold of this instrument and introduce it into the moist place which you find in the posterior part: and withdraw your fingers gradually until you know that the instrument has penetrated the skin
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Then finally touch the hand according to the measure of the size of the posterior part
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	Then withdraw the Intromissum and consider what has come out through its wound
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	If therefore moisture is running out, whatever its colour: then dry it out with a superficial section, as I have said in the remaining sections concerning the posterior part
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	If it does not run out, then you know that it is fat: dry it out therefore with a section having the shape of a cross, as it has been taught you: and suspend it with hooks, and scrape the skin from all sides with ease: and hold the fat in place if you can, until you have extracted it whole with the Node
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	If however the sac is ruptured during the operation, and it is not possible to extract it whole: much the same happens in this case, then extract it fragment by fragment, until nothing remains of it
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	For if anything remains of it, little or much, the Node returns in most cases.
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	If it swells and remains small: then make a hole beside your completion and pour in corrosive powders of sharpness: and bind up the hole, and place above it what rests upon the soft cushion, and care for it with the rest of the treatment, until it is healed.
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	If there is a large knot, then cut through its two lips, and care for it as that which has been incarnated
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	If however there is a swelling that is painful, or that does not swell: then cleanse it, and make an incision in the place where the swelling is greatest, and drain it out for two or three days, until the swelling has gone down, and the blood has clotted: and then return to the original condition
¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	As to the instruments for the cutting and perforating of the wound.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter XLVI.
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	There are three forms of instruments for the introduction of instruments, and there are three sorts.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	The first is large, the second is medium, and the third is small
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	Let the first be of iron, the square end of which is blunt in the middle, so that it facilitates the entrance into the swelling
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	And these are the forms of the instruments of the experienced, and no, that is, perforating: and one of them is called the beris, that is, the perforator, and there are three sorts
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	The first is large, the second is medium, and the third is small
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	They join together, that they may investigate the swelling, and the exits, and the fistula, and the abscesses from that which is between the bones
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	And others are round, and square, and flat, like a great needle which sews under silk, from citrine or from air, or from iron, or from silver
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	And the better things are those which come from the citron.
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	And experience is also derived from black lead, which, when applied to these fistulas, causes them to reflect like glass with their smoothness.
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	There are three things in number.
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	For as regards the size of the wound, it is either wide, medium, or narrow, according to the quantity of the diameter of the fistula and the degree of its constriction
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	The shape of the wounds is diverse, and there are many kinds of them
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	For as regards their kind, there are simple wounds, which have but one curvature: and there are three kinds of them, like liquids, large, medium, and small
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	There are blind wounds also: and there are three kinds of them
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	There are wounds with two curvatures: and there are three kinds of them; and there are wounds with three curvatures: and there are three kinds of them; all of which are necessary in their place
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	And these are the forms of scalpels, with which the knots are cut and excoriated, and abscesses: and there are three kinds of them, for as regards their size, they are either large, medium, or small
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	Their extremities which are cut are acute, and the others are not acute: and they are not to be placed in this way, except when there is an imposition of healing upon the excision of the knots at the fear of the incision of the vein, or nerves: and that the healing may take place through this and not through excessive bleeding during the excision of the abscess
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	These are magdas, and there are three kinds of them
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	They are formed from air, and are like radium, as with which alcohol is made: and at their widest end is a hidden Spatumilis point: and in it runs inwards and outwards as desired, like water.
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	The points of Spatumilis which are driven between the fingers at the perforation of the apostematum: and they are not perceived by the sick: and there are three kinds, large, medium, and small.
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	The exhalations of the veins when the flow of blood is broken: and there are three kinds, large, medium, and small
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	They are formed from air, or from lemon juice, round, about the length of a palm, like water: and they are transparent.
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	And it is necessary that these kinds of veins be large and small with you: in order to break the blood quickly when necessary, and then when it is not there a doctor is not present.
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	However, do not use these things for the breaking of blood in any place of the body, and do not use them except in places where there is carnation: such as wounds of the leg, and hip, and wounds of the arm, and breast, and belly, and groin, and similar places, from wounds of carnation, humors.
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	And sometimes these things become other small instruments like the edges of fists, according to their form: with which the blood is broken when it flows out from the place of phlebotomy, or at the incision of a vein, or an artery: and sometimes these things become round according to this form.
¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	As for the care of the breasts of men who suckle the breasts of women.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter XLVII.
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	When the breasts of some men swell with sleep (that is, when they begin to soil during sleep) until they resemble the breasts of women: and they remain with post-traumatic fever.
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	Whoever loathes that [disease], must secrete above the nipples a section like a crescent, from this line to that line, and then scrape off the fat altogether.
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	Then apply an ointment of mercury from the medicine box.</start_of_turn>
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then join together two lips of the wound with sutures, and care for it until it heals.</start_of_turn>
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	If however the nipple turns downwards, and is softened by its size, as often happens with women: then it is necessary to find in the two upper sides two sections like the crescent, each one containing the other at the ends as far as the greater line contains the lesser, according to this shape from this line to that line, b. to that line, g. Then scrape off the skin which is between the two lips, and remove the fat, and administer what we have said concerning the sutures and powders, which is necessary for the cure, until it heals.</start_of_turn>
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	If however you do not wish to perform an incision of it because of the patient's anxiety or because of bleeding: then you must apply a poultice soaked in corrosive unguent under the wound, and let it go, until it has eaten away what remains of the fat.</start_of_turn>
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.</start_of_turn>
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	In the perforation of the apostematis, which happens under the nipple.</start_of_turn
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter XLVIII.</start_of_turn>
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	These apostemata which happen under the nipple, are of the kind of hard Strophula, which contains vesicles, and from these are those which contain humours.</start_of_turn
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Which are from the humours which contain moistures, must be cut away with a crescent-shaped section, according to this shape from this line to that line, b. to that line, g. and when all that is in the apostemata is evacuated from the blood, then apply a poultice to the old wound, and let it go until another day.</start_of_turn
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then the foot shall be raised up, and cared for with an unguent suitable for it, until it is healed.
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	If the swelling be from a kind of knot of the Strophular kind, then it must be cut above the same, as we said in the section on the Strophulas which are equal.
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	If, however, a boil extends in this way as to emit pus, then apply cautery to it, according to what has been said previously.</start_of_turn>
¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	As for the section of a boil which happens because of an artery and a vein.</start_of_turn>
Caput XLIX.	Chapter XLIX.</start_of_turn>
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When an artery is ruptured, and the skin above it is consolidated, then there is much swelling from the boil: and in the same way, a vein is also ruptured, as in the case of the boil and the swelling.</start_of_turn
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	And the signs by which it is known that the swelling is from an artery and a vein, are: because when the swelling is from an artery, it is long and aggregated in the depth of the body: and when the swelling is from an infected wound of the fingers, you feel as if there is a constriction there.</start_of_turn
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And that which is from a vein, is round in the open part of the body.</start_of_turn
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	And the section of this boil is dangerous, especially when it is under the armpits, and the groin, and the neck, and in many parts of the body: and it is very dangerous.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	Therefore it is necessary to take care of it with iron, and that which is from the outside also in the extremities, or in the head, it is necessary to take care of it.</start_of_turn
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	Concerning that which is from the outside, from the swelling of the orifice of the artery, find in the skin in the section in length.</start_of_turn
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then open the part with hooks, afterwards the artery: and loosen the gut from the tunic until it is detached.
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then insert the hook under this and make the gut penetrate through to the other side, and bind the artery with a doubled thread in two places, as you were taught concerning the extraction of two arteries which are in the belly
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	Then bite the place which is between two ligatures with the ligature needle, until the blood which is in it has gone out, and the clot is dissolved.
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then apply an antidote which produces pus, until the ligatures fall off: afterwards care for this with suitable unguents until it is healed.
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	As for a clot which has happened from a vein, then it is necessary to take out the hand which is possible from the clot with the skin.
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Then insert the hook under the place where you held your hand, and make the gut penetrate: and there be in it a doubled thread, until you have pulled it out from the other side.
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	Then bind with this very clot the gut which is in this place: according to what I have told you concerning the ligature of a vein, from two parts with two extremities of thread.
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	If however you fear that the thread is being pulled out, then insert another hook with another thread under the whole clot at the incision of the needle: first of all, and bind your thread in four places
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	Then dry the clot in its middle, until when it comes out what is in it: then cut off the excess of the skin, and discharge that which is bound from it
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	Then put upon this the powder which you submerged in wine, and fat.
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then apply a cure which is made with salves and unguents, until it is healed
¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	Concerning the swelling which occurs from the torsion of nerves.
Caput L.	Concerning the swelling which occurs from the torsion of nerves.
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	Just as swelling occurs in arteries and veins due to torsion, in the same way swelling occurs in nerves: which occurs either from percussion or from excessive tension, or in like manner: and it often happens in the armpits, or the calves, and in every place where nerves are twisted together: and it is a serious swelling.
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	It is similar in color to the rest of the body, and it is found in various positions without pain: and when it is grasped with force, a numbness similar to that of intoxication is felt in it
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	It is not a swelling that is collected in the depths of the body, but rather under the skin, and it moves to every part, and does not go forward or backward or downwards.
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	Because it is in the twisted parts, it is not necessary to suture it with iron.</start_of_turn>
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	Perhaps some contraction will occur against it.
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	And in that which is in the head, or in the face, find the skin with a spatula.</start_of_turn>
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	If it is a small swelling, then hold it with forceps and cut it off from its root.</start_of_turn
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	If it is large, then suspend it with a thread and scrape it off: then remove it and join the wound with a suture: and care for it until it heals.</start_of_turn
¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	Concerning the section of the swelling which occurs within.</start_of_turn>
Caput LI.	Concerning the section of the swelling which occurs within.</start_of_turn
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	It often happens to many people in the depths of their bodies, and in the rest of their bodies, these things which are called Fungalia, because they are similar to fungi.</start_of_turn
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	When the root is slight and the head is large, and the lips are joined together.
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	When the root is slight and the head is large, and the lips are closed together.
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	And I saw a man who had two holes in his belly, which were larger than any other like unto mushrooms: there was no difference between them, neither in the white nor in the root, and they were closed together, and moisture ran out of him always.
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	I saw a man who had two holes in his belly, which were larger than any others like unto mushrooms: there was no difference between them, neither in the white nor in the root, and they were closed together, and moisture ran out of him always.
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	Many are expelled from its section with much blood: therefore if blood incites you, then cauterize it.
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	If you see the sickly and timid patient from the incision with the iron, then take a leaden wire made in the center and string it with it: which way is that which we have said, and discharge it in two days.
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	Then add lead to the stricture.
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	Do not cease to string the lead, whenever it prints in the wound, until it is detached, and falls away by itself without toil
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	If, however, the wound is large of the root, then in its incision is something of fear and weakness: especially because of that which is within.
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	But it is possible that you can cut through the middle of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	Then cauterize it, so that it does not return.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then care for it, until the wound is healed
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	And be careful lest you presume to cut through the wound which is of a dark color, little sense, bad appearance: for that is a tumor: and I will remind you of cancer after this
¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	Of the care of the belly wound.
Caput LII.	Chapter 52.
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	The belly wound comes from many cuts.
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	Or from incisions of the flesh which are over the belly: and it exits from the opening in the side, or the intestines, according as happens in the rest of the ruptures
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	Or from the blood which flows from the vein, or from the artery, as has been said before
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	Or from swelling which is contained within it.
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	Or if it is because of a burst abscess, and the opening of the wound: then is the colour of the pus like that of the body: and it is soft, without pain: and appears in diverse places.
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	Or if it is because of the discharge of an intestine, then is its site as we have mentioned, with greater diversity of place.
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	When you touch it with your finger, it is hidden: then it returns, and sometimes there is a sound like that: and it swells greatly at the entrance of the bath, and causes great pain
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	Or if it is because of moisture, it is soft: then it does not hide when you touch it with your hand, neither does it tighten, neither does it increase in size.
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	Or if it is because of blood, then it appears with these signs like a black clot at the edge of the wound
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	Or if it is because of dead tissue: then it is a thick, large, hard pus, and is formed according to the quantity of one thing.
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	Or if it is because of swelling, then its touch is soft.
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	And the treatment for it is as you consider, if the prominence of the navel is because of blood in the Artery or Vein or swelling: then it is necessary to abstain from treatment for it
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	For in this case there is fear and danger, just as I taught you in the chapter where I spoke of pus arising from an artery or vein.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	Or if the prominence of the navel is because of an intestine or a bladder: then it is necessary to expel the sick person, as long as he continues to belch, and to keep him still lying down.
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	Then signs with encasement throughout the circumference of the belly.
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	Then command him to lie between your hands over his back
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	Then circle around with a broad spatula in the circumference of the belly over the place where you encased it.
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	Then stretch out the middle of the belly towards the upper parts, with a large hook
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	Then bind him firmly in the circumference with a strong thread, or with a silk cord: and let the knot of the ligation be firm.
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	Then open up the middle of the belly that was stretched out above the ligament.
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	If you find the intestines caught by the ligation: then draw out the encasement, and introduce the index finger into it, and push the intestine inwards towards the belly: and if you find a hernia, then grasp it with the hook, and cut off its excess
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	But if the artery or a vein is contrary to this: then circle it around a great deal
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	Then return to your operation.
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	And grasp two needles, and introduce them through two strong threads: and introduce two needles in the circumference that you made around the belly in the manner of a cross, which you make penetrate
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	Then tighten the belly in four places over the needles: and if you wish, take out the needles and leave the place, until the extended flesh putrefies: and it will fall away by itself: or cut it off when it softens and putrefies
