Euentus huius Ramicis est ex sectione, quae accidit in sifach extenso super uentrem in parte inguinum ex mirach uentris.	The event of this Ramus is from the section which happens in the great siphons above the belly in the part of the groin from the wonder of the belly.
Quare descendunt intestina ex illa Ruptura ad unum testiculorum.	Why do the intestines descend from that rupture to one testicle?
Et haec Ruptura est aut ex sifach, aut extensione eius.	This rupture is either from the siphons or from the expansion of this
Et accidunt istae duae species ex caussis multis: aut ex percussione, aut saltu, aut clamore, aut eleuatione rei grauis, et similibus.	And these two kinds happen from many causes: either from a blow, or from a jump, or from a cry, or from the elevation of a heavy thing, and the like
Et signum, quando est ex extensione sifach.	And the sign when it is from the expansion of the siphons
Est quod accidit paulatim in tempore longo, et non accidit subito: et est apostema aequale uersus profundum: propterea, quod sifach comprimit intestinum.	That which occurs gradually in a long time, and does not happen immediately, is an equal aftereffect throughout its depth: because it compresses the intestine.
Et signum eius quando est ex sectione sifach, quia facit accidere ex principio sui dolorem uehementem subito: et est apostema diuersum, apparens sub cute propinque: et illud est propter exitum intestini, et cursus eius ad exteriora sifach.	When it is excised from the portion of the intestine which lies immediately beneath the surface of the skin, the pain instantly increases at its commencement: and the aftereffect is variable, being apparent on the surface of the skin immediately beneath: because of the extrusion of the intestine through the opening of the siphons
Et quandoque egreditur cum intestino zirbum: et nominatur haec Ramex intestinalis, et zirbia: et quandoque fit cum uentositate.	When it is extruded with the intestine, it is called intestinal hernia and swelling: and sometimes it is associated with swelling.
Et quandoque currit in intestinum stercus, et retinetur illic: et est cum eo pernicies infirmi: quoniam facit accidere dolorem prauum, et praecipue quando premitur.	When it runs into the intestine, stool remains there: and this is with great pain: because it makes the pain severe, especially when it is pressed out.
Et in curatione specierum aegritudinis huius cum ferro est timor: quare oportet ut caueatur casus in ea.	And in the treatment of such diseases of the intestines, fear of death is present: wherefore it is necessary to guard against its occurrence.
Et modus operationis est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut reducat intestinum manu sua ad interiora concauitatis suae, si obedit reditui.	The method of operation is to expel the major part of the intestine into the depths of the cavity, if it obeys its return.
Deinde resupinetur super collum suum inter manus tuas: et eleua crura eius.	Then it is returned over its column between your hands: and lift the limbs.
Deinde extende cutem quae sequitur cutem ad superiora, et seca cutem testiculorum totam per longitudinem.	Then spread out the skin following the skin upwards, and dry the whole of the scrotum thoroughly
Deinde fige in duobus labiis sectionis uncinos, secundum quod indiges ad aperiendum sectionem cum eis: et sectio sit secundum quantitatem, quod sit possibile, ut egrediatur ex ea ouum.	Then fix in two incisions the hooks of the section of the intestines, according as it is necessary to open the section with them: and the incision should be made according to the quantity, as much as is possible, so that it may be easily evacuated from it
Deinde excoria siphak, et quae sunt sub cute testiculorum, donec quando detegitur sifach album, durum ab omni parte: tunc intromitte digitum tuum indicem in eo quod sequitur testiculum, in eo quod est inter siphach album, quod est sub cute oui, et inter sifach secundum, et absolue cum eo adhaerentiam quae est in posteriori parte oui.	Then cleanse the siphons and those which are under the skin until the white intestine is detected, hard throughout: then introduce your finger of indication into that which follows the testicle, which is between the white siphons, which is under the skin, and the second siphons, and the whole together with that which adheres to it at the back of the testicles.
Deinde moue cum manu dextra ad interiora cutem testiculorum: et cum hoc extende sifach album ad sursum, cum manu sinistra: et eleua ouum cum sifach ad partem sectionis: et praecipe ministro, ut extendat ouum ad sursum: et tu solue adhaerentiam, quae est retro solutione completa.	Then move your right hand towards the inside of the skin of the testicles: and with this extend a white patch upwards with your left hand: and elevate one with the patch towards the part of the section: and command the minister to extend one upwards: and you shall solve the adherence, which is the complete reverse solution.
Et quaere digitis tuis, ut non sit aliquid illic ex intestino inuoluto in sifach albo duro.	Inquire your fingers, that nothing be there in the white patch hard or soft from the intestine
Si autem inuenis ex eo aliquid: tunc impelle ipsum ad uentrem inferius.	If however you find anything in it: then drive it down to the lower belly
Deinde accipe acum, in qua sit filum grossum, factum licinium ex decem filis: et intromitte ipsam apud postremum sifach, id est, tunicae, quod est sub cute testiculorum quae sequitur sectionem: deinde incide extremitates quae eminent ex filo, donec sint quatuor fila.	Then take hold of a needle, which has a thick thread made of ten threads: and insert it through the back of the white patch, which is under the skin of the testicles which follows the section: then cut off the extremities which project from the thread, until there remain four threads.
Deinde compone quaedam eorum super quaedam cum figura quae sit in modo crucis: et liga cum eis alsifach, de quo diximus, quia est sub cute testiculorum ligamento uehementi, donec non possit aliquod ex uasis, quae nutriunt eos mittere ad eos aliquid: ut non accidat inde apostema calidum.	Then make a figure-of-eight with some of them over some: and ligate with two threads, of which we have spoken, because it is under the skin of the testicles a strong ligament which does not permit anything to pass through it: so that there may not arise from this a cold abscess.
Et pone iterum ligamentum secundum extra ligamentum primum, longinquum ab eo minus duobus digitis.	And place again a ligament outside the first ligament, long enough to be less than two fingers.
Et post ista duo ligamenta dimitte ex sifach, quod est sub cute testiculorum, quantitatem magnitudinis digiti: et incide reliquum totum secundum rotunditatem, et aufer ex eo ouum.	And after these two ligaments draw out from the white patch, which is under the skin of the testicles, as much as the length of a finger: and cut off the rest entirely following the roundness, and take out from it one
Deinde seca in inferiori parte cutis testiculorum sectione, ex qua currit sanguis, et sanies: sicut narrauimus in eo quod praemissum est.	Then dry the lower part of the skin of the testicles section from which blood runs, and heal: as we have narrated above.
Deinde administra lanam submersam in oleo, et pone in uulnus: et administra ligamentum quod narrauimus.	Then apply wet wool under oil, and put it in a wound: and administer the ligament which we have mentioned
Et quandoque cauterizatur sifach album quod diximus, post incisionem eius timendo de fluxu sanguinis.	And when the white fat is cauterized, after its incision, fear lest there be bleeding.
Multotiens enim accidit illud.	Much of the time, this happens.
Et dimitte ligamentum, donec cadat per se.	Discharge the ligament until it falls away by itself.
Si autem tardatur casus eius, tunc embrocetur cum aqua calida: et pone super ipsum illud quod diximus, donec cadat.	If, however, its case is delayed, then it is bound with warm water: and place over that which we mentioned before, until it falls away.
Deinde cura uulnus cum reliqua curatione uulnerum, donec curetur.	Then care for the wound with the rest of the treatment of wounds, until it heals
¶ De Ramice uentosa.	Of a swelling wound.
Caput LXVI.	Chapter LXVI.
IN Hac Ramice non uidi aliquem qui ausus fuerit super curationem eius cum ferro.	In such a swelling, do not allow anyone to attempt to cure it with fire
Et primi quidem dixerunt, quod fit sicut narrauimus in Ramice quae est cum Vite.	And first of all they say that it is like what we have narrated concerning the swelling which is with the Vite.
Quod est, ut liges uasa post sectionem super ea cum facilitate inferius: deinde seca in medio, et cura postremo cum eo quod aperit ipsum, donec cadant uasa: et cura uulnus, secundum quod diximus, donec sanetur.	That is, as a bandage is bound up after its section below the surface: then dry in the middle, and care afterwards with that which opens it up, until the fat falls away: and care for the wound, as we have mentioned before, until it is healed
¶ De disruptione quae fit in inguinibus.	Of the disruption which happens in the groin.
Caput LXVII.	Chapter LXVII
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, sicut diximus, et eminet locus, et non descendit ad testiculos aliquid ex intestinis: et si descendit, est illud parum, et redit in omnibus horis: uerum si prolongatur cum ea tempus, additur fissura in sifach, donec descendunt intestina in sifach.	When a rupture happens in the groin, as we have mentioned, and the place protrudes, and does not descend to the testicles anything from the intestines: and if it descends, it is little, and returns in every hour: truly if this prolongates with time, there is added a fissure in the fat, until the intestines descend into the fat
Et accidit illud ex extensione sifach, quod est in inguinibus, sicut diximus.	And this happens from the extension of the fat, which is in the groin, as we have mentioned
Quod est, quia extenditur sifach: deinde mollificatur, et apostematur locus, et eminet.	When the swelling has been extended, it is softened, and the place relaxes, and it emerges.
Et cura eius est cum cauterio, sicut praecessit eius narratio.	Its care is with cautery, as it was mentioned previously.
Et quandoque curatur cum ferro, secundum hunc modum: et est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum inter manus tuas.	And when it is cured with iron, in this way: the patient lies on his back between your hands.
Deinde seca locum Rupturae apostematum et eminentem, sectione per latitudinem, secundum quantitatem trium digitorum.	Then dry the place of the rupture after it has relaxed and emerged, by cutting across its width, according to the quantity of three fingers wide
Deinde stringe alsifak et, quae sunt sub cute, donec quando detegitur sifach album, quod est sub cute quae sequitur ipsum.	Then tighten the swelling and those which are under the skin, until the white swelling is detected, which is under the skin following the latter.
Tunc accipe radium, et pone ipsum super locum eminentem ex sifach, et preme ipsum ad profundum uentris.	Then grasp the radium and place it over the protruding part of the swelling, and press it deep into the belly
Deinde sue duo loca eminentia super extremitatem radii ex sifach, et annecte cum sutura unum eorum cum altero: deinde extrahe extremitatem radii.	Then take two points of prominence on the extremity of the radium from the swelling, and connect them with a suture: then withdraw the extremity of the radium.
Et non incidas alsifach omnino, neque tendas ouum, neque aliud, sicut feci te scire in curatione ramicis intestinalis.	And do not cut the swelling at all, neither tear any skin, nor anything else, as I told you in the care of intestinal branches
Deinde cura illud curatione uulnerum.	Then care for this wound.
Cum ergo incidis fila, mundifica illud, et restaura uulnus, donec consolidetur.	When you have finished cutting the thread, soften this and restore the wound, until it is consolidated
Sisach enim contrahitur, et non additur eminentia Rupturae.	Let the swelling subside, and do not add to the prominence of the rupture
Et cauterium est melius in hoc loco: quoniam est propinquius ad salutem.	And cautery is better in this place: because it is closer to the vein.
¶ De mollificatione cutis testiculorum.	About the softening of the skin of testicles.
Caput LXVIII.	Chapter LXVIII.
Multotiens mollificatur cutis testiculorum in quibusdam hominibus, propter quod mollificantur carnes quae sunt inter ea, et foedatur aspectus eius.	The skin of testicles is softened in many people, because the meat which is between them is softened, and the appearance of this becomes spoiled.
Ergo necesse est ei qui rogatur in curatione eius, ut faciat iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et incidat totam cutem quae mollificata est super cutem naturalem.	Therefore it is necessary for him who is asking for care of his health, to make the patient lie upon his back, and to cut through the entire skin which has been softened upon the natural skin.
Deinde aggreget duo labia cum sutura: et si uis, sue in primis superfluitatem cutis mollificatae tribus suturis, aut quatuor, et firma suturam.	And then two lips are to be gathered together with sutures: and if desired, blood should be let out at first from the surplus of softened skin by means of three or four sutures, and then firmly suture
Deinde incide inter sututuras.	And then cut through between the sutures
Deinde cura curatione reliquorum uulnerum, usquequo sanetur, et cadant fila.	And then care for the remaining wounds until they are healed, and the thread is cast off.
¶ De Castratione.	(The text continues with a section on castration.)
Caput LXIX.	Chapter LXIX
Scias, quod Castratio in lege nostra excommunicata est: et propter illud liceret mihi, ut non rememorarer eius in libro meo isto: et non est necessaria rememoratio eius, nisi propter duos modos.	You know that castration is forbidden in our law: and for that reason I will not mention it in this book: and it is not necessary to mention it, except for two cases.
Quorum unus est, ut sit illud in scientia medici quando interrogatur de ea: et ut sciat curationem eius cui accidit.	Of which one is that it is in the science of medicine when it is inquired about: and to know its treatment when it happens.
Et modus alter est, quod nos multotiens indigemus castratione quorundam animalium, propter iuuamenta nostra per illud, sicut arietum, hyrcorum, et gattorum, et similium ex animalibus.	And the other case is that we often need castration for some animals, because of our desires concerning them, such as asses, hinds, and cats, and the like of animals
Dico ergo, quod Castratio fit secundum duos modos.	I say therefore that castration is done in two ways.
Aut per attritionem.	Or by cutting off.
Aut per fissuram, et sectionem.	Or by incision, and cutting through
In illa autem quae fit per attritionem, uia operationis est: quod nos faciamus sedere animal in aqua calida, donec mollificentur testiculi eius, et leniantur, et pendeant: deinde attere eos manu tua, donec resoluantur et non appareant sub tactu.	In which way, however, which is done by attrition, the operation is this: that we make the animal sit in warm water, until the testicles are softened and relaxed, and hang down: and then cut off the testicles with your hand, until they are resolved and do not appear to the touch
In castratione autem per fissuram et sectionem, oportet ut teneas animal, et premas cutem testiculorum eius cum manu sinistra.	In castratione autem per fissuram et sectionem, oportet ut teneas animal, et premas cutem testiculorum eius cum manu sinistra.
Deinde liga suspensorium, et seca super omne ouum sectione una, donec quando procedunt duo oua: tunc incide ea postquam excoriaueris utrumque, et non dimittas super ea ex sifaket aliquid praeter sifac subtile, quod est super uasa.	In castration, however, through incision and section, it is necessary to keep the animal still, and to clamp the skin of the testicles with the left hand.
Et iste modus castrationis est melior eo qui fit per attritonem: quoniam attritio fortasse relinquit aliquid ex testiculis, quare desiderat animal coitum.	And this method of castration is better than that by attrition: for the attrition may perhaps leave something behind from the testicles, which the animal desires to have coitus.
Deinde cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	Then care for the wound, until it has healed.
¶ De cura Hermafroditae duorum modorum.	There are two methods for caring for the hermaphrodite.
Caput LXX.	Chapter 70.
Hermafrodita ex uiris est secundum duos modos.	A hermaphrodite is from two [things] according to two methods.
Vnus eorum est, quia apparet in eo quod sequitur spacium, aut in cute testiculorum, in eo quod est inter duos testiculos, figura quasi uulua mulieris, in qua sunt pili: et quandoque currit urina ex eo quod est in cute testiculorum.	One of them is that it appears in it what follows the space, or in the skin of the testicles, in which there is a figure like a woman's vulva, having hair: and sometimes urine comes from that which is in the skin of the testicles.
In mulieribus autem est species una, et est uulua mulieris super pectinem sicut testiculi uiri parui omnino, eminentes ad exteriora: quorum unus est sicut priapus uiri, et duo sicut duo testiculi.	But in women there is one kind, which is the woman's vulva which is on the belly like the testicles of a small man, protruding outwards: of which one is like the penis of a man, and two like two testicles
Et curatio trium specierum, duarum ex uiris, et speciei unius ex mulieribus, est: quia oportet ut incidas carnes additas, donec effugiat impressio earum.	And the care of the three kinds, of two from the males and one from the females, is: because it is necessary to cut away the added flesh until the impression of them has fled
Deinde cura eas curatione reliquorum uulnerum.	Then care for the rest of the wounds
In specie autem secunda uirorum, ex qua egreditur urina, quae est in cute testiculorum, non est operatio, neque est eius curatio omnino.	As for the second kind of hermaphroditism, from which urine comes from the skin of the testicles, there is no operation, neither is there any care for it at all
¶ De incisione Tentiginis, et carnis eminentis in uuluis mulierum.	On the incision of the Tentiginis, and the protruding flesh in the female pelvis.
Caput LXXI.	On the incision of the Tentiginis, and the protruding flesh in the female pelvis.
Tentigo fortasse additur super rem naturalem, donec foedatur et turpis fit aspectus eius: et quandoque magnificatur in quibusdam mulieribus adeo, donec expanditur sicut in uiris, et peruenit usque ad coitum.	The Tentiginis may perhaps be added above what is natural, until it becomes swollen and unsightly: and sometimes it is also greatly enlarged in some women, until it extends as far as the groin.
Oportet ergo ut teneas superfluitatem Tentiginis manu, aut cum uncino, et incidas: et non ultimes in incisione, praecipue in profundo radicis: ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	It is necessary therefore to ligate the superflous Tentiginis, either with a ligature or with a single suture, and to make the incision: and do not reach the deepest root, especially as the blood supply is liable to be disturbed
Deinde cura ipsam curatione uulnerum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the wound itself, until it is healed
Caro autem orta, est caro quae nascitur in orificio matricis, donec impleat ipsum: et fortasse egreditur ad exteriora secundum similitudinem caudae: et propter illud quidam primi nominant aegritudinem caudatam.	But the flesh which arises in the orifice of the womb, until it has been expelled: and perhaps it comes out to the exterior like the tail: and for this reason some call it caudal fistula.
Oportet ergo ut incidamus eam sicut incidimus Tentiginem, et curemus eam, donec sanetur.	It is necessary therefore to make an incision like that of the Tentiginis, and to take care of it, until it is healed
¶ De cura Alratica, quae est uulua mulieris non perforata.	Of the care of the Alratica, which is the unperforated vulva of a woman.
Caput LXXII.	Of the care of the Alratica, which is the unperforated vulva of a woman
Alratica est, ut sit uulua mulieris non perforata, aut sit foramen paruum.	The Alratica is, as it is the unperforated vulva of a woman, or as there is a small opening.
Et est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	It is either natural or accidental.
Accidentalis est ex aegritudine quae praecessit: et ipsa quidem fit aut ex carne nata addita, aut sifach subtili, aut spisso: et fit aut in profundo matricis, aut in lateribus eius, aut in superiore ipsius, aut inferiori eius: et prohibet a coitu et impregnatione, et partu, et fortasse prohibet menstrua.	It is accidental from some ailment which preceded it: and sometimes it is caused either by the addition of fleshy tissue, or by fine sand or hair, or by swelling: and it may be either in the depths of the womb, or in the flanks, or above or below: and it hinders coitus and conception, and delivery, and perhaps menstruation itself
Et cognitio illius fit per aspectum obstetricis, si opilatio est apparens propinqua.	Knowledge of that is obtained by the aspect of the obstetrician, if the opening appears close at hand.
Si autem non est apparens, tunc quaere eam digitis tuis, aut cum radio.	If it is not apparent, then seek with your fingers or with an instrument.
Si autem opilatio est ex sifach subtili, et est propinqua duobus labiis: tunc propera, et disrumpe ipsam.	If however the opening is from a thin layer of fat, and is close to the two lips: then grasp firmly, and break it through.</start_of_turn>
Et est, ut ponas super duo labia puluillos.	And it is like putting over two lips little nails.</start_of_turn>
Deinde pone indices tuos duarum manuum simul, et mulier sit super dorsum suum expansis cruribus suis.	Then place your two fingers of both hands together, and the woman should sit with her buttocks expanded over her thighs.</start_of_turn>
Deinde extende duo labia cum fortitudine, donec disrumpatur sifach subtile, et aperiatur opilatio.	Then stretch out the two lips with force, until the thin layer of fat is broken through, and the opening is made.</start_of_turn
Deinde accipe lanam, et imbibe eam in oleo, et pone ipsam super locum: et coeat mulier omni die, ut non consolidetur locus uice alia.	Then grasp the lanet and soak it in oil, and place it on the place: and the woman should continue to press daily, so that it does not solidify in another place.</start_of_turn>
Si autem sifach est grossum, spissum: tunc oportet ut seces ipsum cum spatumili lato simili folio myrti.	If however the layer of fat is thick and tough: then it is necessary to cut it out with a spatula like a broad leaf of myrtle.</start_of_turn
Si autem opilatio est ex carne nata, tunc suspende eam cum uncinis, et incide eam: et sint tecum medicinae quae fluxum sedant sanguinis absque mordicatione, sicut acacia, et sanguis draconis, et thus aggregatum cum albugine oui.	If however the opening is from natural flesh: then suspend the bleeding with hooks, and cut through it: and let there be with you physicians who can stop the flow of blood without causing harm, such as acacia, and dragon's blood, and thus gather with alum or wool.</start_of_turn
Deinde administra cannulam ex plumbo amplam, ut non consolidetur uulnus uelociter, teneat eam diebus aliquot: et administra licinium ex lino sicco, deinde curetur reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then administer a large lead cannula, so that the wound does not close up too quickly, keep it for a few days: and administer dry lint, then care for the rest, until the wound is healed.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque nasciur in matrice natiuitas carnium aliarum: oportet ergo ut incidantur secundum hunc modum: dum non est apostema cancerosum apostemati enim canceroso quod est in matrice, non fiat contrarietas cum ferro omnino.	And when there is birth in the matrix of other meats: it is necessary therefore that they be cut through in this manner: as there is no cancerous tumor in the matrix, let there be no resistance with iron of any kind.</start_of_turn
¶ De cura hemorroidarum, Athehelil, et Bothor rubeae in uuluis mulierum.	Concerning the care of hemorrhoids, Athehelil, and Bothor of the red kind in the veins of women.
Caput LXXIII.	Concerning the care of hemorrhoids, Athehelil, and Bothor of the red kind in the veins of women.
Hemorroides quidem sunt apertio orificiorum uenarum, donec currit ex eis sanguis multus assidue.	Hemorrhoids are indeed swellings of the veins of the rectum or anus, from which much blood flows excessively.
Cum ergo antiquantur hemorroides, fiunt thelil: et iam dixi in diuisione species earum, et signa ipsarum: et dicam hic quae ex eis recipiunt curationem, et quae non.	When hemorrhoids exist, there are two things which must be known: the kind of hemorrhoids and the signs of the disease. We will speak of the treatment of these things later; now let us speak of what is necessary and what is not
Dico ergo, quod hemorroides quae sunt in orificio matricis, et non apparent sensui: tunc non est ei curatio cum ferro.	I say therefore that hemorrhoids which exist in the belly and not in the anus are not treated with iron
Quae autem ex eis sunt in orificio matricis super quas cadit sensus, sunt quae curantur.	Those which exist in the belly above which there is no sensation are those which are cured
Oportet ergo ut intromittas mulierem in domum frigidam.	It is necessary therefore that the woman be put into a cold house
Deinde extende athehelil cum forficibus, aut cum panno aspero, et incide eas ex radicibus suis.	Then stretch out Athehelil with forceps, or with a rough cloth, and cut away the roots from them.
Deinde pulueriza super eas apud fluxum sanguinis ex uno puluerum incisiuorum absque mordificatione: sicut acacia, et sanguis draconis, et thus, et similia eis.	Then powder over the wounds with one of the powders mentioned above without causing damage: thus, as acacia, and dragon's blood, and thus, and similar things.
Deinde impellat pedes eius ad parietem hora una.	Then press her feet against the wall for an hour.
Postea depone eam in aquam frigidam.	Then put her in cold water afterwards
Quod si perseuerat fluxus sanguinis: tunc fac eam sedere in decoctione sumach, et corticum granatorum, et gallarum, et similium.	If the bleeding persists: then make her sit in a decoction of sumach, and nutmeg, and gall, and similar things
Deinde accipe farinam hordei, et confice eam cum melle et aceto, et fac emplastrum cum eo super dorsum eius.	Then take barley flour, and mix it with honey and vinegar, and make a plaster with it on her back
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis cum eo, bonum est: et si non, fac adhaerere dorso uentosas, et mammillis, absque scarificatione.	If blood is still bleeding with this, it is good: and if not, make the swelling adhere to the skin, and butter, without making an incision
Deinde accipe lanam, et submerge in succo tarathit, aut succo arnoglossae, aut succo ramorum alaulat, id est, aglanter, uino pontico, et fac adhaerere loeo.	Then take wool and soak it in grease of lard, or in grease of arnica, or in grease of poppy seeds, that is, lanolin, wine of pontic, and cause it to adhere to the wound.
Cum ergo quiescit apostema, tunc cura locum cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	When the wound is quiesced, then care for the place with unguents until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Albarth uero rubeum est simile capitibus alhaasse, et est asperi aspectus.	However red it is like heads of hair, and has a rough appearance.</start_of_turn>
Oportet ergo ut incidas quod apparet ex eo, secundum quod dixi in thelil aequaliter: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	It is necessary therefore that you cut away that which appears from it, as I have said previously: and care for it until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
¶ De perforatione Exiturae quae accidit in matrice.	Of the perforation which happens in the matrix.</start_of_turn
Caput LXXIIII.	Chapter LXXIV.</start_of_turn
Accidunt in matrice species multae apostematum, sicut cancer, et apostema lapideum, et ulcera, et adubelati, et alekilati, id est, herpes, aestiomemus, et fistulae, et hemorroides, et ragadiae, et thelil, et apostema calidum.	Many kinds of wounds happen in the matrix, such as cancer, and stone abscess, and ulcer, and foreign bodies, and swellings, that is, herpes, fistula, and hemorrhoids, and piles, and tumors, and abscesses.</start_of_turn
Et ego quidem iam dixi omnes has aegritudines et species earum, et signa ipsarum, et earum curationes in diuisione: necesse est ut dicam in hoc tractatu apostema calidum quod accidit in matrice, quando est ex apostematibus quae colligunt saniem, et uis scire qualiter fit eius apertio cum ferro.	And I have already said all these diseases and their kinds, and their signs, and their treatments in general: it is necessary to say in this treatise the abscess which happens in the matrix, when it is from wounds which join health, and how it is opened with a knife.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	You must consider this.</start_of_turn>
Tunc si dolor apostematis in incaeptione sua est acutus cum percussione sua, et flamma, et febre: et uides ipsum rubere: si cadit super ipsum sensus, tunc non properes cum perforatione eius: et cura ipsum cum eo eo quod iuuat super maturationem, donec quando quiescat acuitas accidentium.	When the pain of the wound in its beginning is acute with percussion, flame, and fever: and you see it turning red: if it falls outside of your senses, then do not attempt to pierce it: care for it so that the acute pain of the accident subsides, until the cause of the pain has disappeared.</start_of_turn
Tunc oportet ut facias sedere mulierem super sedem quae labeat duo sedilia, et reclinetur, uel appodietur super dorsum suum, et aggreget pedes suos ad partem inferiorem uentris: et sint coxae eius expansae, et ponat brachia sua sub genibus suis, et liget utraque ligamento conueniente ad illud.	Then it is fitting that you make her sit upon a seat which beats two seats, and that she recline, or that you support her upon her back, and that she bring her feet to the lower part of her belly: and that her knees be spread wide, and that she place her arms under her knees, and that you bind each ligament conveniently to that.
Deinde sedeat obstetrix a latere dextro, et administra instrumentum quo aperitur orificium matricis.	Then let the midwife sit on the right side, and manage the instrument with which you open the opening of the womb.
Cuius forma uenit in eis quae sunt post.	Whose form comes into being in the things that are afterwards
Et oportet quando uis administrare hoc instrumentum, ut figas cum Radio profundum matricis mulieris: ut non sit illud quod ingreditur ex instrumento plus, quam profundum matricis, et laedat infirmam.	And it is fitting when you are about to manage this instrument that you place the liver with the rib of the deep belly of the woman: so that there is not that which enters from the instrument more than the depth of the belly, and that it does not damage the lower part
Si autem fuerit instrumentum magis quam profundum, tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos super tecturam profundi matricis: ut prohibeatur introitus instrumenti totius in profundum matricis: et oportet ut ponat uertiginem, quae currit in instrumento, ex latere superiore: et ut teneat instrumentum, et ut reuoluat minister uertiginem, donec aperiatur profundum matricis.	But if the instrument is greater than the depth of the belly, then you must place sponges upon the covering of the deep belly: so that the entrance of the instrument is not introduced into the depth of the belly: and you must place a sponge, which runs in the instrument, from the upper side: and that you keep the instrument firm, and that you rotate the minister of the sponge until the depth of the belly is opened
Cum ergo apparet Exitura, et tangitur manu, et est lenis et mollis: tunc oportet ut seces ipsam apud caput suum cum spatumili lato.	When therefore the exit appears, and the hand touches it, and it is soft and gentle: then it is fitting that you cut it off at its head with a broad spatula.
Cum ergo euacuatur sanies, tunc oportet ut ponas in uulnus licinium submersum in oleo rosaceo: aut oleo uiridi, in quo sit quaedam stipticitas: et pone licinium, et extrahe sectionem in profundo matricis.	When therefore the blood is evacuated, then it is fitting that you place in the wound a sponge soaked in rose-water: or a sponge of green, in which there is some astringency: and put on the sponge and draw out the section from the depth of the belly.
Et pone exterius super matricem, et super pectinem lanam mundam submersam in aqua, in qua bullitae sunt maluae.	And place externally upon the matrix, and upon the navel a wet towel soaked in water, in which there are bad bubbles.
Deinde curetur post duos dies cum unguento quod conuenit ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then it cares for two days with ointment which agrees with it until it heals.
Et quandoque abluitur matrix et uulnus, ita quod clisterizatur cum aqua et melle: deinde cum aqua in qua bullita est radix lilii, aut aristolochia longa: deinde redeat ad unguentum.	When it has bathed the matrix and the wound, it is to be plastered with water and honey: then with water in which the root of lily or long aristolochia has been boiled: then return to the ointment.
Quod si uulnus absconditum fuerit interius in matrice, tunc oportet ut prohibearis ex curatione eius cum ferro, imo cura ipsum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione.	If the wound has receded inwards of the matrix, then it is necessary to protect it from its cure with iron, and to care for it as we said in the direction of the wound.
¶ Doctrinae Obstetricum, qualiter medicentur embriones uiui, secundum figuram non naturalem egressi.	The obstetrical doctrine, concerning how to care for the embryos of women, according to an unnatural form of birth.
Caput Lxxu.	Chapter LX.
Necesse est Obstetrici, ut cognoscat in primis figuram partus naturalis.	It is necessary for the obstetrician to know in the first place the figure of natural birth.
Ex signis ergo eius est, quod quando uides mulierem comprimi ad inferiora, et desiderat odorare aerem, et alleuiatur super eam quod super ipsam est de partu, et festinat exitus embrionis: tunc scias quod iste partus est secundum figuram naturalem, et est exitus eius super caput suum, et secundina cum eo: aut suspensa, uel pendens ex umbilico.	From the signs therefore it is known that when a woman is pressed by the waters below and wishes to smell the air, and alleviates above what is above her from the birth, and hastens the issue of the embryo: then you know that this birth is natural, and is the issue above its head, and the second with it: or suspended, or hanging from the navel
Cum ergo uides haec signa, tunc oportet ut comprimatur uenter eius, ut descendat embrio uelociter.	When therefore these signs are present, then it is necessary to compress the womb so that the embryo comes down quickly
Nam quando descendit super caput suum, descendit secundina cum eo, et mundatur ex illis superfluitatibus mundificatione bona.	For when it descends above its head, it descends with the second part and is delivered from these superabundances by a good delivery
Qui autem est praeter hunc partum, est innaturalis, illaudabilis.	Whoever is beyond this birth is unnatural, harmful
Quoniam quandoque egreditur foetus super pedes suos, et egreditur corpus eius ante caput ipsius, et pedes eius, et manus eius una, aut pes eius unus: aut egreditur caput eius et manus eius: aut egreditur uentrinus: et fortasse conuertitur super collum suum, et similia ex figuris illaudabilibus.	For when the fetus comes out above its feet, and the body of it goes before the head, and the feet and hands together, or one foot: or the head and the hand: or the belly: and perhaps turns upon its collar, and similar things from the harmful figures.
Necesse est ergo Obstetrici, ut sit prudens, subtilis in istis rebus omnibus, et caueat sibi ab errore et decaeptione: et ego sum ostendens omnem figuram ex eis, et qualiter est ingenium in ea, et significetur per illud, et stetur super ipsum.	It is necessary for the Obstetrician to be prudent, cautious in all these matters, and to beware of error and decomposition: for I shall show every figure and how the temperament is in each one, and it is signified by that, and it stands above itself.
Quando egreditur foetus super caput suum egressione sua naturali, et uehemens fit illud super mulierem, et difficilis fit ei partus, et uides uirtutem eius iam debilitatam: tunc fac eam sedere super sedem, aut mulieres teneant eam: et uapora uuluam eius cum foenugraeco decocto, et cum oleis humidis.	When the fetus has gone beyond its head during its natural egress, and the head becomes engaged above the woman, and delivery becomes difficult, and the power of its courage is being crippled: then let the woman sit down, or let the women hold her up: and let the vapor of her breath be driven away with fumigation of rue and with oily substances.
Deinde intromittat Obstetrix inter digitos suos Spatumile paruum, et findat cum eo secundinam, et secet eam ungue suo, donec currat quod est in ea ex humiditate: et preme uentrem mulieris, donec descendat foetus.	Then the Obstetrician inserts his fingers between the toes of the patient, and finds the second one, and seizes it with his nail, until he has drawn out what is in it from the moisture: and he presses down the belly of the woman until the fetus comes down.
Si autem non descendit, tunc oportet ut clisterizetur mulier ex mucillagine foenugraeci, cum oleo sisamino.	If it does not come down, then it is necessary to instill the woman with a cathartic of rue with oil.
Deinde praecipe ei post clistere, ut comprimatur: et fac eam sternutare cum condisi, et tene os eius et nasum ipsius hora una.	Then command her to drink after the catharsis, that she may compress: and make her lie down with her chin resting on her chest for an hour.
Foetus enim egredietur statim.	The fetus will come out immediately.
Quod si egrediantur duae manus foetus in primis, iunc oportet ut reducas eas cum facilitate paulatim.	If two hands of the fetus come out at once, it is necessary to reduce them gradually with ease
Si autem non obedit in introitu, tunc pone mulierem super sedem, et eleua pedes eius sursum: deinde concute sedem super terram: et mulier teneatur, ut non cadat apud concussionem.	If it does not obey in the birth, then let the woman sit down and elevate her feet above the ground: then press down on her seat towards the earth: and the woman shall be held, so that she does not fall from the concussion
Si ergo non egrediuntur manus, et moritur foetus: tunc incide eas, et extrahe residuum foetus: et liga manum eius cum panno, et extrahe ipsum cum aequalitate: nam ipse egredietur.	If, however, the hands do not come out, and the fetus dies: then cut down the sides and extract the fetus: and bind up the hand with cloth, and extract it with evenness: for it will come out itself
¶ Exitus embrionis super pedes suo.	The embryo's exit is above its feet.
Quando egreditur foetus super pedes suos, tunc oportet ut impellat eos sursum: deinde conuertat foetum paulatim: postea aequet ipsum.	When the fetus exits above its feet, it is necessary to drive it upwards: then gradually bend it: afterwards it will be even.
Deinde accipiat unum pedum eius, et extendat eum paulatim.	Then take hold of one foot and gradually extend it
Cum ergo egrediuntur usque ad coxas, tunc praecipe ei, ut comprimatur, et fac eam sternutare cum condisi: egredietur enim, si Deus uoluerit.	When they emerge up to the hips, then command it to bend down, so that it will be crushed, and make it exhale with force: it will come out, God willing
Et si non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc reduc foetum paulatim, donec ponas eum secundum figuram naturalem.	And if it does not come out as we have said, then gradually reduce the fetus until you have set it according to its natural shape.
Nam ipse egredietur tunc egressu facili.	For it will come out by itself when its time comes.
Quod si prohibeatur cum eo toto quod narrauimus: tunc accipe ex mucillagine alteae, et oleo sisamino, et gummi soluto: et percute totum in mortario percussione bona: deinde line cum eo uuluam mulieris, et inferius uentris eius.	If it is delayed as regards all that we have said: then take from the thick mucus above, and salt, and gum dissolved: and pierce all through in the belly with a good blow: then draw out with the woman's palm and the lower part of her belly
Deinde fac eam sedere in aqua tepida, donec consequatur hypocundria.	Then make it sit in warm water, until the afterbirth follows naturally
Cum ergo uides quod iam calefacta sunt inferiora eius, tunc fac ei sief de myrrha: et suppone ipsum.	When its lower parts are softened by the heat, then make for it a sieve of myrrh: and hold it in place.
Quando ergo tenet sief hora una, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem.	When an hour has passed since you put on the sieve, then make it sit on a seat.
Deinde fac eam sternutare: et stringe ipsius os et nasum: et preme inferiorem partem uentris compressione facili.	Then make it exhale: and stretch its bones and nose: and press the lower part of the belly gently
Nam foeus egredietur statim.	For the fetus will come out immediately.
¶ Exitus foetus super genua et manus.	The fetus's exit is above the knees and hands
Quando egreditur secundum hanc formam, tunc ingeniet in intromittendo manus suas paulatim.	When it comes out in this form, then gently bend in its hands little by little.
Deinde resupinetur mulier super collum suum, et pendeant pedes eius ad inferiora: et ipsa sit iacens super lectum, et complicet manus suas.	Then the woman lies upon her pillar, and her feet hang down towards the lower parts: and she herself lies upon the bed, and she covers her hands.
Deinde preme supra uentrem eius paulatim.	Then she slowly raises her abdomen upwards
Deinde extrahe quod est sub pedibus eius ex puluinaribus, donec sit praeparata in inferiori parte.	Then she pulls out what is under her feet from the shoes, until it is prepared in the lower part.
Quod si non egreditur foetus, tunc accipe pedes eius, et moue eos motu uehementi.	If the fetus does not come out, then grasp her feet and move them with a gentle movement.
Deinde preme quod est supra hypocundria paulatim, donec ascendat foetus ad superiora.	Then slowly press what is above the navel upwards, until the fetus ascends to the upper parts
Deinde intromittat manus suas, et aequet foetum paulatim: et praecipe mulieri, ut comprimatur, donec egrediatur foetus.	Then insert your hands and gently deliver the fetus: and command the woman to press, until the fetus comes out
¶ Exitus foetus latitudinaliter pendens ex manibus.	The lateral delivery of the fetus hangs from the hands
Ingenietur in reductione manus eius.	Skill in the reduction of the hand is required
Si autem non potest reducere eam, tunc eleua mulierem, et fac eam ambulare.	If, however, it is not possible to reduce the hand, then lift up the woman and make her walk
Si uero ambulare non potest, tunc fac eam iacere super lectum: et concute crura eius concussione uehementi.	If she is unable to walk, then make her lie upon the bed: and compress her limbs with a gentle touch
Deinde administra linimentum quod praeparasti ex mucillaginibus.	Then administer the liniment that you have prepared from the slime-coats
Quod si accipit eam partus, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem.	If she gives birth, then make her sit on a seat
Deinde stude in reductione manus, et aequa foetum secundum figuram naturalem: et fac sternutare mulierem, et praecipe ei, ut comprimat se, donec egrediatur.	Then study the reduction of the hand, and equal the fetus according to the natural figure: and command the woman to breathe steadily, and tell her to press herself, until she comes out
¶ Exitus foetus super collum suum, expansis manibus, et est facies eius ad dorsum matris suae.	The fetus comes out upon her pillar, with her hands spread out, and her face is towards the back of her mother
Oportet ut teneat Obstetrix manum foetus, deinde reuoluat eum paulatim, et aequet eum cum facilitate.	The obstetrician must hold the hand of the fetus firmly, then gradually withdraw it, and equalize it with ease.
Cum ergo aequatur, tunc pone super uuluam eius quod narrauimus ex oleo et mucillaginibus.	When it is equal, then place above its belly what we have mentioned from wax and mucus
Deinde praecipe ei, ut moueatur paulatim.	Then command it to move gradually.
Cum ergo feceris illud, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem, et praecipe ei ut inclinetur ad latus dextrum.	When you have done this, then make it sit on its seat, and command it to incline to the right side.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut comprimatur: et fac eam sternutare cum condisi.	Then command it to compress: and make it breathe with composure.
¶ Exitus foetus praeparati super latus.	The fetus is prepared to exit through the side
Quando descendit ad orificium matricis secundum hunc modum cum secundina, tunc scinde secundinam cum ungue tuo, donec euacuetur ex humiditate.	When it has descended to the birth opening in this way with the second finger, then cut the second with your nail, until it is evacuated from the moisture
Si ergo suspenditur super faciem foetus, et collum eius, tunc incide eam ex umbilico: ut non retineatur, et moriatur.	If it is suspended on the face of the fetus, and its neck, then cut it from the navel: so that it is not retained and dies.
Deinde impelle foetum ad interiora, donec ponas eam secundum quod oportet: et praecipe mulieri, ut comprimat se aliquotiens: ipse enim egredietur exitu leui.	Then push the fetus inwards, until you have placed it according to what is required: and command the woman to compress herself slightly: it will itself go out through the easy exit.
¶ Exitus Geminorum, aut foetuum multorum.	The birth of twins, or of many fetuses.
Scias, quod Gemini multotiens nascuntur: et quandoque nascuntur tres, et quatuor.	You know that twins are often born multiple: and sometimes three or four are born.
Verumtamen illud extraneum est, et raro contingit.	It is an extraordinary thing, and is rarely found.
Quinque uero est res extra naturam, et non uiuunt penitus: et continet eos, quamuis multiplicentur, secundina una: et separantur per sifach, distinguens inter eos ligatum in umbilico cuiusque eorum.	Five or more is a thing beyond nature, and does not usually survive: and they are retained together, although multiplied, by one: and they are separated by the navel, distinguishing between the cord of each of them.
Et quandoque egrediuntur sicut egreditur foetus unus exitu naturali, facili: et egrediuntur exitu illaudabili, sicut narrauimus.	And sometimes they go out like a single fetus through a natural exit, easily: and they go out through the difficult exit, as we have narrated
Quod si difficiles fuerint quidam eorum apud partum, et perueniunt ad illud quod diximus ex figuris innaturalibus, tunc cura eos sicut narrauimus: et sit ob stetrix subtilis, et faciat quod facit cum facilitate et tarditate, et ingenietur secundum omnem figuram cum eo quod praeparatur ei ex ingenio ducente ad salutem.	If anything is difficult with regard to parts, and they approach that which we mentioned from unnatural figures, then care for them as we have narrated: and let the midwife be gentle, and let her do what she does with ease and delay, and she shall adapt according to every figure as she prepares for it from the guiding principle for health.
¶ Rememoratio eius quod formatur in matrice ex embrionibus, et abortiuntur.	Remember that which is formed in the womb from embryos, and that aborts.
Quandoque formatur in matrice unus, et duo, et tres, et quatuor, et quinque, et sex, et septem, et plures decem: et iam uerificatum est apud me, quod mulier abortiendo emisit septem, et alia quindecim, omnes formatos.	When one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, and more than ten are formed in the womb: and I have seen that a woman has aborted seven, and another fifteen, all of whom were formed
Quod factum est mensuratione gloriosi sapientis.	As has been done by the measurement of a wise man
Hoc ergo totum oportet ut sit in scientia Obstetricis.	Therefore all this must be known in the science of Midwifery
Fortasse enim perueniet ad eam simile illius: opponat ergo ei cum illo quod oportet	Perhaps indeed it will approach like that: oppose to it what is necessary
¶ De extractione foetus mortui.	Of the extraction of a dead fetus.
Caput LXXVI.	Chapter 76.
Quando curas foetum mortuum cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex medicatione, et non egreditur, et cogeris uti operatione cum manu, tunc oportet ut consideres.	When you care for a dead fetus with that which I said in the discourse on medication, and it does not go out, and you must perform an operation with the hand, then you must consider carefully
Si ergo mulier est sanae uirtutis, et non est cum aliquo ex accidentibus, ex quibus timetur super eam perditio: tunc oportet ut resupinetur mulier super lectum, super dorsum suum, et sit caput eius inclinatum inferius, et crura eius eleuata: et ministra teneat eam a duabus partibus, aut ligetur ad lectum, ut non extrahatur corpus eius apud extractionem foetus.	If a woman is of sound virtue and is not with any of the things from which she is afraid that she will lose the child: then it must be that the woman lies over the bed, over her back, and that her head is inclined downwards, and her legs are elevated: and the midwife must hold the child from two parts, or it is bound to the bed, so that it is not pulled out during the extraction of the fetus
Deinde humecta os matricis ex oleis humidis cum mucillagine alteae, et foenugraeci, et seminis lini.	Then moisten the os matrice from oily humids with mucilage of alum, and chaff, and linseed seed.
Deinde inungat Obstetrix manum suam cum istis oleis et mucillaginibus: deinde intromittat eam in matricem cum facilitate.	Then the Obstetrix shall smear his hand with oil and mucus: then he shall introduce it into the matrix with ease.
Deinde quaerat cum ea locum in quo figat uncinos ex foetu, et loca conuenientia ad illud.	Then he seeks the place where the nails of the fetus are fixed, and the convenient place for it
Considera ergo tunc, si foetus est praeparatus ut descendat super caput suum: tunc fige uncinos in oculos eius, aut in collo eius, aut in ore eius, aut in palato ipsius, aut sub barba eius, aut in furcula ipsius, aut in locis propinquis costis, et sub hypocundriis.	Consider then, if the fetus is prepared to descend over its head: then fix the nails in its eyes, or in its neck, or in its mouth, or in its palate, or under its beard, or in its chest, or under its ribs.
Si autem descensus est super pedes eius, tunc in pectine, et costis eius mediis.	If, however, the descent is over its feet, then in the loin and the middle ribs.
Et oportet, ut teneat uncinum cum manu dextra: et ponat curuitatem eius in eo quod est inter digitos sinistrae manus: et intromittat cum manu cum facilitate, et figat uncinum in aliquo illorum locorum quae diximus, donec perueniat ad rem uacuam.	And it is necessary that he grasp the nail with his right hand: and he shall place his thumb in that which is between the little finger of the left hand: and he shall introduce it with his hand with ease, and fix the nail in some one of those places which we mentioned, until it reaches the desired thing
Deinde figat in oppositione eius uncinum alium, aut tertium, si indiges: ut sit contractio aequalis, et non declinet ad partem.	Then he shall fix the other nail, or the third, if necessary: so that there is an equal tension, and it does not lean to one side.
Deinde extendatur extensione aequali, et non sit extensio secundum rectitudinem tantum, imo moueatur ad omnem partem, ut alleuietur exitus eius: sicut fit cum dente apud eradicationem eius.	Then the extension should be equal, and it should not be extended only in a straight line, but should be moved to all parts, so as to alleviate its exit: as it is done with a tooth at its extraction
Et oportet in eo quod est inter illud, ut mollificetur extensio.	And it is necessary at that place between these, so as to soften the extension.
Quod si retineatur ex eo pars, tunc oportet ut inungat Obstetrix quosdam digitos cum oleo, et intromittat eos ex parte, ut reuoluat cum eis quod retinetur.	That if it is retained from that place, then the Obstetrix must smear some fingers with oil, and introduce them from the side, so as to rotate with what is retained
Si ergo egreditur pars foetus, tunc permutentur uncini ad locum alium qui sit altior: fac hoc donec egrediatur foetus totus.	If, however, a part of the fetus comes out, then exchange the nails to another place which is higher: do this until the whole fetus comes out
Si ergo egreditur manus ante alia, et non est possibile reducere eam, propter coartationem eius: tunc oportet, ut inuoluatur super eam pannus.	If therefore the hand goes out before the others, and it is not possible to reduce it, because of its swelling: then it is necessary that it be covered over the bandage.
Deinde extrahe eam donec quando egreditur tota, incide eam aut in iunctura plantae, aut in cubito: et ita oportet ut facias in manu altera, et in duobus pedibus.	If therefore the hand goes out before the others, incides on the skin or in the joint of the limb, or in the elbow: and thus it is necessary that you make in the other hand, and in two feet.
Si autem caput foetus est magnum, aut accidit ei coartatio in exitu, aut est in capite eius aqua aggregata: tunc oportet ut intromittat inter digitos Spatumile spinosum, et findat cum eo caput, et extrahat aquam: aut disrumpat ipsum cum instrumento quod nominatur Almisdac: cuius forma uenit cum formis reliquorum instrumentorum in capitulo quod est post hoc.	If the fetus's head is large, or if it has become coarticulated in the birth, or there is water in its head: then it is necessary that you introduce between the fingers the Spatumile spinosum, and find it with the head, and extract the water: or break it with the instrument which is called the Almisdac, whose form is like that of the other instruments in the following chapter.
Similiter faciat si foetus est magni capitis natura, tunc oportet ut seces algengematu: aut extrahas ipsum cum misdach, sicut diximus.	Likewise do in case the fetus has a large head of natural birth, then it is necessary that you remove the afterbirth: or extract it with a hook, as we have said.
Deinde attrahas ossa cum forcipibus.	Then grasp the bones with forceps.
Quod si egrediatur caput, et coartetur apud furculam: tunc findatur, donec effundatur humiditas quae est in pectore.	When the head comes out, and is grasped at the collar: then it is found, until the moisture that is in the chest is drained out
Si autem non complicatur, neque obedit ad exitum: tunc incide caput frustatim, secundum quod possibile est tibi.	When it does not become complicated, nor does it yield to delivery: then cut off the head roughly, as much as is possible to you
Quod si inferius uentris est apostematum, aut est in eo hydropisis: tunc oportet ut perfores ipsum, donec currat humiditas ex eo.	When the lower belly is apostemated, or there is fluid in it: then it is necessary that you perforate it, until the moisture comes out from it
Si uero foetus est super pedes suos, tunc attractio eius est facilis, et directio eius ad os matricis est leuis.	If however the fetus is on his feet: then the traction of his belly is easy, and the direction of it towards the maternal bones is smooth.
Si autem coartatur apud uentrem, aut pectus: tunc oportet ut extrahas ipsum cum panno quem inuoluisti super manum tuam: et findat uentrem, aut pectus, donec currat quod est in eis.	If however it is coarticulated at the belly, or the chest: then it is necessary that you extract it with the bandage which you have put over your hand: and find the belly, or the chest, until it is drained out
Si autem auferuntur reliqua membra, et redit caput: tunc intromittat Obstetrix manum sinistram.	If, however, the other members are removed and the head remains: then the Obstetrix inserts his left hand into the head.
Si ergo os matricis est apertum, tunc intromittat manum in profundum matricis, et quaerat cum ea caput, et attrahat ipsum cum digitis usque ad os matricis: deinde intromittat in eo uncinum unum, aut uncinos duos, et attrahat ipsum cum eo.	If the mouth of the womb is open: then he inserts his hand deeply into the womb and grasps the head, and pulls it down to the opening of the womb. Then he inserts one or two fingers into it and pulls them out with it.</start_of_turn>
Quod si os matricis coartatur, propter apostema calidum quod accidit ei: tunc non oportet ut laboretur super ipsum, imo oportet tunc administrare effusionem rerum humidarum, pinguium: et administra emplastra: et sedeat in aquis quae mollificant et humectant.	If the opening of the womb is closed, because of a thick clot that has occurred to it: then it is not necessary to work above it, indeed it is necessary to manage an effusion of humors, fat: and apply plasters. And sit in waters which soften and moisten.</start_of_turn>
Quod si foetus est super latus suum, tunc possibile est ut aequetur: tunc administretur quod diximus in foetu uiuo.	If the fetus is above its side: then it is possible to equalize it: then it is administered what we said in the fetus above.</start_of_turn>
Quod si non est possibile illud, tunc incidatur frustatim, et extrahatur.	If it is not possible to do this, then it is done by force, and it is extracted.</start_of_turn>
Et oportet ut non dimittas aliquid ex secundina intus omnino.	And it is necessary that you do not allow anything to go out from the belly altogether.</start_of_turn>
Cum ergo compleueris operationem tuam, tunc administra quod diximus in apostematibus calidis quae accidunt in matricibus.	When you have finished your operation, then administer what we said in the postpartum period which occur in the womb.</start_of_turn
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc descendat in aquis stipticis, et administra reliquam curationem.	If there is a flow of blood, then descend into the waters of styptics, and administer the remaining treatment.</start_of_turn
Et ego quidem iam uidi mulierem, in cuius uentre mortuus erat foetus: deinde impregnata est super ipsum uice alia, postea mortuus est foetus alius etiam.	And I myself have seen a woman in whom there was a dead fetus in the womb: then it was impregnated over her with another, afterwards another fetus also died.</start_of_turn
Accidit ergo ei post tempus longum apostema in umbilico suo, et inflatum est, donec apertum est: et coepit emittere pus.	This happened to her after a long time the clot in her belly burst open: and it became swollen, until it opened: and pus began to emit.</start_of_turn
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius, et medicatus sum ei tempore longo: et non consolidatum est uulnus.	I am summoned here for his care, and I have been his physician for a long time: and it is not consolidated (healed).
Posui ergo super ipsum ex quibusdam emplastris fortis attractionis: et exiuit ex loco os.	I place upon him above some strong sticking plaster: and it has come out of its place from the bone
Deinde praeterierunt ei dies aliquot, et exiuit os aliud.	Then some days passed by, and it came out of another place from the bone.
Miratus sum ergo inde, cum in uentre non sit os.	I am amazed that there is no bone within.
Cogitaui ergo, quia erant ex ossibus foetus mortui.	I think that because there were dead bones of a fetus there
Inquisiui ergo uulnus, et extraxi ossa multa, muliere existente in melioribus dispositionibus suis: et iam uixit taliter tempore longo, et mittit ex loco pus parum.	I inquired about the wound, and I extracted many bones, the woman being in better dispositions: and it has healed in the long term, and there comes out little pus from the place.
Et ego non firmaui hic hoc extraneum, nisi quoniam in eo est scientia, et adiutorium ad illud, quod administrat medicus artifex cum manu ex curatione.	And I did not stabilize this externally, except that there is knowledge of it, and assistance with this, which the artificial doctor administers with his hand in care.
¶ De formis Instrumentorum necessariorum in extractione foetus.	On the forms of the necessary instruments for the extraction of a fetus.
Caput LXXVII.	Chapter 77.</start_of_turn>
Hic inferius est forma Strictorii, quo aequantur libri, cui aequaliter sunt duae uertigines in duabus extremitatibus duorum lignorum.	Here below is the form of the Strictor, with which books are equal, to which are equal two rings in the two extremities of two logs.</start_of_turn>
Verumtamen haec Vertigo oportet ut sit subtilior strictorio: et ut fiat, aut ex ebano, aut ex ligno bussi.	Truly, this vertigo must be finer than the strictor: and that it may be either from ebony or from seasoned wood.</start_of_turn
Et sit latitudo omnis ligni quasi duo digiti: et margo cuiusque amborum est quasi digitus unus, et longitudo cuiusque eorum est palmus et medietas: et in medio duorum lignorum sunt duo additamenta ex genere eiusdem ligni, quae iam firmata sunt in utrisque, quorum longitudo est medietas palmi et plus parum: et latitudo utriusque est quasi duo digiti, aut plus parum.	And the width of every log is like two fingers: and the margin of each of them is like one finger, and the length of each of them is palm and a half: and in the middle of the two logs are two additions of the same kind of wood, which are firmly fixed in both, of whose length is half of the palm and a little less: and the width of each is like two fingers, or less.</start_of_turn
Et ista duo additamenta intromittuntur in os matricis, ut aperiatur cum eis quando tu reuoluis duas Vertigines.	Two additional things are introduced into the matrix bone, so that it opens when you rotate two vertebrae.
Forma Vertiginis qua aperitur matrix.	Two additional things are introduced into the matrix bone, so that it opens when you rotate two vertebrae.
Forma alia ad simile illius, subtilior, et leuior.	Two additional things are introduced into the matrix bone, so that it opens when you rotate two vertebrae.
Fiat ex ligno ebani, aut bussi, secundum similitudinem forcipum.	Two additional things are introduced into the matrix bone, so that it opens when you rotate two vertebrae
Verumtamen in extremitate eius sint duo additamenta, sicut uides hic supra: et longitudo omnis additamenti ex eis est quasi palmus: et latitudo utriusque est, duo digiti.	Two additional things are introduced into the matrix bone, so that it opens when you rotate two vertebrae. The length of each additional thing is like a palm, and their width is like two fingers.
Cum ergo uis aperire matricem cum eo, tunc fac sedere mulierem super lectum, pendentibus pedibus eius, aperto quod est inter crura eius.	When you have thus opened the matrix with these two things, then make the woman sit on a stool, with her feet hanging down, and open what is between her thighs.
Deinde intromitte ista duo additamenta coniuncta in matricem: et tu es tenens extremitatem instrumenti inferius inter coxas eius.	Then introduce these two things together into the matrix: and you hold the lower extremity of the instrument between her thighs
Deinde aperi manum tuam cum instrumento, sicut facis cum forficibus, aequaliter secundum quantitatem quam uis ex apertione oris matricis, donec faciat Obstetrix quod uult.	Then open your hand with the instrument, like you do with pliers, equally according to the quantity that you wish to open the opening of the matrix, until the Obstetrix does what he wants.
Forma Vertiginis alterius quam dixerunt antiqui Forma Impellentis quo impellitur foetus.	The other form of the Vertebra is called the Form of Impulsion which drives out the fetus.
Forma Almisdac, qua conteritur caput magnum: et assimilatur forcipi, cui sunt dentes in extremitate, sicut uides.	The form of the Almside, which contains the large head: and it is assimilated to the forceps, which have teeth at the end, like these things
Et quandoque fit oblungum, sicut forcipes secundum hanc formam, sicut uides, cui sunt dentes sicut dentes serrae, quo inciditur et conteritur.	And when it is flattened, like the forceps according to this form, like these things, which have teeth like saw teeth, with which it incides and contains
Forma Almisdac quo conteritur caput paruum.	The form of the Almside which contains the small head.
Forma Vncini habentis spinam unam.	The form of the Vncini having a single spine.
Forma Vncini habentis spinas duas.	The form of the neighbor having spines two.
Forma forcipis cui sunt dentes serrae, cum quo conteritur caput foetus.	The shape of the forceps having teeth serrated, with which the head of the fetus is held in place.
Forma Spatumilis habentis duas extremitates ad abscindendum caput.	The shape of the spatula having two extremities to clamp the head
Forma duorum Spatumilium etiam latorum.	The shape of two spatulas also the handles.
Ista instrumenta omnia exercentur, et quanto plus multiplicantur species eorum, et praeparata sunt apud artificem, est uelocior ad operationem suam, et altior apud homines, propter quantitatem suam.	These instruments are all used, and the more numerous their kinds and well prepared they are in the artificer's hand, the more rapid is the operation and the higher among men because of their quantity
Non ergo despicies ex eis instrumentum, quin sit apud te praeparatum.	There must not be disdain for any of these instruments, because they are prepared for you
Inexcusabilis est enim necessitas eorum.	Unnecessary is their absence indeed.
¶ De extractione Secundinae.	Of the extraction of the second (tooth).
Caput LXXVIII.	Head seventy-eighth.
Quando retinetur Secundina apud partum, tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmae, ut retineat anhelitum suum.	When the second is retained at delivery, then it is necessary to extract the lower incisors in order to retain its breath.
Deinde fac eam sternutare cum condisi: et stringe manum tuam super os eius, et nares ipsius.	Then make a scar with the forceps: and stretch your hand over the bone of it, and keep your breath.
Si ergo egreditur per hoc, bonum est.	If it comes out through this, that is good
Si non: tunc accipe ollam, et perfora in coopertorio foramen: et pone in ea herbas aperientes os matricis, sicut calamentum, rutam, et anetum, et camomillam, et sseham, et cassiam ligneam, et centauream: accipe omnes istas herbas, aut quasdam earum, et submerge eas cum aqua, et pone eas super ignem.	If not: then take hold of the bone, and pierce at the apex of the socket: and put in it herbs that soften the bone, such as rue, rhubarb, chamomile, and aloe, and poppy seeds, and saffron, and cassia gum, and centaury: take all these herbs, or some of them, and soak them in water, and put them over fire
Deinde pone embulam arundinis super foramen coopertorii ollae, et extremitatem aliam in os matricis: et teneat eam donec perueniat uapor ad concauitatem matricis.	Then put an embolus of bulrush over the socket of the tooth, and the other extremity in the bone of the jaw: and keep it there until the vapor has gone up to the cavity of the jaw
Deinde fac eam sternutare, sicut diximus.	Then make the incision as we have said.
Secundina enim egredietur cum facilitate.	It will then come out easily enough.
Si autem remaneat post hanc curationem, et non egrediatur: tunc praecipe Obstetrici, ut submergat manum suam in oleo sisamino, aut mucillagine alteae.	If, however, it remains after this treatment and does not come out: then command the Obstetrician to put his hand into the belly and press with the thumb on the navel or with the thick mucus of the elder days.
Deinde intromittat in uuluam, et quaerat cum ea Secundinam.	Then introduce the hand into the belly and seek with it the Second [a vein].
Cum ergo inuenerit eam, tunc accipiat eam, et extendat ipsam paulatim.	When you have found it, then grasp it and gradually extend it outwards
Si autem fuerit annexa in profundo matricis, tunc intromittat manum, secundum quod narrauimus, donec quando inuenerit Secundinam, et extrahat eam paulatim secundum rectitudinem, ut non cadat matrix apud attractionem uehementem: imo oportet, ut permutetur cum facilitate ad latera dextra et sinistra: deinde addatur in quantitatem attractionis.	If, however, it is attached deep in the belly, then introduce the hand as we have said until you find the Second. Then gradually withdraw it outwards along a straight line, so that the belly does not tear from the pulling force: indeed it is necessary to change the position with ease to the right and left sides: then add to the degree of tension as required
Ipsa enim obedit tunc, et seruatur, et euadit ab adhaerentia.	The wound will then obey and will be cured, and will go away from the adhesion.
Quod si os matricis est coartatum, sicut nos iam narrauimus: cura eam cum sternutatione, et ex medicatione ollae cum herbis.	If the belly is closed as we have said: treat the wound with incision and with ointment with herbs
Si autem non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc caue ne fatigeris super eam in iteratione extractionis.	If it does not come out with all that we have said: do not be rash in your handling of the wound.
Verum oportet, ut quod egreditur ad os matricis ex ea, liges ad coxam mulieris.	Indeed it is necessary that it come out to the opening of the belly from the woman's waist.
Deinde clisteriza eam cum unguento tetrapharmacon.	Then close the wound with four drugs ointment
Ipsum enim putrefaciet eam post dies, et dissoluetur, et egredietur.	The wound itself will putrefy the wound after a few days, and will dissolve and go away.
Verumtamen quando putrefit, eleuatur ex ea odor malus ad stomachum et caput, et laedit illud infirmam.	Indeed when it putrefies, it will emit a bad odor from the belly and head, and will cause pain which will bring on weakness
Oportet ergo ut administrentur suffumigationes conuenientes ad illud.	It is necessary therefore that appropriate fumigationations be administered for that.
Quidam autem antiquorum iam experti sunt suffumigationem nasturtii, et ficuum siccarum.	Some of the ancients are experts in fumigation with naphtha and dry figs.
Forma instrumenti quo suffumigatur mulier apud retentionem Secundinae et menstruorum.	The manner of the instrument with which a woman is fumigated at the retention of the second and the menstruation.
Fiat ex uitro simile alcama, aut ex zere: et ponatur extremitas ampla super ignem: et suffumigatio sit posita super prunas: teneat eam, donec consumatur illa suffumigatio: et itera aliam.	Let it be like an umbrella from the back: or from the heel: and put the wide end over the flame: and let the fumigation be placed over the berries: hold it until the fumigation is consumed: and do it again
¶ De curatione Ani non perforati.	Concerning the treatment of the unpierced beast.</start_of_turn>
Caput LXXIX.	Chapter LXXIX.</start_of_turn>
Nascuntur multi puerorum, et Ani eorum sunt non perforati, quos iam opilauit sifac subtile.	Many children are born with their nails unpierced, whom I have seen to have been oiled with subtle saffron.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo, ut obstetrix perforet illud sifac digito suo: et si non, perforet ipsum cum Spatumili acuto: et caueat lacertum, ne tangat eum.	It is necessary therefore that the midwife pierce that with her finger: and if not, pierce it with the sharp spatula: and beware of tears, lest they touch it.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam infusam in uino et oleo.	Then put upon it infused wool in wine and oil.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum cum ungentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with the nails, until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Si autem times quod opiletur, tunc pone in foramine cannulam de plumbo diebus multis, et auferatur quando puer uult egerere.	If indeed they are oiled, then put in the hole a lead cannula for many days, and remove it when the child wishes to scratch.</start_of_turn
Et iam accidit opilatio Ani etiam ex consolidatione uulneris, aut apostematis.	And indeed the oiling of the nails is also from the consolidation of the wound, or from the swelling.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut secetur illa consolidatio, deinde curetur cum eo quod diximus ex curatione et plumbo.	It is necessary therefore that the consolidation be dried, then care for it as we have said concerning the treatment and lead.</start_of_turn
¶ De curatione Fistularum quae accidunt in inferiori parte.	Concerning the treatment of fistulas which occur in the lower part.</start_of_turn
Caput LXXX.	Chapter 8.
Fistulae quae accidunt in inferiori, sunt Nodatio, et Grossitudo quae accidunt prope anum deforis: aut in spacio unius partium: et est Fistula una, aut plures.	The fistulas which arise in the lower part are Nodatio and Grossitudo which happen close to the bones of the limb: either in the space of one part or in several.
Cum ergo antiquatur illa Nodatio, aperitur, et currit ex ea humiditas aquosa alba, aut pus subtile.	When the Nodatio is old, it opens, and white watery moisture or fine pus runs from it
Et quandoque sunt ex istis Fistulis penetrantes.	And sometimes these Fistulas are penetrating
Ergo penetrantes cognoscuntur per illud quod egreditur ex egestione, et uentositate, quando utitur infirmus egestione: et fortasse egreditur ex eis uermis.	Therefore the penetrating ones are recognized by the fact that they issue from discharge and swelling, when the patient uses the egestion: and perhaps they issue from worms.
Et sunt ex eis Fistulae quando sunt in spacio penetrantes usque ad uesicam, et usque ad meatum uirgae.	And these are the kinds of Fistulas when they are penetrating until they reach the bone and the marrow of the limb
Et sunt ex eis penetrantes usque ad iuncturam coxae, et usque ad nodum caudae.	And they are penetrating until they reach the hip joint and the tail bone node
Ex eo autem quo cognoscitur Fistula penetrans usque ad anum, etiam a non penetrante, est, ut intromittas digitum tuum indicem in anum: et intromittas tentam subtilem in Fistulam ex aere, aut ferro: quando non est tortuositas.	From this it is known that a penetrating Fistula until it reaches the limb is also not penetrating, as when you put your finger into the limb: and you put in a needle fine in the Fistula from the air or from the iron, when there is no swelling.
Quod si in ea est tortuositas, tunc intromitte in eam tentam ex plumbo subtilem, aut pilum ex pilis equarum, donec sentias tentam, aut pilum in digito tuo.	When there is swelling in this, then put in the needle fine from lead or horsehair until you feel the needle, or put in the hair in your finger
Quod si non sentis ipsam penitus, neque procedit ex foramine aliquid ex egestione, neque uentositas, neque uermis sicut dixi: tunc scias, quia est non penetrans: propera ergo ad curationem.	If you do not feel the needle itself, neither does it go out from the discharge, nor swelling, nor worms as I said: then you know that it is not penetrating: so proceed to the treatment then
Et quando Fistula est penetrans usque ad uesicam, aut ad meatum urinae: tunc significatio eius est exitus urinae ex ea, et prohibitio eius ab hoc ut consolidetur locus cum medicinis.	And when the Fistula is penetrating until it reaches the bone or the bladder: then the significance of it is the discharge of urine from it, and the prohibition of this until it is consolidated with the physicians.
Si uero est penetrans usque ad iuncturam coxae, aut ad os coxae: tunc signum eius est, quod perueniat tenta usque illuc, si non est in ea tortuositas usque ad os: et inuentio doloris in circumitu partis, et quod egreditur pus ex ea semper: et quod non ualeat in ea medicatio, neque consolidatur cum unguento.	If the wound extends up to the hip joint or the hip bone: then its sign is that the limb will hang down, if there is no twist in it up to the bone: and there will be pain in the surrounding parts, and pus will always come from it; and no remedy will be of any avail, neither will it be consolidated with ointment.
Et in istis Fistulis omnibus penetrantibus non est curatio omnino: et curatio earum est labor et uanitas ei, ex stultis medicis, super quem formatur.	In all such penetrating wounds there is no cure: the cure for them is toil and perseverance, from the stupid doctors on whom they are formed.</start_of_turn>
In illa autem quae non est penetrans, et non antiqua, speratur sanatio cum serro: secundum quod ego narro tibi, et ego iam probaui: et est, ut iaceat infirmus inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et eleua crura eius usque supra coxas ipsius, et coxae eius sint inclinatae ad uentrem ipsius.	But in those which are neither penetrating nor old, healing is hoped for with rest: as I have already said, and as I have shown: that the sick man should lie between your hands over his back, and elevate his limbs up to above his hips, and that his thighs should be inclined towards his belly.</start_of_turn>
Deinde intromittetentam plumbi, aut aeris, si est in Fistula tortuositas, donec scias ubi peruenit tenta.	Then introduce lead or air, if there is a twist in the wound, until you know where the limb hangs.</start_of_turn>
Si autem sentit eam infirmus circa anum, tunc oportet ut intromittas digitum tuum indicem in anum.	If, however, the sick man feels about his limb: then it is necessary to insert your finger into the wound.</start_of_turn
Si ergo sentis in digito tuo tentam iam penetrasse per seipsam detectam, praeter quod sentias inter digitum tuum, et inter ipsum sifac, aut carnem: tunc ergo scias certe, quia est penetrans: non ergo labores in ea, quoniam non est eius sanatio, sicut diximus.	If you feel in your finger that the limb is being pierced by itself, as well as between your finger and the flesh, or bone: then you know certainly that it is penetrating: there is no labour in this, for it is not its cure, as we have said.</start_of_turn>
Dixerunt tamen, quia sanatur in quibusdam hominibus caro, et ex medicatione qua ei speratur iuuamentum, est, ut ignias cauterium subtile secundum amplitudinem Fistulae, sicut praecessit, et intromittas ipsum ignitum in Fistulam, donec perueniat circa anum.	They say that in some people the wound heals by itself, and from the medicine which is expected to help: that is, to apply a gentle cautery according to the size of the wound, as has been said before, and to insert the cautery into the wound until it hangs around the limb.</start_of_turn
Deinde itera illud bis, aut ter, donec scias, quia iam adustae sunt omnes illae carnes additae filtratae, quae sunt similes cannulae pennae auis.	Then repeat that twice or thrice until you know that all those meats added to the filter are now soft like the quills of a bird.
Deinde cura illud cum liciniis inuolutis in butyro, donec egrediantur illae carnes, quae adustae sunt: deinde cura illud cum unguentis generantibus carnem et consolidantibus.	Then keep it covered with butter with cloths until the meats have gone out: then keep it with the things which generate the flesh and solidify it.
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est.	If thus it is healed, that is good.
Et si non, tunc non sanatur cum alia curatione unquam.	And if not, it will not be healed by any other treatment.
