Et si egreditur tenta, et non peruenerit usque ad digitum tuum, qui est in ano, et est inter ipsum et tentam uelamen spissum ex carne, aut sifac: et uides Fistulam in eo quod sequitur superficiem cutis, tunc seca cutem ab initio Fistulae, et tu uadis secando cum tenta quod est in fistula, donec perueniat secatio ubi peruenit tentae extremitas, et liberatur tenta et cadit.	If it comes out and does not reach the finger which is in the anus, which is between the thumb and the great toe of the foot, and there is some thick flesh of meat between the thumb and the great toe of the foot, or fat: then make an opening in the skin following the line of the fistula, and dry the skin from the beginning of the fistula until the end of the fistula is reached, and you dry with the thumb which is in the fistula until the end of the fistula is reached, and the thumb will be freed and fall out
Deinde mundifica illas carnes filtratas, quae assimilantur cannulae pennae auis, ut non remaneat ex eis aliquid.	Then soften those meats which are like the quills of a bird which have been added to the filter, so that nothing remains of them
Si autem uincit te sanguis, et soluit inter te et inter operationem tuam ut seces illas carnes: tunc melius quod fit, et uelocioris iuuamenti, cauterizare eam cum igne, aut cum medicina acuta.	If however blood boils up and mixes with you and the operation, so that you must cut away those meats: then it is better that you cauterize with fire or with acute medicine.
Quoniam cauterium cum igne aggregat habitudines bonas, adustionem illarum carnium additarum, et abscisionem sanguinis, et exiccationem humiditatum.	For the cauterization with fire brings together good habits, brings about the softening of those meats which have been added, and cuts off the blood, and dries up the humours.
Deinde cura illud cum liciniis inuolutis in butyro, aut caulibus tritis, donec locus emittat pus, et egrediantur illae carnes adustae in pus.	Then keep it covered with butter with cloths, or with bruised figs, until pus comes out, and the softened meats go out in the pus
Deinde cura tunc uulnus cum unguentis consolidatiuis, generantibus carnem duram: et sunt medicinae in quibus sunt stipticitas et exiccatio.	Then keep it with the things which solidify and consolidate, which generate flesh firmly: and these are the medicines which have styptic and drying properties.
Nam quando restaurantur, tunc iam sanatur: et non times iterationem.	When restoration is complete, then healing takes place: and not by repetition.
Si autem Fistula iam peruenit usque ad profundum ani, et elongatur a superfluitate corporis: tunc intromitte digitum tuum in anum, et inquire cum eo.	When, however, a fistula persists right through to the depth of the rectum, and is prolonged by excessive body fat: then insert your finger into the rectum and inquire concerning it.
Si ergo sentis tentam, et inter te, et inter eam est uelamen ex sifac, aut carne, et est propinqua penetrationi: tunc non est operatio in illo, nisi secundum uiam fiduciae et spei.	If, therefore, you feel tension and between you and the fistula there is something soft, or fleshly, and it is close to the penetration: then there is no operation in that place, except according to the measure of trust and hope.
Quod est, quia administratur in eo unus trium modorum: aut ut cauterizes ipsam, sicut diximus: aut seces eam, donec consequaris concauitatem eius, ut sit possibile tibi intromittere licinia, et curationem ex proximo.	For in that case one must employ three methods: or one cauterizes the fistula itself, as we have said: or one severs the vein, until you have achieved the subsidence of its swelling, so that it is possible for you to insert instruments, and to effect a cure from the next time
Et non procedas multum cum sectione, ut non incidas lacertum continentem anum, et accidat super infirmum exitus egestionis absque uoluntate.	And do not proceed too much with the incision, lest you cut through the membrane containing the rectum, and cause an excessive discharge of feces without your wish
Deinde cura illud cum eo quod diximus.	Then care for that which we have said.
Fortasse enim sanabitur: aut elonges ipsum uelamen, et mundes ipsum postquam secas ipsum usque prope anum, sicut diximus, aut cum tenta, aut cum instrumento alio acutae extremitatis.	Perhaps indeed it will heal: or you will lengthen the vein which we have mentioned, and cleanse it after you have dried it up to the rectum, as we have said, or with the finger, or with some acute instrument.
Deinde mundifica illas carnes filtratas quae sunt in sectione, usque ubi potes cum perscrutatione.	Then remove the fatty tissues which are in the incision, until the bone is found with careful probing.
Deinde conare restaurationem uulneris totius cum sectione, et orificio superiore ubi consolidatur: et remanet Fistula aperta in interiore parte anus, et erit leuius super infirmum.	Then attempt to restore the entire wound with the incision, and the upper orifice where it is consolidated: and the fistula will remain open in the inner part of the rectum, and will be less painful
Et quandoque suitur Fistula secundum hunc modum: et est, quando intromittis tentam in Fistulam: et est in latere ani circa superficiem corporis cum cute et margine ani: tunc accipe tentam perforatae extremitatis, quae est sicut acus aleskef, id est, praeparantium coria, secundum hanc formam.	And when you suture the fistula in this way: that is, when you insert your finger into the fistula: and it is on the side of the rectum around the surface of the body with skin and the margin of the rectum: then grasp the edge of the perforation, which is like a needle with a handle, that is, prepared to pierce the skin, in this shape.
Et intromitte in eam filum inuolutum ex quinque filis, et circiter ea.	And introduce into the loop the twisted thread from the five threads, and surround it.
Deinde intromitte tentam cum filo in Fistulam, donec consequatur concauitatem eius.	And introduce the needle with the thread into the pocket, until it follows the curvature of the latter.
Si ergo est penetrans in margine ani interius prope, tunc extrahe filum ex illo foramine: ita ut intromittas digitum tuum in anum, et extrahas extremitatem fili, et aggreges duas extremitates simul: et stringe utramque, et dimitte illud die uno, aut duobus diebus: et quanto plus incidit filum in carne, stringe ipsum bene, donec incidantur illae carnes quae sunt inter duas extremitates fili, et cadant: deinde cura uulnus, donec consolidetur, et sanetur.	If it is piercing through the inner margin of the anus close to the rectum, then withdraw the thread from that hole: thus you will introduce your finger into the rectum, and withdraw the end of the thread, and gather together both ends: and tighten both of them, and let go of that day, or two days: and the more the thread has gone into the flesh, tighten it well, until those pieces of flesh which are between the two ends of the thread have fallen away: then care for the wound, until it is healed, and restored to health.
Si autem orificium Fistulae non est penetrans: tunc fac ipsum penetrare quocunque modo praeparatur tibi, nisi sit in profundo multum.	If, however, the opening of the pocket is not piercing: then make it pierce in whatever way you prepare it, except that it should not be too deep
Non enim inest tibi, ut facias illud propter lacertum, ut non incidas ipsum.	It is not to be, that you make it pierce because of the wound, lest you should damage it.
Deinde fac cum ea sicut diximus, donec sanetur.	Then do as we have said, until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Forma Spatumilis spinosi quo finditur Fistula, cuius curuitas est acuta ualde, et pars altera est non acuta, ut non incidat illud quod non est necesse, sicut uides.	Form a spindle-shaped bandage which is found in the pocket, whose curvature is acute above and blunt below, so that it does not damage that which is not necessary, like urine.</start_of_turn>
¶ De sutura Hemorroidarum, ex quibus currit sanguis ex incisione earum: et cura fissurarum.	Concerning the stitching of hemorrhoids, from which blood runs from the incision of them: and care of the split wounds.</start_of_turn>
Caput LXXXI.	Chapter 81.</start_of_turn>
Sunt Hemorroides secundum duos modos.	There are hemorrhoids in two ways.</start_of_turn
Aut enim sunt intra anum, similes uesicis carbonum, uel prunarum: aut quasi ipsae sint grana uuae.	Or they are within the rectum, similar to the stones of dates or plums: or as if they were like the seeds of wheat.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis sunt paruae, et magnae: et sanguis currit ex eis semper, et est una, et sunt multae.	There are both small and large intestines: and blood always flows from the intestines. They are one and there are many.
Et sunt extra anum, et in extremitatibus eius.	They are outside the belly and at their extremities.
Verumtamen istae quae sunt extra anum, sunt secundum plurimum paucae humiditatis, ex quibus currit aqua citrina, aut parum sanguinis cursu assiduo: et sunt secundum colorem corporis.	Indeed those which are outside the belly are mostly small intestines, from which flows clear urine or a little blood slowly: and they are of the colour of the body itself
Et curatio eius quae est intra anum, est, ut praecipias infirmo ut assellet: et exprimatur, donec egrediatur anus, et appareant athelil tibi.	And the treatment of the one inside the belly is that you must urge the sick person to cough: and he will vomit, until the anus is expelled, and you will see little of it.
Propterea ergo et suspende cum uncinis: aut tene eos cum ungue tuo.	Therefore hold him back with hooks: or grasp him with your finger.
Deinde incide eos apud radices suas.	Then cut through his bowels at their roots
Si autem non retinentur in eis uncini, propter humiditatem eorum et ipsorum mollificationem: tunc cape eos cum panno aspero, aut cum coto ex diploide lanea, et extrahe eos cum digitis tuis.	If they do not remain in the belly with the ligatures, because of the moisture of their own and their softening: then cover them with coarse cloth, or with felt from a bag of wool, and draw them out with your fingers
Deinde incide eos, et pulueriza super eos post incisionem quosdam pulueres calidos, ut stent eis loco cauterii.	Then cut through the bowels, and sprinkle upon them after cutting whatever fine powder is warm, so that the belly may remain in its place like a burn
Aut cauteriza eos secundum quod praecessit in capitulo cauterizandi.	Or cauterize them according to what was said in the chapter on cauterization
Deinde cura eos cum reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Then care for the bowels until they are healed.
Quod si non obedit anus egressioni, tunc clisteriza infirmum clisteri in quo sit mordicatio parua, ut lauetur cum eo quod est in ano, et obediat egressioni uelociter, quando exprimit se infirmus.	And if the anus does not readily evacuate, then instill the sick person with a cathartic in the belly where there is a little pain, so that he may evacuate more quickly, when he feels the urge to do so
Si autem athelil sunt extrinseci ab ano, tunc res eorum est leuis, facilis: et est ut capias eos cum ungue tuo, aut capias eos cum uncino, et incidas eos.	If however little things are outside the anus, then the matter is light and easy: and it is as if you were to grasp the intestines with your finger, or grasp them with a ligature, and cut through them
Deinde cura eos cum eo quod diximus, donec sanentur.	Then care for them until they are healed.
Et qui abhorret incisionem cum ferro, tunc oportet ut administres suturam eorum secundum hunc modum.	And whoever shuns incision with the iron, then it is necessary to manage the suture for him in this way.
Accipe filum inuolutum, et intromitte ipsum in acum.	Take the thread that has been loosed, and pass it into the point.
Deinde extrahe athelil ad superiora, et fac ipsum penetrare cum acu in radice eius ex parte altera: et inuolue duas extremitates fili, in inferiori parte acus, et sint latitudinaliter: et stringe athelil strictura forti.	Then withdraw the needle upwards, and make it penetrate with the point at the root of it from the opposite side: and pass through two extremities of the thread, in the lower part of the needle, and let them be parallel: and tighten the knot firmly
Deinde noda filum, et extrahe acum.	Then knot the thread, and withdraw the needle.
Fac illud cum omnibus athelil, et dimitte ex eis unum: nec suas ipsum, ut currat ex eo superfluitas sanguinis.	Do this with all the needles, and let go of one: neither leave it in, lest it cause excess bleeding.
Deinde pone super anum pannum infusum in oleo rosato, aut caeroto, et pone ipsum super anum: et praecipe infirmo, ut quiescat.	Then place above the wound a soaked sponge in rosewater, or vinegar, and place it over the wound: and command the patient to rest.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, donec cadat.	Then let go of it until it falls off
Cum ergo cadunt athelil, cura eos cum unguentis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	When they have fallen out, care for them with unguents, and leave the treatment until they are healed.
¶ De cura Fissurarum.	(End of excerpt
Multotiens enim accidunt ex exiccatione stercoris, et constrictione naturae.	Many times these occur from the evacuation of stool, and the constriction of nature.
Cum ergo antiquantur, et non ualet in eis medicina: tunc oportet ut radas cum puncta Spatumilis, aut cum ungue tuo, donec fiant humidae, et auferatur ab eis cortex superior qui prohibet eas a consolidatione.	When they have occurred like this, and do not yield to medical treatment: then it is necessary to grasp with the point of the spatula, or with your finger, until they become soft, and remove from the skin the outer layer which hinders healing.
Deinde cura eas, donec consolidentur secundum quod oportet.	Then care for them until they consolidate as they should
Si autem non consolidantur: tunc itera eas cum rasione uehementiori quam prima, donec sanguinentur multum, et excorientur deinde cura eas, donec sanentur.	If, however, they do not consolidate: then repeat the process of grasping with the greater reason than before, until they bleed profusely, and are then cleansed with care until they are healed
¶ De curatione Almirmar inuersorum, et non inuersorum: et Athelil siccorum, et Formicae.	On the treatment of boils [al-mirmar] of the flesh, and not of the flesh: and the treatment of simple carbuncles [athelil] and ants [formicae].
Caput LXXXII.	Of the treatment of boils of the flesh, not of the flesh: and of simple carbuncles and ants.
Scias quod Almirmar non est nisi nodus rotundus secundum colorem corporis, similis capiti claui: et fit in toto corpore, praecipue in inferioribus partibus pedum, et digitis: et accidit ex eis dolor apud ambulationem.	You know that a boil is not anything except a round knot according to the colour of the body, like a nail head: and it happens throughout the body, especially in the lower parts of the feet and the fingers: and it arises from an inflammation of the flesh at walking.
Oportet ergo ut secetur quod est in circumitu claui, et teneatur cum forficibus, aut cum uncino, et eradicetur ex radice sua.	It is necessary therefore that the surrounding nail be cut away, and held with pliers or with a needle, and be plucked out from its root
Deinde cura illud: et si uis cauteriza illud secundum quod praecessit in capitulo suo.	Then care for it: and if you wish you may cauterize it according to what has been said in its chapter
Ex athelil autem siccis unus est eminentia parua, aspera, filtrata, rotunda supra superficiem corporis.	But as for simple carbuncles there is one which is a small, rough, filtered, round elevation above the surface of the body.
Et multotiens accidunt in manibus puerorum.	And they often occur in the hands of children
Et curatio eius est, ut extendas athelil, et incidas ipsum: aut stringas ipsum cum filo de serico: aut cum pilo, donec cadat.	And the treatment of it is to extend the carbuncle and cut it out: or to ligate it with a silken thread or with hair until it falls out
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum secundum quod praemissum est cum igne, aut cum medicina acuta: et iam eradicantur athelil inuersi, et non inuersi cum instrumento quod ego dicam.	And if you wish, cauterize it according to what has been said above with fire, or with acute medicine: and thus the inward boils are eradicated, and not the outward ones with the instrument which I have mentioned
Formica autem est etiam eminentia parua filtrata, grossa, super superficiem corporis, uadens in profundum ualde: et quando inuenit eam frigus, sentitur in ea simile mordicationi formicae, et fit in corpore toto: et plurimum eius fit in manibus.	As for ants there is also a small, filtered elevation, large, above the surface of the body, which swells inwards to the depth of the wound: and when it comes into contact with cold, it feels like the bite of an ant, and it happens throughout the body: and most of them happen in the hands
Et curatio eius est, ut accipias cannulam ex penna anseris, aut penna uulturis forti: et pone illam cannulam super Formicam, donec contineat circulus cannulae ex partibus eius.	And the treatment of it is to take a thorn from the claw of a bird, or a strong bristle: and put it over the ant, until the circle of the bristle encompasses the ant.
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum cannula, donec seces quod est in circumitu Formicae: et ponas eam in profundo carnis, et eradices Formicam ex radice eius.	Then withdraw your hand with the cannula until you have severed what is around the ant: and place the needle in the depth of the flesh, and pull out the ant from its root.
Et si uis, fac illud cum cannula aeris, aut ferri, secundum hanc formam.	Or if you wish, do this with an air or iron cannula, according to this form.</start_of_turn>
Sit superius cannulae ad sublimitatem trahens surdum inuolutum, ut alleuietur super digitum apprehensio eius et ipsius reuolutio.	Let the upper part of the cannula reach beyond the root of the surds which are drawn out, so that it may relieve the pressure on the thumb and its withdrawal.</start_of_turn>
Et si uis cauteriza Formicam secundum quod praemissum est in cauterizatione Athelil in capitulo de cauterio.	Or if you wish, burn the ant according to what is stated concerning the cautery of the Athelil in the chapter on cautery.</start_of_turn
¶ De formis Instrumentorum quae administrantur ad Clisteria in aegritudinibus Ani, et solutionis uentris, et colicae.	¶ As for the forms of the instruments which are administered to the Clisteria in ailments of the veins and arteries, and the solution of the belly, and the colic.</start_of_turn
Caput LXXXIII.	Chapter 83.</start_of_turn>
Quandoque Clistere fit ex argento, aut ex aurichalco, aut ex aere fuso, aut malleato.	When the Clistera is formed from silver, or gold, or from blown glass, or hammered out.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque fit ex istis Instrumentis paruum, et magnum, secundum illos in quibus administrantur.	And when they are made from these instruments, both small and large, according to those in which they are administered.</start_of_turn
Illud ergo quod administratur in curatione puerorum paruorum, sit paruum: et quorum ani sunt debiles, aut dolorosi, sic et clisteria eorum.	Thus what is administered in the treatment of young children with soft lungs, is small: and for those whose souls are weak or painful, thus also the Clistera of these.</start_of_turn
Clistere magnum.	Large Clistera.</start_of_turn
Cistere paruum.	Small Clistera.</start_of_turn
Canna eius, id est, caput superius in quo ligatur uter, sit amplum secundum hunc modum: et sit ei distinctio ut ligetur uter sicut uides, et extremitas eius inferior quae intromittitur in anum, sit surda, id est, non aperta, lenis, ualde, trahens ad subtilitatem: et in uno laterum eius sint duo foramina, et in latere altero foramen unum.	The cannula, that is, the upper part which is bound to the uterus, is to be wide according to this manner: and there should be a distinction so that the uterus is bound like water, and the lower part which enters the belly should be solid, that is, not open, soft, yielding, drawing towards thinness: and on one side of it there are two holes, and on the other side one hole.</start_of_turn
Et sit amplitudo foraminis secundum grossitudinem radiorum, et grossius parum, et sit uter in quo ponuntur medicinae ex uesica animalis: aut ex charta ouis, quae sit secundum formam asofrati paruae: cuius radix sit palmus unus.	The breadth of the hole should be according to the length of the rays, and somewhat greater; and let there be a socket in which to place the medical instruments from the animal's body: or from parchment paper, which is according to the form of the asofrat of a date.
Et perforetur foraminibus multis sicut reuoluitur, et sit spacium quod est inter omne foramen grossitudo digiti.	The hole is pierced with many holes as it is rotated, and there is space between each hole as wide as a finger
Deinde intromitte in illa foramina filum forte ex filo crudo, quod sit ex decem filis, aut circiter ea, et aggrega cum eo utrem sicut asofrati.	Then insert into the holes a strong thread of gut, which is from ten threads, or thereabouts, and bind it together like the asofrat of a date
Cum ergo ponitur in eo uter, stringatur in capite clisteris inter duo distinguentia constrictione forti.	When it is thus placed in the socket, it is bound at the head of the clips between two signs of constriction strong
Deinde clisteriza cum eo.	And then clip it together with it.
Et haec est forma circuli utris hic depicta, et foraminum.	This is the form of the circle which is here depicted, and of the holes.
Qualitas autem clisterizandi cum eo, est: ut impleas utrem, aut uesicam ex medicina, quae sit calefacta secundum quantitatem tolerantiae infirmi: et caue ne sit calida ualde, aut frigida ualde.	The quality of the clipping with it is: that you may implement both the belly, or the bladder from the medicine, which is warmed according to the quantity of the patient's tolerance: and take care that it is not too hot or too cold, or too cold.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et eleuet crura sua ad superiora: et pone sub eo inthaan, id est, corium super quod iacent homines, aut linteamen.	Then the patient is laid down on his back, and lifts his legs towards his chest: and put under it a cushion, that is, the skin over which men lie, or a linen cloth.
Deinde inunge extremitatem Clisteris cum oleo, aut cum albugine oui, aut cum mucillagine foenugraeci, aut similium.	Then bind the extremity of the clip with oil, or with alum, or with barley mucilage, or like these.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in anum cum facilitate.	Then insert the instrument itself into the hole with ease.
Deinde accipiat minister utrem cum duabus manibus suis simul, et exprimat ipsum cum uehementia, donec euacuet totum quod est in Clisteri in intestinum.	Then take hold of the belly with two hands and squeeze it, until it evacuates all that is in the clip into the intestine
Deinde extrahe Clistere, et eleuet infirmus crura sua ad parietem.	Then extract the Clistere, and elevate the patient's limbs towards the side.
Quod si medicina cogit eum ad exitum, tunc teneat quantum potest.	If the physician considers him to be at the point of death, then let him support him as much as he can.
Et si dormit cum ea nocte tota, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	If he sleeps throughout the night, this is his last hope for recovery
Si autem clisterizas eum in aegritudinibus solutionis uentris, et festinat exitus eius: tunc itera clistere, donec sanetur.	If, however, you administer the clistere in the bowels of the solution of the belly, and he shows signs of imminent death: then repeat the clistere until he is cured.</start_of_turn>
Quod si in ano sunt hemorroides, aut apostemata laedentia, tunc sit clistere subtile ualde, lene, ex clisteribus quibus clisterizantur pueri.	If there are hemorrhoids or painful abscesses in the year, then let the clistere be gentle and soft, from the clisters which are given to children.</start_of_turn
Et haec sit forma clisteris subtilis super quod sit stricta cutis.	And this is the form of the gentle clistere which is over that which is strict of the skin.</start_of_turn
¶ De curatione Vulnerum capitis sine fractura ossis.	Of the treatment of wounds of the head without fracture of the bone.</start_of_turn>
Caput LXXXIIII.	Head wound.</start_of_turn
Iam dixi in diuisione de curatione uulnerum quod conueniebat libro, et ego dicam hic curationem eorum cum manu, et cum medicinis secundum complementum.	I have already spoken in the discussion of the treatment of wounds which agrees with the book, and I will now speak of the treatment of these with the hand and with the help of physicians according to the complement.</start_of_turn
Dico ergo, quod uulnera diuersificantur secundum illud quo fiunt uulnera, et secundum locum super quem cadit uulnus.	I say therefore, that wounds are varied according to the cause of the wound and according to the place where the wound falls.</start_of_turn
Res ergo quibus fiunt uulnera multotiens, sunt sicut iactus lapidis: aut incisio ensis, aut cultelli: aut percussio cum lancea, aut ligno, aut sagitta: et similibus illis ex rebus multis.	The wounds which are caused by many things are like the blows of a stone: or the cutting of a sword or knife: or the percussion with a lance or stick or arrow: and the like.</start_of_turn
Vulnera autem quae fiunt secundum loca corporis sunt, sicut uulnus quod cadit super caput, aut collum, aut pectus, aut uentrem, aut epar: et similia ex eis membris.	Wounds which are caused by the place of the body are like a wound which falls on the head, or the neck, or the chest, or the belly, or an arm: and the like of these from all parts of the body.</start_of_turn
Et ego sum narrans curationes quorundam uulnerum, ut ponam eam ratiocinationem et regulam super reliqua uulnera.	I am now going to narrate the treatment of certain wounds, so that I can set forth the ratiocination and rule concerning the rest of the wounds.
Et ego incipiam a uulneribus capitis simplicibus: quoniam rememoratio compositorum ueniet in principio capituli tertii.	I shall begin with simple head wounds: for the memory of compound wounds will arise at the beginning of the third chapter
Dico ergo.	I say therefore.
Quando accidit in capite uulnus simplex, et non est fractura ossis: considera tunc, si est ex iactu lapidis, aut ei similibus, et iam fregit cutem tantum: et est uulnus magnum, et times super infirmum euentum apostematis calidi: tunc propera, et phlebotoma cephalicam statim: et non tardes illud: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius: si non fuerit prohibens aliquid a phlebotomia, praecipue si fuerit sanguis qui egreditur ex uulnere paucus.	When a simple wound occurs in the head, and there is no fracture of the bone: then consider, if it is from a stone or something similar, and if only the skin is split: then it is a large wound, and the time of healing is long for a wound of such severity: therefore do this: make an immediate cephalic bleed (phlebotomy): do not delay this; and extract from him from the blood according to the quantity of his virtue: if there is nothing to prevent it, especially if there is little blood flowing from the wound
Et sit phlebotomia ex contrario partis uulneratae.	And let the phlebotomy be from the side opposite the wound
Et caueat infirmus sibi a repletione, et uino, et cibis grossis.	And let the patient be careful from repletion, from wine, and from coarse food
Si autem minutionem prohibet aliquid, tunc minoretur ex cibo, et non appropinquet carnibus, neque uinis.	If anything hinders the reduction (of the wound), then let him abstain from food, and not approach meat or drink wine
Et pone super uulnus si accidit ei apostema calidum, cotum infusum in oleo rosato solo, aut cum uino in quo est stipticitas.	And apply upon the wound if it happens that there is a blood clot, a soft compress of saffron only, or with wine in which there is stypticity.
Si autem securus fueris ab apostemate calido, tunc pone super uulnus, si est recens cum sanguine suo, et non mutauit ipsum aer, puluerem quem ego narrabo post paululum: et si iam mutauit ipsum aer, tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, donec sanetur.	And if you are secure from the blood clot, then place over the wound, if there is still some blood in it, and it has not become black, the powder which I shall tell you of later: and if it has become black, then place over it some unguent, until it is healed
Si autem uulnus est magnum, aut est ex incisione ensis, et similium: et non aggregantur labia eius per puluillos, tunc aggrega ipsa cum sutura, secundum quod ego narrabo in uulneribus uentris de sutura eorum.	And if the wound is large, or is from a wound with a knife, or similar: and the edges do not adhere by themselves with little stitches, then unite them with sutures, according to what I shall narrate concerning the sutures of the internal wounds
Si autem uulnus iam detectum est ab osse, et pendet, et non est retentio eius, nisi in suspensorio paruo: tunc incide ipsum.	If, however, a vein has been detected by the bone, and hangs loose, and its retention is not possible, except in a small suspending apparatus: then cut it off.
Deinde cura uulnus cum medicinis, et restaura in eo carnem duram loco cutis, et praecipe infirmo, ut alatur cibis in quibus est grossitudo, sicut sunt capita, et triticum coctum, donec sit ut puls: et eis similia.	Care for the vein with the physicians, and restore it in the place of the skin, and command the patient to eat nourishing foods, such as heads and cooked wheat, until the pulse returns: and let them be similar.
Quod si inuenis in cute putrefactionem, et non adhaeret ossi: tunc incide putrefactum totum, et proiice ipsum: deinde cura illud.	If you find in the flesh putrefaction, and it does not adhere to the bone: then cut off the putrefied part throughout, and throw it away: then care for the wound
Si autem in his uulneribus est arteria, aut uena ex qua fluit sanguis: et non abscinditur per medicinas, tunc inquire super arteriam.	If, however, in his wounds there is an artery, or a vein from which blood flows: and it is not severed by the physicians, then inquire about the artery.
Si ergo inuenis eam non sectam, tunc seca eam cum Spatumili, aut liga eam.	If, therefore, you find it untied, cut it off with Spatumili, or ligate it.</start_of_turn>
Quod si necessitas prouocat quando non confert illud quod diximus, tunc cauteriza eam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If necessity compels you when it does not conform to what we have said, then cauterize it, until the blood is severed.</start_of_turn>
Si autem uulnera ista sunt parua, simplicia, tunc res eorum est facilis, leuis: ita ut puluerizes super ea hunc puluerem: quoniam consolidat ea antequam mutet ea aer.	If, however, these wounds are small and simple, then the matter is easy and light: thus as to make powder of them over this powder: because it consolidates them before they change them by air.</start_of_turn
¶ Modus Pulueris incarnatiui.	The manner of making powder of the flesh.</start_of_turn>
Recipe olibani partem unam, et sanguinis draconis partes duas, et calcis non extinctae partes tres: teratur totum multum, et cribelletur: et impleatur ex eo uulnus, et constringatur constrictione bona, donec adhaereat super ipsum bene, et coaguletur cum sanguine.	Olive oil one part, dragon's blood two parts, and unslaked lime three parts: mix them all together thoroughly, and grind them: and make from this a paste, and bind it with good constriction, until it adheres well to itself, and coagulates with the blood.</start_of_turn
Deinde stringe ipsum desuper cum puluillis, et dimitte ipsum, neque soluas ipsum dum permanet, ita quod non apostemetur.	Then bind it up with sponges, and send it away, and do not wash it until it remains, so that it does not putrefy.</start_of_turn
Nam non eradicatur ab eo medicina, donec sanatur.	Until it is healed, it is not eradicated by medicine from that.
Et quandoque facit illud calx sola, quando non sunt tibi in praesenti olibanum, et sanguis draconis etiam facit eandem operationem in multis ex uulneribus magnis, quando conuenit ut ponatur super ea et stringantur, et sunt uulnera recentia cum sanguine suo, quae non alterauit aer.	Until it is healed, medicine does not eradicate it from that.
Quod si iam alterauit ea aer quadam alteratione, praecipue quando est in tempore aestatis, tunc non est in positione huius pulueris intentio: cura ergo ipsum cum eo quod diximus, ita ut ponas super ea quaedam unguenta digestiua: aut ponas super ea pultes ex farina hordei, factas cum aqua et melle, donec emittant pus.	Until it is healed, medicine does not eradicate it from that.
Deinde cura ea reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Until it is healed, medicine does not eradicate it from that.
Si uero accidat cum uulnere fractura in osse, et est parua, tunc extrahe illud cum Gesti: et ego iam dicam curationem fracturarum capitis in eo quod futurum est.	Until it is healed, medicine does not eradicate it from that
¶ De uulneribus Colli.	Until it is healed, medicine does not eradicate it from that.
Caput LXXXV.	Until it is healed, medicine does not eradicate it from that
SI Autem uulnus accidat in Collo, tunc non est inter ipsum differentia in medicatione, et inter uulnus capitis quando est simplex.	Until it is healed, medicine does not eradicate it from that
Si autem iam incisus est neruus Colli, aut arteria: tunc si est neruus, non est in eo ingenium, nisi ut deuitetur curatio eius cum eo quod facit stipticitatem uehementem, sicut ziniar, et zegi, et eis similia.	Until it is healed, medicine does not eradicate it from that
Quoniam nocent neruis, et contrahunt eos.	Until it is healed, medicine does not eradicate it from that
Et non ponas super uulnus aliquid frigidum omnino: quoniam substantia neruorum est frigida, et continuatio eius est cum cerebro, quod est sublimius membrorum: et sit illud quo curatur ex medicinis lene, sicut calx lota cum aqua dulci aliquotiens infusa cum oleo, aut cum oleo rosato, et tuthia, quando abluitur etiam cum aqua dulci: et reliqui lapides minerales, secundum hunc modum, et unguenta humida.	Until it is healed, medicine does not eradicate it from that
Si autem uulnus est magnum, tunc administra suturam: aut coarta labia eius cum puluillis.	Until it is healed, medicine does not eradicate it from that
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Until it is healed, medicine does not eradicate it from that
Si uero uulneri est profunditas, aut accidit in eo sinus in inferiori parte eius, in quo iam aggregatur pus, tunc perfora ipsum in magis depresso loco in eo.	If the ulcer is deep, or it breaks into that sinus in its lower part, where pus is collected, then perforate it in a depressed place in that.
Quod si iam incisa est in uulnere arteria, et consecutus est sanguinem eius fluxus: tunc separa, uel seca eam, et liga ipsam: aut cauteriza eam, si prouocat necessitas ad illud.	If an artery is cut in the ulcer, and its blood flow is consequent: then separate it, or dry it up, and ligate it: or cauterize it, if need be for that.</start_of_turn>
Si autem iam incidit spondiles gutturis, aut totum, et saluatae sunt alhaudegi: tunc aggrega labia cutis cum sutura super cannam gutturis, et non tangas guttur, imo aequa ipsum, et reduc ipsum super figuram naturalem.	If, however, the cartilage of the gullet is broken in its entirety, and the fragments are close together: then gather the edges of the skin with a suture over the neck of the gullet, and do not touch the gullet, but rather equalize it, and reduce it to its natural shape.</start_of_turn>
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti, et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot.	Then bind it firmly with a dressing, and discharge it in a few days.</start_of_turn>
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis in quibus est stipticitas et exiccatio, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with poultices which have astringency and drying qualities, until it heals.</start_of_turn>
Si autem uulnus iam fecit impressionem in osse, tunc perquire ipsum: tunc si in ipso sunt fragmenta ossis, extrahe ea omnia, aut quae potes ex eis: et quod non praeparatur, dimitte illud, donec putrescat uulnus, et separetur et alleuietur egressio eius.	If, however, the ulcer has made an imprint in the bone, then inquire about it: then if there are fragments of bone in that, extract them all, or whatever can be extracted from it: and what cannot be prepared, discharge it, until the ulcer has healed, and the opening has closed.</start_of_turn
Quod si uulnus fuerit recens, tunc pulueriza super ipsum puluerem quem narraui.	If the ulcer has been scraped, then powder over it the powder which I mentioned before.</start_of_turn
Si autem uidetur in uulnere os, et fit Fistula: tunc cura ipsam cum eo cuius rememoratio uenit in capitulo suo.	If, however, bone is seen in the ulcer, and a fistula has formed: then care for it as is mentioned in its chapter.</start_of_turn
¶ De uulnere in Spatulis.	(The provided text does not include the section title for this section of the manuscript.)
Caput LXXXVI.	Chapter 86.</start_of_turn>
SI Est percussio lanceae, aut cultelli: et uides eius profunditatem, tunc considera.	If there is a percussion of a lance or a knife, and you see its depth, then consider it.</start_of_turn
Si ergo ex uulnere egreditur uentositas, quando anhelat ex eo infirmus, tunc scias, quia uulnus est mortale.	If any blood proceeds from a wound when the patient desires to draw it out, then you know that the wound is mortal.
Quod si non fuerit ei profunditas, et est recens cum sanguine suo: tunc non ponas in eo a prima hora puluerem, neque stringas ipsum, ut non retineatur sanguis in profunditate eius, et reuertatur ad cor, et interficiat infirmum: sed pone in ipso unguentum attractiuum, et solue ipsum in die bis.	If it is not deep and is accompanied by its own blood: then you do not cauterize it in the first hour, neither do you ligate it, lest the blood be retained in its depth, and thereby cause the patient's death: but apply in it a strong dressing, and evacuate it in two days.
Si uero unguentum non est tibi praesens, tunc pone in orificio uulneris cotum uetustum, ut sugat illud quod egreditur de eo ex humiditatibus: et fac ut dormiat infirmus super uulnus, ut currat quod aggregatur in eo.	If indeed no dressing is present in the wound: then apply in the mouth of the wound a thick wool cushion, that it may absorb what proceeds from it from the humilities: and cause the patient to sleep over the wound, that the blood which collects in it may be cured
Si uero iam praeterierint uulneri tres dies, aut plures, et non accidit infirmo spasmus, neque tremor cordis malus, neque strictura in anhelitu, et uides reliquas dispositiones eius bonas: tunc scias, quia uulnus est saluum.	If indeed more than three days or more have passed from the wound and the patient has neither spasm nor bad tremor of the cord, neither bad congestion in the desire to urinate, and maintains all the other conditions: then you know that the wound is healed.
Cura ergo ipsum et cum liciniis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Treat it therefore with care and with medicines, and with the rest of the cure, until it is healed.
Si uero excusatur sanatio eius, et iam aperitur semper, tunc scias, quia iam factum est Fistula.	If indeed the healing is excused, and it always opens: then you know that a fistula has been made.
Cura ergo ipsam ex capitulo suo.	Treat it therefore from its head to its tail
Et si uulnus est ex incisione ensis, aut cultelli, et est simplex in superficie pectoris, aut dorsi: tunc cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit ex sutura, si est magnum: aut cum puluere, si est paruum.	And if the wound is from a cut of a sword or knife, and is simple on the surface of the chest or back: then treat it as if it were large: or with powder if it is small
Si autem iam fecit impressionem in osse, et incidit ex eo frusta: tunc inquire uulnus, et propera ad extrahendum illa frusta, si sunt separata.	But if it has made an imprint in the bone, and has burst from it: then inquire about the wound, and proceed to extract the fragment, if they are separated.
Si uero non sunt separata, tunc dimitte ea, donec putrefiat uulnus, alleuiatur enim extractio eorum.	But if they are not separated: then leave them alone, until the wound putrefies, so that the extraction of them may be easier.
Reliquorum autem uulnerum accidentium in reliquis membris iudicium in curatione, est iudicium eius quod diximus.	The judgment concerning the remaining wounds on the other limbs is that of the physician.
¶ De uulneribus Ventris, et exitu intestini, et exitura eorum.	Concerning the wounds of the belly, the intestines, and their exits
Caput LXXXVII.	Chapter 87
Disruptio quae accidit uentri, est magna, et media, et parua.	The disruption that occurs within the belly is great, medium, or small.
Ex magna igitur quandoque egreditur intestinum, aut numerus intestinorum.	From the great comes the evacuation of the intestines, or a number of intestines
Quare fit intromissio eorum, et eorum sutura uehementior et difficilior.	Therefore the introduction of the bowels, and their suture, is more difficult and demanding
Et disruptio parua etiam fit difficilis ex modo alio.	And the small disruption is also difficult in another way
Sequitur ergo, ut sit reductio eorum difficilior, si non properas in intromissione sua ad locum suum statim: quoniam inflatur, aperitur, et ingrossatur: quare fit difficilis introitus eius.	Therefore, it follows that the reduction of these is more difficult if you do not immediately perform the introduction into its place: for it swells, opens, and becomes thickened: which makes its entrance difficult.
Propter hoc ergo fit melior disruptionum disruptio media: quoniam cum ea non fit difficilis reductio intestini, sicut fit dissicilis in his duabus speciebus.	For this reason, the medium disruption is better: because with it the reduction of the intestines is not difficult, as it is with the small or great disruptions
Scias, quod sutura uenris est secundum quatuor modos.	You know that the suture of the bowels is done in four ways.
Duae suturae communes conueniunt in sutura uentris, et in sutura reliquorum uulnerum corporis: et duae suturae aliae proprie communicant reliquis uulneribus.	Two sutures are common in the suture of the belly, and in the suture of the rest of the limbs: and two other sutures are done properly with the rest of the wounds
Verumtamen sunt magis propriae cum sutura uentris: et ego narro tibi unamquamque cum expositione, et declaratione.	However, there are other proper methods when suturing the belly: and I shall narrate them all with their exposition and their declaration.
Dico ergo, quia quando uulnus est paruum, et egreditur ex eo aliquid ex intestino, et fit difficile reducere ipsum: tunc illud est propter unum duorum modorum.	I say, because when a wound is small, and something from the intestine comes out of it, and it is difficult to reduce it: then this is due to one of the two methods.
Aut propter paruitatem disruptionis, sicut diximus: Aut quoniam in intestino est inflatio propter frigus aeris.	Either because of the smallness of the disruption, as we have said: or because there is inflation in the intestine due to the cold of the air.
Quando ergo illud est ita, tunc oportet ut calefacias ipsum, ita ut submergas spongiam, aut pannum humidum in aqua tepida sola.	When it is thus, then it is necessary to heat it, so that you may immerse the sponge or wet bag in tepid water alone.
Aut decoquas in aqua squinantum, et cyperum, et spicam, et embroces cum ea intestinum, donec resoluatur inflatio.	Or boil it in water with barley, pepper, and spicery, and embrace the intestines with these, until the swelling subsides.
Quandoque facit illud uinum in quo est stipticitas: et est melius quam aqua sola in resolutione inflationis.	When it has made the liquid in which there is stickiness: it is better than plain water in resolving the swelling
Cum ergo uides inflationem iam resolui, tunc humecta intestinum cum aqua in qua decocta est altea, aut malua.	When the swelling has been resolved, then moisten the intestines with the water in which it has been boiled, or with vinegar.
Nam per illud alleuiatur introitus eius cum re parua.	For in this way it will soothe its entrance with a small thing.
Si autem excusatur reditus eius post hanc curationem, tunc finde in disruptione parum, cum instrumento quo secantur hemorrhoides.	If however it escapes after this treatment, then you will find it in slight disruption, with the instrument with which hemorrhoids are cut off
Et curatio prima est melior quando praeparatur, quam sectio: et non fit coactio ad secandum post necessitatem et defectum instrumenti.	The first treatment is better when it is prepared, than when it is forced, and does not cause a pressing of the cutting instrument beyond what is necessary and the defect of the instrument itself
Sit pars eius una quae est torta, acuta, et pars eius altera non acuta, et extremitas subtilis non sit cum subtilitate Spatumilis, imo sit obtusior parumper: et est illa quae similatur caiada, sicut uides.	Let one part be acute and the other not acute, and the outer part should not be like that of Spatumilis, but rather be somewhat blunt: and this is like a chick's foot, as regards the liquid
Cum ergo amplificatur uulnus, et ingreditur intestinum, tunc oportet, ut sit reductio eius secundum formam suam naturalem in loco suo sibi proprio, si possibile est super illud: quoniam est melius.	When the vessel has been strengthened and the intestine has been introduced, then it is necessary to reduce it according to its natural form in its own place, if possible over that: for this is better
Quando uero disruptio est ampla in inferiori parte uentris: tunc oportet ut facias iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et pone crura sua altiora capite suo.	When the rupture is wide at the lower part of the belly: then it is necessary to make the sick man lie on his back, and place his knees higher than his head.
Et si est in superiore parte uentris, tunc pone caput eius, et pectus ipsius altiora quam eius inferiora.	And if it is in the upper part of the belly, then place his head and chest higher than his feet
Et similiter si est disruptio in una duarum partium uentris, tunc pone intentionem tuam, et tuam considerationem semper in hoc, ut pars in qua est uulnus sit altior parte altera.	If there is a rupture in one of the two parts of the belly, then set your intention and consideration on this, that the part which has the wound be above the other part.
Et ita oportet, ut admimistres illud in uulneribus magnis, et in uulneribus mediis.	And thus it is necessary, that you should look at these things in great wounds and in medium wounds
In uulneribus autem paruis, pone illud secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	In small wounds, set it according to what is prepared for you
Deinde fac ut sit praesens inter manus tuas minister pius, qui teneat disruptionem totam manu sua: et aggrega labia eius.	Then make it present between your hands, your pious assistant who will hold the whole disruption of the hand: and gather its lips.
Deinde detege ex ea ei qui sequitur suturam aliquid post aliquid: et iste est modus suturae communis unius.	Then take from it whatever follows the suture something after something: and this is the method of common suture of one
Et est, ut accipias acum, aut numerum acuum secundum quantitatem amplitudinis uulneris.	And it is, that you take the needle, or the number of needles according to the quantity of the wound
Deinde dimitte ab extremitate disruptionis quantitatem digiti anularis, id est, medici: et fige acum unam praeter quod intromittas in eam filum in duabus extremitatibuis cutis, cum duabus extremitatibus sifac quod est sub cute ab interioribus, donec facias eam penetrare ab alia parte, et tu iam aggregasti duas extremitates cutis, et duas extremitates sifac: et fiunt quatuor ordines.	Then send from the extremity of the disruption the quantity of the little finger, that is, the physician: and fix the needle once having passed it into the flesh in two extremities of the skin, with two extremities of fat which is under the skin, until you make it penetrate from another part, and you have gathered together the two extremities of the skin, and the two extremities of fat: and there are four orders.
Deinde stringe cum filo duplo in circumitu acus aliquotiens a duabus partibus simul, quousque sint aggregata duo labia uulneris aggregatione decenti.	Then string with a double thread around the circumference of the needle several times from two parts together, until two lips of the wound are gathered together with a decent aggregation.
Deinde dimitte grossitudinem digiti etiam, et fige in eis acum aliam: postea reta eam cum filo, sicut fecisti cum acu prima.	Then send away the length of the little finger also, and fix in the flesh another needle: afterwards draw back the seam with the thread, as you did with the first needle.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum eo quo indiges ex acubus, donec compleas constrictionem uulneris totius.	Do not cease doing this until you have completed the constriction of the whole wound
Et sint acus mediae inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem: quoniam acus subtiles ualde uelociter incidunt carnem: et grossae sunt difficilis introitus in cutem: propter illud oportet ut sint mediae in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	And the needles are medium between the length and the thickness: because the fine needles slip easily through the flesh: and the thick ones are difficult to enter the skin: because of this it is necessary that they be medium in thickness, and long.<start-of-turn>
Et non oportet, ut figatur acus in duabus extremitatibus cutis propinquae multum: ut non incidatur caro uelociter, et aperiatur uulnus ante consolidationem sui, et non elongentur etiam cum sutura, ut non prohibeatur uulnus a consolidatione.	Neither should the needle be left protruding at two distant points of the skin near each other: for thereby the flesh will be more likely to split or tear before consolidation has taken place, and will even remain elongated even after stitching, thereby hindering consolidation.
Deinde incide extremitatem acuum, ut non laedant infirmum apud somnum suum: et pone eis puluillos ex pannis ab omni parte, qui teneant extremitates acuum: et dimitte eos, donec scias quod uulnus iam consolidatum est.	Neither should the needle be left protruding at two distant points of the skin near each other: for thereby the flesh will be more likely to split or tear before consolidation has taken place, and will even remain elongated even after stitching, thereby hindering consolidation.
Et haec quidem species suturae cum acubus taliter est conuenientior in uulneribus paruis.	And thus is the kind of suture which is more suitable for small wounds.
Quoniam sufficit in sutura eorum acus una, aut duae, aut circiter eas.	For in stitching, one or two needles, or somewhat more, will suffice.
Sutura autem secunda communis est, ut aggreges cum sutura extremitates quatuor: extremitates, duas cutis, et extremitates duas sifac in uice una, cum acu in qua sit filum inuolutum aequale in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	The second common kind of suture is that in which the four extremities are held together by two stitches: two of the skin and two of the fat with the needle in which the thread is wound being of equal thickness and size
Deinde quando penetraueris cum acu has extremitates quatuor, reduc acum a parte a qua incaepisti eadem, ut cadat filum retatum a superiori parte uulneris: ut sit sutura, sicut sutura panni quo stringuntur panni, et pone inter omnem suturam quantitatem grossitudinis digiti minoris.	And when you have penetrated with the needle through the four extremities, reduce the needle from the part from which you began, so that the wound may be held by the remaining thread: as is the case with the stitching of cloth by which cloth is bound, and put between every suture as much of the thickness of a little finger
Hanc autem suturam sciunt homines.	This kind of suture is well known to men
Et cum hac sutura ego sui uulnus quod acciderat uiro in uentre suo, qui fuerat uulneratus cum cultello, et erat disruptio uulneris maior palmo uno: et exierat ex intestinis circiter duos palmos ex intestino medio, et erat disruptio in medio uentris.	And when I performed this suture on a wound which had been caused by a knife in its belly, which was ruptured through and through from the palm of the hand, and had burst out from the intestines almost two palms from the middle of the intestine, and there was a rupture in the middle of the belly
Reduxi ergo illud postquam stetit intestinum eius extra uulnus xxiiii horis.	I reduced the wound accordingly after I had set the intestines outside the wound for twenty-four hours
Consolidatum est ergo uulnus in spacio quod fuit circiter XV dies: et curaui ipsum, et sanatus est: et uixit post illud annis multis, conuersatus in suis dispositionibus.	The limb has been consolidated for about fifteen days and has healed: I have treated it and it is now cured. It has remained sound ever since, and has returned to its normal condition.
Et medici iudicauerant, quod non sanaretur.	The physicians declared that it would not recover.</start_of_turn>
Et ex miraculo fuit, quod non curaui illud cum unguento.	And miraculously, I cured it without medication.</start_of_turn>
Quoniam fui in loco in quo non inueniebatur unguentum, neque aliquid ex medicinis.	Since I was in a place where unguent was not to be found, and there was no doctor there.</start_of_turn>
Posui ergo super uulnus cotum uetustum bis in die, et assiduaui ablutionem eius cum aqua mellis, donec sanatum est.	I put on the limb a warm compress twice a day, and I bathed it diligently with sweet water until it healed.</start_of_turn>
Duas autem species suturae proprias dicam secundum narrationem sermonis.	I used two kinds of stitches as described in the sermon.</start_of_turn>
Et est, ut incipias cum sutura acuta: et intromittas acum ab exteriori ad interiorem partem.	And it is necessary to start with a fine suture: and you insert the point from the outside to the inside of the part.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo penetrat acus in cutem, et in lacertum euntem secundum longitudinem et latitudinem totius corporis: dimitte extremitatem sifac in latere in quo intromisisti acum, et fac penetrare in extremitatem aliam ab interiori parte ad exteriorem in extremitate altera mirach.	When the needle has penetrated the skin, and has passed through the tough part of the wound according to the length and breadth of the entire body: withdraw the point which you inserted at the beginning in the side where you introduced the needle, and make the needle pass through from the inside to the outside of the opposite side at the other end.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo feceris eam penetrare, tunc fac eam penetrare secundum hoc in eadem hac extremitate mirach ab exteriori parte ad interiorem: et dimitte extremitatem sifac, quae est in hoc latere, et fac penetrare acum in extremitatem alteram ab interiori parte ad exteriorem: et fac penetrare cum penetratione tua qua facis eam penetrare in sifac extremitate mirach, quae est in parte eius, donec penetret in ipsum totum.	When you have made the needle pass through, then make it pass again in the same place from the outside to the inside: and withdraw the point which is in this side, and make the needle pass through the opposite side from the inside to the outside: and make the needle pass through with the same direction as you made it penetrate in the point which is in the part, until it penetrates the whole thing.</start_of_turn
Deinde incipe etiam ab hoc eodem latere, et sue ipsum cum extremitate, quae est ex sifac in latere alio, et extrahe acum ex cute quam penetrauit.	And then start from this side also, and join it with the opposite side, and withdraw the needle from the skin where it penetrated.</start_of_turn
Deinde reduc eam in illam cutem, et sue extremitatem sifac, quae est in latere alio, cum hac extremitate mirach: et extrahe eam ex cute quae est ex parte eius, et fac illud uice una, et alia: et fac illud uice post uicem, usquequo suas extrinsecum totum secundum illud exemplum.	Then reduce the skin to that same area, and scrape off the outer extremity which is on the other side, along with the inner one: and extract from the skin that which is from its part, and make it one with the other, and the other with the first: and make the latter one like the former, until the outer surface is complete according to that example.
Et summa huius suturae, est ut suas sutura pellipariorum qua suunt pelles: ita ut suas sifac uice una ex parte una extremitate cutis: et ut dimittas eam uice alia ex parte alia, donec compleas.	The sum of all these sutures is that of the skin-stitches which are to be made for the skin: so that the scraped area may be made one with the remainder of the skin by means of the sutures which are to be made from the outer part of the extremity to the inner part, and from the inner part to the outer part, until the surface is complete.
Secunda species suturae propriae, quam dixit Gale nus.	The second kind of proper suture which Gale has mentioned.
Iste eius sermo narratus est, ut suas eam secundum similitudinem, qua suunt eas quidam medicantium, ita quod aggregant omnem partem ad comparem suam conuenientem per naturam: et applicant extremitatem sifac ad eius aliam extremitatem, et extremitatem mirach ad extremitatem eius aliam.	This is how it is said that they should be made like the things which some physicians do, in order that every part may be gathered according to its kind: and that you should scrape off one extremity against the other, and the inner against the outer.
Et illud fit secundum quod narro tibi.	And this is done according to what I have told you.
Oportet ut figas acum in extremitatem mirach propinquam tibi ab exteriori parte, et facias eam penetrare ad interiorem in eo solo: et dimittas duas extremitates sifac.	The liver should be placed against the inner side of the outer extremity, and the skin should be pierced through from the outside inwards in that place: and extract the two extremities.
Deinde reuolue acum, et fac eam penetrare ab exteriori parte ad interiorem in duas extremitates sifac, scilicet utrinque.	Then draw out the liver, and make the skin penetrate from the outside inwards through two extremities of the scraped area, namely both of them.
Deinde reuolue utrasque, etiam fac penetrare utrasque ab interiori usque ad exteriorem, in duas extremitates mirach alias, quae sunt in latere opposito.	Then draw out both of them, and also make them penetrate from the inside outwards through the two outer extremities which are on the opposite side
Et iste modus suturae est melior sutura communi facili, et est sutura cuius praecessit rememoratio.	This is the best way of stitching, and is the suture which requires the greatest memory
Iste est ergo sermo Galeni etiam.	This is indeed what Galen has said.
Et dixerunt quidam.	And some have said.
Retificatur sutura uentris cum duabus acubus.	The suture within is corrected with two squares.
Quod est, ut intromittas in eis utrisque filum unum: et incipe cum intromissione acus, ex eo quod est apud te, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, secundum suturam eorum qui suunt coria aequaliter.	When the suture is within, two squares are added. That is, you pass through the tissue with one thread: and begin with the needle that is towards you, and make it penetrate until it reaches the other side, following the direction of the suture which joins the tissues equally
Et scias, quod quando disruptio est in medio uentris: tunc sutura eius est difficilior quam reliquorum locorum uentris.	And you know that when the disruption is in the middle of the belly: then the suture of that is more difficult than the rest of the belly
Iudicium uero medicationis uulneris, est iudicium reliquorum uulnerum.	The judgment of the ulcer of the wound is the judgment of the rest of the wounds.
Quod est, quia quando tu consequeris uulnus recens cum sanguine suo, antequam alteret ipsum aer: et reducis intestinum, et suis ipsum, et aptas ipsum: tunc pone super puluerem incarnatiuum.	When you follow the wound along with its blood, before it changes itself: and you reduce the intestine, and bring it close, and fix it: then you put on powdered ochre over the wound
Quod si aer iam alterauit uulnus: tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, quae sunt tibi praesentia, donec faciant pus: et cadant fila, et consolidentur sifac, et mirach.	When the air has already changed the wound: then you put on over it some unguents which are present, until they make pus: and the threads fall out, and they are consolidated, and it is healed
Deinde cura illud sicut est curatio reliquorum uulnerum, donec sanetur.	And then care for it as for the healing of the rest of the wounds, until it is healed
Si autem non sunt tibi praesentes medicinae, tunc pone super ipsum statim, exquo incipit emittere pus, cotum uetus: et permuta ipsum bis in die, sicut docui te, donec sanetur.	But if there are no remedies at hand, then you put on over it immediately, from which point it begins to discharge pus, slightly fat: and change it twice a day, as you have been taught, until it is healed
Nam tu non indiges medicatione alia in pluribus dispositionibus, quando uulnera sunt simplicia.	For you do not apply another remedy in many situations when the wounds are simple
Si autem times, quod communicet uulnus membris principalibus in laesione, tunc oportet ut submergas lanam lenem in oleo temperatae caliditatis, aut in oleo rosato: et pone ipsam in circumitu locorum quae sunt inter inguina, et sub ascellas.	If however you fear that the wound communicates with the principal parts of the body in the lesion: then it is necessary that you immerse fine wool yarn in lukewarm water, or in rose water: and put it around the parts which are between the groin and the armpits
Quod si sentit dolorem, aut punctiones, aut putrefactionem in intestinis suis (nam multotiens accidit illud) tunc clisteriza ipsum cum uino stiptico, nigro, tepido: praecipue si putredo iam peruenit in intestino, et facta est exitura penetrans usque ad concauitatem eius.	If he feels pain, or swelling, or putrefaction in his intestines (for this often happens to him), then he must anoint himself with vinegar of wine, black and warm: especially if the putrefaction has already penetrated the intestine, and an opening has been made through to its cavity.
Et scias, quod illud quod est ex intestino grosso, est facilioris sanationis: et quod ex eis est ex subtili, difficilioris sanationis.	And know this, that which is from the great intestine is easier to heal: and that which is from the small intestine is more difficult to heal.
Intestinum autem quod nominatur Ieiunum, non suscipit sanationem ex uulnere quod accidit in eo omnino: et illud est propter multitudinem eius, quod est ex uenis, et magnitudine earum, et propter subtilitatem corporis eius, et propinquitatem ipsius naturae neruorum.	But the intestine which is called the jejunum, does not endure healing from the wound that has happened to it throughout: and this is because of the multitude of its veins, and the greatness of their number, and because of the subtility of its body, and for its nearness to its own nature of nerves.
Si autem illud quod procedit ex uulnere est zirbum, et consequeris ipsum recens: reduc ipsum secundum reductionem tuam, qua reducis intestina aequaliter.	If, however, that which proceeds from the wound is pus, and you follow it, then reduce it according to your reduction which you make of the intestines equally.
Si uero praeteriit ei spacium, et iam factum est uiride, aut nigrum: tunc oportet ut stringas ipsum cum filo supra locum qui denigratus est ex eo, ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	If, however, it has passed beyond that space, and has become black or dark: then it is necessary to string it with thread above the place which has become defiled, in order that the blood does not flow out from it.
In zirbo enim sunt uenae et arteriae.	For in the pus there are veins and arteries.
Deinde incide quod est praeter illud ligamentum, et pone duas extremitates fili pendentes ex inferiori parte uulneris extra ipsum: ut alleuietur super te attractio eius, et extractio ipsius apud casum zirbi, et emissionem pus uulneris.	Then cut through that which is beyond that ligament, and place two hanging threads from the lower part of the wound outside of it: in order to support over that which attracts it, and to extract it from the case of the pus, and to emit the pus of the wound.
¶ Rememoratio uulneris quod accidit in Intestino.	Remember the wound that happened in the Intestine
Quando accidit disruptio in Intestino, et est parua: tunc possibile est, ut restauretur in quibusdam hominibus: propterea, quia ego uidi qui fuit uulneratus in uentre suo cum percussione lanceae, et erat uulnus a dextra stomachi, et antiquatum est uulnus: et factum Fistula, et exiuit ex eo egestio, et uentositas.	When disruption happens in the Intestine, and it is small: then it is possible, in some people, that it may be healed: because I saw that which was wounded in the middle of the stomach by the blow of a lance, and the wound was ancient: and a fistula was made, and it went out from it egestion, and swelling.
Posui ergo curationem, usque quod ego non fui confisus in sanatione eius: neque cessaui subtiliare ipsum, donec sanatus est, et consolidatus est locus.	I remain in attendance until he is cured, for I am not relieved until his health has recovered completely: neither do I cease until he is fully healed and his position is firm.
Postquam ego uidi locum iam consolidatum, timui super infirmum, quod accideret super infirmum accidens malum in uentre suo: et non accidit ei ex illo accidens malum.	Once I have settled in his place, I fear over the patient, lest something bad should happen to him: and nothing bad has happened to him from that which might have happened to him.
Et remansit in melioribus dispositionibus suis, comedens et bibens, et futuens, et intrauit balneum, et exercitatus est in dietis suis.	I remain in better positions, eating and drinking, trusting and having hope, and I bathed him and exercised him in his diet.
Et iam dixerunt quidam experimentatorum, quia quando accidit in Intestino uulnus, et est paruum: tunc oportet ut ligetur secundum hunc modum.	And some of the experimenters say, when there is a wound in the intestines and it is slight: then it must be bound in this way.
Et est, ut accipias formicas magnorum capitum.	And it is like taking large ants.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris, et pone formicam unam ex eis quae habeant os apertum super duo labia uulneris.	Then join together two lips of the wound, and put an ant on one of those which have an open jaw above two lips of the wound
Cum ergo capit super ea, et stringit os suum, abscinde caput eius, adhaeret enim, et non soluitur.	When the head is over them, and it binds its jaw, cuts off its head, and it will adhere to it, and will not break
Deinde pone formicam aliam prope primam, et non cesses facere illud cum formica post formicam secundum quantitatem uulneris totius.	Then put another ant close to the first, and do not cease doing this until the wound is complete
Deinde reduc ipsum, et sue uulnus.	Then reduce it, and its wound.
Illa enim capita remanent annexa in Intestino, donec cibetur Intestinum, et sanetur, et non accidat infirmo nocumentum penitus.	These heads remain annexed to the intestines until the intestines are fed and healed, and do not cause pain to the patient
Et iam possibile est, ut ligetur Intestinum etiam cum filo subtili: quod abstersum est ex intestino animalis, annexo cum eo postquam intromittitur in acum.	And it is possible to bind the intestines even with a fine thread: which has been taken from the intestines of an animal, and is annexed to it when it is introduced into the belly
Et est, ut accipias extremitatem huius fili ex intestino, et excarnetur multum.	And take the extremity of this thread from the intestines, and remove a great deal of it.
Deinde liga in extremitate eius filum lini subtile inuolutum.	Then the ligament at its extremity is wrapped with a fine thread.
Deinde intromitte illud filum in acum, et sue cum eo intestinum.	Then introduce the thread into the knot, and pass it through with the gut
Deinde reduc ipsum in disruptionem.	Then tighten the knot.
Et iste modus suturae cum formicis et intestino, non est nisi secundum uiam fiduciae et spei.	And thus is the manner of stitching with needles and gut, except for some cases of great confidence and hope.
Scias, uulnus quod est magnum, amplum, praecipue si est in uno intestinorum gracilium: tunc non est ingenium nisi subtiliatio, neque est eius sanatio omnino.	You know that a large, wide vessel, especially if it is within a graceful gut: in such a case there is no skill except meticulous suture, and no healing is possible
¶ De cura Zuchemen, et Fistularum.	With regard to care of wounds and fistula.
Caput LXXXVIII.	Chapter 88.</start_of_turn>
Scias, quod omne uulnus, aut apostema quando ueterascit et antiquatur, et fit ulcus, et non consolidatur, et emittit pus semper, et non abscinditur: tunc nominatur uniuersaliter in quocunque membro fuerit Fistula, et nos nominamus ipsum Zuchemen.	You know that every wound, or fistula when it has become old and hardened, and has become a ulcer, and does not consolidate, and emits pus constantly, and does not heal: in such a case it is called universally in every part of the body a fistula, and we call it Zuchemen.</start_of_turn>
Et Fistula quidem est secundum ueritatem nodatio filtrata, dura, alba: cum qua non est dolor, cui est concauitas pennae auis: et propter illud nominant eam quidam Risati, id est, pennam.	And a fistula is indeed according to truth a filtered node, hard, white: which does not cause pain, which has the consistency of a feather of a bird: and for this reason they call some of them Risati, that is, feathers.</start_of_turn
Et est in quibusdam horis humida, quae emittit pus.	And sometimes in certain hours it is wet, which emits pus.</start_of_turn
Et fortasse scinditur humiditas in quibusdam horis.	And sometimes the wetness may split in certain hours.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque est haec humiditas multa, et est pauca: et est grossa, et est subtilis.	And sometimes there is much of this wetness, and little: and it is large, and is soft.</start_of_turn
Et ego iam praemisi in diuisione, tunc cum dixi uulnera, quod omne ulcus quod non sanatur, neque nascitur in eo caro, non est illud nisi propter unam nouem caussarum.	And as I have said previously in the discourse, when I said that every ulcer which does not heal, and which is not born in this flesh, is not because of one cause.</start_of_turn
Quarum una est, aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore: aut propter maliciam eius: aut quoniam inter ipsum, et super labia eius est caro dura, prohibens natiuitatem carnis: aut quia est multae sordis et sordiciei: aut quoniam ulcus in seipso est putridum, et materia quae mittitur ei est malae qualitatis: aut quoniam medicina est inconueniens in curatione eius: aut quoniam corruptio cadens in regione est genus pestilentiae, aut per proprietatem in regione, sicut accidit in Caesaraugusta: in qua fit difficilis digestio aegritudinum, et tardatur in ea sanatio apostematum per naturam: aut quoniam in eo est os unum, aut numerus ossium.	When one is in a state of scarcity of blood in the body: or because of the malice of the blood itself: or because of the hardness of the flesh between the labia, which hinders the birth of flesh: or because of the abundance of pus and phlegm: or because the ulcer in itself is putrid, and the matter which discharges from it is of bad quality: or because the medicine is unsuitable for its treatment: or because corruption is falling in the region, and is a kind of pestilence: or by reason of property in the region, as for example in Caesaraugusta, in which there is great difficulty of digestion for ailment, and the healing of wounds is delayed by nature: or because in it is one bone, or a number of bones.
Et ego iam ostendi omnes istas caussas et signa earum, et curationes ipsarum cum medicinis in diuisione: et oportet hic ut faciam te scire curationem Fistulae et Zuken, quae fit per uiam operationis cum manu.	I have also mentioned all these causes and signs, and the treatments for them with physicians. It is necessary that you write here the treatment for fistula and swelling, which is done by one operation with the hand.
Scias ergo, quod Fistula accidit in omnibus membris corporis.	You know therefore that fistula can occur in all the members of the body.
Nam ex eis sunt Fistulae quae perueniunt ad uenas magnas et arterias, aut neruos, aut sifac: aut ad intestinum, aut ad uesicam, aut ad aliquam ex costis: aut ad aliquam ex spondilibus dorsi, aut ad aliquam iuncturarum compositarum compositione: sicut manus, et pedis: et ex eis sunt quae uadunt ad propinquitatem membri principalis, et similium.	There are fistulas which extend to large veins and arteries, or nerves, or fat: or to the intestine, or the bladder, or to some of the bones: or to some of the vertebrae or to some of the compound joints: such as the hand, and the foot. And there are those which arise from proximity to the main limb and its parts of the same kind
Quae ergo ex his Fistulis est secundum hunc modum, est ex aegritudinibus difficilis sanationis, et non recipit curationem, et occupatio cum ea est labor et ignorantia.	For this reason, the fistulas are of this kind because of the difficulty of healing the ailment, and do not receive treatment, and are accompanied by labor and ignorance
Quod si est ex Fistulis aliqua cuius profunditas non peruenit ad haec loca quae dixi: et speras, et confidis in curatione eius, et uis peruenire ad cognitionem illius, tunc accipe tentam ex aere, aut ferro, si Fistula tendit secundum rectitudinem, et perquire eam cum ipsa.	If, however, any fistula does not reach this depth, and you hope and trust in the treatment of it, and wish to reach cognition of it, then attempt to drain it from the air, or from iron, if the fistula follows a straight course, and inquire about it with her/him.
Si autem in Fistula est tortuositas, tunc inuestiga eam cum tenta de plumbo subtili.	If, however, there is a twist in the fistula, then you should investigate it with a fine lead weight.
Quoniam plumbum cum lenitate sui corporis alleuiatur, et curuatur circa tortuositatem.	Since lead is flexible with its body, it will curve around the twist
Quod si Fistula est habens orificia multa, non est tibi possibile ut significes super eam cum tenta.	If there are many openings in the fistula, it is not possible to perform an investigation with a weight on a hook.</start_of_turn>
Clisteriza ergo ex eis orificium ex orificiis suis.	Explore the cavity from each opening through its own opening.</start_of_turn>
Nam humiditas qua clisterizas ipsum, uadit uersus orificia alia, et currit ex eis.	For moisture which you apply to explore will spread out over other openings and will run out of the cavity.</start_of_turn
Deinde exquisite inquire secundum quem modum est tibi possibile: ut cognoscas quod illic est os, aut neruus, et est Fistulae concauitas longinqua, aut propinqua: aut est Fistula una cui sunt orificia multa, et sta super totum illud, cum summa fortitudinis tuae: cum interrogatione tua, qua interrogas infirmum, et inuentione doloris apud compressionem cum manu tua super locum, et similibus ex significationibus et caussis accidentibus apostemati.	Then inquire carefully in what way is it possible: whether it is a bone or a nerve, and whether the fistula is long or short: or whether it is a single fistula with many openings, and that lies throughout the whole, with the sum of your strength: with your questioning of the patient, and the finding of pain in compression with your hand over the place, and similar signs and symptoms accompanying the accident.</start_of_turn>
Cum ergo steteris super omnia illa statione uera, tunc uade ad curationem secundum confidentiam: et est, ut consideres tunc, si est Fistula propinqua apparens, aut in loco saluo longinquo a iunctura, aut a neruo, aut arteria, aut uena, aut uno locorum quae dixi tibi: tunc seca Fistulam secundum quod praemissum est ex narratione mea, et aufer quod est in ea ex filtratione, et carnibus corruptis, quod nascitur in orificio eius ex carne, aut thelul, et similibus: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	When you have stood in all these positions truly, then you can proceed to the treatment with confidence: and it is that you consider whether the fistula is clearly adjacent or in a remote place from the junction, or from a nerve, or an artery, or a vein, or one of those places which I mentioned to you: then dry the fistula according to what has been said above, and remove what is in it from filtration, and corrupt tissues, which arise in its orifice from the flesh, or pus, and similar things: and treat it until it is healed.</start_of_turn
Si autem Fistula est longinquae profunditatis, et est secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut seces eam in profundo quantum est tibi possibile.	If, however, the fistula is of great depth and is according to the rule: then it is necessary to dissect it as deeply as possible.</start_of_turn
Deinde mundifica ipsam ex omnibus carnibus eius corruptis.	Then expose the whole of its corrupt tissues.</start_of_turn
Deinde administra licinia inuoluta in medicinis acutis: et intromitte ea usque ad concauitatem Fistulae quam comprehendisti cum ferro: fac cum ea illud aliquotiens, donec corrodat medicina acuta totum quod remansit in concauitate Fistulae ex corruptione.	Then administer the ligature tightly in acute cases: and introduce it until you have grasped the fistula with the iron: do this repeatedly until the acute medicine has eaten away all that remains in the fistula from corruption.
Deinde restaura ipsam cum unguentis quae generant carnem sanam, donec sanetur.	Then restore it with the sutures which generate healthy flesh, until it is healed
Si uero non sanatur per illud, tunc cauteriza ipsam secundum quod narrauimus.	If, however, it does not heal by this, then cauterize it as we have said.
Si ergo caussa Fistulae est os, et certificatur apud te illud: tunc inquire ipsum, et seca ipsum secundum quod narraui tibi: si non prohibet te aliquid ex uena, aut neruo, aut membro principali, sicut diximus.	If, however, the cause of the fistula is bone, and you suspect this to be the case: then inquire about it, and dry it as I have said: if this does not suffice, or if there is any other limb, vein, or main artery which is opposed to this, as we have mentioned.
Si ergo detegitur tibi os, et est in eo quiddam corruptionis, et nigredinis: tunc rade ipsum, donec auferatur corruptio eius tota.	If, however, it is detected that there is bone in it, and there is some corruption and blackness: then burn it until the corruption of it is completely consumed
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with that which nourishes it, until it is healed.
Quod si non sanatur, et emittat pus sicut faciebat: tunc scias, quod tu non peruenisti ad totam eradicationem corruptionis.	That if it does not heal, and pus comes out as before: then you know that you have not achieved the complete eradication of the corruption
