Detege ergo super illud secundo, et exquisite fac rasionem eius, et mundificationem ipsius cum ultima fortitudine tua.	Observe it carefully afterwards, and make reason for it, and treat it with the utmost care and skill
Deinde restaura ipsum.	Then restore it
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est: et si non, tunc scias quod illa corruptio est in profunditate longinqua corporis, quam non es consecutus.	If, however, it heals, that is good: and if not, you know that the corruption is in a profound depth of the body, which you were not able to overcome
Non est ergo tibi in ea ingenium, nisi dimittere ipsam naturae.	It is not in this way that you will overcome it, except by resorting to the natural order of things.
Quod si corruptum est os paruum, et est possibile tibi, attrahe ipsum cum forficibus subtilibus quae conueniunt ad illud.	If the small bone is corrupted, and you are able to do so, draw it out with fine forceps which are suitable for this purpose.
Si autem sunt ossa multa, tunc exquisite fac attractionem eorum omnium, neque dimittas ex eis aliquid cum tua fortitudine.	If many bones are present, then take care to make an attraction of them all, and do not send anything away from the bones with your force.
Si uero contrarietatem facit tibi aliquid ex humiditatibus, et non est in incisione eorum timor, uel error: tunc incide illas humiditates et carnes, si sunt illic, et libera ossa.	If, however, there is any moisture in the incision, and there is no fear of error, then cut through the moisture and the flesh there, and free the bones.
Si uero non est tibi praeparatio auferendi ossa ex hora tua, tunc pone super uulnus quod putrefaciat ipsum: et dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat quod est in circumitu illorum ossium ex carnibus et humiditatibus.	If you are not prepared to extract the bones from their place at this hour, then put upon them something which will cause them to putrefy: and send them away, until they putrefy, that is, until the bones are freed from the flesh and moisture surrounding them
Et custodi uulnus ut non consolidetur.	And keep the bandage so that it does not consolidate.
Et constringatur sectio quam tu secuisti in operatione tua.	And let the incision be firm as you made it in your operation
Imo pone super ipsum, si times, cotum submersum sulfure trito cum oleo: aut cotum submersum in unguento aegyptio, aut aliquo unguentorum uiridium.	And if you put upon it, if necessary, a bandage soaked in sulfur trioxide with oil: or a bandage soaked in Egyptian unguent, or any other unguents of your desire.
Nam quando putrefient illae scilicet humiditates, et separantur ex eis ossa, alleuiatur ablatio eorum, et ipsorum attractio.	For when the moisture putrefies, and separates from the bones, it alleviates the loosening of the bones, and their attraction
Si autem est os unum magnum, sicut os cruris, aut os coxae, et similia illis, et quod ex eo corruptum est, est pars magna: tunc rade ipsum rasione ultima, donec auferatur illa nigredo et corruptio.	If there is a large single bone, such as a thigh bone or a hip bone, and the like of them, which is corrupted, it is a great part: then take away that part last, until that black spot and corruption is removed from it.
Deinde restaura uulnus.	Then restore the bandage.
Si uero quod est in eo corruptum, est pars magna, et corruptio iam consecuta est medullam ossis, tunc necesse est serrare ipsum, et incidere ipsum totum usque ad locum, ubi peruenit corruptio: tunc cura ipsum, donec consolidetur.	If, however, that which is corrupted is a great part, and the corruption has already proceeded to the marrow of the bone, then it is necessary to cut through it and open it right up to the place where the corruption remains: then cure it, until it is consolidated
Et ego narro tibi zuken, quae accidit uiro in crure suo: ut ponas ipsam exemplum et adiutorium super operationem tuam.	And I tell you this, which happened to me in my thigh: that you may take this as an example and aid in your operation.
Fuit uir iuuenis aetate circiter triginta annos, cui accidit dolor in crure suo, a caussa quae mota est super ipsum intra corpus, id est, ab interioribus, donec peruenerunt materiae ad crus, et apostematum est apostemate magno: et non fuit ei caussa extrinseca.	A youth of about thirty years of age suffered pain in his leg, because something had become displaced from above downwards within the body, that is, from the interior, until it reached the leg, and there was great swelling: and there was no external cause of the matter.
Extensum est ergo cum eo tempus cum errore medicorum, donec apertum est apostema, et concurrerunt cum eo materiae multae.	The swelling had continued for a long time, with the error of the physicians, until the swelling was opened up, and many materials came out together with it
Et postposita est curatio eius, donec fistulatum est crus, et facta sunt in eo orificia multa: quae omnia emittebant pus, et humiditates corporis.	And after this the healing was delayed, until the leg was bandaged, and many holes were made in it: from which pus and moisture of the body issued out
Curauit ergo ipsum multitudo medicorum circiter duos annos, et non fuit in eo sapiens in arte manus, donec uocatus sum, et uidi crus eius, et materias quae currebant ex illis orificiis cursu magno: etiam omne uiri corpus iam tabuerat, et color eius citrinus erat.	The matter was treated by many physicians for two years, and there was no skill in their art to be found in this matter, until I was called, and I applied a remedy to the leg, and the matters which were running out of the holes greatly decreased: even all the swelling of the body disappeared, and its colour became pale yellow.
Intromisi ergo tentam in uno locorum orificiorum, et peruenit tenta ad os.	There was an introduction of the hand into one of the holes, and the hand went up to the bone.
Deinde perscrutatus sum orificia omnia: et inueni ea peruenire ad se inuicem ex omnibus partibus cruris.	And then I examined all the holes, and I found that they were all connected with each other throughout the whole leg
Properaui ergo, et secui super unum illorum orificiorum, donec detexi partem ossis: et inueni ipsum corruptum: quod iam corrosum erat, et denigratum, et putruerat, et perforatum erat, donec penetrauerat usque ad medullam.	I then treated it, and I applied a dressing over one of the holes, until I discovered a piece of bone: and I found that it was corrupted: for it was rotten, discoloured, and putrified, and perforated, until it had penetrated right up to the marrow
Serraui ergo quod detectum est mihi, et praeparatum ex osse corrupto.	I saw that which had been detected was prepared from the corrupted bone.
Et deputaui, quod non esset in osse nisi illa corruptio, quam abscidi, et serraui.	And I concluded that there was no soundness in the bone except for that corruption which I had cut off and bound up
Et ego iam eradicaueram eam.	And I extirpated it.
Deinde posui restaurationem uulneris cum medicinis consolidatiuis spacio longo.	Then I order restoration of the wound with the consolidated physicians in a spacious area.
Et non est consolidatum.	It is not consolidated.
Deinde tentaui, et detexi super os secundo supra detectionem primam: et inueni corruptionem continuam cum osse: et serraui quod apparuit mihi etiam ex illa corruptione.	Then I attempted, and I found upon the second examination above the first: and I found continuous corruption with the bone: and I observed that there appeared to me also from that corruption
Deinde conatus sum restaurationem eius.	I attempted to restore it.
Et non est restauratum.	It is not restored
Detexi ergo super ipsum iterum, et non cessaui incidere os particulatim, et conari restaurationem eius: et non est restauratum, donec incidi ex osse circiter palmum unum, et extraxi illud cum medulla sua.	I found therefore upon it again, and I did not cease to cut the bone piecemeal, and to try to restore it: and it is not restored, until I cut from the bone round about one palm, and I extracted that with the marrow
Deinde restauraui ipsum cum medicinis, et consolidatum est uelociter, et sanatum: et non fuit necessaria haec iteratio in operatione eius, et sectione ipsius, nisi propter dispositionem debilitatis infirmi, et paucitatem tolerantiae eius, et timorem meum super ipsum de morte: quoniam accidebat ei in omnibus horis ex superfluitate euacuationis syncopis mala.	Then I restored it with the physicians, and it was consolidated quickly, and healed: and no further operation was necessary for this operation, and the section of the same, except for the disposition of the weakness of the patient, and his little tolerance, and my fear of death for him: because it was happening to him in every hour from the excessive evacuation of syncope.
Sanatus est ergo sanatione integra: et nata est in loco ossis caro dura, et bona facta est dispositio in corpore suo, et rediit uirtus eius: et conuersatus est in dispositionibus suis: et non fecit ei contrarietatem in ambulatione nocumentum omnino.	He was healed completely: and was born in the place of the hard bone, and a good disposition was made in his body, and his strength returned: and he convalesced in his own dispositions: and did not make him contradict in walking at all
Si autem os eminens in loco corporis iam fractum est: tunc oportet ut serres ipsum, secundum hunc modum: et est: ut accipias ligamentum, et stringe ipsum in extremitate ossis eminentis: et praecipe alicui, qui extendat ipsum ad sursum: et pone ligamentum aliud ex lana grossius ligamento primo.	But if the prominent bone in the body is fractured: then it is necessary to bind it up according to this method: that you take the ligament, and bind the bone at the extremity of the prominent bone: and command someone to extend it upwards: and put another ligament from a thick thread beside the first ligament.</start_of_turn>
Deinde liga ipsum super carne, quae est suh osse: et extende extremitatem eius, ut trahas carnem ad inferiora: et tu detegis carnem super locum quem uis serrare, ut non laedat Serra carnem.	Then bind the ligament over the flesh, which is on the bone: and extend the extremity of it, so that you draw the flesh downwards: and you detect the flesh over the place where you wish to cut, so that it does not injure the flesh.</start_of_turn>
Pone lignum, aut tabulam sub osse inferius decenter: quoniam quando facis illud, non prohibetur quin secet carnem corruptam.	Place wood or a board under the lower bone in the center: for when you do this, it will not hinder that it will secrete the corrupted flesh.
Et oportet ut sit Serratura super locum corruptum parumper, ut non sit in concauitate ossis corruptio: et non appareat in apparitione sua sensui, et cogat ad Serraturam sui uice alia.	The wound should be closed above the corrupted area without tension, so that there is no deformation of the bone's corruption: and it must not be visible in its appearance to the sense, and must incite to closure of its wound in another way.
Quod si os est corruptum, et non est eminens, imo continuatur pars eius cum parte: et corruptio est in medio eius, aut in parte ipsius: tunc detege carnem ab omnibus partibus totam.	If the bone is corrupted and is not prominent, continue the part of it with the part: and the corruption is in the middle of it or in the part itself: then remove the flesh from all parts of it whole
Deinde pone lignum inferius.	Then place wood under it
Postea serra illud ex parte prima, ubi est corruptio, donec continuetur Serratura ex parte altera: et sit Serratura secundum longitudinem a corruptione parumper, secundum quod diximus.	Then secure the wound from the first part where the corruption is, until the closure is completed from the other side: and let the wound be as far from the corruption as possible, as we said before.
Quod si corruptio est in iunctura, incide ipsam iuncturam corruptam, et serra os ubi continuatur ex parte altera.	If the corruption is at the junction, cut through the corrupted junction, and secure the bone where the closure is completed on the other side.
Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	If indeed the corruption is in the continuation of two junctions, then there is no wisdom in it except to burn it.
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	If the corruption is in the palm of the hand, or in the palm of the foot: then the matter is difficult to handle
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	It is true that you must inquire about the nature of the corruption.
Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	And burn it, and cleanse it as you can in any way possible, and with any ingenuity: when it does not make opposition to the Vein or Nerve
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	You know that the forceps and scissors for cutting this bone are many, according to the position of the bones, and their preparation, and the size of them, and their fineness, and the magnitude, and the number of them, and their rarity
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Wherever necessary, one must prepare an instrument suitable for each kind of operation.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	Know that these operations are significant to you above the kind of instrument that you do not know well.</start_of_turn>
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And the knowledge of the methods of this art is a testimony to the methods of healing: for then you will find for yourself what is suitable for all diseases from the instruments.</start_of_turn>
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	I am firm in the end of this chapter concerning the number of instruments, which I have set as examples for which you inquire, and the proof that you will experience with others.</start_of_turn>
Forma Serrae.	Form of the Saw.</start_of_turn>
Forma alterius Serrae.	Form of the other Saw.</start_of_turn
Forma Serrae alterius.	Form of the third Saw.</start_of_turn>
Forma Serrae alterius.	Form of the fourth Saw.</start_of_turn
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This form of Saw is cut in the middle.</start_of_turn
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Let its arc be superior, its point from the iron: and its handle from the box, and let it be pyramidally cut in the middle.</start_of_turn
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	Form of the Scissors for joining.</start_of_turn
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	Let the head of this Scissors be according to the form of the head of the star-shaped key: and its points according to the form of the holes of the elish.</start_of_turn
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	And it does not fit, except when it is scraped with that head of the joining, when the bone is broken, or the limb is wide, and great.</start_of_turn
Forma maioris Rasorii.	Form of the greater Scissors.</start_of_turn
Forma medii Rasorii.	Form of the medium Scissors.</start_of_turn
Forma Rasorii lati.	Form of Rasassa lati.
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	Form of Rasassa in which there is a cavity
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	Form of Rasassa of the latter kind of softer substance
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	Form of Rasassa of the latter kind of curved extremities
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	Form of Rasassa small, soft of tension.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	Form of Rasassa with which bones are joined together
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	Form also of Rasassa large
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	This is like Radio, and the extremity is as a Saw: it appears in many places because of the reason of bones
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	Form of Rasassa which agrees with the reason of that which is perforated by bones.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	Its extremity is triangular, and the extremity of it is acute
Fit ex Indi.	It is from India
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And it is like this concerning all that we have said of Rasassa, and Incisor, and Saw
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	Concerning the incision of extremities, and the suture of bones.
Caput LXXXIX.	Chapter LXXXIX.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	Extremities become putrefied, either by an external cause, or an internal one
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	When therefore you have treated the disease with medical care, and the cure has not been effected: and when the disease has progressed to such an extent that it does not yield to treatment: then it is necessary to cut off that limb up to the point where the disease has ceased to progress, so that the patient does not succumb to the disease, or from the consequence of the defect of the limb.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign of that is that the limb is blackened, until it is burnt: that fire has consumed it, or it has become putrid after it has become black: until that putrefaction has spread throughout the body
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Properly therefore with the incision itself, and in like manner if the cause of the corruption is percussion of some venomous creatures: such as the scorpion of the sea, and spiders, and fleas, and their kin.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	If therefore corruption exists, or percussion at the extremity of the digit, then incise the digit, and not leave space for the corruption, so that it may reach to the remainder of the hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And in like manner if it happens in the palm of the hand, then incise from the root of the bone, and not leave space for the corruption, until it has reached the bone of the forearm
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it comes to the bone, then incise the arm at the elbow in its joint
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	If however the corruption passes around the elbow: then in that is the mark of the infirmity.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And to administer besides this from the cure, is the quantity of ointment.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And in like manner do concerning the foot, when the corruption comes to the digit, then incise it at one of the nodes: and if it comes to the heel, then incise the whole foot
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	If however it reaches the knee, then incise the thigh at the knee joint
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	What if the corruption has already passed above the knee? Then it is not in that it is impotent, except for dismissal, and leaving the infirmity to die.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the manner of incising the limb, or preserving it, is that you tie the ligaments below, which you wish to cut: and tie the ligament above in the place of the cut
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And extend one minister of the ligament downwards: and extend the other minister of the ligament upwards
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you separate the flesh which is between two ligaments, with a broad spatula, until the whole flesh is detached
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then it happens, or it returns.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	Then it happens, or it returns. It is necessary to draw from all parts of the wound line, and not to touch the healthy area: and the wound will be added to the infirmity, and the swelling will become cold.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	If blood flows inwards during the operation, then cauterize the place quickly: or put over it some powder which will absorb the blood.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to your medicine until it is complete.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind up the wounded limb with a suitable bandage, and care for it until it heals
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I tell you what happened in the foot, behold that this is what happens which I tell you.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	Because it happened in his foot black, with a burning which assimilates with the heat of the fire: and the corruption happened first in his finger, until the whole foot was affected
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	He therefore escaped from his misfortune, after he had cut off the corruption from the limb with his knife, because of the pain, and the burning: and it happened at the joint, and he was healed
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after a long time had passed, the same corruption happened in the thumb of his hand.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	He came to me, and I attempted to recover the superfluousness with what I found on the hand from the doctors after the restoration of his body: and the superfluousness was not recovered, and it began to spread to another finger: until the corruption reached the hand itself
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	He called me to cut off his hand: and I did not do it, hoping for the return of the superfluousness: and I was also afraid of the death of his hand at the incision
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	Since the man was very strong over the case.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	After he had departed from me in despair, he returned to his land: and he came to me because he was anxious, and he grasped my hand completely: and he was healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	And do not believe this story, except that it be of service concerning this which has fallen from the kind of this disease: and that it be indicative of what is signified, and according to how it is done.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	Of the care of limbs, and the quality of blistering with the physicians.
Caput XC.	Chapter 90.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When swelling occurs in some limb with pain, and the extent of the swelling is prolonged until collection of pus has taken place: then it is broken open, or pierced, and the pus which is in it is ejected, and the place which was filled with pus is left like a cavity: and the skin which is above it is like a thin veil which has been stripped off: and it does not reach its ultimate corruption, neither does it affect the bone, nor the nerve, nor the ligament: it is called a sinus and not a fistula, although if its extent is prolonged, until corruption affects some parts of the limb, then it is called a fistula or swelling
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And its care is that you cut through the whole skin as if you were rolling it: and especially when it is thin, and made like a veil: and trust that it will not adhere to the place because of its corruption.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	If, however, you hope that the skin will adhere, and that there is no ultimate consequence from this: and if there is thickness in the skin from the flesh, then cure it with blistering: and consider it as a sinus
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	Then if it is large, and the pus which comes out of it is foetid in odour: then blister it with Egyptian medicine, which is vinegar, and oil, and alum, in equal parts, gathered up in fat: and boil them over a fire, until the medicine boils: and apply it to the swelling with honey
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take from that which you need: dissolve it with water and honey, and instill it with that Sinum: and clamp its orifice, and send the medicine into it for two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then draw it out with expression: do this for several days until the sinus is healed, and the odor is gone.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And when it is instilled with aqua cineris, when it is not present this medicine: then take cineres of wood or cineres of ilex leaves: and sprinkle them on water.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then close the wound, and instill it with that, until you are confident that the sinus has been closed
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	If the patient does not tolerate the Egyptian medicine, neither aqua cineris, then instill it with water and honey, to which something of pounded ginger has been added
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or instill it with honey and wine mixed together, because of the property of honey to heal and soften, and the wine makes the sinus adhere, especially when there is excess of styptic and drying matter in the wine
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	When you have done this often, and are confident that the corruption of the sinus has passed away: then instill it with that which makes new flesh in it
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And it is good to take from dyafinicon ointment: and dissolve it with rose water and wine vinegar: or instill it with some medicine, and oil of other things whose properties are written in the treatise on unguents.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	If the orifice of the sinus is narrow, in which the cannula for instillation will not pass: then enlarge it with a small piece of iron: or place in the opening a pledget of lint soaked in Egyptian ointment, or in basilicon ointment, until it is enlarged
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	Likewise, if the opening is large, then gather its lips together with sutures: and discharge from it the quantity which enters the abscess without addition.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	Likewise, if pus runs from the opening, it is raised upwards: then dry it in the lower place which is in it, so that it runs from it downwards: for pus, when congealed in depth, hinders the generation of flesh in it
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	For if it is not possible to dry the sinus downwards, then try to prepare the limb by preparing it in such a way that it runs from it the pus with ease as is prepared for you.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Try that nothing of the pus remains in it: and take solidifying medicines which are placed over the mark, suitable for that which you wish.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And extend the ease over the edge of the skin.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And let the skin be of such quantity as to make communication of the whole sinus.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then cut with scissors directly at the opening of the sinus, widening the opening of the sinus more
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then stretch out from the strings of intestines over the other skin, according to the quantity of the hole: and put it over itself in a long position from the opening of the sinus, so as to alleviate the escape of pus from it: and do not tighten the skin too much, except after a few days once it has healed somewhat.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	He who is over the opening of the sinus must move in every hour, so that it may go out what is gathered in it from the pus: and you shall know whether it runs out much or little: or digested or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And when you have done this again, consider the place of the sinus itself, whether the master of it feels pain there, or whether there is no pain there, or whether there is swelling there, or whether there is no swelling there.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	When the medication has been administered as directed, and you see that the material issuing from the Sinus opening has ceased, then you know that the Sinus is adhered, or is close to adhesion: then you must remove it by hand, or on the third day. And when you have removed the clot, then exchange the bandage and renew the dressing.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	If, however, it continues to issue from the Sinus after a long space of time with a slight flow, then you must not despair of adhesion, for healing approaches, because there are people who are slow to form flesh in their wounds, and there are those who act contrariwise to this.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	If, however, it continues to issue from the Sinus after many days with undigested pus, then you know that the Sinus is not adhered
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	If, therefore, the adhesion of the Sinus is delayed and its condition persists: then add in the treatment the moisture of medicines, truly make the physicians perform this, that there be moisture in the substance and dryness in the air: like unguentum dyafinicon, when added to this there is an excess of moisture
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And from the last thing which is to be cured, that is, to take unguentum dyafinicon and mix it with rose water, and apply it over the old liquid equal in quantity to the substance itself
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then keep it with it, and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And it does the same thing as this action, when there is no unguentum dyafinicon present, honey, when you boil it, until it is reduced, and you use it with this.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Or take myrrh, aloes, and olibanum: all of these together, and grind it up on honey when it is over the fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then smear over the bandage, and bind it over the Sinus: and smear with the honey which you boiled until it was reduced: and grind over it the spices, and put over the bandage, and bind it.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And when administered in that place, long aristolochia, and roots of celestial lily, and is lily: and seed of herb, and centaurea.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	And use either singly or compounded with these, and powder of that which I have mentioned, and use that also.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	If it prolong the condition of the sinus and does not recover with this treatment: then you know that in its depth there is corruption: or that it makes an imprint in bones, or in other hard members or ligaments: then cure the fistula itself, according to what has been said before
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	Of the treatment of panaritis and drawn nails, and incision of the added digit, and section.
Caput XCI.	Chapter XC-I.</start_of_turn>
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	Panaritis is a swelling which arises under the nail of the thumb or finger, and perhaps in the other digits.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	When it prolongs the condition of that, and is neglected, and swells with heat: or it becomes corrupted and emits pus, until it corrupts the root of the nail: and perhaps it corrupts the whole thing, and perhaps the corruption extends to the bone, and there is a foul odor: and the digit becomes wide at the end, and its color becomes dark
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	When you have cured it with what we said before, and the condition does not recover: then it is necessary to cut off the entire superfluity that remains from the nail with a knife
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterize the nail afterwards.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	The cautery is to be made hot
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	If indeed the bone is sound, and the nail is also sound, and the addition of the nail has already penetrated the flesh and begins to pierce it, and causes pain: then it is necessary to place a small radium under the angle of the nail which is piercing the flesh, and push it upwards: and cut the flesh with ease, and place over that which remains of the flesh from the physicians who have burned and corroded it until it is removed entirely
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	If, however, corruption has already set in the bone, then it is necessary to cut off the bone and extract it: for it will not heal as long as corruption remains in it.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	If the swelling and corruption spread to a limb, then cut it at one joint, as has been mentioned previously concerning its sensation
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	If, however, there is attrition or percussion of the nail, and there is pain in it: then it is necessary to bleed the diseased part at first.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then dry the nail with a sharp knife, cutting across from above to below to the tip
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And be careful that the cutting does not reach the flesh under the nail, for this will cause additional pain and swelling in that place
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then care for the place with that which rests pain.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	The finger which has been added which is born in the hands of men, perhaps is altogether fleshy: perhaps there is something in some of its bones, perhaps in that there is the nail: and some of them are born in the root of the joint, or that is the origin of their nature in some part of the limb.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	He who is born in some part of the limb does not move: and he who is born at the junction of the limb, perhaps moves
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	He who is born of flesh is easily cut through
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	As you would cut it at the root with a broad knife
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	As for him whose origin is in the root of the joint, the treatment is difficult
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	Abstain therefore from incision of it.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	Abstain therefore from incision of it.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
¶ De incisione Vitium.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Caput XCII.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then bind the limb of the sick from the upper part of the thigh down to the lower part of the knee with an outturn.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then draw up the limb in one place, or two, or three wide sections.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then elevate, that is, draw out the blood from the lower part of the leg up to the top, and from the top let the blood flow down as phlebotomies for the sick in the first place.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then bind the limb until below: until the blood which you drew out has gone out from the limb in an amount sufficient, and as much as the sickness can tolerate.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Then bind the limb again: and command him to abstain from foods which generate black bile: and repeat the evacuation and phlebotomy when the veins are full, and it will benefit the sick man
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	The elevation of it is, however, done in this way.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	The limb of the sick person, if there are many hairs in it
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then immerse the limb in a bath: or embroider the limb in the knee with warm water, until it turns red, and the veins swell: or perform an exercise of force, if there is no bath for him, until the limb is warmed up
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then bind the skin along the vein section: or at the end of it at the knee, or at the lower part of it at the heel
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the skin with needles, and scrape the vein from every side, until it appears sensible: and it is at the appearance of it that the blood will change from red to black.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When it has gone out of the skin, the blood will be like white thread
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then put under it radium, until when it is raised and comes out of the skin: suspend the limb with a bandage of lead wool
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then dry the other section close to that section by three fingers.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then scrape the skin from the upper part of the wound until it appears
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then lift the tissue with forceps as you did before, and suspend it with another loop, as you did at first.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then dry the other section, or several sections, if necessary.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then lift up and divide the last section at the heel
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then remove the tissue up to the section that is above it
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	Do this until you have removed the tissue from the superior section, or from all the higher sections, until you have reached the end: then divide the tissue
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	If, however, you are unable to remove and lift the tissue: then introduce a strong needle with a double thread, and ligate the tissue, and remove it: or introduce it under the tissue: and draw the hand back over the whole part until it has gone away
Et caue, ne incidatur.	And take care not to damage it
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if it is damaged, it is difficult to lift the tissue afterwards, and infection enters through that wound
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	When you have therefore removed the whole tissue: then place over the wound a soaked wool pad in wine or rose oil, or oil: and care for it, until it is healed.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	If the vein is contracted, having a twist to which the blood supply is obstructed, and is not as we have described in accordance with the rule: then you must find on the tissue over all the parts the twist of the vein itself, and the place of obstruction.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then suspend the tissue with sutures, until you have lifted the whole tissue: and take care at the site of your incision over the tissue that you do not damage the vein, or wound: for it is difficult to lift or extract the tissue from there
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Beware therefore of your prudence.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	Take heed therefore of your prudence.
Forma Vncini caeci.	Beware therefore of your prudence.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	Beware therefore of your prudence, for it is neither cowardly like the rest of men, nor acute at the extremities, as to wound the vein: but it is great in flexibility, gentle: for if it were slight, it would wound the vein by its own softness. And indeed it is superfluous to have great flexibility, as we have said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	Concerning the extraction of the vein of the leg
Caput XCIII.	Chapter XCIII.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein originates in the legs in warm lands, like Alizegi and the Arabs, and in dry, warm lands, few in number, that is, in which no herb or tree grows
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it originates in other parts of the body besides the legs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	And its generation is also from the putrefaction which happens under the skin, as when serpents and worms are found inside the body, and worms which are generated between the skin and the flesh
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And the sign of the beginning of this vein is that inflammation occurs in the leg with swelling.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then the place is to be dried up.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the vein begins to come out of that place of drying up, as if it were the root of a plant, or an animal
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	When it appears from that extremity, then it is necessary to cover over the lead with lead, whose weight is from a drachma to two drachmas and a node: and let the lead fall from the leg
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	Whenever anything is brought out from this towards the outside, let it be solidified in lead and bound.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	If it persists for a long time, then its part must be excised, and the remainder solidified.</start_of_turn>
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And do not cut through the root before the whole has gone out.</start_of_turn>
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if you cut through it, it contracts and enters the flesh: and causes the swelling to increase, decay in the place, and a bad ulcer.</start_of_turn>
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Therefore it is necessary to handle it gently and extract it slowly, until nothing remains of it in the body: and from this vein it goes out in some people as far as the tip of the thumb and the little finger.</start_of_turn
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And indeed it has come to me that it has come out from the urine of twenty palms.</start_of_turn>
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	If, however, this occurs at the time of your medication: then introduce radium into the cavity of its wound, and pierce the wound through and through with the body, until all that is in it is evacuated: and administer treatment for the wound with physicians for a few days.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then care for the swelling.</start_of_turn
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And this vein often has many branches, especially when it appears in the joint of the foot, or in the foot itself: and there are many outlets for it, and it goes out through every outlet branch.</start_of_turn
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	Care for it accordingly, as we have said before, and as is proper.</start_of_turn
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	About the cutting of the worms generated under the skin, and it is called Bovine Disease.</start_of_turn
Caput XCIIII.	Chapter XCIV.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	Chapter XCIV.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	And it proceeds throughout the whole body, ascending and descending: and is perceptible to the sense during its walking from limb to limb, until it is ruptured at every place where it is ruptured in the skin in its place.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And its generation is from the putrefaction of some humors.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	Like worms and serpents, that is, lice and worms in the belly
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And they are fearful of its malice
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	Because when it itself proceeds into the body, and ascends to the head, and comes to rest in a place: then perhaps it will open in that place, and depart, and destroy the eye: and that is what often happens
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	When therefore one wishes to cure it and extract it, then it is not done except during its walking and the appearance of its sense.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	It is necessary therefore to string what is above it and what is under it with strong ligation
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry over it, and extract it.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	If it has gone deep into the flesh, and you do not find it: then put on the place above it a cautery with fire, until it dies
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And greater than that which is feared is its corruption, which corrupts the eye, as we said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	If however you find that it has come to rest near the eye in the head: then string under it over the eyebrow with good ligation.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry over it, and extract it
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And it is necessary that the sick person should take care of the purification of his body, with physicians resolving the bad humors.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And let him beware of foods that generate putrefaction
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	On the section above the navel.
Caput XCV.	Regarding the section above the navel
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	The pain located above the navel is called Nakir in our land: it is a pain that occurs in some parts of the body, and then changes from one part to another.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And I myself have seen it happen, as I will tell you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I was called to a woman who was sick in some village
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And I saw her arm swollen, and I found an inflammation of the vein of the arm
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after an hour had passed, I saw another swelling appear with a worm, which went up towards his shoulder more quickly than is possible: just as silver flies from one place to another
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	The pain therefore departed from that place and settled in the shoulder
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	And after a while it went away throughout the rest of the body, until it reached the other arm
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	And she told me that it returned to its whole body, as I saw it
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	I am amazed at the speed of its change from one limb to another
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And I myself had never seen such a pain before like this in the same way as this
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	But I have seen many people who have had pain changing from one limb to another: and I had never seen anything like that before in a woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	I do not believe this is possible, except that it is because of the women of those regions who are known for their swelling veins: from there therefore appears to be a change of sensation throughout the body.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	It is necessary that they do not appear according to this ratio in those who are delicate and have moist bodies, and in secret veins.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	When therefore the physician sees that the patient feels pain, and if it is evident to him that the ailment appears to the eye, as we have said, then he must bind over that part above and below quickly: and dry above that part until the swelling subsides: and cauterize the place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	If however you do not see it with your eyes: then care for it with the exclusion of the body, and with that which ejects the swellings, and calm it with poultices of rue, and of saffron, and the like.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	(The provided text does not include information regarding the extraction of Sagittarum, so I cannot translate that portion.)
Caput XCVI.	Chapter XCVI.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Sagittae are varied according to their kinds and the places from which they are extruded from the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	And their variety is such: because some of them have large teeth and few: and some are concave and others are convex
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And there are those which have three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And those which have tongues
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And those which have stars
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	As for those which are according to the members from which they are extruded, it is according to two kinds
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	Either the members are from the main bodies which are concave, such as the brain, and the heart, and the spleen, and the lung, and the kidneys, and the intestines, and the bladder, and things of that kind
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	When therefore it falls into any of these members, and a sign of death appears to you, which I will tell you afterwards, then it is necessary to extract that arrow from the body, for death follows the wound in many arrangements
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when these signs do not appear, and the arrow is not hidden in the depth of the limb, then extract it, and care for the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	When these signs do not appear, and the arrow has not penetrated the bone, then extract it and care for the wound.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood will flow from the nail or from the flesh.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps the flesh will be severed and the bone will be broken
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And from the wound will come out a white moisture like pus
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And from it will come out something like the moisture of meat
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If these signs appear, then abstain from treatment, and extract the arrow if it does not come out.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of an arrow that has entered the cord are: that it is close to the left breast: and that it feels as though it is fixed in something hard, not in something soft
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the arrow will move like the pulse: and blood will flow from the wound.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And following this will be cold extremity, and cold sweat, and fainting
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	You know therefore that death approaches with doubt
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	The sign of an arrow that has pierced the lung is the exit of bloody foam from the wound: and the breath that follows the head becomes thick and changes color like that of the sick person
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	He expires greatly and with difficulty: and he seeks the attraction of cold air
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	If the arrow falls into the chest, that is near the ribs: then there is great pain with breathing, with sighing: and all the limbs of the arms move violently
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	If an arrow should fall into the stomach, it may possibly emerge from the wound through some undigested food.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	If an arrow should fall into the belly and settle there: something of stool or vomit or intestine which has been ruptured will issue from the wound.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	There is no hope for its cure, neither in the extraction of the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	If an arrow falls into the bladder and comes out with urine: and something proceeds from it outwards, and the pain is more severe: then you know that it is deadly
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	As for the rest of the members, such as the face, and the neck, and the gut, and the spatula, and the attendant, and the rib cage, and the backbone, and the shoulder, and the hip, and the thigh, and the like of these members, if they do not find the arrow in the artery or nerve: and if there is no venomous arrow.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	I tell you, concerning these arrows, that I have heard of none of them, except as a sign of your desperation concerning your cure.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	That is because I have heard that an arrow once fell into the tear-duct of his eye, or in the root of his nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	I extracted it from the other side, under the earwax of his ear: and he was healed, and no harm remained in his eye
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I extracted another arrow from a Jew, which had fallen into the fat of his eye under his lower eyelid: and the arrow was hidden, and I did not find its tip until I had cut through its wood: and it was a large arrow, such as those which the Turks shoot with their bows, with lead in it, in which there are no ears
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	He was healed of this, and no harm befell him in his eye
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I extracted another sausage from the Christian's belly.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And it was an Arab sausage, which is like that which has ears.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	And so I went above and beyond two ribs: and it was submerged in his belly.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	I was careful with it and brought it out: and the Christian was healed
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I extracted another sausage which had burst inside him: and we thought that it would die from it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	After that, for thirty days, nothing changed in his condition concerning the sausage: and I saw that it had healed, and I extracted it: and he was healed, and nothing bad happened to him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And I saw the man from whom the sausage had burst in his back, and the wound was closed with a bandage over the sausage
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	And after seven years, the sausage was extracted from the root of his hip bone
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And I saw a woman whose sausage had burst inside her: and the wound was closed with a bandage over the sausage, and the sausage remained inside her: and no change occurred in her condition from her natural operations
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And I saw another man whose sausage had burst on his face: and it was closed with a bandage, and it remained, without causing him much pain: and similar things happened to many people
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I extracted a sausage from the belly of the King, which had burst in the middle of his nose, and it had declined to the right side: and the sausage was completely hidden
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	I was called to care for him after the bursting of the sausage until three days later
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	I found the arrow stuck quite tightly in the flesh.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	I grasped it with a fine hook, and did not feel it: and indeed I found the point of the arrow and the pain from its side on the right hand
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	I supposed that it was the point of the arrow at the extremity of the arrow.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	I plastered the place with a plaster which was moist and sticky, confident that the place would be relaxed, and that I would see the sign of the arrow, that is, that it would leave its mark above the wound: and this did not happen in the place where the arrow had followed the place of the wound.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	I remained with the plaster on for many days: and it did not happen that anything occurred, and the arrow remained stuck in the meantime: and he remained sick from the extraction of it until he felt the arrow one day enter his nose.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he told me this.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	I put on him a sharp, corrosive medicine on that place for many days: until it opened: and when I grasped it with my hook, and I felt the extremity of the arrow slightly which adhered to the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	And I added in the opening of the wound by that sharp medicine until we saw the extremity of the arrow clearly: and we passed it out with it in that space of time for about four months.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	And when the wound had healed, and it was possible for me to introduce forceps into it, and to move it, and it did not obey the coming out: then I did not cease to grasp it with a fine hook, and to fashion above it with the wisdom of experienced men, until I was able to grasp the arrow with forceps at the end, and I drew it out
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I restored the limb.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And the physicians say that the cartilage of the nose is not restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	I restored it therefore itself, and the limb was consolidated, and the illness was healed completely: nothing was left of it
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I tell thee the quality of the extraction of some arrows: so that thou mayest know the rule and the signification of that which I have not said
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	For the parts of this art and the distinctions of them are not comprehended with the narration: neither doth this book comprehend them, and a prudent artificer compares them with little to much: and with that which is present, with that which is absent: and he finds a new operation and an new instrument among the descent of the things of this art when they happen.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say therefore that arrows do not go out of the limbs in which they are fixed, except in two ways.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Either by attraction from the place from which it came in.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or by turning back the other part
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which goes out from where it came in, or the arrow proceeding in the fleshy place: it is attracted and goes out.
