Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	If it does not obey the going out at the hour in which it fell: then it is necessary that thou shouldest let it go a few days, until the flesh which is around it is putrefied: and the attraction of it and its going out will be removed
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And in the same way if it is caught in a bone, and it does not obey thee at the going out, then thou shouldest also let it go a few days: and repeat it every day with the attraction and the motion, until it goes out
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	If it does not obey thee at the going out after days, then it is necessary that thou shouldest perforate round about the arrow in the bone from all sides with a fine thread, until the arrow be amplified
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then draw out the abscess, and extract it.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	If however the arrow is fixed in the head of a bone, and has proceeded into one of the ventricles of the brain, and appears from the sickly parts some of the accidents which I mentioned: then abstain from the drawing out of the arrow, and leave it, until it be equal to its former state after a day.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the arrow remains in the brain, the poison does not prolong its duration.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed, except in the body of a bone, and does not penetrate as far as the brain: and remains sick for some days, and no accident happens to him from these things: then think of the drawing out of the arrow and its extraction.</start_of_turn>
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	If however it is fixed firmly, and does not obey you in the drawing out: then apply a poultice round about the arrow, as I have told you before: then keep the place still, until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	If however the arrow has vanished from its place in the body, and is hidden and concealed from sense: then inquire about it with care.</start_of_turn
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If you feel it, then draw it out with some instruments which are suitable for its drawing out.</start_of_turn>
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	If however you are unable to do so because of the constriction of the wound, and because of the length of the arrow in its depth: and there is no bone, nor nerve, nor blood vessel: then find above the wound until you can amplify the wound, and it be possible to extract the arrow.</start_of_turn
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	When there are ears which hold the flesh fixed in the bone from all sides, from every ingenuity which you can think of, and you think of freeing them, if you cannot make the evacuation of the flesh from the fracture of the ears, and the twisting of the ears, until it becomes easy.</start_of_turn
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	When you administer the extraction of the Sagitta, in whatever place it is, then use a twisting of your hand with the forceps to all parts, until you have made it go away: and under the last subtle degree, that it does not break the Sagitta, and that it becomes difficult for you to draw it out, and for the extraction itself.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	If you are unable to accomplish this in one hour, then delay the procedure for a few days, until the surrounding parts have decayed.</start_of_turn>
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then repeat it: if indeed it opposes the flow of blood, then administer what we have mentioned in its chapter: and preserve your virtue from the incision of the vein, or nerve, or cord.</start_of_turn>
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And administer with all possible wisdom the evacuation of the Sagitta: and let this be with ease, and tranquility, or with slowness, and firmness, as I have said.</start_of_turn
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And it is necessary that you do this when you draw out the Sagitta, that the patient is according to the figure, according to what was with the Sagitta itself in this case.</start_of_turn
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	For thus is the art of healing.</start_of_turn>
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	If indeed this is not possible for you, then administer what is possible from the figure.</start_of_turn
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	The Sagitta which comes out from the opposite side, or which proceeds from something to the exterior: or it makes a swelling of the extremity of the Sagitta by means of the sense from the superior part of the skin close by, and it brings up the swelling: dry therefore above the swelling, and make the incision according to the quantity that they grasp in the forceps.</start_of_turn
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then draw out the Sagitta: for itself is made easy to come out.</start_of_turn
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	If it remains in the bone, then twist your hand according to the circumference, until the arrow has been driven into the bone, and will thereby be increased: then draw it out.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	If not: leave it for a few days: then repeat the process until it has departed.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	If the arrow-shaft is in it, then push it out with that itself.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	If however the bone has fractured, and you wish to apply a force: then introduce into the wound an instrument with a concave surface, so that its curvature may engage with the head of the arrow: then push out the arrow with the instrument itself.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	If the arrow is concave, then push it out with the instrument entering through it
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	The arrow will thereby be driven out through that.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	If the arrow is poisoned, then it is necessary to remove the entire piece of flesh in which the poison is contained: if this is possible
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then take care of the wound as is appropriate to it
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	If the arrow has fallen into the chest, or the belly, or the arm, or the side: and is close to that which you touch with your hand, and it is possible to dry over the wound: then dry, and burn away from the wound, the nerve or bone, and draw out the arrow.</start_of_turn>
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then keep the wound covered with a bandage, if necessary, and care for it until it heals.</start_of_turn>
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	This is the manner of the forceps, by which arrows are drawn out.</start_of_turn>
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	The extremities are like the beak of a bird, which are made like iron: when they grasp the arrow, they do not relax it.</start_of_turn
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	There are many kinds of wounds, large, small, medium, according to the quantity of the size of the arrow, the density of its substance, the breadth of the wound, and its constriction.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	The wound is of a concave shape.</start_of_turn>
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	The wound is of a blunt shape.</start_of_turn
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is the shape of the extremities like a Radius, so as to facilitate the entrance of the arrow into the concave sagittam, and it is driven by it.</start_of_turn
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	The extremity of this wound is concave like the beak of a bird: so as to facilitate the entrance of the arrow into itself and the driving force of it.</start_of_turn
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	About the cutting of veins.</start_of_turn>
Caput XCVII.	Chapter 129.</start_of_turn>
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	The veins which it is customary to cut in the body are thirty in number.</start_of_turn
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	Of these, there are six in the head: two pulse veins which are behind the ears, two Herbae veins, two Arteries which appear in two temporal regions, and two veins which are in the two lachrymal ducts of the two eyes, which are called Aspicientes: and a vein prepared in the middle of the forehead: and a vein which is at the extremity of the nose.</start_of_turn
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two Guidegi veins which are in the neck.</start_of_turn
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins which are in the upper lip of the mouth.</start_of_turn
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins which are in the lower lip.</start_of_turn
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	And these are the veins which are called Algecherich.</start_of_turn
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two veins which are under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	And the veins which are phlebotomized in the arms, are five veins in every arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is the Cephalic, and it comes from the side of the collarbone: and it names the vein of the head.
Et Fusca.	And the Fusca.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And it is the Median vein, and it is composed of the branches of the Basilic and Cephalic veins: and it names the vein of the body
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	And the Basilic, and it is placed on the domestic side: and it is also called the Titillicaris.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And it names the vein of the belly
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	And the Radial, and it is placed over the elbow: and it is that from which phlebotomy is made, and that which appears above the thumb with a visible mark
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And the Palateal: and it is a vein which is between the ring and little fingers: and there are two branches to it.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	And there are three veins in the leg and foot.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is which is under the curvature of the thumb from the side of the collarbone.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	And the second is the Saphenous: and its place is beside the calcaneus from the domestic side
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	And the Popliteal: and its place is beside the calcaneus from the side of the collarbone
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	And in the other leg there are three veins similar to these
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	Of the phlebotomy of the two veins after the Golden Age
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	Phlebotomy of the two veins which are after the Golden Age is useful for ancient cataracts, headache, haemorrhoids, and a bad headache of the head.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	And what is the quality of a phlebotomist according to what I have said?
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	And it is, as I have said, that the phlebotomist should cause the head of the patient to bleed: and he should grasp the head of the patient at the two veins near the rough cloth with good friction.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then he should tighten the patient's neck with a cloth, until two veins appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And their places are behind the ears in two depressed places of the head
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	Ask therefore easily with your finger, and where you feel the pulse of the veins under your finger, there will be a sign with the cautery.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take the phlebotomist's knife, which is called Incidens.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then insert it under the vein into the skin, until the phlebotomist reaches the bone.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then raise your hand with the vein and skin towards the upper part, and cut the vein with the incision of the phlebotomist.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And let the length of the incision be the quantity of two joined fingers, or thereabouts: and let blood flow out as much as you wish
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then tie up the wound with threads, and let go of the wound, until it is healed.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And thus it is in the beginning of the book that the incision of the ears and their cautery are mentioned
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	Of the phlebotomy of the two veins in their times
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	The two veins which are in two times of phlebotomy are esteemed for old migraine: and for strong swelling, and for the excessive flow of acute matters towards the eyes
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	What quality of bleeding is easy according to what I have told you?
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	The bleeding is easy when the patient's neck is much constricted, until two veins become evident to the sense of touch: and the pulse of these veins is shown under your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	Then there is a sign with a haematemesis.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then raise the skin above the vein with your index finger, and make an incision below, and elevate the vein upwards.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And cut the vein like you did in the two veins above: and cause the blood to flow according to the quantity you need
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then loosen the constriction of the patient, and place your finger over the vein for an hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then place over the neck and the pulse, and tighten it up from the constriction: and release it when it is healed
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And remember the application of the bandage, the incision of the vein, and the extraction of the clot at the beginning of the book
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	About the bleeding of the front vein after the cephalic phlebotomy.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	The after-effect of phlebotomy of the front vein after cephalic phlebotomy is for the old pains of the face: and for headache, and redness: and for wounds and ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of bleeding of this vein is, according to what I have told you
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	The patient tightens his neck when he is sick, until the vein becomes evident to the eye
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then take the instrument which is called the Fossorium.
Cuius haec est forma.	Which has this shape
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Place the apex of the incision on the head of the Fossorius bone above the vein, and pierce above it with the needle, or in any other way as you please: and let the blood flow out in accordance with the quantity you desire.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Close the perforation of the patient, and tie off the vessel, until healed.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And when opened with a wide lancet.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	It is not proper that the phlebotomus be of acute extremity, like the rest of the phlebotomies, but rather of broad extremity
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	The phlebotomy must be performed according to the passage of the vein: for the bone is close by: and perhaps in this the phlebotomy will be fractured when it is slight
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	As for the phlebotomy of the veins in the two lacrimal bones.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	The sign of the two veins which are in the two lacrimal bones of the two eyes, is at the eye from scabies and redness: and swelling in the eye, and pains of the face.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And the quality of the phlebotomy of them is that it tighten the limb of the patient with the thumb
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then the phlebotomy is easy: and you stand over his head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And do the phlebotomy according to the passage of the vein to a small length, with a small needle, broad rather than narrow, for there is no flesh in the place
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	If the phlebotomy is slight of extremity, perhaps it will be fractured.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then let the blood flow out as much as is necessary for you
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	And put over his wound the coat, and tie up his limb once at night, and close it
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	On the phlebotomy of the veins of the nose.
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	The veins of the nose are to be bled in acute fever, excessive sweating, and facial ailments such as migraine and redness of the face, especially when they are of an old standing.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And the quality of the bleed in this case is such as to tighten the patient's neck
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then take the left thumb of your hand and make the phlebotomy beneath the nail, long: and fix it in the middle of the nose itself, between that which distinguishes the nose according to its direction.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	For the vein does not appear to the sense there, and because blood immediately begins to flow.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	And it is necessary, that you should immediately remove your last hand with the phlebotomy: and cause the blood to run outwards according to your need
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	Then bind it up at night once
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	The nose will itself restore itself soon.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	Note: The next section of the text is not included in the provided text, so I am unable to translate it.
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	However, as regards the phlebotomy of the veins of the guide, it is useful in constriction of the breath, and the commencement of leprosy, and melancholic ailments, and itching and ulcers of the bad kind, and corrosive, that is, those caused by worms in the bowels.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	And the quality of the bleed of these is such as to tighten the patient under both cheeks of the neck with a ligature: and let the artificer stand over the head of the patient, and the patient be sitting over his seat.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then bleed the vein to the length of the wide phlebotomy immediately above.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then extract from the blood the required quantity, or according to what you need for that.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Do the same with the other limb./Then do the same with another limb.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Afterwards suture the ligament and tighten two limbs with the middle suture: so that the diseased part is not injured./Afterwards suture the ligament and tighten two limbs with a middle suture: so that the diseased part is not injured.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And keep it quiet until morning./And leave it quiet until morning
Sanatur enim uulnus.	The wound is healed./The wound has healed.</start_of_turn>
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	Of the phlebotomy of veins according to Algeberich.</start_of_turn>
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	The veins of Algeberich are phlebotomized because they cause swelling in the mouth, corruption of the gums, bad ulcers, cracks in the lips, bad ulcers, also those that are in the nose and in the surrounding area.</start_of_turn>
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And the quality of the phlebotomy of these veins is that you make the patient sit facing you and tighten his collar with a loop.</start_of_turn
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then pull down his lip and look at two veins: one is on the right side of the lip, and the other on the left side: and the sign of both is by their blackness.</start_of_turn
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And this is true: because in the circumference of these there are small veins, black.</start_of_turn
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	Cut therefore each of them according to the incision.</start_of_turn
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	If however you doubt and do not know which of these is to be cut: then take resort to the greater incision of both of them, and their mark.</start_of_turn
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And do the same with the two veins that are in the upper lip: and most of them run together with this: and cut two veins that are in the lower lip.</start_of_turn
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	From a phlebotomy of the vein under the tongue after the phlebotomy of the Cephalic vein.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	From a phlebotomy of the vein under the tongue after the phlebotomy of the Cephalic vein.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And as for the quality of the phlebotomy, let the patient sit between your hands facing the sun: and lift up his tongue, and look under the tongue from one side with one hand, and from the other side with the other hand: and the colour of both should decline towards blackness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	The phlebotomy must be performed on both sides: and take hold, do not hold your last hand in the phlebotomy.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For under the tongue there are arteries, and perhaps blood will flow from them.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	Of the three veins in the elbow
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	However, three veins are usually phlebotomized in the elbow
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And their phlebotomy is done in two ways.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Either by grasping with a large needle: or by lancing with an awl to the point of slight bleeding: or by cutting with a knife, which is called Alnesil.
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Thus Alnesil is when it agrees to the section
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	There are broad and narrow species according to the width of the veins and the tension of them. The form of phlebotomy with the large needle is broad, like oil
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	It is suitable for opening wide, full, protruding, apparent, large, and those containing thick blood
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	This phlebotomus is of smaller width and finer extremities.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	It is suitable for the phlebotomy of fine veins which contain thin yellow blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	Of the phlebotomy of Albucasis.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	Basiliae, however, which is one of the three veins mentioned for phlebotomy, is an instrument.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Because it draws blood from the swellings which are under the jaw and the collar, from the part following the chest and the groin: and it is suitable for the phlebotomist because of its resemblance to the phlebotomus of the veins, so that it should not cause fear that there is an artery beneath it
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If, therefore, it err, and the puncture of the phlebotomy should happen, the artery will be injured, and the flow of blood will be interrupted
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Therefore it is necessary not to perform phlebotomy with the phlebotomus at the same time as the puncture: but rather let it dry with Alnesil.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	If, however, Basilica does not appear visibly, then it is necessary to seek it elsewhere: either by means of other veins or by inquiry of another person; or to perform the phlebotomy in another place, such as the elbow vein
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	For it is itself evident, and should be left dry with the Anesil, as we have already said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	If, however, you wish to perform the phlebotomy on itself, then before you tighten the band around the limb, touch the place to recognize the place of the pulse.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then mark the place with a scar, afterwards the limb, and dry the vein with the concave section of the phlebotomus using the Anesil, as we have already said.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And let the blow not fall outside the space of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	And when you ligature, when you tie the string, the inflation in the place that you marked with the cautery, then that inflation is the inflation of the artery: you must therefore do the thing.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	And if you see blood escaping at the phlebotomy, like the urine of a boy, and it is pale, red: then you know that it is from the artery
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Then do you act promptly, and place your finger over that long space, and then remove your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	If blood is therefore shed (for it is often shed), then tighten the arm, and let go of it: and let the patient be still: and keep above fear of him.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	And do not move him for a few days, until he is healed.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	But if blood is not shed, and you are doubtful: and there is no physician present at your time, then cut the artery if you see it
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	For its extremities are tense, and blood is shed.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Or take a piece of the skin of the buttock, and find it: take the middle third, and tighten it above the place of the constriction below, with string and threads until another day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if blood is shed, that is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	And if not: then care for him as one who remembers the location of the bleeding vessels: and the bleeding of the artery is not difficult in many positions, because of the smallness of the wound, and the possibility of tying the artery from the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	¶ On phlebotomy of the forearm.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	Veins of the neck are the instruments of phlebotomy, as they draw blood from the upper part of the head and the lower part of the body: because they are composed of the basilica branch and the cephalic branch, as we have said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	It is convenient for the phlebotomist that there be some distance above the site of phlebotomy, for under that is the nerve
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	If therefore any one adds to the puncture of the phlebotomy, and finds the nerve, there will result in that state of stupor, and the healing will be difficult, and perhaps will not take place at all
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve is supplied to sensation.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	And if in any one it is hidden, and is slight, and is not visible: then it is necessary to put in phlebotomy beyond the place where you phlebotomize, with Alnesil, and to divide the nerve with care
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	If the vein is between two nerves, then find the vein in its length.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	Of the cephalic vein.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	Phlebotomy of the cephalic vein is an instrument, as it draws blood from the head and supplies it to the eyes.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	It is necessary in this vein alone, if you will, to phlebotomize with the olive-leaf needle, or with the Myrtle needle: because it is safer for the veins of all, because there is neither artery nor nerve under it
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	Indeed it is convenient to you in phlebotomy to ask for the soft parts [of the head] with the first blow, and to seek a softer place: and it does not harm if it is not found with the first blow, as it will return with subsequent phlebotomies.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	Perhaps the swelling may disappear in some individuals when the percussion does not take place at the first attempt, but it does not harm them in any way.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	Regarding the use of phlebotomy and precautions to be taken in its performance.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	The quality of phlebotomy and the accidents associated with it, concerning which you must reflect
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	Firstly, know that phlebotomy is not to be undertaken except for the preservation of health, and for the cessation of ailments, and for the prevention of diseases.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	It is to be performed in the cubital veins, that is the Cephalica, and the Fusca, and the Basilica.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	It should be performed in the spring after Lent, in the summer, and in the autumn, and in the winter after meals, when there are signs of fullness
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	It should be performed on the first or third day after the lapse of three hours
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	Phlebotomy for diseases has no fixed time: but when it is necessary and convenient, day or night, at any hour and at any time.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	It should not be performed in children until they are more than fourteen years of age
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	Neither should it be performed in a pregnant woman except from the fourth month until the seventh month
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	Nor in an elderly person who has passed the age of sixty years
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	When anyone wishes to undergo phlebotomy for whatever reason: it is necessary to administer a laxative before phlebotomy if there is much stool retained in the intestines: in order that they do not adhere to the main veins during phlebotomy, causing harm to the body
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	Neither the patient's vomiting nor the nausea itself should be forced, neither by pressure nor from drunkenness, until the cause of the former has vanished from the body.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Neither with hydrophobia shall the patient be left
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And let another bloodletting be performed after the colic passion, vomiting, diarrhea, frequent urination, sexual abstinence, rest, exercise, joy, and fasting, which dissolve strength from the body or the animal
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Then consider the sublimity of the humors before that, if blood is thick with food and drink, and with physicians: if it is possible for him.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Then let a bath be introduced, if it does not forbid it: or let some exercise be performed, in order to temper the blood.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And let a phlebotomy be made of him in the chest, about the third day: as we have said: and endeavor that he evacuate his chest from all these bad things: such as envy, wrath, fear: and from all bodily things, such as labor, suffering, and superabundance, and such like these.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And make his food be present with things which are customarily used by men from fragrance, and odor, and delight, and the like, as much as is possible
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Then let the phlebotomist sit above the patient's heel, which is higher than the heel of the phlebotomist: then he shall extract his arm and wipe it with his hand twice, or three times.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Then tie the ligament with a bandage, and wrap it twice around the limb twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And let the restraint be temperate, for when the restraint is unequal, or through excessive restraint, then it hinders the course of the blood: or in softening, then also it hinders the course of the blood
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then after the stricture has been passed, it is necessary that the phlebotomist should immediately seize both hands together and hold them close to the belly, until the veins have filled up and the sense has returned.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then let the phlebotomist take hold of the vein with a slight grasp, as before.</start_of_turn>
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then he places his finger on the index finger of the left hand over the vein at the place where he wishes to make the phlebotomy, slightly: so that the vein does not slip away, and that the percussion is set.</start_of_turn
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	For from the veins is more to be feared like a flying cord during phlebotomy: and from the blood that is filled with air: and when you place the phlebotomy on the vein, it contracts under the phlebotomy, and the phlebotomist is struck, and the vein is not opened by the phlebotomy: and if it is opened, it is a stricture: because of this, it is necessary that the phlebotomist should be firm and attentive in all these things.</start_of_turn
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then he lets go of the phlebotomy.</start_of_turn
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If thus the vein opens from the blood, then it is good.</start_of_turn
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then repeat it with another vein nearby, or above that with force: if the place does not recover.</start_of_turn
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	And if it recovers, or if the patient becomes pale, then send him away on the first or second day, and do not tie the ligament.</start_of_turn>
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	Perhaps indeed the swelling will subside.</start_of_turn
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	Neither must you put in a poultice.</start_of_turn
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then repeat the phlebotomy if necessary.</start_of_turn
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	If the opening is small, or blood runs slowly: take care that it does not escape from the blood more than is necessary. Then repeat the phlebotomy in the same place according to custom, and add a little more to the operation.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	Do it with speed, before the place is closed. For the place is split in many people during the operation itself
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	If therefore you see that the matter is already closed, do not go over it again completely, for this may excuse you for anything.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And place upon it some of the fat of oil: because it will soothe the running of the blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	It is better in this place than pure oil, and than any other oil.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And do the same with the fat of oil in all your phlebotomies, which you do on account of the running of the blood: and they will make it like tyriaca alfarach, and sage, when you place one of them upon the place
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	The blood will become thin and dissolve, when it is thick
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	If therefore it happens in the place of the phlebotomy that there is a large opening, namely in many people who are not phlebotomized except for this wound, or because the opening is small of the vein, then be careful and place upon the place a sponge soaked in water and salt, warmed up slightly: and bind it for an hour: because it will dissolve
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	And it is necessary that you do this after the blood has escaped from the vein, with the addition of some of its own, or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	If anything black or yellow remains in the place after a few days, it does not harm: and if you wish, place upon it some aloe, or balm of myrrh: or something of the juice of mint, that is, calamine or something like that.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	Many wounds also occur at the knee and hip joints among the phlebotomists of the Basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	Put your hand over the area and if you find suppuration beneath your compression, then that swelling is bad
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Therefore, do as we have said concerning that thing
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps blood flows from that artery.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But make a plaster over it with something that has styptic power, so that the place is closed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for the rest of the treatment until it is healed.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And it is necessary that every man should draw out of blood according to the quantity of his virtue
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And that which appears from the color of the blood above the blood itself.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For if the blood is black, then let it go out until it becomes red: and in the same way if you see it thick: then let it go out until it becomes thin: and in the same way if it is acute: then let it go out until the sharpness is gone
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	And it is necessary for the full, strong, and indigent person to take only one draw of blood, so that the phlebotomy may be ample and the phlebotomist wide: and in the one who is feeble, let him do the opposite of that
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And it is necessary to draw it in vessels and that the opening be strict: and better is that which is administered in phlebotomy than a puncture, that it should be a transverse section, not a puncture
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	And this method of phlebotomy is safe from the flow of blood, from the incision of the nerve: and it is more praiseworthy and safer than phlebotomy by breadth and length
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	Whoever remains standing near the phlebotomist during a syncope must provide the patient with bread soaked in wine before the phlebotomy: or dry bread, if he is feverish. And take from him from the blood in three or four doses.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	If the patient is pale, take before the phlebotomy bread soaked in pomegranate juice, or in honey syrup scented with spices, or in scented rosewater.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	If it happens that there is a syncope during the phlebotomy, and the cause of this is the escape of much blood: then it is necessary to take in the pot a little meat broth, and aromatic syrup of low degree: and let it be flavored with spices, and cool the patient with it: and do all that we said in the chapter on syncope in relation to emesis.</start_of_turn>
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	Whoever wishes to stop his arm and solve his blood by a second bleed: must take what has escaped from the phlebotomy because of much emesis, and be weak, so that he gradually solves the blood by the amount of weakness in the days following.</start_of_turn>
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	Whoever wishes to stop his arm and solve his blood by a second bleed, and his body is strong: then do this after seven hours, or nine from his first phlebotomy.</start_of_turn>
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from his body in the opposite direction to which it flows: must do this in the second or third day.</start_of_turn
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	In whose body there is much hot blood, which is acute and causes fever: must be drawn out of him from a vein, and take from him in great quantity: and augment it by opening until syncope occurs: after which you will have restored all the conditions of the phlebotomy, and put your hand over the pulse of his wrist near the course of the blood, so that there is no more risk of syncope.</start_of_turn
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	Many times, this happens when the phlebotomist is ignorant and neglectful.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	It should not be when one wishes to solve the arm and solve the blood second, when the orifice of the vein is closed, and there is difficulty in the exit of the blood, as it comes before to that with haste and extends the swelling sooner
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	For indeed that is bad, rather let it go, until the phlebotomy is done second time
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Or move it with the sharpness of the phlebotomy that which has clotted in the orifice of the vein, and put over that something of salt dissolved in water.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	And put over that something of thyme alopecarum, or sage, and put on it gentle compression, until the blood comes out
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	If indeed the vein is already clotted, then let it go, and do not tighten it, until the clot has settled down.</start_of_turn>
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	And if necessity compels to solve the blood second, and it is not excused, then either perform the phlebotomy above the place, or in another arm in another vein.</start_of_turn>
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	But indeed the vein of the arm is phlebotomized in the place of the cubitus, and of the basilica, when they are not found, and are hidden, because they are composed of bones.</start_of_turn>
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of the phlebotomy is that it lets the patient put his hand into warm water, until the flesh turns red, and the vein appears clearly.</start_of_turn
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then it should be bound over with a ligature of moderate constriction.</start_of_turn>
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then the phlebotomy should be done second in a transverse direction gradually, not latitudinally, neither in length: and let the opening be wide, and let your phlebotomy be like that which you make over the palm of the hand that is near the wrist.</start_of_turn
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	If blood flow is prohibited, then re-wet your hand in warm water and let the blood run off into the water until you achieve your need.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	If you are in the summer days, then you may excuse yourself from the repetition of wetting your hand in warm water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	And mostly it is put into practice that the course of blood is let into warm water in the cold season.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	And the letting of blood of this kind is more useful than all other methods, because there is no pulsating under this kind of letting, neither nerve
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	The letting of blood from the right hand is beneficial for the jaundice of the liver.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	And the quality of this letting of blood is that you must bind the wrist of your hand with a ligature or your finger, after you have introduced your hand into the warm water, until the hand swells and the sense of cold disappears.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then let the blood flow across.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you cut the blood entirely, it will not cause any harm to him in any way.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And be careful not to cut your hand too close to the phlebotomy
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	Under these there are naked nerves of the fingers from the flesh
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then re-wet your hand in warm water, and let the blood run off into it
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	For if you do not re-wet your hand in warm water, the blood clots in the mouth of the vein, and is prohibited from flowing.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	When you have therefore drawn out from the blood the quantity necessary, then put on the hand oil and salt: that it may not harden too quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And in the like manner it must be done with every limb that is strict
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	The dressing of the left arm from the phlebotomy is thus: because it is appropriate for the ailments of the spleen. Do the same in the phlebotomy as you did in the second time equally.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	The dressing of the phlebotomy of the saphenae is for ailments that are in the lower parts of the body, such as ailments of the uterus, retention of menstrual blood, kidney disease, ulcers of the buttocks and ancient crura, and similar ailments
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is that it lets the patient put his foot into warm water: and make above it friction, until the veins are bursting: and tie above the juncture of the foot with a bandage.</start_of_turn>
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	The veins are at the heel, appearing under the thumb: and are pulled out from it on the face of the foot many times.</start_of_turn>
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	The phlebotomy is therefore to be done in the greater branch of the vein, or at the heel in its collection: because this is better and safer.</start_of_turn>
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	If the phlebotomy is done on the face of the foot, then take care of the nerves that are under it over the face of the foot.</start_of_turn
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And put your phlebotomy through from the side, like you wish to cut through it: and let the phlebotomy be of the Nesil type.</start_of_turn
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	If, however, the blood is prohibited from coming out, then do it again with the foot in warm water: and let the blood flow out through the vein, until it is evacuated.</start_of_turn
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	If the phlebotomist has made a mistake in the first attempt, then do it again with the phlebotomy towards the upper parts, for the place is safer, and does not cause harm, when you cut from the nerves, as we said.</start_of_turn
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	Likewise, with the other foot of the saphenous vein.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	The vein of Sciatica is located, as we have said, at the heel from the lateral side of the anklebone.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	The sign of the vein is its swelling, when there is congestion of cold blood in the anklebone area.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	The quality of the vein is such that it inflates a soft swelling, and is quick to disappear: it tightens the ankle from the side of the ankle up to the heel for four fingers, with a fine long mark below, which does not appear except in this case.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When it appears, then the vein must be evacuated by whatever means is possible, or by stripping: and it is better either to cauterise it by incision, or to ligate it by section
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	Its place is harmless, and in many men it is hidden under the skin.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	If you do not find it and it does not appear to the senses: then you must evacuate some branch of it, which appears in the back of the foot and below the heel: and cauterise from nerves, and make run out blood as much as you desire.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then loosen the tension, and place over the site of the phlebotomy a layer of skin, and tighten the area.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	It heals quickly.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	Note: The next section continues the discussion of the saphenous vein and its variations.
Caput XCVIII.	Chapter 103.</start_of_turn>
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	Veins are derived from the bodies of blood vessels, from the air, and from the veins themselves.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	And the sensation of the veins is of two kinds
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	When the incision is made, and blood is drawn out: the other is the administration of medication without incision.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	And this administration of medicine which is without incision, is according to two ways.
Aut enim est cum igne.	Or it is with heat.
Aut est absque igne.	Or it is without heat
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And the medicaments which are administered with incision and blood-letting are fourteen in number in the body.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	These include Ventosatio Alnocrati, which is the most posterior of the head: and Alkehel, which is in the middle of the neck: and the unguents Alhagdahim, which are two layers in the neck from two parts together: and the unguents menti, which are under the mandible in the lower part of the mouth: and the unguents duarum spatularum: and the unguents Alachosos on the tip of the tail: and the unguents duorum focilium, which are in the middle of the two arms: and the unguents duorum crurium: and the unguents duarum cauillarum
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	And indeed the medicine which we call Ventosatio does not extract blood from small veins scattered through the flesh, but on account of this it does not cause a loss of blood like phlebotomy does
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	Neither is it necessary that the medicine should be administered with heat or without heat in any ailment which comes from congestion, until the whole body is evacuated
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	If indeed necessity demands that we should use medicine for an ailment, or because of custom, we shall administer it at any time in the beginning of the month, in the end of the month, and in the middle of the month, and at any other time as needed
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	For in men when they are multiplied in blood, until they grow weary of it, they find in their head a great swelling and a raging headache
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And from the eye there is one who increases the swelling and redness in his face, head, and neck.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And from the eye there is one who increases itching in his face, forehead, and eyebrows, and haziness and dimness in his eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And from the eye there is one who scratches the area of moisture of his eye.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And from the eye there is one whose laughter increases
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And from the eye there is one who increases the taste of blood in his mouth: either the tongue swells and expels blood.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And from the eye there is one whose sleep increases
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And from the eye there is one who bleeds in his sleep, redness, and moisture, and spots and things that are like them
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	When we see anything of these things, and it has been more than two or three hours since they appeared, we then order that the moisture be driven out
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	The ointment of the night is beneficial: because it causes a weight in the head and what flows down to the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	And indeed it should be after the evacuation of the entire body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	This is the treatment for cephalic phlebotomy.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	It is not permitted to use it on those who are cold in complexion or in whom there is a catarrh.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it brings on a great swelling
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	For because of this it is not permitted to use it in the elderly, and in whom there are cold spots on the head
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	Whoever is excessive with it generates over the eye socket
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	Therefore, it is necessary, according to the instructions of the Wind-bringer, to place the hand with the palm downward towards the lower parts, fearing lest oblivion be generated.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	The Wind-bringer or Alkehel is the place of the vein of the Fusca, and of the vein of the Basilica, and because of this it brings about swelling, constriction of the breath, and cracking of the instruments of the breath, and vomiting, and distension.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	It is necessary to push the Wind-bringer of the Alkehel downwards, for if it is placed downwards, it generates stiffness in the heart and the stomach
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	The Wind-bringer also causes headaches, sneezing, and pain in the temples, and swelling, and perforation, and pain in the roots of the teeth: and it is the place of the vein of the Basilica
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	It is necessary, according to the instructions of the Wind-bringer, not to place the hand too quickly with the scarification: in order not to tear the artery and to cause the flow of blood to be stopped.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	The Wind-bringer under the chin brings about swelling of the tongue, corruption of the gums, and similar things which are in the mouth: and it is the place of the vein of the epiglottis, which are in two folds
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	The Wind-bringer of the sputa brings about swelling of the face, which is caused by reflection and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	The Wind-bringer of the inner parts of the two cavities [chest and abdomen] brings about the drawing together of the veins of the uterus, Basilica, Fusca, and Cephalic: for it attracts blood from all these small veins which are in the flesh: and these small veins from other large veins until the attraction reaches the three veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	It is necessary, therefore, that the surgeon take caution, so that he does not go too far with the incisions: for the place is stripped of flesh, and beneath it are nerves and blood vessels.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	However, the wind which is applied above the ulcers, brings about hemorrhoids of the anus and lower ulcers.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	It is necessary, therefore, that the surgeon take caution, so that the wind be great and dry: for the place requires strong suction, and the fine veins may perhaps be torn by the incision: and the incision should be great
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	The fine veins of the limbs diminish in size noticeably: for they draw blood from the whole body, and cause old aches in the buttocks, thighs, and groin: they bring on menstruation, and cause swelling, and stiffness: and they are in the place of two saphenous veins, and the horseshoe-shaped bones
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	But they weaken the body greatly, and cause fainting in many men.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	The horseshoe-shaped bones are near the two large veins.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.
