Quod si fractura mandibulae iam separata est in duo, tunc oportet, ut administres extersionem a duabus partibus, secundum rectitudinem: donec possibilis sit aequatio eius.	If the fracture of the lower jaw has already separated into two pieces, then it is necessary to manage the expansion from both parts, according to their direction: until their equilibrium is possible
Si autem iam accidit in dentibus commotio, aut disruptio: tunc stringe illos de quibus speras quod remaneant cum filo auri, aut argenti, aut seta.	If however there is displacement in the teeth, or rupture: then bind those from which you hope that which remain with a thread, or silver, or silk.
Deinde pone super mandibulam fractam caerotum.	Then put over the fractured jaw a cushion.
Deinde pone super ipsum pannum duplicatum, et pone super pannum astellam magnam decenter factam: aut frustum cutis soleae aequale, in longitudinem mandibulae.	Then put over it a doubled pad, and put over the pad a large sponge made hollow: or a piece of the sole of a shoe of equal length to the mandible.
Deinde liga ipsum desuper, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ligatura eius, et conuenit ipsius applicatio, donec non destruitur: et praecipe infirmo, uti tranquillitate et quiete: et pone cibum eius sorbitiones lenes.	Then tie it up above, according to what is prepared for its ligation, and agree with its application, until it is not destroyed: and command the patient to rest in peace and quiet: and give him food of soft consistency.
Si autem estimas, quod iam alteratur aliquid figurae aliquo modorum: tunc propera, et solue ipsum in die tertio.	If however you estimate that something has changed with the figure or mode: then be careful, and solve it on the third day
Deinde rectifica quod alteratum est ex eo, et emplastra ipsum ex puluere molendini, cum albugine oui, aut cum farina sisami, postquam tu abstuleris caerotum: et pone super emplastrum lanam lenem.	Then mend what has been altered, and plaster it with fine flour of wheat, with alum or with sesame flour, after you have removed the tumor: and put on a layer of soft wool over the plaster.
Dum ergo permanet annexum illud emplastrum super ipsum, et non alteratur ossis dispositio, dimitte ipsum, ne soluas, donec sanetur: aut stringe fracturam.	While that plaster remains attached to that, and does not change the position of the bone, remove it, do not dissolve it, until it has healed: or bind the fracture.</start_of_turn>
Multotiens enim stringitur haec fractura in tribus septimanis.	Many times this fracture is bound for seven days.</start_of_turn>
Quod si interim accidat apostema calidum, tunc administra illud quod diximus multotiens in sedatione eius, donec remoueatur illud apostema.	If in the meantime a callous swelling should happen, then manage it as we said before until that swelling has subsided.</start_of_turn
Et si fractura est cum uulnere, considera.	And if the fracture is with a wound, consider it.</start_of_turn>
Namsi iam separatur ex osse frustum, aut a satagie: tunc subtilia te in hoc, ut auferas illa frusta satagiae cum eo quod conuenit tibi in ablatione eorum ex instrumentis.	For if it is separated from the bone fragment, or from the satay: then be careful in this, that you do not increase the fracture with those instruments.</start_of_turn
Si uero orificium uulneris est strictum, tunc amplifica ipsum cum phlebotomo secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	If indeed the opening of the wound is strict, then enlarge it with a lancet according to the quantity of necessity.</start_of_turn
Deinde quando abstuleris illa satagie, et non remanserit ex eis aliquid, sue tunc orificium uulneris, si est amplum: et si non, pone super ipsum ex emplastris quae conueniunt ad illud, et incarnant illud, donec sanetur.	Then when you have removed that fragment of satay, and nothing remains of it, seal up the opening of the wound, if it is wide: and if not, put on over it the necessary plaster, and bind it, until it has healed.</start_of_turn
¶ De restauratione Furculae, quando frangitur.	On restoration of the Furcula when it is fractured.</start_of_turn
Caput VI.	Chapter VI.</start_of_turn>
Plurimum quidem frangitur Furcula ab anteriore parte ex parte humeri, et fractura eius fit secundum unum trium modorum.	Indeed, the Furcula is most frequently fractured from the front part towards the humerus, and the fracture of it is done in one of three ways.</start_of_turn
Aut enim frangitur et separatur in duo, praeter quod accidant in ea satagiae: et est facilius ad restaurationem eius.	Or it is fractured and separated into two, besides which they happen in those satayes: and that is easier for its restoration.</start_of_turn
Aut ita, quod accidunt in osse satagiae: et est difficilius ad restaurationem.	Or thus, what happens in the case of a fracture of the bone of the thigh: it is more difficult to restore.
Aut ita, quod est fractura cum uulnere.	Or thus, when there is a fracture with an ulcer.
Et operatio in ea quando fractura est absque uulnere, est, ut facias praesentes esse duos ministros, ut teneat unus eorum adiutorium quod sequitur Furculam fractam, et alter extendat collum uersus partem.	And the operation in such case when there is a fracture without an ulcer is that you must keep two assistants, one of whom holds the fractured fragment in place, and the other extends the limb above the fractured part.
Deinde aequa fracturam digitis tuis, donec fiat forma eius, secundum quod oportet: et non sit in ea eminentia, neque concauitas.	Then equalize the fracture of the fingers of your hand, until it has attained its proper shape, as it should be: and let it not be prominent, neither hollow
Quod si indiges extensione plus, tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico infirmi spheram ex panno, aut lana: et sit magnitudo eius secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae: et extende, et eleua Furculam, et coarta spheram manu tua, donec aeques fracturam, secundum quod oportet.	If, however, it does not straighten out by extension alone, then it is necessary to place under the knee of the patient a ball of wool or felt: and let the size of it be according to the quantity of necessity. And extend and elevate the fractured limb, and cover the ball with the hand, until the fracture is equal, as it should be
Quod si non potes trahere extremitatem Furculae ad exteriora: propterea, quia peruenit ad profundum: tunc oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et ponas sub humero eius puluinar medium in magnitudine, et premat minister humerum eius ad inferiora, donec eleuetur os Furculae quod est in profundo ad sursum: atque tunc rectifica fracturam, et aequa eam digitis tuis.	If it is not possible to pull the limb of the fractured bone outwards: because it has gone deep: then it is necessary to recline the patient upon his chest: and place under the elbow of him the middle finger of his hand in size, and keep his arm minister to the lower part: until the bone of the fractured limb which is in the depth has been raised up: and then straighten the fracture and equalize the fingers of your hand
Si autem sentis sathaiatum ex Furcula, et mouetur: tunc oportet, ut findas super illud, et extrahas ipsum alsathaiatum cum facilitate.	If, however, you feel swelling from the fracture, and it moves: then it is necessary to find above that and extract it easily.
Si autem est retentum in osse, tunc ingenia in incisione eius cum uno Incisoriorum quae praeparasti ad illud, postquam tu posueris sub Furcula instrumentum quod seruat sifach: et est instrumentum ex ligno, aut ex ferro.	If, however, it is retained in the bone, then make an incision in it with one of your surgical instruments which you have prepared for this purpose: after you have placed under the fractured limb an instrument which will hold the bone in place. And the instrument is of wood, or of iron.
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form.
Assimilatur cochleari cui non est concauitas.	It is like a cochlea which has no cavity
Et sit latitudo eius secundum illud quo indiges eo ex magnitudine ossis, et paruitate eius.	Its breadth is according to that from which it proceeds from the magnitude of the bone, and its height/width is small.
Longitudo uero eius etiam secundum quod possibile est tibi ad operationem.	Its length is also according to what is possible for you in the operation.
Et habeat duas extremitates, sicut uides: et extremitas una sit ampla, et altera stricta.	And it has two extremities like a pair of tongs: one extremity is wide and the other is narrow
Si autem disruptio uulneris quod scidisti quando extraxisti sathaiatum ossis, est ampla, et securaris ab apostemate calido: tunc aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura.	If, however, you tear the wound when you extract the clot from the bone, it is wide, and secure it from the heat of the afterburn: then join together the two lips of the wound with suture.
Et si disruptio est parua, aut times apostema calidum: tunc imple uulnus cum pannis, et puluillis secundum quantitatem scissurae uulneris.	And if the tear is small, or the afterburn is slight: then close the wound with pieces of lint, and with sponges according to the quantity of the wound
Quod si accidat apostema calidum, tunc infunde pannum in oleo rosato, et aceto, et uino, et pone super ipsum.	If there is afterburn, then pour oil of roses, aceto, and wine over the wound and put on top of it.
Strictura uero ossis quando est absque uulnere, et absque sectione, est, ut ponas super os emplastrum factum ex farina molendini cum albugine oui.	The stiffness of the bone, however, when there is no wound and no section, is to put over the bone a plaster made of ground barley with almonds or eggshell.
Et pone stuppam lenem super ipsum.	And put on a soft cushion over it.
Deinde pone spheram sub titillico eius, si indiges illa.	And put under the head a sphere if you do not digest it
Deinde accipe himematem, id est, rotam quam tenent Saraceni, quae sit longa ualde: et sit latitudo eius palmi unius, aut circiter illud.	Then take a sponge, which is like the one which the Saracens hold, which is long and wide: and its breadth is like that of a palm of the hand, or somewhat less
Deinde pone puluillum duplicatum super stuppam et emplastrum.	And put a doubled sponge over the cushion and the plaster.
Deinde accipe astellam ex tabula subtili, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, et in longitudine similiter.	And take a needle from a thin board, whose breadth is three fingers wide, and in length like that
Deinde inuolue eam in panno.	Then immerse the wound in the cloth.
Deinde inuolue pannum illum cum astella in loco alhimemati qui cadit super fracturam et locum.	Then immerse the wound in the cloth covering the fractured area that is above the break and the surrounding area.
Deinde pone alhimemati super fracturam sicut reuoluiur, et inuolue eam super collum eius, et sub titillico eius sano, et sub titillico eius infirmo: et reduc eam super omnem partem, et quomodo uides quod strictura tenet fracturam strictura decenti: et est illud, quod non occultatur super te, et totum, ut non remoueatur astella desuper os fractum.	Then place the bandage over the fracture as if rolling it up, and immerse the wound above the collar of the healthy side and below the collar of the diseased side: and reduce the wound over all parts, and as much as the dressing holds the fracture steady: and this is what is not visible from above, and all, so that nothing is disturbed from the fracture itself.
Et propter hoc oportet, ut aspicias infirmum in omni die.	And for this reason it is necessary to wash the diseased area every day.
Quotiens ergo mollificatur ligamentum, et uides astellam iam remoueri: tunc rectifica illud, et stringe ligamentum.	Whenever the ligament is softened and the dressing is loosened: then rectify that and tighten the ligament
Deinde pone somnum infirmi super dorsum eius, et pone sub titillico eius apud somnum eius puluinar paruum in nocte, ut cum eo eleuetur adiutorium eius a latere ipsius.	Then place the patient to sleep on their back, and place under their chin the small pillows in the night, so that when they are raised up their attendants will support them on their side.
Eleuatur ergo fractura furculae per eleuationem humeri.	The fracture of the collarbone is elevated by elevating the arm
Aut liga brachium eius ad collum ipsius: et non soluas ligamentum, si non accidat in loco accidens ex pruritu, aut ab apostemate, usque ad duodecim dies.	Or bind the arm to the chest: and do not loosen the ligament unless a wound occurs from itching or from a swelling, until twelve days have passed
Deinde renoua emplastrum, si uideris faciem eius ad illud.	Then renew the dressing if you see its face to be wet
Et adde in strictura, et dimitte ipsum, donec restauretur et coaguletur.	And repeat the binding, and loosen it, until it is restored and coagulated.
Et fractura quidem furculae stringitur et confortatur secundum plurimum in uigintiocto diebus: et quandoque fit in quibusdam hominibus in minore illo.	And the fracture of the collarbone is bound and comforted according to many for eighty days: and in some people in less time
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spatulae.	Regarding the restoration of the fracture of the collarbone.
Caput VII.	(The remaining text is not included in the provided context.)
Raro frangitur Spatula, et in loco lato eius: et non franguntur ex ea nisi margines eius.	Rarely does the spatula break, and in its wide place: and they do not break from its margins.
Quando ergo frangitur ex eo locus, et frangitur in medio eius, et non cognoscitur illud nisi per tactum: tunc secundum quod est figura fracturae conare praeparationem eius.	When it breaks from that place, and breaks in its middle, and it is not known except by touch: then it is necessary to prepare it according to the form of the fracture.
Et reduc eam super figuram naturalem omni modo ingenii, quod est tibi possibile.	And reduce it in accordance with the natural form in every way that is possible.
Deinde pone super locum puluerem molendini cum albugine oui, et stuppam lenem, et pone desuper puluillum ex panno duplato.	Then put over the place fine powder of mill with alum, and a soft cushion, and put above it a double layer of cloth.
Deinde pone super ipsum astellam latam ex tabula subtili secundum quantitatem Spatulae totius, aut ampliorem ea parum.	Then put over it a wide bandage from a thin board according to the quantity of the spatula, or a little more.
Si uero sub astella est concauitas in aliquo locorum Spatulae, tunc aequa illam concauitatem cum stuppa leni, donec descendat astella secundum aequalitatem.	If indeed under the bandage there is a concavity in some place of the spatula, then equalize that concavity with a soft cushion until the bandage descends evenly
Deinde ftringe desuper cum alhimemati longa, constrictione decenti, et firmitudine astellae, donec non remoueatur a loco suo.	Then bind it up again with long silk, gentle tension, and firmness of the bandage, until it does not move from its place.
Et considera ligamentum in omni die.	And consider the ligament every day.
Quotienscunque ergo mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum, et aequa astellam si remoueatur a loco suo: et iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	Whenever it is softened, string it up, and equalize the bandage if it moves from its place: and let the patient lie on his sound side
Et Spatula quidem restauratur in uiginti diebus, aut in uigintiquinque diebus.	And the spatula is restored in ninety days, or in ninety-five days.
Quando ergo completur iste numerus, tunc solue ligamentum: et tu sis in securitate.	When this number is completed, then loosen the ligament: and you will be secure
Nam ipsa est ex ossibus quorum communitio non timetur, neque eorum solutio.	For it is from the bones whose communication does not change, and whose solution does not take long
Si autem procedat ex osse frustum, et pungit sub cute: tune scinde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum.	If however it proceeds from a broken bone, and protrudes under the skin: then split over it, and remove it.</start_of_turn>
Et fac quod diximus in fractura furculae ex sedatione apostematis calidi, si accidat ex eo aliquid.	And do as we have said concerning the fracture of the furcula from the sedation of the apostematis calidi, if anything be added to it.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Pectoris.	And do as we have said concerning the fracture of the breastbone from the sedation of the warm afterpulse, if anything be added to it.
Caput VIII.	Chapter VIII.</start_of_turn>
Pectus quandoque frangitur in medio sui, et raro accidit illud.	The breastbone sometimes fractures in the middle, and this is rare.</start_of_turn>
Extremitates eius quidem plurimum franguntur, et comminuuntur ex accidentibus eius.	The extremities of it are indeed most frequently fractured, and they break from its accidents.</start_of_turn
Quando frangitur eius medium, quod declinat ad inferiora, et accidit ei dolor uehemens, et difficultas in anhelitu, et tussis: et fortasse euomit sanguinem, et declaratur concauitas in osse fracto, et non occultatur sensui, Restauratio eius est, ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et pone inter Spatulas eius puluinar.	When it fractures in the middle, which inclines downwards, and there is pain, difficulty in swallowing, and cough: and perhaps blood is omitted, and there is a bulge in the fractured bone, which is not hidden from sense. The restoration of it is that the invalid be placed upon his back: and put between his shoulder blades a cushion.</start_of_turn
Deinde preme humeros eius, et aggrega costas a duabus partibus uel lateribus cum manibus: et subtiliare in aequatione eius, secundum omnem modum quo possibile est illud et conuenit, donec redeat figura ossis, secundum quod oportet.	Then press his arms, and bind his ribs from two parts or from two sides with hands: and twist them in its equilibrium, according to every possible way which can be done for it and which agrees, until the shape of the bone is restored, as it should be.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone super ipsum emplastrum et stuppam, et pone desuper astellam ex tabula subtili ex salice, aut chalingi, et ex eis similibus in leuitate, postquam tu inuoluis eam in panno.	Then place upon it a compress and a cushion, and place upon it a bandage of fine gauze from a willow, or from hemp, or from something similar in lightness, after you have bound up the hand.
Deinde subtiliare in ligando eam super os fractum, ut non remoueatur: et uade cum ligatura secundum rotunditatem ad dorsum aliquotiens, et stringe ipsum strictura decenti.	Then twist the bandage around the fractured bone, so that it does not move: and keep it firm with a bandage according to the roundness of the body, and bind it tightly.</start_of_turn
Deinde considera ligaturam in omni hora, et quotienscumque mollificatur, stringe eam: et si necessitas eius prouocat ad solutionem eius apud pruritum, uel corrosionem quae accidit in loco, aut dolorem, aut apostema: tunc propera, et solue eam, et eradica emplastrum, et rectifica quod accidit cum modo curationis eius.	Then consider the bandage at every hour, and every time it is softened, tighten the bandage: and if its necessity indicates its solution at the swelling, or corrosion which happens in the place, or pain, or apostem: then expedite it, and solve the bandage, and remove the compress, and straighten out what has happened in the method of its treatment.</start_of_turn>
Deinde reduc emplastrum, si uides ad illud faciem: et annecte ei stricturam, donec sanetur.	If the wound is on the face, reduce the dressing and bind it tightly until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Costarum, quando franguntur.	When the bones are fractured, restore them.
Caput IX.	Chapter IX
Scias, quod Costarum fractura non accidit, nisi in locis grossis quae sequuntur dorsum, et ex extremitatibus earum ab anteriori parte.	You know that a fracture of the bones does not happen except in the great places which follow the backbone, and from the extremities of them from the anterior part
Et non accidit eis attritio, nisi propterea, quia sunt cartilaginosae.	And does not happen except for this, because they are cartilaginous
Et cognitio ipsius non occultatur sensui apud inquisitionem cum digitis.	And the knowledge of it is not hidden from the sense in the examination with the fingers
Et restauratio eius fit ita, ut aeques fracturam cum digitis secundum modum possibilem, donec aequetur figura, secundum quod oportet.	And its restoration is done in such a way that it makes the fracture even with the fingers as much as possible, until the figure is equal, as it should be
Deinde emplastra, et stringe os fractum cum astella, si indiget illo.	Then the dressing, and bind the fractured bone with a pin if necessary.
Et si fractura Costarum est decliuis ad interiora: tunc accidit infirmo dolor uehemens, et punctura, sicut punctura illa quae accidit illi qui habet pleuresim: propterea, quod os pungit uelamen, et etiam ei accidit difficultas anhelitus, et tussis, et uomitus sanguinis multi: et haec est difficilis curationis.	And if the fracture of the bones is downward towards the inside: then it happens with great pain which is unbearable, and swelling, as in those who have pleurisis: because the bone pierces the membrane, and also it happens that there is difficulty with breathing, and coughing, and vomiting of blood: and this is a difficult healing.
Et iam ingeniati sunt antiqui in ea cum ingeniis multis: et ex eis sunt qui dicunt, ut ponas cibos infirmi qui generent inflammationem et uentositatem, ut inflammetur uenter, et extendatur, et impellatur fractura ad exteriora.	And the ancients were skilled in this with many skills: and among them are those who say that you should put on bandages the sick who cause inflammation and swelling, so that the belly inflates, and expands, and drives out the fracture towards the outside.
Nos uero abhorremus, ut non fiat caussa uelox ad faciendum apostema calidum, si non accidit.	We, however, abominate that it should be a cause of making the swelling worse, if it does not happen.
Si autem iam accidit, tunc addit in eo.	If however it happens, then join in it.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum: ponatur super locum uentosa, deinde sugatur cum fortitudine, et est similius ratiocinationi.	And some of them say: put on over the swelling place, then draw it together with force, and this is similar to the calculation
Verumtamen timetur, quod attrahat uentosa superfluitates ad locum, propter dispositionem debilitatis.	Truth be told, when moist substances are drawn towards a location, it is due to the disposition of the disabled.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum: oportet ut cooperiatur locus cum lana quae iam submersa est in oleo calido: et ponantur puluilli inter Costas, donec impleatur: ut sit ligatura aequalis quando inuoluis eam secundum rotunditatem.	Some have said: It is necessary for the place to cooperate with the wool which is already submerged in warm oil: and they put in feathers between the ribs until it is firm: so that there is an even ligation when you roll up the belly according to its roundness.
Deinde curetur infirmus curatione pleuresis ex cibo et medicina.	Then one must care for the wounded man with food and medicine.
Quod si coartat infirmum res uehemens, quam non tolerat, et os pungit uelamen punctura laedente, et timemus super infirmum: tunc oportet, ut scindamus super locum, et detegamus a Costa fracta.	If one binds up a patient too tightly with that which he cannot tolerate, and if the bone is pierced with a wound that is gaping, and we fear that the patient will die: then it is necessary to split open the place and remove the fractured rib bone
Deinde ponamus super ea instrumentum quod conseruat sifac, cuius rememoratio praecessit: et incidamus os cum facilitate, et incidamus ipsum.	Then we put over this an instrument which preserves the fat, whose memory has gone before: and we break the bone easily and break through the bone itself
Deinde aggregemus duo labia uulneris, si est magnum cum sutura: et curemus ipsum cum emplastris, donec sanetur.	Then we join together two lips of the wound, if there is a large one with a suture: and we care for it with poultices until it heals.
Quod si accidat interim apostema calidum, tunc propera, et infunde puluillos in oleo rosato, et pone super locum: et curetur infirmus cum eo quod conuenit apostemati.	If in the meantime a swelling becomes hot, then cool it down, and pour pultices of rose oil over the place: and put on it: and care for the patient with what agrees with the swelling.
Interim etiam resupinetur super latus super quod dormit, donec sanetur.	Even between times he rests on his side over which he sleeps, until he heals
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spondilium dorsi et colli.	On the restoration of fractures of the rib and neck bones.
Caput X.	Chapter X.
Ossibus quidem colli quandoque aduenit fractura, et raro accidit eis attritio: et similiter Spondilibus dorsi etiam.	The bones of the neck when they are fractured sometimes happen by attrition: and in the same way the rib bones also.
Cum ergo accidit illud alicui, et uis scire, an sanetur, an non sanetur: tunc confidera.	When this happens to anyone, and you do not know whether he will heal or not: then keep quiet
Nam si uides manus eius iam mollificatas, et stupefactas, et mortuas: et non potest mouere eas, neque extendere eas, neque constringere eas: et quando constringis eas cum digitis tuis, et pungis eas cum acu, non sentit illud, et non sentit in eis dolorem: tunc scias, quia non sanatur, et in pluribus dispositionibus est mortale.	If you aid the hand when swollen, stiff, and dead, it will not move, neither extend nor contract: and when you compress it with your fingers and needles with an awl, you do not feel pain, neither do you feel it in its insides. Then you know that it is not healing, and that it is deadly.
Quod si mouet eas, et sentit in eis constrictionem cum digitis et puncturam: tunc scias, quia nucha ossis salua est, et quod infirmus sanabitur cum curatione.	When it moves, and you feel constriction in its insides with your fingers and needle, then you know that the bone is broken, and that it will heal only with treatment.
Quod si eueniat Spondilibus dorsi simile illius, et uis scire, an sanetur etiam, an non: tunc considera ad pedes eius: tunc si uides quod mollificati sunt, et accidit in eis illud quod accidit in manibus: deinde quando iacet super dorsum suum, egreditur uentositas et egestio absque uoluntate: et quando resupinatur super uentrem suum, egreditur egestio sine uoluntate: et quando resupinatur super dorsum suum, et uult mingere, et non potest: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	If you bring close to each other the pain of the back like that of the hand, and you do not know whether it will heal or not: then look at its feet. If you aid what is softened in the hands and comes into this in the back: then when it lies over its belly, there comes out swelling and discharge without its will. And when it lies over its belly and wishes to move, and it cannot: then you know that it is deadly.
Non ergo labores in curatione eius.	It is of no use to work on its cure.
Si uero non accidit ei aliquid ex illo, res est leuior.	If indeed nothing happens to it from this, then it is easier.
Et curatio eius quod accidit ex illo est, ut coneris sedationem apostematis calidi: ita, ut ponas super Spondilem attritam oleum rosatum solum: aut cum uitellis oui assati.	Its cure from this is that you bring near its afterburn with the warmth of oil of roses: thus, put on the back what is attracted to the Spondila with olive oil or balm.
Pone super ipsam illud aliquotiens in die, donec quando sedatur apostema calidum: tum pone super locum unum ex emplastris confortantibus, exiccantibus, et stringe super ipsum cum ligamento: et praecipe infirmo, ut utatur quiete et tranquillitate.	Put on it at every other time in the day until when the afterburn has subsided: then put on one bandage over the place and cover it with a soft dressing, and bind it up with a thread: and command the patient to rest quietly and peacefully
Nec dormiat super partem cum qua inuenit dolorem, donec sanetur.	Let him not sleep over the part where he has pain until it has healed
Quod si accidit apud attritionem ossis sathaiatum, aut aliquid quod iam separatum fit ex eo: tunc oportet, ut seces super cutem, et auferas illud.	If anything happens at the attrition of the bone of the thigh, or if anything is separated from it: then it is necessary to cut above the skin and raise it up.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris, si est magnum, cum sutura.	Then join together two lips of the wound, if it is large, with a suture.</start_of_turn>
Deinde cura ipsum cum aliquo incarnatiuo, ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with some nourishment, from unguents, until it heals.</start_of_turn>
Si uero frangitur postremum ossis alhausos, et est finis caudae: tunc oportet, ut intromittas pollicem manus sinistrae in anum, et aeques os fractum manu altera, secundum quod possibile est, et secunda aequatione.	If indeed the thigh bone is fractured behind and the end of the leg is hanging: then it is necessary to insert the little finger of the left hand into the buttock, and equalize the fractured bone in the hand, according to what is possible, and with the second hand.</start_of_turn>
Deinde pone super ipsum, et aufer ipsum: et cura uulnus cum curatione quae praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then place above it [the bone] and elevate it: and care for the wound with the care that went before, until it heals.</start_of_turn
¶ De restauratione Anchae.	Of the restoration of the limb.</start_of_turn
Caput XI.	Chapter 11.</start_of_turn>
Raro franguntur ossa Ancharum.	Rarely are the bones of the limb fractured.</start_of_turn
Quod si franguntur, tunc fractura eorum non est, nisi comminutio in extremitatibus ipsorum: et scinduntur in longitudine, et declinantur ad interiora: et accidit infirmo dolor in loco, et punctura: et stupescit crus quod frangitur.	If they are fractured, then the fracture of them is not, except for a dislocation in the extremities: and they are torn along their length, and bend inwards: and there results mild pain in the place, and swelling: and the leg that is fractured becomes stiff.</start_of_turn
Et restauratio quidem eius est, ut extendas manum tuam super ipsum, donec stes super fracturam qualiter est figura eius.	And the restoration of it is that you extend your hand over it, until you are over the fracture as well as it is in its figure.</start_of_turn
Quod si fractura est in extremitatibus eius tantum, tunc aequa illam fracturam, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ex aequatione, donec assimiletur figurae suae naturali.	If the fracture is only in the extremities of it, then equalize the fracture, according to what is prepared for you from the equation, until they are equal in figure to their natural form.</start_of_turn
Si autem fractura est in longitudine, aut iam declinat ad interiora: tunc fac iacere infirmum super uentrem suum, donec praeparetur tibi restauratio illius fracturae.	If the fracture is in length, or if it hangs downwards towards the interior: then let the patient lie upon his belly until restoration of the fracture is prepared.
Quando ergo aequaueris ipsam, pone super ipsam emplastrum: deinde pone super ipsam astellam ex ligno, aut ex cute: et stringe strictura super quam non timeas permutationem fracturae, neque remotionem astellae.	When the fracture has become even, put upon it a dressing: then put upon it a bandage of wood or leather: and bind tightly over which you fear not the displacement of the fracture, nor the removal of the bandage.
Et aequa concauitatem illorum cum eo quod impleat eam, donec capiat eam strictura secundum aequalitatem: et praecipe infirmo, ut dormiat super dorsum suum, aut super latus suum sanum.	And equalize the swelling with that which the dressing will contain: until you have taken hold of the fracture with a tight binding: and command the patient to rest upon his back, or upon his sound side.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum: tunc cessa ab extensione eius, et ipsius restauratione, donec sedetur apostema calidum: et pone super ipsum quod sedet ipsum, secundum quod praecessit, deinde redi ad restaurationem eius: et stringe ipsum sicut oportet.	If, however, a callous swelling should arise: then cease from its extension, and from its restoration: until the callous swelling has subsided: and put upon it what has subsided, as before, and return to the restoration of it: and bind it as seems good
Si uero accidit in osse satagie, aut comminuitur, extrahe.	If indeed it happens in a bony prominence, or is fractured, extract it.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Adiutorii.	Of the restoration of the fracture.
Caput XII.	Chapter XII.</start_of_turn>
Adiutorium est illud, quod est inter cubitum usque ad caput Spatulae.	The aid is that which is between the elbow up to the head of the scapula.</start_of_turn>
Si ergo frangitur, tunc restauratio eius est secundum unum duorum modorum.	If indeed it is fractured, then the restoration of it is according to one of two methods.</start_of_turn
Quorum unus est: ut accipias lignum planum mediae grossitudinis, secundum hanc formam, quae sequitur.	One of them is: that you take a flat piece of wood of medium thickness, according to this shape.</start_of_turn
Et ligentur in duabus extremitatibus duo ligamenta.	And two ligatures are bound at the two extremities.</start_of_turn
Deinde suspendatur ex loco eleuato: et sedeat infirmus super sedem.	Then it is suspended from a high place: and the patient sits upon a seat.</start_of_turn
Deinde proiiciat brachium suum fractum super lignum, donec perueniat ad titillicum eius, in cuius medio sit annexa curuitas ligni.	Then he will project his fractured arm over the wood until it reaches the elbow of his limb, in which middle there is an attached fragment of bone.
Deinde suspende desuper ipsum aliquid graue, ut extendat ipsum minister ad inferiora.	Then he will suspend something weighty above it, so as to extend the limb downwards.
Deinde aequet medicus fracturam manibus suis simul, donec redeat fractura, secundum quod oportet.	Then the physician will stabilize the fracture with his hands, until the fracture has healed, as required
Et modus alter est, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et suspende manum eius a collo ipsius cum ligamento.	And another method is that the patient should rest on his bed: and suspend his arm from his neck with a ligament
Deinde praecipe duobus ministris, ut teneat unus eorum illud quod est supra fracturam cum manibus suis: et ut alter teneat inferius eius, et extendat unusquisque eorum ad partem suam.	Then command two assistants, that one should hold that which is above the fracture with his hands, and that the other should hold the lower one, and that each of them should extend his to his part.
Et si uis, ut sit extensio fortior, tunc stringe sub fractura cum ligamento, et supra ipsam cum ligamento alio: et extendat ea unusquisque duorum ministrorum ad duas partes suas.	And if desired, in order that the extension may be stronger, then bind under the fracture with a ligament and above it with another ligament: and extend both of them by two assistants to their two parts.
Si ergo fractura est propinqua extremitati humeri, tunc oportet, ut ponatur unum ligamentum sub titillico, et alterum sub fractura uersus cubitum.	If the fracture is close to the elbow of the arm, then it is necessary to put on one ligament under the elbow and another under the fracture above the elbow
Et similiter si fractura est propinqua cubito: tunc oportet, ut ponatur ligamentum super illum locum, et super cubitum ipsum.	And in the same way if the fracture is close to the forearm: then it is necessary to put on a ligament over the place of the wound, and over the forearm itself.
Deinde aequa fracturam cum facilitate absque labore, donec quando aequatur fractura secundum quod oportet, et applicatur applicatione bona: tunc stringe eam, si non accidit apostema calidum.	Then stabilize the fracture easily without toil, until the fracture has healed according to what is required, and apply a good dressing: then bind it up, if it has not already gone cold
Si uero accidit apostema calidum, tunc dimitte stricturam usque ad diem septimum.	If indeed a cold swelling has occurred, then remove the bandage until the seventh day.
Et pone super ipsum lanam succidam imbibitam in aceto et oleo rosato, donec quando quiescit apostema: tunc stringe eam: et modus stringendi eam est, ut ponas emplastrum super fracturam.	And put upon it a soaked bandage in vinegar and salt, until the swelling has subsided: then bind it up: and the way of binding it up is that you put on a plaster on the fracture.
Deinde pone inuolutionem ex panno nouo super emplastrum.	Then place a new patch over the wound.
Deinde aggreget brachium super adiutorium ipsum, et ponat manum suam apertam super humerum suum.	Then take hold of the limb with your arm, and open your hand over the shoulder bone.
Et pone pannum, et stringe super adiutorium brachium, ut brachium stet loco astellarum: si non prohibet te ab illo aliquid, neque alteretur super te aliquid ex osse fracto.	Put on a bandage, and bind the limb with your arm so that the limb is fixed in place without hindering you from anything or causing you any pain from the fractured bone
Quod si times, quod alteretur super te ex osse fracto aliquid, tunc utere astellis: et est, ut ponas super fracturam ipsam astellam quae sit latior et fortior reliquis astellis.	If at any time you notice something wrong with the fractured bone, put over it the larger and stronger bandage of the two
Et ponas inter omnem astellam latitudinem digiti: et sit longitudo astellarum secundum fracturam cum additione trium digitorum ab omni parte.	And place between every bandage a width equal to the breadth of a finger. And let the length of the bandages be according to the fracture plus three fingers from all sides
Deinde stringe super astellas strictura quam dixi in principio capituli.	Then bind over the bandages as I said at the beginning of the chapter.
Et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae strictior.	And let your binding be tighter over the site of the fracture
Et quanto plus elongatur fractura, sit strictura minor.	The more prolonged the fracture, the tighter the binding should be
Si ergo uides situm astellarum et stricturam, sicut diximus, in hora qua restauras membrum statim, tunc fac: et si times apostema calidum, tunc dimitte stricturam et astellas usque ad diem septimum, sicut diximus.	If therefore you observe the position of the bandages and the binding at the time you restore the limb, do this: and if you notice swelling, loosen the binding and the bandages until the seventh day, as we have said before
Deinde considera ligamentum in omnibus tribus diebus, ut non accidat in loco pruritus, aut inflatio, aut prohibeatur cibus peruenire ad membrum, propter dispositionem superfluitatis stricturae.	Then consider the ligament in every three days, so that no pain, swelling or impediment to the passage of food to the limb occurs due to the tension of the binding
Rectifica ergo illud totum, secundum quod diximus.	Do all this, as we have said before
Si uero es super fiduciam, ut non accidat ex illo aliquid: tunc non soluas ligamentum, nisi post tres dies, aut plus.	If you are in doubt, do not loosen the ligament before three days, or more
Et sit dormitio infirmi super dorsum suum, et manus eius super stomachum suum: et pone sub adiutorio culcitram plenam lana aequaliter.	Let the patient rest with their head on their chest, and their hand on their stomach: and place under the support a full cushion of wool equally.
Et considera in omni hora noctis, aut diei, ut non soluatur figura membri fracta, aut mollificetur ligamentum.	Consider at all times of night and day that the figure of the fractured limb should not be allowed to become loose, or the ligament should not be softened.
Rectifica ergo illud totum uirtute tua.	The limb should be set firmly in its entirety for your entire care
Et pone cibum infirmi secundum ordinem quem praemisimus, ita ut sit cibus subtilis in primis, donec incipiat os stringi: tunc oportet, ut ingrosses cibum eius.	And provide the patient with food in accordance with the order we have given, so that it be light in the beginning, until the bone begins to knit: then it is necessary that you increase the amount of food gradually.
De consuetudine enim adiutorii et cruris est, ut stringatur in quadraginta diebus: tunc ergo oportet, ut soluatur, et administretur balneum, et medicetur cum unguentis quae rectificant illud.	As for the attendance of the attendants and the patient, it is necessary that the limb be bound for forty days: then it is necessary that it be loosened, and a bath should be administered, and that unguents be applied which will rectify this
Quod si fractura fuerit foeda, attrita: tunc non soluas ab ea ligamentum et astellas usque ad quinquaginta dies, et usque ad duos menses.	If the fracture be dirty or raw: then do not loosen the ligament or the fragments until fifty days have passed, and until two months have elapsed.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Brachii.	Regarding the restoration of a fractured limb.
Caput XIII.	Chapter 13
Brachium est compositum ex duobus ossibus, quae nominantur duo focilia.	The arm is composed of two bones, which are named the two ulnae.
Quorum unum est paruum: et est illud quod sequitur pollicem.	One of them is the forearm: and that which follows the thumb
Et alterum est magnum, et est illud quod est positum sub paruo ab inferiori parte.	The other is the forearm, and that which is placed under the forearm from the lower part
Fortasse ergo frangitur focile maius solum, aut paruum: et fortasse franguntur simul.	Perhaps therefore the large bone is fractured only, or the forearm: and perhaps both together
Quando ergo frangitur focile paruum superius, tunc restauratio eius est facilis, et sanatio eius est facilior.	When therefore the upper forearm bone is fractured, then the restoration of the same is easy, and the healing is more rapid
Et quando frangitur focile inferius, est fractura eius mala, et sanatio eius difficilis.	And when the lower forearm bone is fractured, the fracture is bad, and the healing is difficult
Et deterior ea est, quando franguntur duo ossa simul.	And it is worse when both bones are fractured together
Si ergo os quod frangitur est focile parum superius, tunc conuenit medico apud restaurationem eius, ut ponat extensionem paruam cum facilitate, donec aequet ipsum.	If the bone which is fractured is slightly above the navel, then the physician must be present at the restoration of it, in order to place the extension of the gut with ease, until it equals itself.
Si uero focile magnum est illud quod fractum est: tunc oportet, ut ponat stricturam fortiorem ualde.	If the fracture is of a large bone: then it is necessary to place a stronger support around it
Et oportet, ut ponat figuram manus apud restaurationem eius, et ipsius extensionem extensam super puluinar.	It is necessary to place the hand figure at the restoration of it and to extend the limb beyond the elbow
Et sit pollex manus ad superiora altior omnibus digitis: et sit articularis inferior omnibus digitis, uel reliquis: et infirmus sedens quadratus super seipsum, et sit puluinar coram eo, uel in directo eius, in altitudine, ut non incurrat infirmus laborem.	The thumb should be placed above the wrist of all fingers and the lower joint of all fingers, or of some of them: and the patient should sit square upon himself, and the elbow should be at the level of the shoulder or somewhat above it, so that the patient does not incur any pain.
Deinde extendat minister Brachium ab inferiori parte, aut manu sua, aut cum ligamento.	Then extend the arm from below, or with the hand itself, or with the ligament.
Et minister alius extendat desuper similiter.	And the other limb extends in the same way from above
Deinde aequet medicus os, donec reducat ipsum secundum meliorem figuram quam potest.	Then the physician must equalize the bone, until it is reduced to a better shape than before
Quod si in fractura ossis sunt satagiae, tunc conare reducere omne frustum in loco suo uirtute tua.	If there are any protrusions in the fracture, then try to reduce them in their place without haste.
Si uero apparet in eo sathaiatum separatum, et pungit cutem, et non est tibi spes in restauratione eius: tunc finde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum secundum modum quem diximus in eis quae praemissa sunt.	If there appears in it a separated piece of cartilage, which has pierced the skin, and there is no hope of restoring it: then find above it and remove it in the manner which we mentioned above
Si autem fractura est cum uulnere, ego iam feci ad illud capitulum singulare, ergo accipe curationem illius inde.	If however the fracture is with a wound, I do this for the head alone, and take care of the cure from that moment on
Quod si accidat in principio tuae restaurationis apostema calidum, tunc line pannum cum caeroto facto ex oleo rosato, et caera alba, et sit medium inter spissitudinem et subtilitatem: et stringe pannum super ipsum strictura subtili, donec quando sedatur apostema: tunc remoue caerotum, et pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum albumine oui.	If at the beginning of your restoration you see a soft swelling, then draw the gut with a piece of cotton wool which has been made fine, and white, and put the middle between the thickness and the thinness: and bind the gut over it with a fine suture until the swelling has subsided: then remove the cotton wool, and put an ointment prepared from pounded wheat with albumin or oil.
Deinde pone astellas, et sit astella quae ponitur super fracturam ipsam latior parumper, et fortior.	Then place sponges, and let the sponge which is placed over the fracture be wider and stronger.
Et scias, quod numerus astellarum Brachii est sex in pluribus dispositionibus: siue sit fractura in focili uno, aut in duobus focilibus simul.	And know that the number of sponges for the arm is six in various positions: if the fracture is in one cavity, or in two cavities simultaneously.
Deinde pone stricturam tuam super locum fracturae fortiorem et uehementiorem, et aliquanto plus cum strictura ad superiora fracturae, aut ad inferiora eius: aut pone stricturam molliorem strictura eius parumper, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius in principio capituli.	Then place your bandage firmly over the fracture stronger and more tightly, and a little more with the bandage above the fracture, or below it: or place a softer bandage under the previous bandage alongside it, according as the recollection of it was at the beginning of the chapter
Et sint panni qui inuoluuntur super fracturam, panni lenes, humidi: et non sint duri, asperi.	And let there be cloths which cover the fracture, soft cloths, moist: and not hard, rough.
Et sit filum quo stringitur ex lino proprie, medium inter subtile et grossum, sicut narrauimus.	And let the thread which is drawn from the linen itself be medium between subtle and coarse, as we have narrated.
Et considera membrum et ligamentum post dies.	And consider the limb and the ligament after days.
Quod si accidat aliquid cuius rectificatio sit necessaria, sicut pruritus qui accidit membro: tunc oportet, ut embroces membrum cum aqua calefacta, donec quiescat ille pruritus, et dimittas membrum non constrictum, donec quiescat, deinde itera stricturam.	If anything happens whose rectification is necessary, such as itching which occurs in the limb: then it is necessary to bathe the limb with warm water until the itching ceases, and then loosen the limb, until it is quiet, then repeat the bandage
Quod si strictura iam mollificata est, et os iam remotum, et similia illis: tunc rectifica illud totum uirtute tua, et considera iterum.	If the bandage is already softened, and the bone is already removed, and things are similar to these: then rectify all this with your skill, and consider it again.
Nam si nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad membrum, propter superfluitatem stricturae, tunc oportet, ut mollifices ipsum parumper, et dimittas ipsum aliquot diebus, donec currat ad ipsum nutrimentum, deinde stringe ipsum.	For if the nourishment is hindered from reaching the limb because of the excess of the bandage, then it is necessary to soften it a little, and let it rest for a few days, until the nourishment reaches it again, then bind it again
Si autem non accidit infirmo aliquid eorum quae diximus, tunc non oportet, ut soluatur, nisi post uiginti dies, aut circiter hos.	But if no ailment happens to the sick person of the things which we have mentioned, then it is not necessary to break it off, except after eighty days or so
Deinde suspendatur manus infirmi ad collum eius.	Then the hand of the patient is suspended at his collar.
Et sit collum eius aequale, et custodiatur uirtute sua a motibus agitatiuis.	The collar is made equal, and his body is guarded from disturbing movements.
Et fac eum dormire super dorsum suum.	Let him sleep over his back.
Et scias, quod haec fractura in triginta diebus, aut in triginta duobus diebus restauratur: et fortasse restauratur in uigintiocto diebus.	Know that this fracture is restored in thirty days, or in thirty-two days: and perhaps in eighty days.
Totum illud est secundum dispositiones complexionum, et dispositiones uirtutis.	All this is according to the arrangements of the temperaments, and the arrangements of virtue
¶ De restauratione fracturarum Manus.	Of the restoration of fractures of the hand.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter 123.</start_of_turn>
Scias, quod pectini Manus, et nodis digitorum raro accidit fractura.	Know that the bones of the hand and the nodes of the fingers are rarely fractured
Et non accidit ei, nisi attritio multotiens.	And do not happen to them except for a great attrition.</start_of_turn>
Quando ergo accidit plantae fractura, aut attritio: tunc oportet, ut sedeat infirmus quadratus: et coram eo sit sedes secundum aequalitatem.	When therefore such a fracture of the bone happens, or an attrition: then it is necessary that the patient sit square: and before him be placed a seat equal in height.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone Manum eius super eam extensam.	Then place his hand over his extended palm.</start_of_turn
Deinde extendat minister ossa fracta, et aequet ea medicus, donec quando coniunguntur coniunctione bona.	Then extend the minister of the fractured bone, and the doctor must make them equal, until when they are reunited with a good junction.</start_of_turn
Tunc oportet, ut ponat emplastrum et stuppam, si non accidat apostema calidum.	Then it is necessary that he put on a plaster and a bandage, if the swelling does not subside naturally.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone astellam desuper secundum quantitatem loci: et tu iam inuoluisti eam in panno lini.	Then put on a bandage above according to the quantity of the place: and I put the hand into a linen cloth.</start_of_turn
Si autem fractura est ad inferiora circiter uentrem plantae, tunc fac simile spherae ex panno: et praecipe infirmo, ut coartet super eam cum planta sua fracta: deinde stringatur cum panno longo.	If however the fracture is towards the lower part round about the wrist, then make like a sphere of cloth: and command the patient to keep his hand resting on his fractured bone: and bind it with a long cloth.</start_of_turn
Et sit astella ex corio, in quo sit lenitas, ut applicetur corium cum corpore plantae: et stringe eam, secundum quod oportet.	And let the stitches be from the skin, in which there is softness, so that the skin may be applied to the body of the plant: and bind them firmly, according to what is necessary.
Si autem fractura est ad exteriora, tunc oportet: ut ponas astellam desuper, et astellam aliam ab inferiori in planta: et sit manus aperta recta.	If the fracture is on the outside, then it is necessary: that you put a stitch above and a stitch below in the plant: and let the hand be open and straight.
Deinde pone stricturam, sicut reuoluitur manus: et extende inter digitos cum ligamento.	Then put a support, as it is bent by the hand: and extend between the fingers with the ligament.
Quod si accidat fractura alicui nodorum digitorum, tunc si est pollex, aequetur secundum quod oportet.	If it happens that the fracture is of some bone of the fingers, then if it is the thumb, make it equal according to what is necessary
Deinde stringatur cum planta: et si amas, pone ei astellam rectam, paruam: ut eleuetur fractura, et non moueatur.	Then bind with the plant: and if there is swelling, put on a straight stitch, firm: so that the fracture is elevated and does not move.
Si autem fractura est reliquis digitis, sicut medio, et indici, aut auriculari, et anulari, tunc aequetur, et ligetur cum digito sano qui sequitur eum: aut ligentur omnes secundum continuationem: et est melius.	If the fracture is of the remaining fingers, such as the middle, and index, or ring, and little, then make them equal, and bind them with the healthy finger which follows them: or bind them all together: and that is better.
Aut pone super ipsum astellam paruam, sicut diximus in pollice.	Or put on the tip a firm stitch, as we said concerning the thumb.
Et considera in restauratione tua, et post ipsam dispositionem apostematis calidi: et oppone cum eo quod oportet, quando accidit aliquid ex illo, secundum quod iteratur eius narratio.	And consider in your restoration, and after the setting of the wound: and oppose with it what is necessary, when anything happens of that, according to the course of its story.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Coxae.	Of the restoration of the fracture of the thigh bone.
Caput XV.	Chapter 15.
OS Coxae multotiens frangitur, et declaratur sensui: quoniam conuertitur ad interiorem et posteriorem partem.	The thigh bone is fractured many times, and it is declared by sense: because it curves inward and outward parts
Et restauratio eius fit ita, quod stringitur ligamentum supra fracturam, et ligamentum aliud sub fractura.	And its restoration is done thus, that the ligament is sutured above the fracture, and the ligament is sutured below the fracture.
Et infirmus prostretur super faciem suam.	And the infirm is returned to his face.
Deinde extendat omne ligamentum minister ad partem suam secundum aequalitatem: et hoc, quando est fractura in medio ossis.	Then extend all the ligaments around the part to its side according to their equality: and this is when there is a fracture in the middle of the bone.
Si autem est fractura propinqua radici Coxae, tunc sit ligamentum ad partem pectinis, ut cadat extensio ad sursum: et ligamentum aliud sub fractura.	If however the fracture is close to the root of the coxae, then let the ligament be around the part of the hip so that the extension may go up: and let the other ligament be under the fracture
Et sic similiter si est fractura propinqua genu, tunc sit ligamentum propinquum genu, ut sit extensio ad inferiora.	And thus in the same way if there is a fracture close to the knee, then let the ligament be close to the knee so that the extension may go downwards
Deinde aequet medicus os utriusque manibus suis, donec reducat ipsum secundum similitudinem figurae naturalis: et coniugatur os coniunctione bona.	Then the physician must fix the bone with both his hands, until he has reduced it according to the likeness of its natural figure: and join the bones with a good suture.
Tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum et stricturam, si non accidit membro apostema.	Then it is necessary to put on a plaster and bind it, if the limb is not restored after the fracture
Quod si accidat in eo apostema: tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur apostema calidum, deinde redi ad curationem tuam.	And if this happens in the restoration of the limb: then leave it for a few days, until the limb becomes calm, and then return to your treatment.
Strictura autem eius ita sit.	And the stricture of it is like this.
Oportet ut inuoluas super fracturam imema duram, id est, bindam: et dupla eam bis, aut ter: et remaneat ex ea superfluitas.	It is necessary to cover over the fracture with a firm covering, that is, a bandage: and double it twice, or three times: and remain from that excess.
Deinde inuolue crus, donec perueniat calcaneus apud radicem natis.	Then cover the leg until the heel reaches the root of the nail.
Et intromitte filum longum inter Coxam et crus prope genu ad inferiora, et ueniant extremitates fili a superiori parte duarum partium.	And insert a long thread between the coxae and the leg near the knee downwards, and bring the ends of the thread from the upper part of both parts
Deinde reuolue super Crus et Coxam quod superfluit ex alimema.	Then roll up over the leg and the coxae what is in excess from the other part
Deinde pone super Coxam in loco fracturae ipsius astellas, et pone ex eis astellam unam super os cruris.	Then put on the coxae in the place of the fracture itself little nails, and put on a nail from above on the bone of the leg
Deinde imple uacuitates inter crus et coxam cum pannis lenibus, ut aequetur strictura.	Then fill the cavities between the thigh and hip with wool pads, so as to equalize the tension.
Deinde incipe cum strictura forti a medio super locum fracturae tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor.	Then begin by making the tension strong from the middle above the fractured area, with three or four inversions
Et quanto plus elongaris cum ligamento a loco fracturae, sit strictura tua minor et mollior, et lenior.	And the more you lengthen with the ligament from the fractured place, the less tension you will have, and the softer and more gentle it will be
Deinde intende ad duas extremitates fili, quod tu intromisisti inter coxam et crus.	Then take two threads to the two extremities which you have introduced between the hip and thigh
Liga ergo cum utrisque tres astellas quae sunt desuper.	Tie them thus with both three threads that are above.
Deinde uade cum duabus extremitatibus fili ad inferiora, donec peruenias ad cauillam pedis.	Then lead both thread extremities down until you reach the heel of the foot
Et cum utrisque stringe etiam extremitates astellarum a parte altera: ut non remoueatur ligamentum ex loco suo.	And when you have tied both strings, also bind the extremities of the pins from the other side: so that the ligament does not slip from its place
Deinde dimitte stricturam super illud, dum permanet, ita quod non accidat membro corrosio, neque apostema, neque inflatio, et similia eis.	Then release the tension above it, while it remains, so that no fracture, no swelling, nor inflation, or the like occurs to it.
Quod si accidat aliquid ex illo.	Which if anything should happen from this
Propera ergo cum solutione eius, et rectifica illud quod accidit inde totum, secundum quod diximus multotiens.	Then act diligently with its solution and restore what happened from the beginning, as we have said many times before
Si uero in osse est frustum ex osse quod pungat: tunc oportet, ut aeques illud, si est tibi possibile.	If there is a piece of bone that projects from the bone: then it must be leveled, if this is possible.
Et si non, finde super illud, et remoue illud: et cura cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio, donec sanetur.	And if not, find above it, and remove it: and take care of it until the pain has passed away
Et quandoque stringitur haec fractura Coxae, praeter quod addantur ei astellae, sicut diximus in adiutorio et brachio.	When this fracture of the hip is bound, besides the pins which are added, do as we said in the treatise and in the arm
Verumtamen in restauratione eius taliter fracta, non accidit infirmo claudicatio.	But do not let it be that in restoring it, the fracture should become weaker
Et si restauratur sola, praeter quod applicetur ei crus alterum, tunc necesse est, ut claudicet ille cuius est, semper.	And if it is restored alone, besides what is applied to the other limb, then it is necessary that the limb which has been closed should be opened always.
Et scias, quod Coxa stringitur in quinquaginta diebus, uel additur parum, aut minuitur parum: totum illud est secundum diuersitatem complexionum, et reliquarum dispositionum.	And know that the coxae is strung out in fifty days, or is added slightly, or diminished slightly: all this is according to the diversity of complexions and the remaining parts.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Rotulae genu.	About the restoration of the fracture of the knee-joint
Caput XVI.	Chapter XVI
Scias, quod Rotulae genu raro accidit fractura, sed accidit ei attritio multotiens.	Know that the knee-joint rarely happens to fracture, but it often happens to it to be bruised many times
Si uero accidit ei fractura, tunc non nisi aut fissura, aut foramen in partibus suis.	If it happens to fracture, then it is not without a break or a hole in its parts.
Et est illud cum uulnere, et absque uulnere.	It is just as with a wound, and without a wound
Et statur super illud totum cum sensu.	And it remains in that state with sense.
Et restauratio eius est ita, ut aequetur quod disruptum est ex partibus eius cum digitis, donec aggregetur, et coniungatur secundum quod possibile est ex aequatione et facilitate, et fabricatione.	And its restoration is in this way, that it be equal to what has been disrupted from its parts with the digits, until it is joined together again, and connected according to what is possible with equality and with facility, and with fabrication
Deinde pone emplastrum ex farina sisami, uel molendini, cum albumine oui: et pone super ipsum astellam rotundam, si indiges illa: et stringe desuper strictura conueniente ad illud.	Then put on a dressing of barley flour or meal with albumin, or oil: and put on top of it a round bandage, if necessary: and bind up from above with a convenient bandage to that.
Deinde considera omnes dispositiones quas narrauimus in reliquis fracturis: sicut apostema calidum, et similia illi: ita, ut opponas omni accidenti cum eo quod conuenit ei, donec sanetur.	Then consider all the arrangements which we have narrated in the other fractures: thus as a cold poultice, and the like: thus, that you oppose every accident with that which is suitable to it, until it is healed
¶ De restauratione fracturae Cruris.	About the restoration of the fracture of the thigh
Caput XVII.	Chapter XVII
Scias, quod Cruri sunt duo ossa, quorum unum est grossum, et nominatur nomine Cruris: et alterum subtile, et nominatur Focile.	Know that the thigh has two bones, of which one is thick, and is called the Cruris: and the other is thin, and is called the Focile
Et accidit utrisque ex speciebus fracturae quod accidit duobus ossibus brachii: et propter illud fit restauratio eius, sicut restauratio brachii aequaliter, et operatio est una.	And it happens in both cases from the species of fracture which happens to two bones of the forearm: and because of this its restoration is effected, just as the restoration of the forearm equally, and the operation is one.
Quod si franguntur duo ossa simul, conuertitur Crus ad omnes partes.	If two bones break together, the forearm turns around to all parts
Et si frangitur os subtilius, conuertitur Crus ad anteriorem partem.	If a thin bone breaks, the forearm turns around to the anterior part.
Et si frangitur os grossius, inuenis illud inferius: et est ex eis quae non occultantur tibi.	If a thick bone breaks, its lower part is found: and it is from that from which the bones do not appear.
Deinde administra extensionem, et aequationem, et ligationem astellarum secundum illud aequaliter.	Then administer extension, and equating, and ligation of the tendons according to that equally.
Verumtamen oportet, si fractura Cruris est fractura foeda, habens sethagie multa: ut sit extensio minor, et lenior alleuiatione tua.	It is true that if the fracture of the forearm is a compound fracture, having many lacerations: so that the extension is less, and the alleviation is more gentle to you
Et in Crure quidem est ex operatione quiddam super brachium: et est, ut quando tu aequas astellas, et comples omnem operationem tuam, tunc accipe duas fascias ex ligno pini, quod administratur in fabricatione solariorum quod ponitur sub tabulis: et fiunt ex spatulis palmae: et elige ex eis quibus est grossitudo parua, et neque sint ex minutis: et sit longitudo earum secundum longitudinem Cruris a genu usque inferius.	And in the forearm there is something from the operation which is more than for the arm: and it is that when you equal the tendons and perform all your operation, then grasp two bands of pine wood which are administered in the fabrication of solar plates which are placed under the boards: and they become from the palm splints: and choose from those which have a small thickness, and neither are they from the smallest: and let their length be according to the length of the forearm from the knee to the lower part
Deinde inuolue super unamquamque pannum duabus inuolutionibus secundum longitudinem eius.	Then bind over one and a half fingers two bands according to its length
Et pone unam partem Cruris a parte una, et alteram a parte altera: et sint ex genu usque inferius pedis.	And put one part of the forearm from one side, and the other from the other side: and they are from the knee to the lower part of the foot
Deinde liga duas fascias in tribus locis ex duabus extremitatibus et medio.	And bind two bands in three places from two extremities and middle
Cum enim strictura prohibetur, Crus declinat ad dextram et sinistram, et stat statione bona.	When the tension is forbidden, the forearm declines to the right and left, and remains in a good position.
Et iam quidem administretur cunabulum ex ligno secundum longitudinem Cruris, et ponatur in eo Crus, ut conseruet ipsum a motu.	And thus is administered a cubulum of wood according to the length of the Cruris, and is placed in that Cruris, that it may preserve it from movement.
Et plurimum quidem oportet, ut facias illud in fractura quando cum ea est uulnus proprie.	And much more is required, that you make it firm in fracture when it is its own bone
Deinde considera Crus in omni die, et stude cum eo studio ultimo ab apostemate, aut inflatione, aut reliquis aliis.	Then consider the Cruris every day, and study it with the utmost care from the apostemate, or swelling, or any other thing.
Si ergo accidit aliquid ex illis, tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur, si Deus uoluerit.	If anything happens to it from these things, then oppose it with that which is necessary, until it is healed, if God wills it.
De fractura ossium Pedis, et Digitorum.	Of fractures of the bones of the Foot and Fingers.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter 18.
Calcaneo quidem non accidit fractura penitus.	The Calcaneus never fractures completely
Ossibus uero Pedis accidit quandoque fractura, et Digitis parum etiam accidit fractura: et non accidit eis nisi attritio in pluribus dispositionibus.	The bones of the Foot indeed fracture sometimes when a fracture occurs, and the Fingers somewhat also: and it does not occur except by rubbing in various positions
Quod si accidit ossibus Pedis fractura, et uides illa ossa sublimari super se adinuicem, tunc ponat infirmus Pedem suum super terram praeparatam, sicut ambulans.	If a fracture occurs in the bones of the Foot, and you wish to lift up that bone above itself, then place the patient's Foot upon the prepared Earth, like a walker
Deinde sta tu, et pone Pedem tuum super illud quod eleuatur ex illis ossibus: postea preme, uel calca eam: et aequa ipsam, donec redeat in locis suis.	Then stand still, and place your Foot upon that which will lift up these bones: afterwards press, or apply a heel: and keep it equal, until it returns to its place
Deinde pone emplastrum, et stuppam desuper: et pone sub uentre Pedis tabulam paruam, cui sint duo capita plana.	Then apply a compress, and bandage: and place under the Foot a board having two flat heads
Deinde stringe eam cum Pede strictura decenti, postquam tu inuoluis eam cum pannis, et reliquis quibus indiget.	Then bind the Foot with a strong bandage, after you have wrapped it with cloth and other things as necessary
Cum ergo praetereunt ei tres dies, aut quatuor, tunc solue ligamentum.	When three or four days have passed, or four, then loosen the ligamentum
Nam tu inuenies ossa aequata, siue sint fracta, aut sint dislocata.	You perceive the bones to be equal, whether they are fractured or displaced.
Operatio ergo in eis est, sicut uides.	The operation is thus in the bones, like water
Si autem franguntur aliqui digiti, tunc restaura eos, et aequa ipsos secundum quod narraui tibi in restauratione digitorum manus.	If any fingers are fractured, then restore them, and make them equal as before, as I have said concerning the restoration of the fingers of the hand
Deinde pone digito tuo astellam secundum longitudinem digiti, et sit latior eo parumper: deinde pone sub Pede hanc tabulam quam narraui tibi, et stringe eam strictura decenti.	Then place your finger on the splint according to the length of the finger, and let it be broader than the other: then place under the hand this board which I have mentioned, and bind it securely.
Si uero quod frangitur ex ossibus est duo, aut tria, aut plus, tunc pone super omnem digitum astellam suae quantitatis, inuolutam in panno lini: et stringe tabulam in inferiori Pedis: et sit stans super unum capitum tabulae extra uentrem Pedis, ut teneat retentione bona.	If indeed that which is fractured from the bones is two, or three, or more, then place upon every finger a splint of its own quantity, bound in linen: and bind the board in the lower part of the foot: and let it rest upon one head of the board outside the foot, so that it may retain its stability
Et conuenit tibi, ut non obliuiscaris, quin consideres omnia quae dixi tibi in reliquis fracturis ex accidentibus quae diximus: et oppone omni accidenti cum eo quod oportet.	And it is convenient for you to remember, that you must consider all that I have said concerning the remaining fractures from accidents which we have mentioned: and oppose every accident with what is necessary.
¶ De fractura Vuluae mulieris, et ossis pectinis, et uirgae uiri.	Concerning the fracture of the woman's vulva, and the bone of the thigh, and the swelling of the man.
Caput XIX.	(The provided text does not include the content of Chapter XIX, so I am unable to translate it.)
Quando frangitur Vulua mulieris, tunc fac eam sedere quadratam.	When the woman's vulva is fractured, then make her sit in a square position.
Deinde inclina eam ad partem dorsi ipsius parumper, et teneatur retro.	Then incline her to the side towards the back of her, and keep her firm behind
Deinde impleat obstetrix Vuluam eius coto, donec impleat eam: et fiat in Vulua ex eo sicut sphera.	Then let the midwife grasp her vulva with her hand, until she grasps her: and make within the vulva like a sphere
Deinde concutiatur mulier, et eleua dorsum eius paulatim.	Then let the woman groan, and raise her back gradually.
Illud enim cotum egreditur, donec fiat ante portam Vuluae sicut sphera, et os fractum redit.	The limb thus departs from the socket until it stands before the gate of Vulua like a sphere, and the fractured bone returns.
Deinde pone puluillum super dorsum eius.	Then place a cushion over its back.
Quando ergo uult mingere, remoueat cotum cum facilitate, deinde mingat: et reduc ipsum secundum modum, quo intromisisti ipsum in primis: deinde redeat ad puluillum suum primum.	When he wishes to move, move the limb easily, then mix: and reduce it as before, as you introduced it at the beginning: then return to its cushion first
Faciat illud septem diebus, aut circiter, os ipsum enim restauratur.	Do this for seven days, or thereabouts, and the bone will be restored
Et si uis, accipe uesicam ouis, et stringe super foramen eius cannulam arundinis, et intromitte uesicam totam in Vuluam eius.	And if necessary, take the urine from the privy, and apply it over the opening of the wound, and insert the whole bladder into the belly.
Deinde suffla in cannulam cum uirtute, donec infletur uesica intra Vuluam, fractura enim redit.	Then blow into the bladder with urine, until the bladder is inflated inside the belly, the fracture will be restored.
Deinde impleatur cum coto, et stet aliquot diebus, secundum quod narrauimus, donec sanetur.	Then keep it bound with the limb, and rest for a few days, as we have narrated, until it is healed.
Et quando frangitur os Pectinis uiri, aut mulieris, tunc administra in restauratione eius, et ipsius aequatione illud quod narrauimus in osse Anchae.	When the bone of the breast of a man or a woman is fractured, then manage its restoration, and give it the same treatment as we have narrated for the bone of the elbow.
Et non occultatur rectum in his fracturis propinquis, quae parum contingunt, praecipue cui est quiddam studii, uel usus.	And do not hide the rectum in its near fractures, which are of little importance, especially for one who has studied or is skilled in this matter.
Et intellige librum meum istum multum, quoniam fractura ipsa significat tibi in pluribus dispositionibus uiam rectam in restauratione sui, et strictura sui: intellige ergo.	And understand my book well, for in many positions the fracture itself indicates to you the right way to restore and straighten it: understand therefore.
In Virga autem uiri quando frangitur, accipe guttur anseris: et intromitte uirgam in ipso.	But in the case of a man who is in the Virga when his bone fractures, take the tip of the tongue: and insert the tongue into it itself
Deinde pone super ipsum inuolutionem ex panno, et inuoluatur, et dimittatur tribus diebus, aut circiter eos, et sanabitur, si Deus uoluerit.	Then place above it an ointment from a cloth, and bandage it, and leave it for three days, or thereabouts, and it will heal, if God wills it
¶ De restauratione fracturae ossium, quando est cum uulnere.	On the restoration of fractures of bones, when associated with a wound.
Caput XX.	In the restoration of fractures of bones, when associated with a wound.
Conuenit ei cui accidit fractura cum uulnere, praecipue si est magnum, sicut os coxae, aut adiutorii, aut simile illi, ut properes, et phlebotomes ipsum statim: si attestantur tibi conditiones phlebotomiae, sicut praemisimus.	It is necessary in the restoration of fractures which are associated with a wound, especially if they are large, such as the femur or the pelvis, or similar to them, so that the wound is properly restored, and phlebotomy is performed immediately: if these conditions of phlebotomy are confirmed, as we have mentioned before.
Quod si uulnus effluit sanguinem, tunc oportet, ut properes ad abscisionem eius, ita ut puluerizes super ipsum zegi tritum: si non est tibi praesens aliud.	If blood flows from the wound, it is necessary to ligate it immediately, so that the surrounding tissue is not powdered over the wound: if nothing else is present in the vicinity
Deinde incipe restaurare fracturam in illo eodem die: et non postponas illud, si non accidit apostema.	Then commence the restoration of the fracture on the same day: do not delay it, if there is no swelling
Si uero accidit apostema calidum, tunc dimitte restaurationem eius usque ad diem nonum, donec sedetur apostema.	If indeed swelling occurs, then defer the restoration until the ninth day, until the swelling has subsided
Et non appropinques ei in die tertio, et quarto omnino, nam tu faceres ei accidere accidentia mala.	Do not approach it in the third or fourth day, for you will cause him further injury
Si autem os fractum est eminens super cutem detectum: tunc oportet, ut coneris reducere ipsum, et aequare ipsum manibus tuis cum facilitate et extensione parua.	If, however, the fractured bone is prominent above the skin, you must reduce it and level it with your hands with ease and small extension
Si autem non praeparatur extensio eius, et ipsius aequatio manibus tuis: tunc reduc ipsum cum isto instrumento.	If it is not prepared for extension, and its equalization with your hands: then reduce it with this instrument.
Et est instrumentum quod fit ex ferro, cuius longitudo est quantitas septem digitorum, aut octo: et eius latitudo est secundum quantitatem uulneris.	And the instrument is made of iron, its length is equal to seven fingers, or eight: and its width is according to the size of the wound
Et propter illud necesse est medico, ut accipiat ex eis tria, aut quatuor secundum quantitatem qua indiget ad illud ex curatione in omni specie fracturae.	And it is necessary for the physician to take from him three, or four according to the quantity required for the cure of any kind of fracture
Et sit rotundum: et sit in eo grossitudo parua, ut non duplicetur apud compressionem super ipsum in hora operationis: et sit acutae extremitatis, cui sit margo in extremitatibus suis.	It must be round: and be of small size, so that it does not double under compression in the hour of operation: and it must have a sharp point at the extremities, which must have a margin at their extremities
Et sit superius eius ad grossitudinem ex medietate eius usque ad inferiora.	And above it to the breadth from the middle to the lower parts.
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its shape.
Oportet in Hac Operatione, ut ponatur extremitas eius acuta curuata super extremitatem ossis eminentis: et impelle ipsum cum eo uice una, donec quando redit os et aequatur quadam aequatione.	It is necessary in this operation that you place the acute edge of the instrument curved over the prominence of the bone: and push it with the same until the bone returns and is equal to the surrounding parts.
Conare ergo aequare extremitates fracturae adinuicem.	So to make the extremities of the fracture even with each other
Quod si extremitates eius fracta est subtilis, et non accipit eam instrumentum accaeptione bona, tunc opotet, ut incidas extremitatem illius ossis, donec instrumentum potestatem habeat eius.	If its extremities are slightly fractured and do not grasp the instrument well, then you must cut off the end of that bone until the instrument has the power to grasp it
Si uero non potes reducere eos cum eo quod narrauimus omnino, tunc incide ipsum cum eo quod conuenit ei ex Incisoriis quae diximus: aut serra ipsum cum una serrarum quocunque modo possibile est tibi.	If indeed it does not suffice to reduce them as we have said before, then cut it with the knife which we mentioned before: or draw out the bone with a saw in any way that is possible to you
Deinde rade illud quod remanet in osse ex asperitate et corticibus minutis.	Then remove what remains of the bone from the asperities and small fragments.
Cum ergo reducitur os, et inuenit infirmus post reductionem eius dolorem uehementem laedentem, tunc scias, quod os non rediit ad locum suum naturalem.	When it has been reduced and finds itself after reduction in pain and discomfort, then you know that the bone has not returned to its natural position
Fac ergo illud.	Do this.
Nam tu confers infirmo iuuamentum magnum, cum completur restauratio tua quam facis ossi.	For you must confer great comfort to the patient when you finish your restoration of the bone.
Tunc submerge pannum in uino stiptico, nigro.	Then immerse the wound in vinegar, black.
Et proprie si est in aestate.	And if it is in summer.
Et non ponas super uulnus caerotum, neque aliquid in quo sit oleum: ut non faciat accidere in ipso putredinem et corruptionem.	Do not place on the wound a wet cloth or anything containing oil: so that it does not cause putrefaction and corruption
